title: Heart Recipient Is Candidate
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 (AP) Louis B. Russell Jr., the world's longestsurviving heart transplant recipient, is running for an atlarge seat on the City Council in Tuesday's election. He received his new heart on Aug. 24, 1968. Mr. Russell, a Democrat Is 46 years old.

title: 3 Robbed of $100,000 at River House
description: Three armed, welldressed robbers stole more than $100,000 in jewelry from Mrs. Arthur Hugh Bunker, sister inlaw of the American Am bassador to South Vietnam, Ellsworth Bunker, and two friends early yesterday morning in the private drive way of River House at 435 East 52d Street.

title: Personal Finance
description: Tax planning before the yearend can involve simply selling investments to turn paper profits or losses into reality. Then profits become subject to taxes, while losses can result in savings.

title: First Swiss Woman Wins Federal Office
description: GENEVA Oct. 31 Mrs. Use Girardin, Geneva's first woman Mayor, was elected today to the Council of States, the Swiss equivalent of the United States Senate, in the first parliamentary election since Swiss women won the right to vote and hold federal office.

title: Shop Talk
description: So you thought you'd seen the last of those monster shoes? Well, take another look, for the shoes that are around the stores this season look as if they might have been worn by Dr. Frankenstein's boy himself. Platform solesnever the most graceful of fashionsare back. Some reach as high as 4 inch es, have all the delicacy of spacewalk boot and tend to give the wearer a peculiar, shuffling gait. Shoe Biz at Henri Bendel has a slew of them, but per haps the granddaddy of them all is a plat form of maroon suede, 4 inches high, that is the basis for a navy sude, instep strapped sandal. The price is $35

title: GRAFFEN PIANIST FOR THE NATIONAL
description: The National Symphony of Washington opened its five concert season at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday'afternoon a solid program, ably if some what soberly played. Antal Dorati, the musical director, teamed with Gary Graffman in the day's most persuasive perience, Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 3, in which Mr. Graffman a fluent, objec tive perfomance of the solo part.

title: COLONELS EDGED BY NETS, 107103
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 31The New York Nets, who are growing pretty slick at the racehorse finish, spotted the Kentucky Colonels 14 points tonight before generat ing a stretch drive that pro duced a 107103 victory in the final seven minutes.

title: German Banker Declares U. S. Is Spurring a World Recession
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, Oct. 31What we have seen in the last six months con vinces me of only one thing that we are still capable of making all the mistakes of the nineteenthirties.

title: JERUSALEM ISSUE IS FOUND DIVISIVE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31A rift is reportedly developing among Christian clergymen and lay leaders over attitudes toward Israel's control of Jerusalem.

title: Debate Masks Specifics Of Transportation Plan
description: Amid the wellamplified de bate over Governor Rocke feller's proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue, the specific provisions of the plan have been partly obscured. What exactly does the bond issue propose to accomplish?

title: WILLIAM J. KENT JR., OF BOHACK, IS DEAD
description: William J. Kent Jr., president of H. C. Bohack, Inc., the food chain, from 1957 to 1963, died in Brooklyn Hospital yesterday. Mr. Kent, who lived at 35 Pros pect Park West, Brooklyn, and Bayport, L. I., was 73 years old.

title: Multinational Bank Sees A Few Clouds Next Year
description: A further slowdown in the rate of growth in world trade, a temporarily clouded out look for economic growth in the main industrial countries and less inflation and lower interest rates were predicted yesterday for 1972 by a leading multinational bank.

title: CANADIANS FIND SOVIET TRADESHY
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31The So viet. Trade Commissioner in Ottawa has a variety of items for sale in Canada. But the eightday visit of Premier Alexei Kosygin left the im pression last week that Mos cow is not so much inter ested in exchanges of goods as in a protracted period of ritual istic improvement of relations.

title: Hopes for New York Club In C.F.L. Slim, Aurelio Told
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31 (Reuters) New York's Deputy Mayor, Richard Aurelio, had a meeting today with Jake Gaudaur commissioner of the Canadian Football League, to discuss the chance of getting a league franchise for New York.

title: Harvard Sailors Finish First In McMillan Cup Regatta
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 31 Harvard University came from seventh place today to win the 43d annual McMillan Cup Re gatta at the Naval Academy. Good air prevailed for the four races today.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, Oct. 31President Pompidouhaving bid good by yesterday to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, after a week of talks is preparing to send a letter to Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany.

title: Franciscans Seek Sites of Jesus' Life
description: CAPERNAUM, Israel, Oct. 6  The sweaty, redfaced man driving the tractor is a distinguished Franciscan monk, a scholar with 42 years' experience in the Holy Land. The laborer in the Tshirt and dusty sailor hat is his younger colleague in the order, an Americantrained expert in deciphering ancient history from potsherds.

title: Drop in U.S. Capability Worries Military
description: Senior Army, Navy and Air Force officers believe that the United States capability to in tervene militarily in support of American and allied interests abroad has been drastically re duced.

title: LEADER IS CHOSEN BY COPTIC CHURCH
description: CAIRO, Oct. 31A blindfold ed Egyptian boy pulled one of three names from a silver box today, making a former army officer, Bishop Shenuda, they 117th successor to Saint Mark as patriarch of the Coptic Or thodox Church and Pope of Al exandria.

title: McCreary Named to Coach Blues as Abel Is Promoted
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 (UPI) Bill McCreary, coach of the Denver Spurs in the Western Hockey League, was promoted last night to the job of head coach of Denver's parent Na tional League club, the St. Louis Blues.

title: White House and Senators Deadlocked Over Scope of Office on Drug Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The White House and a Senate committee are deadlocked over the creation of the Presi dent's Special Action Office on Drug Abuse.

title: 4Car L.I. Special Carries 125 Riders Into the Past
description: Juice fanselectric rail roading buffshad an all day ramble across Long Is land yesterday aboard a four car special train that included a private, openend observa tion car built in 1912 for the likes of Diamond Jim Brady.

title: Blast in Tallest British Building Is Laid to I.R.A. Unit by Caller
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  A man speaking with an Irish accent said that the Kilburn battalion of the I.R.A. had been respon sible for the explosion that damaged Post Office Tower, Britain's highest, building, early this morning.

title: Chargers Rout Jets, 4921;
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 31The decline of the New York Jets through injuries and ineffi ciency reached disaster propor tions today.

title: BREZHNEV IN 2D DAY OF TALKS IN BERLIN
description: BERLIN, Oct. 31Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Commu nist party leader, conferred for a second day today with Com munist leaders of East Germany on Europe and the Berlin issue, amid indications that continu ing differences had forced him to extend his visit.

title: Cuellar, Blair Help Orioles Down Japan AllStars, 41
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 31 (AP) Mike Cuellar hurled a four hitter and Paul Blair cracked a home run today, pacing the Baltimore Orioles to a 41 vic tory over a Japanese allstar team before more than 50,000 fans at Koshien Stadium.

title: Blast Rocks Barracks
description: LONDON, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP) A violent explosion rocked an army barracks a quarter of a mile from Parlia ment early today, damaging the main doors and shattering windows.

title: Saigon Reports 31 of Foe Killed; Arnerical Division Deactivated
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31 (AP)The South Viet namese military command said today that a Vietcong battalion of about 200 men shelled and assaulted South Vietnamese in fantrymen yesterday near a dis trict town 40 miles northwest of Saigon.

title: FULBRIGHT SEES CONGRESS VOTING INTERIM AID PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Senator J. W. Fulbright, Chair man of the Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that Congress would approve an interim solution to keep foreign aid alive, but he indi cated opposition to the formula being devised by the Nixon Administration.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Blanda Rallies Raiders to 2020 Tie With Chiefs
description: George Blanda is: (a) the old est man playing professional football today; (b) the player who has scored more points than anyone else in pro foot ball history; (c) the most suc cessful benchwarming quarter back in the National Football League.

title: 38 Years With O'Casey: A Rich and Fruitful Life
description: LONDON, Oct, 31In 1926, A young chorus girl named Eileen Carey visited a New York fortune teller who in formed her that she would return to England to meet a man with piercing eyes and heavy boots, a man who would be world famous and whom I would marry. Mrs. Eileen Carey O'Casey smiles now with the recollection.

title: U.S. Judge Bids Virginia Halt Abuse of Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 A Federal judge in Virginia has issued a sweeping injunction against that state's prison sys tem, barring as cruel and un usual punishment of inmates the regular use of bread and water, chains, physical punish ment, enforced nudity and the censorship of mail.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 31 (AP)Lee ChangKil of South Korea, Orient junior welter weight champion, successfully defended his title tonight by knocking out Kazuyoshi Kuba kura of Japan in the eighth round of a scheduled 12round match. Lee weighed 137 pounds, Kubokua 138.

title: Saving Foreign Aid
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will meet today to consider what to do about the foreign assist ance program after the unexpected Senate vote last week to kill the aid authorization bill. Many Senators have had second thoughts about their reckless action and the Nixon Administration seems to have done some soulsearching about its failure to provide the leader ship that could have salvaged the authorization.

title: Group of Ten Meeting Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (Reu ters)Treasury Secretary John B. Connally has called a meet ing of the finance ministers of the Group of Ten for currency and trade talks, informed sources said tonight. The meet ing is to be in Rome Nov. 2324 following a meeting of the min isters' deputies on Nov. 22, they said.

title: Nixons Return to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon re turned to the White House this afternoon after an overnight stay at Camp David in Mary land. They returned by helicop ter shortly before dark after the President had watched the WashingtonNew Orleans pro fessional football game at the Presidential retreat in the Ca toctin Mountains.

title: Christa Ludwig and Bernstein Perform Brahms
description: As Arthur Nikisch was to Elena Gerhardt, as Bruno Walter to Lottie Lehmann, as Wilhelm Furtwngler to Elis abeth Schwarzkopf, so Leon ard Bernstein was to Christa Ludwig yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. In each of those cases a busy conductor put baton away and went to the piano to accompany an admired singer.

title: The Risks of Economic Failure
description: As the weeks have passed since the President launched his New Economic Policy, the initial upsurge of public confidence that the program would stop inflation, boost national output and employment and restore equilibrium to the balance of payments has given way to doubts and uncertainties. These anxieties stem directly from the way the Administration has handled both its foreign and domestic economic policies.

title: Nixon Will Honor Students Acting to Save Environment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) President Nixon announced a program today to stimulate high school students to under take projects designed to pro tect the environment.

title: U.N. GROUP BACKS NEW RATE POLICY
description: GENEVA, Oct. 31  Experts of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe have coma out against any attempt to return to a fixed pattern of exchange rates of the type that long underpinned the post World War II international monetary system.

title: Leafs Tie Rangers, 33, On 2 Goals in 3d Period
description: For the first time this young National Hockey League sea son, the Rangers last night heard hooting directed against them at Madison Square Gar den.

title: T.C.U. NAMES TOHILL AS FOOTBALL COACH
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP)Texas Christian Univer sity today named Billy Tohill, an assistant coach, to succeed Jim Pittman as acting head coach of the football team.

title: Canada's Exporters in a Pinch
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31Arnold Simoni is a man in the middle, a man pinned down in the crossfire of international eco nomic events.

title: Cynthia Wyner Bride of David T. Weiss
description: Miss Cynthia Wyner and David Thomas Weiss were married yesterday afternoon in the Kingsway Jewish Cen ter in Brooklyn by Rabbi Samuel Chill. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Wyner and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Weiss, all of Brooklyn.

title: To Elmhurst Residents, the Issue Is Homes Versus Highways
description: The city engineer, using charts and maps, argued for the $2.5billion bond issue for subways and highways. It was hopeless. One after another, homeowners from Elmhurst, Queens, rose to at tack the proposal at the public meeting in the New town High School audito rium, called by Community Planning Board 4.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Oct. 29It is an unconfirmable story, but it rings true. Soon after he ve toed Britain's first application to join the Common Market, in 1963, General de Gaulle said privately that some day the British would come in. But first there would have to be polit ical changes: the Conservatives would lose office and then, after a time, return to power under a new leader the man who had just headed the British team in the vetoed application, Edward Heath. Mr. Heath would take Britain into Europe.

title: Peking's Listing at the U. N. Will Be Under C for China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 31China today cleared the way for the raising of her flag tomor row at the United Nations head quarters. Peking did so by send ing a cablegram to Secretary General Thant advising him that it wants to be listed as China, People's Republic of.

title: Janeway Sees Dow Plunging to 500 in 1972
description: A political economist. That's how Eliot Janeway, 58 years old and formidable, prefers to describe himself. He is widely known as an au thor, lecturer and television show guest. The other day, he talked with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times staff. Excerpts from their conversation follow:

title: Books of The Times
description: LIVINGSTONE'S COMPANIONS. Stories by Nadine Gordimer. 248 Pages. Viking. $6.95.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Nov. 1, 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Happy Chandler Is Running Hard in His Last Hurrah
description: VERSAILLES, Ky., Oct. 29 The old folks are sitting on their front porch when they hear the loudspeaker blaring My Old Kentucky Home. A camperbus pulls up and a sturdy 73 yearold man steps out  out of the history books, as it were.

title: REVSON IS VICTOR IN CANAM SERIES
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 31 Denis Hulme ran away with the 10th and final CanAm race of the season here today as his teammate, peter Revson, finished second to win the Canadian  American Challenge Cup.

title: Theater: On the Town, Bernstein's 1944 Musical
description: The Bronx is still up, and the Battery is downas they still singbut Leonard Bern stein's 1944 musical On the Town is just about in the middle. As revival opened last night at the Imperial Theater, and while some of the glory has doubtless de parted, there were moments of brightness if not incan descene. Perhapscould it be?New York has changed. Certainly music has.

title: TigerCats Triumph, 2315
description: TORONTO, Oct. 31 (Canadi an Press)The Hamilton Tiger Cats, with John Manel going most of the way at quarter back, stunned the Toronto Ar gonauts, 2315, today to take second place in the final East ern Football Conference stand ings.

title: Chiang's Birthday Is Celebrated Festively on Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 31 Ten thousand students and mili tary cadets formed ranks in front of the Presidential Office Building this morning to sing songs of tribute to Nationalist China's Great Leader on his 84th birthday.

title: If the Bond Issue Fails
description: In their accelerating campaign of support for the proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue, New York City officials are making it clear that defeat of the proposition would mean more than higher transit fares for the city. It would directly, and adversely, affect the precariously balanced city and state budgets alike.

title: Tito Visiting Clifornia
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP)President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived today by plane from Houston to begin a visit at the home of the indus trialist Leonard Firestone. He is scheduled to remain in Southern California until Tues day, and is to deliver an ad dress tomorrow to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council.

title: WILLIAM T. MUSE
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 31 (AP) Dr. William T. Muse, dean of the University of Richmond Law School, died today. He was 65 years old.

title: Ulster Violence Continues
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 31 (AP)Guerrillas am bushed British Army patrols in Northern Ireland today, wound ing two soldiers, after a week end of sniping and bombing.

title: Rochas Will Introduce Married Men's Cologne
description: Gather round gentlemen. If you're a happily married man, or ready to join the ranks, you'll be interested in knowing that Parfums Marcel Rochas, Inc., is introducing this fall Monsieur Roches Extra Strength, The First Cologne For Married Men.

title: Idle Dice Triumphs In President's Cup; Jenkins Top Rider
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Idle Dice won the President's Cup for international open jumpers for the second year in a row to night at the windup of the six day Washington International Horse Show.

title: Beame Says Delays in Aid For City Spur Borrowing
description: The city nearly tripled its shortterm borrowing in the last fiscal year to cope with delays in state and Federal aid and to anticipate its own tax collections, Controller Abra ham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: I Have Seen the Past and It Works
description: What I have to tell is, I know, not going to be believed. I know this be cause a Chinese surgeon, chief at the major metropolitan hospital in Canton, told me that he had not believed it himselfuntil he had seen it many times over.

title: Onassis Marriage Contract Said to Contain 170 Clauses
description: LONDON, Oct. 31  Ac cording to Christian Kafa rakis, former chief steward on Aristotle Onassis's yacht, Christina, the marriage con tract between Mr. Onassis and his wife, the former Jacqueline Kennedy, was so complex that it required 170 clauses.

title: Fate of Bonds Shaky in Tomorrow's Vote
description: A day before the voters go to the polls, the fate of the $2.5billion transportation bond issue is still in doubt, although virtually every major civic group and politician in the state supports it.

title: 9 New York Banks' Behavior Criticized
description: Major banks in New York City, through their eagerness to accommodate the credit, needs of large corporate cli ents, have helped to drive in terest rates to record levels and have hampered the ability of the Federal Reserve System to stabilize the national economy, a key research official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York charged over the week end.

title: Last Singapore Review Held by British Fleet
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 31 (AP) The Far East fleet steamed past here in a farewell review today hours before the 150 yearold British Asian Naval Command was replaced by an integrated force under fivecountry pact.

title: Questions Over Kent State
description: Twentyfive students of Kent State University have been told that they must stand trial for their alleged part in the 1970 campus disorders during which four students were killed by National Guard gunfire. The indicted stu dents have considerable grounds for questioning the course justice has taken, particularly since the grand jury report on which their indictments are based has been ruled illegal and improper. However, the Court of Appealsthough agreeing with the lower court's assess ment on the jury reporthas let the indictments stand.

title: TOY POODLE BEST IN DOGSHOW HERE
description: An apricotcolored, toy poo dle, Ch. Peeples Red Head, hailed as one of the Soundest and most typical represent atives of the breed I've ever seen, by Alva Rosenberg of Wilton, Conn., was named best in show at the 39th annual fix ture of the Progressive Dog Club yesterday.

title: Liberia Is Changing After the Tubman Era
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Oct. 17 There is a new atmosphere of pride, relief and expectation in the small West African na tion of Liberia.

title: $380 Minimum Approved At Washington Daily News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) Editorial personnel and The Washington Daily News reached agreement tonight on a new contract that will raise the minimum pay for journeymen newsmen to $380 a week by December, 1973. The present minimum for journeymenper sons with at least four years' experienceis $295.

title: Unbeaten Alabama Hopes Winning Tide Will Sweep Team Into Orange Bowl
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant's 1966 Alabama football team was certainly the most frustrated team he coached, if not the best. Though undefeated in 10 regularseason games, that Crimson Tide, with such stars as Ray Perkins at end, re mained in the shadow of Notre Dame and Michigan State, who finished undefeated but tied after their historic 1010 strug gle.

title: STATE GETS GRANT FOR COAST STUDY
description: New York State has received Its first Federal money$600, 000under the new Sea Grant Program to explore the develop ment of the state's 2,400 miles of coastline along the Atlantic Ocean and Lake Erie and Lake Ontario.

title: 8 Die in 2 Swiss Air Crashes
description: BERNE, Oct. 31 (AP)Eight persons were killed in two plane crashes within 20 miles of each other in the Lake Thun area, Swiss authorities reported today. The planes were on private tours of the Swiss Alps when the crashes occurred yes terday. There were no survivors. The victims were reported to be Swiss and West German na tionals.

title: Soviet Feminists Are Beginning to Speak Out Against Sexual Inequality
description: MOSCOW  The Soviet Union has no active wom en's liberation movement, but feminist voices are be ing raised in the press over inequities imposed on work ing womenhalf the work ing force. Indeed, a male editor urged husbands to help their wives more with household chores.

title: 3 Win Cabot Awards at Columbia
description: The Maria Moors Cabot Prizes for interAmerican journalism are to be awarded Thursday at Columbia Uni versity to Georgie Anne Geyer of The Chicago Daily News, Julio Scherer Garcia, director general of the news paper Excelsior of Mexico City, and Juan Carlos Colom bres of Buenos Aires, one of Latin America's bestknown editorial cartoonists.

title: 19 CUBANS ABSENT ON EVE OF PARLEY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 Participants in the triennial congress of the International Society of Sugar Cane Tech nologists gathered today with out the 19man Cuban delega tion, which is interned at a naval air station nine miles away across the Mississippi River.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Welles's War of Worlds Still Stirs Consternation
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 31 (AP)A Buffalo radio station's local adaptation of the Orson Welles's classic radio drama tization of War of the Worlds lit up the city police switch board with more than 100 calls from worried residents tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Allende Hails Rise of U .N. Office As a Sign of Socialism's Power
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 31 In a blockparty atmosphere, President Salvador Allende Gossens gave a barbecue for diplomats and construction workers last night at the rap idly rising headquarters build ing for the third United Na tions Conference on Trade and Development. The conference will be held next April.

title: Chick Korea, Pianist, Is at the Vanguard
description: Chick, Korea, the onetime Miles Davis pianist who was leading a group called Circle during the last year, has now broken up Circe and is taking the first steps toward the de velopment of a promising new sextet.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Since Rocket Richard scored 50 goals in a season during World War II, people have been saying the National Hockey League is embarking on a new era. The various eras can be marked by Boom Boom Geoffrion's slap shot, expansion, the twogoalie system, and the recognition that hockey players are subject to, of all things, emotional stress.

title: Boy Drops 3 Stories Into Brother's Arms
description: An 8yearold boy jumped from his burning fourthfloor apartment in Harlem into his brother's arms yesterday and suffered only minor injuries.

title: Ukrainian Bishops Defy Vatican By Planning Autonomous Synod
description: ROME, Oct. 31Sixteen bish ops of the Ukrainian Catholic Church reportedly defied the Vatican tonight and voted to convene a synod to set up an autonomous government for their church.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDONOn March 30,1967, Presi dent Johnson had all the Democratic state chairmen to the White House for a reception. As each shook the Presi dent's hand, a photograph was taken to be sent to the chairman as a use ful political memento.

title: ELECTIONS IN U.S. TOMORROW FOCUS ON RACIAL ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31In one guise or another, racial problems will play an important part in many of the state and local elections across the na tion on Tuesday.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS LIFTS NET IN QUARTER
description: Texas Instruments, Inc., real ized a 28 per cent increase in thirdquarter earnings and a 4.5 per cent gain in the nine month profit, despite lower sales, according to the report released today.

title: Vietnamese Delay Convoy
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP)  A crowd of angry Vietnamese surrounded a United States army convoy and prevented it from leaving the scene of an accident for 1 hours, Army spokesman reported today. The incident occurred yesterday on Highway 1, 44 miles south of Danang.

title: Presidential Message
description: In a proclamation issued for the United Service Or ganization' 30th annive sary, Presi dent Nixon said:

title: Nerve Cells of Eye and Brain Are Shown to Interact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Sim ple materials Injected Into an animal's eye find their way into the visual cortex of the brain, research team has reported to a scientific meeting here.

title: TV: A Primer on China
description: If a clue can be taken from the level of the public dia logue surrounding recent ac tions in the United Nations, Americans generally are star tlingly ignorant about China. For most, the debate seems to have something to do with Communists and nonCom munists. For some, whose in terests tend to be more vested, it has everything to do with Communists and nonCommunists.

title: JEWISH GROUP URGES NIXON PLEA IN SOVIET
description: The Jewish Labor Committee yesterday urged President Nix on on his forthcoming visit to the Soviet Union to ask the Kremlin to free Soviet Jews who are in prison.

title: Squires' Maloy on Waivers
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31 (AP)  Mike Maloy, former college star at Davidson, was placed on waivers last night by the Virginia Squires of the Ameri can Basketball Association.

title: Tudo and Loss Highlight Dance Theater Bill
description: The most vital thing any young choreographer needs after having the opportunity to show his work once is to show it again and again. It is only after repeated exposure to dif ferent audiences that the crea tive artist can gauge his work and it is just this opportunity that Dance Theater Workshop grants to its fledgling talents. On Saturday evening it showed the second of its weekend pro grams running through Novem ber.

title: Slow Track for Amtrak
description: Opposing an increase in the present subsidy for Amtrak, Under Secretary James M. Beggs of the Depart ment of Transportation calls for a twoyear experi mental period to determine whether there is a true place for rail passenger service in a modern national transportation system. This is the wrong approach because it asks the wrong question.

title: Germans Assail Tax on Pets
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Oct. 31 (AP)Hundreds of howling dogs and their irate owners occupied Hamburg City Hall briefly today to protest a planned 100 per cent increase in the state pet tax, bringing it to $36 yearly.

title: Wajima of Japan Captures Junior Middleweight Title
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31 (UPI)  Koichi Wajima used his unorth odox crouching and weaving style to advantage tonight and wrested the world junior mid dleweight crown from Carmelo Bossi of Italy by a split deci sion in a 15round title fight.

title: Current U.S. Refunding and Treasury Moves Viewed Favorably
description: The bond market Showed signs last Friday of coming back to life, and dealers hoped this resurgence of optimism will continue this week.

title: Anne Ends Hong Kong Visit
description: HONG KONG, Mnoday, Nov. 1 (UPI)Britain's Princess Anne ended today a weeklong visit to this crown colony that in cluded a look at Chinese rice lands across the border, a ride on an armored car and a sam pan trip to a poor village. The 21yearold daughter of Queen Elizabeth II is to leave for Lon don this afternoon after in augurating the second satellite station of Cable and Wireless, Ltd., and attending a luncheon party at Government House.

title: U.S. Health Policy Called Manipulated
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Representative Paul G. Rogers, chairman of the House Subcom mittee on Public Health and the Environment, charged today that the Nixon Administration was allowing budget bureau accountants to make national health policy.

title: Alonzo G. Moron Is Dead at 62; Hampton Institute ExPresident
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 31 (AP) Alonzo G. Morn, former dep uty regional director here of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment, died today after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Held as 60 Demonstrate Outside Johnson Library
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 31 (AP)  The police arrested two men at a demonstration today at the Lyndon B. Johnson Library by about 60 persons identify ing themselves as Yippeis.

title: Equal Dollars for School Districts
description: BERKELEY,. Calif.The decision of the California Supreme Court in Ser rano V. Priestthe school finance caseprobably deserves the label historic applied by the media. If its rationale proves infectious, the case could eventually alter the distribution of educational resources in this coun try. Thus far, however, the decision has been grossly misconstrued and its scope wildly exaggerated. The strict limitations of the decision de serve as much emphasis as its novelty and significance. Indeed, it is the very restraint of the California court which gives the result its very powerful credibility.

title: Notes on Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The 41 members of New York State's diverse Congressional delegation, who seldom agree on much of anything, have fi nally found unanimity on at least one matter of self inter est  Congressional reappor tionment. The unity, however, apparently, got the delegation nowhere. Writ ing on behalf of the entire dele gation  Demo crats as well as Republicans  Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn and the 83yearold dean of the delegation, ap pealed to Governor Rockefeller last week not to put off until next year the drawing of new Congressional districts for the state.

title: LON NOL'S CHOICE FIRMLY IN POWER
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 30The name to be applied to Cambodia's form of govern ment, now that rule by decree has replaced the semblance of democracy, remains a subject of tepid discussion, but there is no doubt in any political quarter who governs Cambodia.

title: BADILLO IN PLEA FOR PUERTO RICO
description: Representative Herman Ba dille called yesterday for Fed eral job development in Puerto Rico and equal treatment for the island and mainland in oth er Federal programs, declaring that Puerto Ricans were migrat ing because of an economy that was even more depressed than the mainland's.

title: Muskie, Disputing Nixon, Urges Full Atom Test Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 Senator Edmund S. Muskie took issue with the Nixon Ad ministration today by arguing that recent progress in detec tion methods should permit the United States, to enter into comprehensive treaty banning all nuclear tests.

title: A Prime Election Issue in San Francisco Is a Proposed Ban on High Rise Buildings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 Although the race for mayor has attracted more attention, a proposition that would vir tually end all highrise build ing in San Francisco has be come a prime issue in Tues day's municipal election.

title: Public Directors Proposed for Major Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31  Robert Townsend, the former chairman of the Avis Rent a Car System, Inc., and author of Up the Organization, pro posed today that each of the country's 110 biggest corpora tions be required to allocate $1million a year for a pro gram designed to protect the public interest in the company's dealings.

title: Three Die in Virginia Crash
description: IVOR, Va., Oct. 31 (UPI) A twinengine Piper plane crashed into a field during foggy weather last night and killed three persons. The dead were Bobby Lee Swain, 41 years old, his wife Jacqueline, 39, both of Bowie,. Md., and Wil liam Marr, 55, of Columbia, Md.

title: Casper Is RunnerUp
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 31 (AP)  Shigeru Uchida of Ja pan scored a twounderpar 70 in the final round today and won the $11,000 first prize in the Tokai Classic international open golf tournament with a total of 283.

title: Hoving Offers Art Museum's Staff An Increased Role in PolicyMaking
description: In the wake of increased union organizing efforts by professional museum em ployes, Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum, has presented to his staff a 10point program for its greater participation in museum policymaking.

title: DR. ARTHUR ETTINGER
description: Dr. Arthur Ettinger, clinical professor of radiology at New York Medical College, Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hos pital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 200 East 63d Street.

title: Rarely Given Einem Concerto Performed by Bostonians Here
description: Gottfried von Einems Violin Concerto was given what seems to have been its first New York performance by the Boston Symphony Orchestra and Chris tiane Edinger at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, and there is little reason to think that an other performance will be de manded in the near future, if ever.

title: How Nixon Got to China
description: When Henry Kissinger and his 13 aides drove into Peking airport Oct. 26 to board their Presidential Boeing 707 for Washington, they noticed some thing missing: the huge billboard that had faced them on arrival six days before. Gone were the 40foothigh, Chinese characters, each mounted on a wooden framework, that proclaimed: Oppose U.S. Imperialism and All Its Running Dogs!

title: NICKLAUS, ON 269, IS 8SHOT VICTOR
description: HOBART, Australia, Oct. 31 (AP)Jack Nicklaus shot a two underpar 70 today, his worst round, and captured the $22,400 Quantas Australian open golf tournament by eight strokes with a total of 269.

title: Soprano and Mezzo Share Debut Program
description: Helen Chen Lee, a Chinese soprano recently arrived in New York, and Rosemary Leeder, a Canadian mezzo who has lived here since 1962, shared a debut program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon, Both women have strong, basically appealing voices and a feeling for the dramatic content of their material; neither has com pletely solved the technical problems that restrict their present level of accomplish ment.

title: Wilkes 400 Race Rained Out
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N. C., Oct. 31 (AP)The Wilkes 400 mile stock car race was post poned for a second time be cause of rain today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Violence in Children's Literature Eyed.
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 31The fantasies of princes, fairies and beanstalks in children's litera ture often hide the harsh reali ties of broken heads and muti lated bodies. In a colloquium on children's literature at Yale University today, a distin guished panel of writers, illus trators and critics found that the fairy tale confronts real problems, such as violence, but at the same time avoids the shock of adult, literature or television.

title: Dr. William Wolf, a Founder Of Psychotherapy Group
description: Dr. William Wolf, a founder of the Association for the Ad vancement of Psychotherapy and its secretary for five years, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 40 Central Park South.

title: James E. Wolfe is Dead at 69; Rail Industry Labor Negotiator
description: OAK PARK, III., Oct. 31 (AP) James E. (Doc) Wolfe, former chief negotiator for the railroad industry, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 69.

title: Bridge: Stuart and Waldmann Teams Reach Final in L.I. Regionals
description: Teams captained by Joel Stuart of New York and Art Waldmann of Wethersfield, Conn., clashed last night in the final of the knockout team championship at the Long Island regionals at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Theater: Shawn in Yale's Big House
description: NEW HAVEN  Wearing cutaway and sneakers, Dick Shawn calmly pours a bottle of vodka over his shaggy head, rubs in soap and gives himself a shampoo. Then he takes a long swig of Scope, explaining, I want my hair to smell as nice as my breath, and combs his hair while looking at himself ad miringly in a washboard. It is immediately clear that we are in the hands of a master clownno matter, what hap pens around him.

title: Missile Hits Judge's Home
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 31 (UPI) Navy jet accidentally dropped a nonexplosive 900 pound training missile at an al titude of 5,000 feet today and it ripped through the palatial farm home of a judge. No one was injured, but Judge James W. Parrott of the Tennessee State Court of Appeals said his home near Strawberry Plains was a total loss. The Navy said that Comdr. Virgil Tedder of Atlanta accidentally released the device.

title: Modern Witches and Ghosts March to an Old Refrain: Trick or Treat
description: All Hallows' Eve, known more familiarly as Halloween, brought out the usual excited clusters of small witches, cowboys, fairy princesses and ghosts last night as children rang doorbells to chant the ritual, Trick or treat!

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CITES TRADE CURBS ABROAD
description: An Assistant Secretary of the Treasury charged yester day that the same countries that have complained about the American 10 per cent im port tax have practiced dis criminatory trading against United States exports to their countries for years and years.

title: Irving Rate Stays at 5 %
description: The Irving Trust Company announced yesterday that its floating prime rate would re main at 5 per cent for the week beginning today. On Fri day, the First National City Bank, which kicked off the move to a more flexible mini mum charge on business loans on Oct. 21, reduced its base lending rate to 5 per cent from the 5 per cent level posted by other banks.

title: N.Y.A.C. Harriers Capture A.A.U. 3,000Meter Title
description: With Howie Ryan leading the way, the New York Athletic Club won the national senior Amateur Athletic Union 3,000 meter crosscountry team cham pionship yesterday.

title: 16,228 Fans Greet Return of Roller Derby at Garden
description: The Roller Derby returned to New York on a regular basis yesterday for the first time since 1959, and its fans, apparently, are ready to re embrace it. The crowd of 16,228 savored every elbow thrown, each fight, and all the scoring as the Chiefs, New York's team, edged the Red Devils, 3130.

title: Chess: In Which a Queen Sacrifice Succeeds in Losing a Queen
Redskins Set Back Saints For 6th Triumph, 2414
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31The Redskins were not a very good team today but the Saints were even Worse as Washing ton beat New Orleans, 2414, in a game that had 19 penal ties, six fumbles and three in tercepted passes.

title: Youth Linked to Shots Fired at Soviet Mission Here Called Very Religious
description: Fifteen years ago, in the pre dominantly Jewish section, of Borough Park, Brooklyn, Isaac M. Jaroslowitz might have played punchball on the streets or in the driveways between the redbrick, twofamily houses.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: 9 HELD IN DRUG RAID; ARMS CACHE SEIZED
description: Nine persons were arrested last night after the police from the Bronx and Yonkers raided a threestory house in the Kingsbrige Heights area of the Bronx and found a cache of arms and seven ounces of am phetamines worth $5,000.

title: Wingate Prep: A Second Chance in Paradise for Young Dropouts
description: Ruben Hernandez  a quiet, serious, pleasantfaced. youth with curly hair and muttonchop sideburns, who used to be a high school dropout  paused at lunch time the other day in the lounge at Wingate Prep in Brooklyn, where he is one of 80 students, and reflected on what the school had meant to him.

title: Giants Lose
description: The real New York Giants, the ones with Ron Johnson, and Tucker Frederickson ?? the backfield, Don Herrmann and Bob Tucker holding onto Fran Tarkenton's passes And Jim Kanicki and Witlie Williams helping the defense, made their first appearance of 1971 at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: TUNISIA IS FACING LEADERSHIP CRISIS
description: TUNIS, Oct. 27  Tunisia, long one of the most stable of Arab republics, is under going a serious political crisis as sickness and age gradually loosen the tight grip of her long established leader, Habib Bourguiba.

title: Saigon Begins the Release Of 2,938 Enemy P.O.W.'s
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31The South Vietnam ese Government today released the first of nearly 3,000 Viet cong prisoners under a recently announced amnesty.

title: Servants re Proud to Be Servants, in a Moroccan Village Hotal
description: TAFRAOUT, MoroccoIn a hotel din Ing room about 65 miles of mountain road from anywhere, a whiteuniformed waiter pours the ritual taste of wine with the deft formality of a threestar restaurant's maitre d'htel.

title: SOME FISH UP 25% IN RECENT WEEKS
description: Prices for fish supposedly stabilized by the Federal wage price freeze rose in New York City during the last 11 weeks. For halibut steak, the rise was 25 per cent.

title: 10 PRELATES PUT UP TO HEAD CONFERENCE
description: Cardinal Cooke, Archbishop of New York, is one of 10 Roman Catholic prelates nom inated to succeed John Cardinal Dearden of Detroit to a three year term as president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the United States Catholic Conference.

title: Marino Wins Billiard Title
description: JOHNSTON CITY, Ill., Oct. 31 (UPI)Jim Marino of Los Angeles defeated Luther Las siter, of Elizabeth City, N. C., this morning in a playoff for the world allround pocket bil liards championship. Marino won, 112, in nineball after Lassiter had won, 12468, in straight pool. Marino tri umphed, 40, in onepocket play.

title: Fish Fries Raise Funds For Mississippi Blacks
description: CANTON, Miss., Oct. 31 Amzie Cotton smiled broadly and with some obvious pride when asked how the Madison County Loyal Democrats had raised some $6,000 to support their 28 black and two white candidates for county positions in Tuesday's elections.

title: Ashe Defeats Pasarell
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 31 (AP)  Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., defeated Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 36, 63, 76, today in the Belgian $10,000 professional tennis tournament. Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., eliminated Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 64, 26, 63.

title: How Area's Senators Voted Last Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31Fol lowing are the votes of delega tions from New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yester day.

title: By a MIGRANT WORKER'S WIFE.
description: LA BELLE, Fla.I am writing in hopes that in some way The Times may be able to help many people that really need and deserve help from someone, for we are really the for gotten people.

title: Kenny Machine Is Seen In Peril in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 31With many of its leaders convicted or indicted on charges of cor ruption, the oldline Hudson County Democratic organiza tion was reported by some of its top leaders today to be se riously threatened with the loss of its monolithic control of City Hall in Tuesday's special mayoral election.

title: Jets and Giants Defeated
description: The New York Jets lost yesterday to the Chargers, 4921, before 44,786 at San Diego and the Giants were beaten, 1710, by the Minne sota Vikings as 62,829 watched at Yankee Stadium. (Details on Page 59).

title: Advertising: Looking at Self  Sufficiency
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30  Having thoroughly ex plored the area of advertis ing regulation the day before, the Association of National Advertisers yester day looked into the industry's second most popular conver sation topic. That's the growth of advertiser self sufficiency and its effect on the fullservice advertising agency.

title: Miss Scacchia, David J. Oestel Are Wed on L.I.
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Oct. 31In St. Edward Confessor Roman Catholic Church this after non, Miss Adrienne A. Scac chia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Scacchia of Mut tontown and Southold, was married to David J. Oestel, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oestel of Upper Brookville and Hawley, Pa. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. John P. Henry.

title: Prices to Industry Stable in Freeze
description: Industrial commodity prices in October achieved their great est stability since World War II, according to a survey con ducted last week by the Nation al Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Calendar of Eurobonds Is Heavy Again as Issues Regain Popularity
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 31  A blockbusting $100million fi nancing announced recently by Esso Overseas Finance has put the cap on the resurgence of classic, straightdollar debt on the international capital market.

title: Connecticut Woman Enters China to Visit Son in Prison
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 31 (UPI) Mrs. Mary V. Downey, 70 years old, of New Britain, Conn., crossed into China today to visit her son who has been held on spy charges for 19 years in Peking.

title: Legal Obstacles Blocking Boston Grand Jury in Its Investigation of the Release of Pentagon Papers
description: BOSTON, Oct. 31  After nearly three months of inves tigation, a Federal grand jury looking Into the unauthorized distribution and publication of the Pentagon papers appears to be far from completing its in quiry.

title: Japan's Defense Units, Gaining in Public Esteem, Mark 21st Year
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31With their ensigns curling in the light breeze and to the beat of martial music, troops of Japan's army, navy, and air force marched in review past Premier Eisaku Sato today to celebrate their 21st anniversary.

title: BARKLEY RESIGNS AS WINGS' COACH
description: DETROIT, Oct. 31 (AP) Doug Barkley resigned tonight as coach of the Detroit Red Wings, declaring that he just couldn't get the team going.

title: Gabriella Tucci Meets Challenges of Luisa
description: Since the title role of Verdi's Luisa Miller makes musical demands comparable to those of Violetta in Travlata, the soprano who can cope with one opera is very likely to turn the trick with the other.

title: EVACUATION PLAN PRINTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 31A news paper from the Soviet central Asian Republic of Tadzhikistan, which adjoins China, has pub lished an unusually detailed set of instructions for evacuation of city residents in case of nu clear attack.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Richmond Coach Improved
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., Oct. 31 (UPI)Frank Jones, University of Richmond head football coach, was reported in satis factory condition at a hospital here today after suffering what doctors described as a mild concussion. He was struck by colliding players while standing along the sideline during last night's Southern Mississippi game.

title: Migrant Farm Laborers Hold Their Own Hearings
description: MERCEDES, Tex., Oct. 31 In midautumn, the air in the Rio Grande Valley is as soft as in spring, with the fragrance of late  ripening melons and early oranges and grapefruit.

title: BLEAK 4TH PERIOD IS SEEN FOR STEEL
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 31  Steel producers were resigned last week, to profitless oper ating levels for the rest of 1971.

title: ALEX J. PAGEL, 83, OF PULP COMPANY
description: Alex J. Pagel, retired presi dent of Pagel, Horton & Co., importers of wood pulp and newsprint, died yesterday, in Sun Oaks Hospital, Amityville, L.I. Mr. Pagel, who, lived at 67 Woods Lane, East Hampton, L.I., was 83 years old.

title: House to Debate School Aid Bill Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31In the midst of a national dispute over the busing, of school children from one school dis trict to another, the House of Representatives begins to mor row what promises to be a vig orous debate on President Nix ons bill to give financial help to communities that are deseg regating their schools.

title: Study Panel Recommends That Public Employes Have Limited Right to Strike
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 31 A panel of 70 toplevel govern ment, legal, academic, business and labor leaders recommended today that public employes have a limited right to strike after obligatory procedures have been exhausted.

title: Trevino Wins Sahara Golf, Sets Season Earnings Mark of $227,243
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 31 (AP)Lee Trevino, the flam boyant Super Mex who has be come pro golf's dominant fig ure, hosted his sixth victory of the year today with a gritty triumph in the Sahara invitation golf tournament and established a singleseason money winning record.

title: Executive Promoted By ScrippsHoward
description: Edward W. Estlow was named general business man ager of the ScrippsHoward Newspapers yesterday, suc ceeding Frank B. Powers, who will continue to serve as vice president and a mem ber of the board of the E. W. Scripps Company.

title: 2 Urban Families Flee to Southern Town
description: GLENVILLE, W. Va., Oct. 31   Two months ago Robert Arnold, 42 years old, was senior vice president of New, York's First National City Bank, the second largest in the country. A close friend, Stan Meseroll, 46, was managing editor of Sports Afield, an out door magazine with a circula tion of more than 1.5 million.

title: Five Officials Warn of Fare Rise in a BondIssue Defeat, but Kheel Disagrees
description: Mayor Lindsay and four oth er public officials supporting the proposed $2.5billion trans portation bond issue, and Theo dore W. Kheel, its chief op ponent, disagreed sharply in televised debate last night over whether defeat of the issue in tomorrow's election would prompt a transit fare increase here.

title: Cambodia Charges Foe With Use of Nausea Gas
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday, Nov. 1 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported today that Commu nistled forces used toxic gas for the first time last Satur day, knocking out more than 100 Government soldiers de fending a strongpoint on the embattled northeastern front.

title: Drysdale Eliminates Stone, Lutz Gains at Stockholm Net
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 31 (UPI) Cliff Drysdale of South Af rica, who is seeded fifth, de feated Alan Stone of Australia today in the first round of the $45,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament. The scores were 36, 63, 64.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: It's a Hard Life for Women in Other Communist Nations, Too
description: VIENNA (Reuters)  Wo men's life styles in Eastern Europe would hardly, satisfy the women's liberation fight ers of the West, even though sexual equality is enshrined in Communist constitutions.

title: Mayo Clinic Wins Poll
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI)  The Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., was voted the nation's best hospital as regards case of patients in a recent poll of doctors. Results of the poll, which drew 628 responses, ap peared in the November issue of Today's Health, an American Medical Association publica tion.

title: Warning on Botulism in Beans Rescinded by U.S. Food Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Food and Drug Admin istration rescinded today its warning that a batch of Stoke lyVan Camp green beans might be contaminated with botulism.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Coloring Additive for Frankfurters Is Proposed by U.S.
description: The Department of Agricul ture will propose today the use of yet another coloring additive in the preparation of that great old American institution, the hot dog, whose ingtedients have yielded steadily to commercial pressures.

title: City Rules Close Some Nursing Homes
description: Three nursing homes here have closed voluntarily this year as the city Health Depart ment has stepped up code en forcement amid expanding new construction to replace old fa cilities and overcome a pres ent shortage.

title: Recreation and Parks Unit Presents Awards to Three
description: At its annual convention, held in Houston, the National Rec reation and Parks Association presented awards to Prof. Rey nold E. Carlson of the Univer sity of Indiana, Mayor William F. Laman of North Little Rock, Ark., and John B. Oakes, editor of the editorial page, The New York Times.

title: MYRON W. WOLFE
description: UTICA, N. Y., Nov. 1Myron W. Wolfe, president of Wolfe News Service, Inc., wholesale distributors, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  The afternoon sun was warm and a gentle breeze moved across the October fields, fluttering the dresses of the women guests at the wedding recep tion at the Stanley Murphy home.

title: Dow Chemical Sets Plant
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced plans yesterday to construct a multimilliondollar chlorine caustic production plant at Sarnia, Ontario, to re place an existing facility that has been criticized for mercury pollution problems. The plant is scheduled for completion it early 1973.

title: Thousands in India Killed By Storm and Tidal Wave
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1Thou sands of people, perhaps as many as 10,000, were killed by a cyclone and tidal wave that hit the eastern coast of India Friday night and Satur day morning, according to re ports reaching the capital.

title: ST. PAUL COMPANIES SHOWS PROFIT GAIN
description: Earnings of the St. Paul Com panies, Inc., advanced sharply in the first nine months but rose only slightly in the third quarter, figures released by the insurer showed yesterday.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. IPeople in most American cities are fed up with government that doesn't work, or doesn't seem to serve what citizens think is the public interest. Here in this sunlit city something drastic is being done about it via Proposition T.

title: Johannesburg Dean Gets 5Year Term on Plot Charge
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 1The Anglican Dean of Jo hannesburg, an outspoken op ponent of South Africa's racial separation policies, was sen tenced today to five years' im prisonment under the sweeping provisions of the Terrorism Act. He was released in $14,000 bail pending appeal, which is not expected to be heard before next March.

title: MORE DATA SOUGHT ON MANMADE TURF
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The executive director of the National Football League Play ers' Association called today for a moratorium on the in stallation of artificial turf sur faces until it was determined whether they caused or reduced injuries.

title: CONNALLY HOLDS TALKS WITH THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 1Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally met with Pres ident Nguyen Van Thieu today in talks covering the future of continued American economic aid to South Vietnam and the Senate vote last week to kill the fereign assistance program.

title: Silver Knight Takes Cup
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 2 (Reuters) Silver Knight, a New Zealand stallion ran away with Australia's most famous race, the $120,000 Melbourne Cup today at Flemington. Rid den by Bruce Marsh the 4year old swept past the leaders half way down the stretch and won by 1 lengths. Igloo, another New Zealander horse, was sec ond and Tails was third another 1 lengths back.

title: About Pro Football
description: With 2 minutes left, the Raiders' Don Highsmith hit the Kansas City line on third down and was stopped inches short of the Chiefs' goal. Oakland trailed, 2017. John Madden, the coach, sent out 44yearold George Blan da, who kicked an 8yard field goal. The game wound up 2020. Mad den's option on fourth down was to try for a touch down and maybe win, 2420, or lose, 2017. The only time you don't go for a tie, he explained later, is when a tie won't do you any good. You play for a tie unless you need a win. We've got seven games left.

title: Market Place: To the Defense Of Little Guy
description: Conventional wisdom tells us that the Little Guy is so wrongheaded about the mar ket that when he and all his little buddies sell stock it's time for the smart money to buy.

title: State Gets Prison Aid
description: The state will receive $4,304, 000 under the Federal Safe Streets Act to improve its cor rection programs, Governor Rockefeller announced yester day. The funds will be used for reforms involving staff training, inmate health care and develop ment of more vocational and hobby training, he said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Stewart & Co. Fills Post
description: Stewart & Co., a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, announced yester day that Norbert R. Christen recently made executive vice president, has been elected president, succeeding John C. Gillivan who was named chair man, preparatory to his retire ment effective Fob. 1, 1972.

title: JOHN J. DWYER
description: John J. Dwyer, retired resi dent counsel and secretary of the Bank of Commerce, with which he had been associated 40 years, died Sunday in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. His age was 70. He lived at 8559 112th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL PLANS CASTING UNIT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Cor poration announced yesterday plans for building a continuous casting facility to produce slabs at its Burns Harbor, Ind., plant. Stewart S. Cart, chair man, said this would be the company's first commercial installation of the equipment although it has conducted a joint experimental program with Inland Steel, Republic Steel and Johnstown Sheet and Tube.

title: Teleprompter Corp. Says Kahn Remains As Chief Executive
description: The directors of the Tele prompter Corporation voted unanimously at a special meet ing yesterday to make no man agement changes now and to proceed with a scheduled elec tion of directors on Nov. 24.

title: State's Debt of $7Billion Bars Bond, Kheel Says
description: Ina final attack on the pro posed transportation bond issue yesterday, its leading opponent, Theodore W. Kheel, cited fig ures from State Controller Ar thur Levitt to show that the state was more than $7billion in debt.

title: RICKLES IS CALLED A NUT BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay called his Air Reiources Commissioner, Rob ert N, Rickles, a damn fool and a nut yesterday for op posing Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5billion transpor tation bond issue.

title: The AnkleLength Skirt (Surprise!) Is Making Fashion Inroads
description: Fashion fickle? You know it. Remember the outcries a year ago about the midi? How women swore they wouldn't wear it because it made them feel old, dowdy and out of it? How they screamed they wouldn't be dic tated to, they'd rather wear their old clothes?

title: MOSCOW REASSURES. CUBANS ON SUPPORT
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1 (Reuters) The Soviet Union, in a joint communique issued here, as sured Cuba today of its back ing against the United States, apparently to allay any concern in Havana over President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE VANTAGE POINT. Perspectives of the Presidency 19631969. By Lyndon Baines Johnson. 636 pages. Illustrated. Holt, Rine hart & Winston. $15.

title: A.Willis Robertson, 84, Is Dead; Headed Senate Banking Panel
description: LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 1 (AP)A. Willis Robertson of Virginia, who served in the Senate for 20 years, died in hospital here, today at the age of 84.

title: U.S. to Send Observers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell ordered Federal ob servers, at the request of local officials and other leaders to the polls in 16 counties in Mis sissippi for tomorrow's election.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Is Critical of U.S. View on Refugee Aid
description: LONDON, Nov. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of In dia charged today that the United States was taking a shortterm view of the crisis with Pakistan and warned that the influx of East Pakistani refugees had strained India be yond the breaking point.

title: Kennedy Asks U.N. Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 1Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy urged today that the Nixon Adminis tration support efforts to bring the East Pakistani situation be fore the United Nations Gen eral Assembly in the interests of reaching a political settle ment of the crisis.

title: Theater: Pantagleize
description: WASHINGTONWashing ton is becoming a theater town. At present it has a Neil Simon play in its pre Broadway tryout, Leonard Bernstein's Candide is at the Opera House of the Ken nedy Center, there is a new play at the Arena Stage and Edward Albee's All Over is being staged by the Wash ington Theater Club.

title: Nets Trade Leaks to Stars, Get Moore of Chaparrals
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 1 (AP)The New York Nets of the American Basket ball Association traded Manny Leaks, a forward, to the Utah Stars today and acquired a center, Gene Moore, from the Dallas Chaparrals.

title: Federal Official Scolds Labor At Ceremony for Ship Terminal
description: Maritime labormanagement problems, surfaced unexpected ly yesterday at groundbreaking ceremonies for the Consolidat ed Passenger Ship Terminal at West 48th Street when the head of the Federal Maritime Commission said phenomenal labor costs were a principal reason for the ultimate de mise of Americanflag passen ger ships.

title: Jessica Tower, President Of a Book Service, Is Dead
description: Jessica Tower, president of Tower Associates, a bookpro motion service for publishers at 404 East 55th Street, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness.

title: Giants, Renewed, Await the Answers
description: When the New York Giants return to work this morning at Yankee Stadium, to begin the second half of their sea son, they will be eager to know:

title: Mercer Stages Are a Supermarket
description: In Greenwich Village, hard by a row of shippingreceiv ing platforms, there is one small door that leads to five OffBroadway theaters. A flag over the entrance marks the Mercer Arts Center a family of theaters under one roof that, until very recently, leaked.

title: 60 SENATORS SEEKING U.N. CHARTER REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Sixty Senators have rallied behind a resolution to revise the United Nations Charter, particularly to change the one countryonevote system in the General Assembly.

title: Discretionary Excise Tax Favored for Foreign Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Senate Finance Committee voted today to give President Nixon additional discretionary tools, through the tax system, to bring pressure on foreign governments to follow the in ternational economic policies that the United States wants.

title: Karachi Says Raid Is Repelled
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov.1 The Pakistani radio said today that 72 raiders were killed and 39 wounded when they attacked Pakistani posi tions in the Syihet, Rajshahi and Dinajpur districts of East Pakistan today.

title: Reynolds Securities' Net Down Sharply in Quarter
description: Reynolds Securities Inc., a major Wall Street brokerage house, experienced a sharp earnings decline in this year's third quarter as a result of a slowdown in trading volume in the stock market. The decline, which came to light in a newly issued prospectus for the concern's proposed public offering, provides an indication that thirdquarter revenues contracted sharply in the securities industry. Reynolds has in recent years been one of Wall Street's most profitable houses.

title: NASDAQ STARTING VOLUME REPORTS
description: Volume statistics for the over thecounter market became available yesterday for the first time and confirmed that trad ing in unlisted stocks is sub stantial.

title: Davis Trial Delayed By Plea to Exclude Letters to Jackson
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 1 (UPI)  Angela Davis's trial was delayed today as her at torneys asked for suppression of personal memoirs they in dicated expressed her love for George L. Jackson, the black revolutionary who was killed this year at San Quentin prison.

title: Sale of Yonkers Track Expected Soon
description: YONKERS, Nov. 1Control of Yonkers Raceway, which has been held by the Tananbaum family since 1956, is expected to be transferred in a few days to a financially responsible purchaser, believed to be the Rooney family of Pittsburgh. The buyer wants to remain unidentified until final details are completed. The deal is ex pected to cost about $35million.

title: National Horse Show to Open Today
description: The eightday equine extrav aganza known as the National Horse Show officially gets un der way at 10:30 this morning at Madison Square Garden when 20 green hunters compete in an open conformation class.

title: Namath, Jets Debate His Return
description: With the Jets' franchise vir tually awarded to the Red Cross, the controversY has be gun. Should Joe Namath return at quarterback this season even if he's healthy? Or should he wait until next year for a fresh start with a healthy team?

title: Maine Governor in Tax Plea
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 1 (UPI) Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis made an 11thhour appeal today urg ing voters to reject a referen dum aimed at repealing the state's twoyearold income tax.

title: CONGRESS CHIEFS AGREE FOREIGN AID SHOULD CONTINUE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Congressional leaders agreed today that the foreign aid pro gram should have a new lease on life, but there was wide dif ferences about the duration and scope of any extension as well as the shape of any per manent legislation to follow.

title: Hopes Rise for Canadian Football Here
description: Despite a lack of optimism on the Canadian side, Dep uty Mayor Richard R. Aurelio said yesterday there was a very good chance for New York to obtain a franchise for a new Canadian Football League team.

title: CABLE TV TO TAKE VIEWERS TO OPERA
description: Teleprompter Manhattan CATV Corporation will present a live telecast of the New York City Opera Company's produc tion of RimskyKorsakoff's Le Coq d'Or to its 42,000 sub scribers next Tuesday from 8 P.M. to 10:30.

title: BRONX CLUB OWNER CLEARED OF CHARGES
description: Charges of serving liquor without a license and posses sion of two pistols and one ounce of cocaine against the proprietor of a social club in the Bronx were dismissed for insufficient evidence on Fri day after a brief nonjury trial in Bronx Criminal Court.

title: Too Loud and Clear
description: The airplane like the automobile is a necessary but noisy intruder in city life. Few quarrels can be more bitter than those between airport managers and citizens who live in communities below an airport's flight pattern. It is difficult even to get agreement on what it is that is being argued about because in this dispute one man's distant hum is another man's dreadful roar.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 General Count Dracula, controversial military dictator of the Democratic Republic of Terror del Luna, arrived in Washing ton on Saturday night via his personal, monogrammed jet coffin.

title: Tomy Lee Is Destroyed
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 (UPI)Tomy Lee, winner of the 1959 Kentucky Derby, has been destroyed to end his suffering from a massive kidney infec tidn. The 15yearold colt was killed by injection of a poison ous chemical last Friday.

title: Tunex Takes Aqueduct Dash by a Head
description: Although he got away awk wardly, Tunex of the Hobeau Farm showed enough determi nation and speed to overtake the entire field and win the feature event at Aqueduct yes terday.

title: EIGHT WOMEN WIN IN SWISS ELECTION
description: GENEVA, Nov. 1At least eight women won seats in the nation's Parliament yesterday in the first federal elections in which women had been allowed to participate.

title: A.F.LC.I.O.OpposesIncentives In Welfare as Big Brother Idea
description: New York State's two pend ing welfare demonstration pro posals were vigorously opposed by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations in a letter made public yesterday urging Federal disapproval.

title: Fund to Spur Peking Trade Urged
description: The head of a Hong Kong based trade research and de velopment company proposed here yesterday the establish ment of a private China trade fund to promote commercial exchanges between mainland China and the United States.

title: Bayard Rustin in Hospital After Heart Attack Sunday
description: Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, was reported rest ing comfortably yesterday in the intensive care unit of Sharon Hospital in Sharon, Conn., after suffering what was described as a major heart atttack on Sunday.

title: Upstate Student Nurse, 19, Is Found Slain in Boston
description: BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Christine M. Ross, 19 years old, of Penfield, N. Y., a student at Northeastern University School of Nursing, was found beaten to death last night in the bedroom of a vacant secondfloor apart ment in the Back Bay.

title: Wurlitzer Opens Drive on 42d St. Smut
description: Music to decontaminate West 42d Street by, they called it yesterday, as an ar ray of jazz stars helped long time merchants start an anti pornography campaign.

title: New Bus Service Is Started Between Midtown and Bronx
description: Express bus service between the Soundview section of the Bronx and midtown Manhattan was started yesterday and the first coach made the run from White Plains Road to 26th Street in 43 minutes.

title: Wally Jones Sues N.B.A. For $5Million in Damages
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (UPI)The suspended Philadel phia 76ers guard, Wally Jones, filed today a Federal suit which his attorney termed a compre hensive attack on the structure of the National Basketball Asso ciation.

title: EARNINGS RAISED BY EL PASO GAS
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company reported yesterday sizable gains in operating rev enues and net income for three and nine months ended Sept. 30. The report placed revenues at $246,888,000 for the Sep tember quarter against $222, 905,000 a year earlier. Net in come rose to $12,745,000, or 41 cents a share, from $7,628,000, or 24 cents a share on fewer shares, in the three months ended Sept. 30, 1970. Operat ing revenues for the first 9 months totaled $752,553,000, against $689,993,000 a year ago while net income rose to $38, 590,000, or $1.25 a share, from $29,207,000, or 97 cents a share also on fewer shares, in the like 1970 period.

title: Making of a Communist
description: MADISON, Conn.In 1935, the Edgar Snows were living in Peking at 13 K'uei Chia Ch'ang near the Fox Tower. The house was reported to be haunted by werefoxes. It was also the haunt of forlorn hopes among the Chinese students of the American Yenching University in Peking.

title: Help Asked in Mine Towns
description: STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP)Sheriff's officers called in extra help today after 18 coalmine operators in five eastern Ohio counties an nounced plans to reopen union closed mines Wednesday. Rov ing strikers of the United Mine Workers reportedly stopped at small mines in the area and asked that they cease opera tion. The mines have contracts with independent unions not affiliated with the U.M.W., now in a monthold strike.

title: Tanzania Airport Open
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 1 (Reuters)The first scheduled flights landed today at a new international airport near Mount Kilimanjaro. The $10million airport is capable of handling jumbo jets.

title: Bar Panel Charges Justice Unit Leaked Court Vote Report
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1,The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Ju diciary charged today that the Justice Department leaked the news last month that the A.B.A. group had found two of Presi dent Nixon's potential Supreme Court nominees not qualified.

title: RING BOARD TAKES NAPOLES'S TITLE
description: The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday with drew recognition of the world welterweight champion, Jose Napoles of Mexico, and sus pended him along with his man ager, Alfredo Cruz.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A FADED TANGIER TAMER NOWADAYS
description: TANGIER, MoroccoMoroc cans in long robes and young foreigners in blue jeans sit around the cafes in the medina, the Arab quarter of this inter national meeting point, sipping coffee, mint tea and CocaCola. From time to time, sebsis, long stemmed pipes with tiny bowls, are passed around the tables and each man inhales deeply.

title: House Rejects Nixon Bill On School Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1  The House of Representatives rejected today the Nixon ad ministration bill that seeks spe cial Federal financial help for communities that are desegre gating their schools.

title: Brezhnev Spurs Germans on Berlin Talks
description: BERLIN, Nov. 1Leonid I. Brezhnev ended two days of consultations with East German leaders today with a call for the fastest possible conclusion of their talks with West Germans on the practical arrangements for putting into effect the re cent fourpower accord on West Berlin.

title: Van Breda Kolff, Quitting as Coach, Criticizes the Fans
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 (UPI)Bill van Breda Kolff, claiming he would never coach again re signed abruptly today as head coach of the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Associa tion.

title: Eliot, Educator, Is Named Head of Salzburg Seminar
description: Thomas H. Eliot, a lawyer and former chancellor of Wash ington University in St. Louis, succeeded Paul M. Herzog yes terday as president of the Salz burg Semirmar in American Studies, an organization that holds six seminars annually in Salzburg, Austria, to foster Eu ropean understanding of Ameri can affairs.

title: Some Schools Close for Black Solidarity Day
description: Three school districts in Brooklyn with an enrollment of more than 90,000 students were closed yesterday in observance of the third annual Black Soli darity Day.

title: Linda Fialla Wed To Robert Mettler
description: Miss Linda Fialla was mar ried in a civil ceremony in Hong Kong Saturday to Rob ert Mettler, who is technical manager of the Hong Kong branch of Sandoz, the chemi cal company.

title: No Soviet Aid Reported
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1  Mrs. Fania Jordan, Miss Davis's sis ter, who is here on a European tour, said today that Soviet groups, though sympathetic, had made no financial pledges to Miss Davis's defense fund.

title: ExecutivePrivilege Claim Pressed in AirBag Dispute
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 1 The Nixon Administration has claimed executive privilege in contesting a suit for disclo sure of communications be tween the White House and Department of Justice on a pending automobile safety standard.

title: RICHARD L. EVANS, MORMON VOICE, 65
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 1  Richard. L. Evans, a Mor mon Apostle for 18 years and commentator on the longest net work prograrn in radio, died this morning at the age of 65.

title: Filipino Gunman Frees Girl After Copter Escape
description: MANILA, Nov. 1  The 14yearold daughter of a wealthy American business man escaped unharmed today after she was held hostage for almost 10 hours by a gun man who shot and critically wounded her mother and stabbed a maid to death dur ing an attempted robbery, of their spacious home just out side Manila.

title: GROWING DEMAND FOR CREDIT SEEN
description: The total demand for funds in the credit markets will rise substantially in 1972, an econ omist predicted. But, because the supply of credit should be ample and the expectation of future inflation diminished, up ward pressures on interest rates should be limited.

title: Merger News
description: The Coburn Corporation of America and the Lincoln Amer ican Corporation yesterday signed an agreement to merge.

title: Missouri Town Closes Schools in Tax Dispute
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 1 (UPI)The city's 25 public schools closed today and 17, 000 students were sent home because residentS had voted down tax increases.

title: Another Male Bastion Falls
description: The Trinity School, a pres tigious West Side private school for boys aged 6 to 18, did something a little revo lutionary this semester. It ad mitted girls.

title: 130 Lawyers Arrive to Observe Mississippi Voting
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 1 More than 130 outofstate lawyers woke up in mostly poor black homes this morn ing to a state that is in the middle of a bumper harvest and a promising hunting sea son, and is facing what many here are calling the most im portant election of our times.

title: Dr. Winthrop Phelps, 77, Dies; Noted for Cerebral Palsy Work
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 1 (AP) Dr. Winthrop Morgan Phelps, known for his pioneering work in developing diagnostic and treatment techniques for cere bral palsy, died at his home yesterday. He was'77 years old.

title: Bus Strike Curbs Service To 3 Major Airports Here
