description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Sec retary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans will visit the Soviet Un ion later this month for high level talks on ways to enlarge SovietAmerican trade, the White House announced to day.

title: 18YearOld Is Elected
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 2  Maureen Massiwer, an 18 yearold freshman at Brown University, captured first place tonight in the race for one of the six seats on the school committee in Pawtucket, an in dustrial city directly northeast of Providence. The victory makes Miss Massiwer one of the youngest elected officeholders in the United States.

title: DOW RISES BY 2.12 AS TRADING IS UP
description: Stock prices steadied yester day to finish slightly higher, following Monday's sharp plunge that sent the DowJones industrial average to a 1971 low.

title: INSPECTION PROCESS FOR C5A DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI)  Frank E. McCreery, presi dent of the Rohr Corporation, Chula Vista, Calif., said today that extensive investigation had produced no evidence that the company had delivered cracked jet engine mountings for the Air Force's big C5A jet trans port.

title: BULLS BEAT SUNS WITH LATE SURGE
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) Chet Walker scored 9 points in the last two minutes tonight to help the Chicago Bulls defeat the Phoenix Suns, 108101, in a National Basketball Associa tion contest.

title: Blaze at School in Wilton Causes $300,000 Damages
description: WILTON, Conn., Nov. 2An earlymorning fire at Wilton Middle chool caused damages estimated in excess of $300,000.

title: Fall Kills Jersey Boy, 13
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 2 (UPI)A 13yearold boy fell six stories to his death last night after he and five other children sniffed glue, the police said today. The boy was identi fied as Fernando Alamo of 320 Marshall Drive. The police said he was sitting on a window ledge when he fell.

title: 11% Increase Shown by Chain Stores for September
description: September sales of leading chain store and catalogue or ganizations, as compiled by The New York Times, showed an increase of 11 per cent above the level of sales in the year before.

title: Theater: Capote's The Grass Harp Makes Its Debut as Musical
description: The new musical The Grass Harp, which opened last night at the Martin Beck Theater, is unpreten tiousunderstandably unpre tentious. It is based on the novel and play by Truman Capote that were both folsky and fey. The musical is also folksy and fey, in so far as it has any real character at all, for it is the kind of show that is almost as difficult to dislike as to like.

title: CORE Vows to Oust O.T.B. From Harlem As a White Symbol
description: The Congress of Racial Equality vowed yesterday to root out betting done through the Offtrack Betting Corpora tion in Harlem because it sucks out all the money and none comes back.

title: YONKERS RACEWAY TO BE SOLD TODAY
description: YONKERS, Nov. 2The sale of Yonkers Raceway and its other holdings to a Pennsyl vania group headed by John Rooney, the president of the William Penn Racing Associa tion, operator of Philadelphia's Liberty Bell Park, will be con summated tomorrow, a source close to the negotiations dis closed today.

title: NIXON APPROVES HERBERT ADVANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  President Nixon has approved the Army's recommendation for promotion of Lieut. Col. An thony E. Herbert, whom the Army sought to oust after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged at trocities committed by Ameri can servicemen in Vietnam.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Rise; Federal Securities Not Traded
description: The bond marketpartly closed yesterday for Election Daycontinued to move de terminedly toward higher prices and lower interest rates.

title: LAVER CONQUERS MAUD BY 63, 64
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 2 (UPI) Rod Laver of Australia made his first appearance in the $50,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament today and defeated Bob Maud of South Africa, 63, 64, in a secondround match.

title: ISRAELIS PRESENT DILEMMA FOR U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 Israel has confronted the United States with a negotiating di lemma by her refusal to par ticipate in indirect talks with Egypt until Washington re sumes shipments of Phantom fighterbombers, American offi cials said today.

title: Union Pay Gains Fall By OneFifth in Year
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP)In the year ended Sept. 30, unions settled for pay increases averaging one fifth less than they did in the same period a year earlier, the Labor Department said today.

title: IRENE DAYE SPIVAK
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Nov. 2 (AP)Irene Daye Spivak, a for mer vocalist and wife of Charlie Spivak; the bandleader, died yesterday at a hospital here after a long illness She Was 53 years old.

title: Vergari and Del Bello Winners in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 2 Westchester County District Attorney Carl A. Vergari and Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello won reelection today in the two major elections in the county.

title: Presidential Realty Elects
description: The Presidential Realty Cor poration elected yesterday Jus tin Glickson as chairman of the executive committee, Thomas M. Viertel as vice chairman of the board and Steven H. Baruch as executive vice president. Mr. Glickson, formerly vice presi dent, secretary and general counsel, succeeds Jules Sha piro. Mr. Shapiro, who was president of the company from 1948 to 1956, has been named president emeritus of the com pany.

title: Executive Changes
description: DPF, Inc., formerly Data Processing Financial & General Corporation, announced yesterday the elec tion of Bertram J. Cohn as chairman. Mr. Cohn, a director of the company, is president of Morgan County Metals Corporation. Harold M. Wit, execu tive vice president of Allen & C. Inc.; and Arthur B. Kramer, a partner in the law firm of Nickerson, Kramer, Lowenstein, Nessen & Kamin, were elected directors.

title: DAVIS CASE MOVED TO SAN JOSE COURT
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. (UPI)  The Angela Davis trial was ordered transferred today from the Marin County Civic Center here to San Jose, 50 miles south.

title: BRITISH STRIKE HITS AIRLINES FOR 2D DAY
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 Britain's two major airlines were vir tually at a standstill today, the second day of an unofficial strike by ground personnel at Heathrow Airport.

title: Texts of the Chinese Messages
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 2Following are the texts of two cablegrams received by Secretary General Thant today from the Acting Foreign Minister of China, Chi Pengfei, regarding the composition of the Chinese delegation to the General Assembly and the Chinese rep resentation on the Security Council. The messages were in English.

title: CITY TO CLEAN UP CRIME IN STREETS
description: The Police Department, noting that street crimes  muggings, purse snatching and robberies  are increasing, announced yesterday the formation of a citywide robbery division to clean up the city.

title: COACHES' RATINGS By United Press International
description: The top 20, with points fig ured on a 10.987654321 basis for first through 10th places (firstplace votes in par entheses) and wonlost records through games of last Saturday.

title: Basic Phone Rates Here Unchanged in 13 Years
description: Minimum basic charges for residential telephones re mained unchanged here for 13 years from 1957 until last year, the New York Tele phone Company said last night.

title: Population Tops 207 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 AP) The Census Bureau said today that the total population of the United States was estimated to be 207,372,000 on Sept. 1. The figure, which includes armed forces overseas, was an in crease of 2,159,000, or 1.1 per cent, over the estimate for Sept. 1, 1970;

title: Doesn't Anybody Here Count Sheep Any More?
description: As Freud once observed, nearly every body has a pet ritual in preparing for a night's snooze.

title: Local 295 Holds Sway at Kennedy In Cargo Handling
description: Harry Davidoff's union, Local 295 of the International Broth erhood of Teamsters, has for several years been the elusive target of law enforcement agencies seeking to curb theft, extortion, bribery and intimi dation at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2  Walliur Rahman, second secretary of the Pakistani Embassy in Berne, announced today that he had resigned because of the events in East Pakistan and was seeking asylum in Switz erland.

title: DETROIT BANK GIVES FLOATINGRATE DATA
description: The Michigan Bank in De troit, which two weeks ago joined the First. National City Bank and the Irving Trust Com pany in setting a floating prime rate, announced yester day the details of its new low pricing plan.

title: Manson Is Found Guilty Of Two More Murders
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) Charles M. Manson, the clan leader already under sentence of death in the seven Sharon Tate murders, was convicted to day on two more counts of first degree murder.

title: Defeat for the Bond Issue
description: The resounding defeat of the $2.5billion transportation bond issue by voters of New York State yesterday regrettable as it may becan only be interpreted as a popular revolt of significant dimensions. It is a revolt against further public debt and the soaring faxes needed to pay off that debt, against the bulldozer rule of the highway lobby in Albany and against the tactics used by state and city officials in hope of ramming the bond issue through.

title: VIOLINCELLO MUSIC PLAYED BY DOMBS
description: Music for violin and cello is rare enough. A program of nothing but such music is rarer still. Yet this is what Carol Sindell and Daniel Domb elected to present in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night. They brought so much youthful zest to their playing, making the auditorium vibrant with their performances, that what could have been monotonous and dull became rich and vital.

title: 291 Reported Killed
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 2 (AP)The Government today reported 291 North Vietnamese and Vietcong killed in the cam paign at Prakham.

title: AIRPORT DAMAGE TO NEIGHBORS SET
description: Property owners on the ap proaches to New Haven's air port suffer damage bacause of air traffic, a Federal judge ruled here yesterday, and he directed the City of New Haven to pay for the loss.

title: Evers Is Defeated In Large Turnout In Mississippi Vote
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 William L. Waller, the white Democratic nominee, decisively defeated Charles Evers, the black independent challenger, in the Mississippi election for Governor today.

title: Hayes Misses Practice
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (AP)Thel Houston Rockets center, Elvin Hayes, missed practice today, subjecting himself to an auto matic fine and a probable de motion from the starting line up against the New York Knicks here tomorrow night.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS ARRIVE IN ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 2  The Presidents of four African countries arrived tonight to start a new peacemaking mis sion that the Israeli Govern ment hopes will modify the pro Egyptian positions previously adopted by the Organization of African Unity.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Heavy selling by speculators and profit taking erased a gain of 2 cents a bushel in soy bean futures in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. At the close soy beans were off  cent to 1 cents a bushel.

title: Superior Court Overturns Ruling in 2 Newton Trials
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 2 (UPI)  Superior Court Judge Lyle Cook rejected today ruling by the judges in Huey P. Newton's two previous trials on manslaughter charges.

title: ElectionDay Drinkers Toast Tavern Openings
description: Drinking was light but steady here yesterday, and indications were that when all the opinions were counted samplings were still being taken well into this morning  the state legislative de cision permitting taverns to operate on Election Day will have been overwhelmingly approved.

title: PLAYBOY'S OFFERING OF SHARES IS TODAY
description: Playboy Enterprises, Inc., which in 18 years has built Playboy magazine into a $130 millionayear publishing, hotel and key club empire, will find out today how much interest the public has in its common stock.

title: School District Sues Education Board
description: A Manhattan district school board has brought suit in State Supreme Court contesting the City Board of Education's reg ulations for dismissing teach ers to meet budget economies.

title: U.N. Stamp Will Reflect New China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 2Peking's admission to the United Nations has wrought a smallscale cultural revolu tion in the organization's Pos tal Administration, a bigtime operation that has produced 700 million stamps.

title: About Pro Football
description: The pro football season has reached the halfway mark with four apparent twoteam races and two others involving three, clubs. This means there are 11 like ly contenders for the eight playoff berthS.

title: NIXON PANEL SETS A GUIDELINE OF 4% IN DIVIDEND RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2A guideline limiting increases in corporation dividends to 4 per cent was announced today by the committee regulating in terest and dividends in the sec ond phase of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

title: ISRAELI MUSICAL TOOK LONG ROUTE
description: One of Broadway's newest musicals may have set a long distance record for outoftown tryouts: before New York it had previewed in a Tel Aviv suburb, in English, making it a foreignlanguage production in its own country.

title: MAKERS DISPUTE ASTROTURF STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2A leading manufacturer of arti ficial turf charged today that a.study linking a rise in football injuries with the use of artificial surfaces was super ficial and inconclusive.

title: KARLA S. GROSSINGER, HOSTESS AT RESORT
description: Karla Seifer Grossinger, for mer director of guest relations at Grossinger's resort in the Catskills, died of a heart attack Monday in Rome. She was 72 years old and had been living in Montecatini, Italy, since leaving the hotel in 1960.

title: Pole's Asylum Extended
description: BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP)  A Polish sailor who jumped ship here last week to avoid return ing to his native country will be allowed to remain in the United States for at least one year. The United States Immi gration and Naturalization Service said yesterday that the original grant of asylum for Wojcieck Ostrowski, 35 years old, would be extended from 30 days to one year.

title: Smut Raids in Dallas
description: DALLAS, Nov. 2 (AP)Law enforcement officers raided 17 movie theaters and bookstores today in a crackdown against pornography that Police Chief Frank Dyson said had all the earmarks of organized crime in Dallas.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Man In the News
description: Chiao Kuanhua, who is to head the new Chinese dele gation to the General Assem bly, is one of Peking's most accomplished diplomats.

title: Senate Democrats Balk at 90Day Extension for Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2De spite new Administration, ap peals, the Democratic leadership of the Senate balked today, at proposals for a 90day exten sion of the foreign aid, program financed at last year's $2.64bil lion annual rate.

title: Teamster Official Is Accused of Extorting Tickets From Airline
description: The secretarytreasurer of Local 295 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, whose members handle air freight at Kennedy Internation al Airport, was arrested yester day on charges of extorting tickets worth $9,627 from Trans Caribbean Airways be tween October, 1966, and November, 1970.

title: MARINER EMERGENCY OVER AFTER 5 HOURS
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 2 (AP)An emergency situation was declared today with the Mariner 9 spacecraft but was lifted five hours later. Officials decided the craft was again operating normally and on course for its rendezvous with Mars.

title: Court Rejects Plea By Carey for Writ To Halt Walkout
description: A Federal Court judge in Brooklyn yesterday rejected the Carey Transportation Com pany's application for a tem porary restraining order against its bus drivers who are staging a work stoppage.

title: Third Appeal Filed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) Conservation groups filed third court appeal today seek ing to halt the Amchitka test.

title: Oil Nations Seeking Role in Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2  Major American, British and French oil companies have be gun negotiations with 11 oil producing nations, most of them Middle Eastern, on the producers' demand for partici nation in the companies and for compensation for the re duced value of the dollar.

title: Falling Birth Rate
description: Is the muchpredicted and oftlamented baby boom of the 1970's turning into a baby bust? It is still too early for a final answer, but some provocative and unexpected data on this subject have been emerging in recent months.

title: America Is Not a Repressive Society
description: RICHMOND, Va.At a time when slogans often substitute for rational thought, it is fashionable to charge that repression of civil liberties is widespread. This chargedirected pri marily against law enforcementis standard leftist propaganda. It is also made and widely believed on the campus, in the arts and theater, in the pulpit and among some of the media. Many persons genuinely concerned about civil liberties thus join in pro moting or accepting the propaganda of the radical left.

title: Teacher Drops Guard for Pupils
description: Hey, kids! Ever had an urge to punch your school teacher in the nose? Or wanted to see someone else punch him?

title: Opposition to School Prayer Amendment Mounting in the House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Po litical and religious opposition to a proposed constitutional amendment to permit nonde noninational prayers in the public schools mounted today.

title: 130,000 ALCOHOLICS FOUND IN MILITARY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2, (AP)  Congressional investigators today reported that there were an estimated 130,000 alcoholics in the armed forces but said that the Pentagon had done little to treat them, preferring punishment instead.

title: Transit Workers Will Ask 30% Raise and a FourDay Week
description: A wage increase of 30 per cent for 37,500 subway and bus employes, a fourday, 32hour work week and increased fringe benefits are among the major demands in a new twoyearcon tract proposal that the Transport Workers Union has approved.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan Bars 53 Election Contests
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 2  The Pakistani Government an nounced today that 53 of the National Assembly seats taken away from members of the out lawed Awami League in East Pakistan would be filled with out contest.

title: Indian Storm Toll Up to 4,000, but It May Reach 20,000
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 2The estimated death toll con tinued to rise today in the cyclone and tidal wave that struck the eastern coast of India over the weekend, with some officials predicting that it might reach 20,000 or more.

title: PAKISTANIS IN INDIA BEAT BENGALI AIDES
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 2West Pakistani employes of Paki stan's diplomatic mission here beat Bengali employes with sticks and iron bars today as they were trying to leave the mission and join the East Paki stani independence movement.

title: RERI GRIST PORTRAYS GILDA IN RIGOLETTO
description: Even in this era of the visually credible opera singer it would be difficult to find handsomer people for the lead ing romantic roles in Rigo letto than the Metropolitan Opera offered in the season's fifth performance on Monday night. Berl Grist looked like a Gilda capable of disturbing the dreams of any Mantuan noble man, and Franco. Bonisolli made a dashing, youthful Duke. Miss Grist, moreover, could effortlessly deliver Caro nome in silvery, limpid tones, the intervals precisely in tune. There was even a suggestion of dramatic intensity that should grow with experience in the part.

title: RIZZO WINS RACE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2 Frank L. Rizzo, who calls him self the toughest cop in America, swept to a solid vic tory today over his Republican opponent, Thacher Longstreth, to become Mayor of the coun try's fourth largest city.

title: U.S. Car Output May Top 8.55 Million Units in 1971
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2 (Reuters) United States auto output could exceed 8.55 million units this year, according to Ward's Auto motive Reports.

title: Dobson of Orioles Beats Japan Team With NoHitter, 20
description: TOYAMA, Japan, Nov. 2 (AP)  Pat Dobson made interna tional baseball history today as he hurled the first nohit, norun game of his career and gave the Baltimore Orioles a 20 victory over Japan's champion Tokyo Yomiuri Giants.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2Vice Presi dent Agnew has been accused of almost everything except a lack of saying right out what he thinks, and one of the attractive aspects of this compulsive candor is that he applies it to himself.

title: Japanese Fishing BoatSeized
description: SITKA, Alaska, Nov. 2 (UPI) A 190foot Japanese fishing vessel tried unsucessfully to outrun Coast Guard planes to day after she was sighted alleg edly fishing illegally off the Alaska coast. The Ryusho Maru No. 5, after a 90minute chase, surrendered and was escorted to this potr to await action by the Justice Depart ment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Huang Evinces Surprise
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 2  Ambas sador Huang said tonight that he had learned from reporters of his appointment as a repre sentative at the United Nations.

title: INEQUITIES SEEN IN SCHOOL FUNDING
description: A Federally funded, fouryear study of public school financing has found that great inequities exist in the amount of funds raised and spent in the school districts of nearly every state and result in unequal educa tional opportunities.

title: OilProduct Demand Rising
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) The Independent Petroleum As sociation of America predicted today that domestic demand for petroleum products will grow 5.1 per cent next year, up from an estimated growth rate of 3.8 per cent this year. The 5.1 per cent projected increase for 1972 would be near the average for the past five years.

title: SURTAX EXEMPTION FOR CANADA URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (UPI) A group of Congressmen plans to introduce a bipartisan resolution tomorrow urging the Government to exempt all Ca nadian exports to the United States from the 10 per cent sur charge imposed by President Nixon's new economic policy.

title: Queen Speaks on Ulster
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP)The crisis in Northern Ireland was referred to in the Queen's speech in the House of Lords and in the Commons debate that followed.

title: White House Concedes Nixon Spoke to Powell
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. (AP)The White House acknowledged today that President Nixon had talked with Lewis F. Powell Jr. sev eral days before announcing his nomination to the Su preme Court. But a spokes man said that Mr. Powell was not asked, specifically to ac cept the nomination until the day Mr. Nixon announced it.

title: Charles Davis, Circus Buff, Spanish War Veteran, 93
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Nov. 2 (AP)Charles E. Davis, a life long circus enthusiast and veteran of the SpanishAmeri can War, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospi tal here. He was 93 year old.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS RETURN OF OKINAWA
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (Reu ters)The Senate Foreign Re lations Committee today ap proved the treaty to return Okinawa to Japan next year. The approval cleared the way for ratification by the Senate, possibly next week.

title: Silverless Dollars Due
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) The Federal Reserve System has started supplying banks with 62 million silverless dol lars commemorating President Eisenhower and man's first moon landing. The new cop perandnickel coins will reach banks by the end of this week. One side bears the image of the late President. The other bears a reproduction of the em blem worn by the astronauts ?? Apollo 11, an eagle against the moon's surface.

title: 3 BLAZES DAMAGE A JEWISH CENTER
description: Three small fires of suspi cious origin damaged curtains, books and a prayer shawl in the Congregation Chovevei Torah Synagogue, at 885 East ern Parkway, near Albany Ave nue in the Crown Heights See tion of Brooklyn.

title: 3,000 HONOR DIEM AT SAIGON RITES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 2In a vast outpouring of nostalgia, 3,000 people, in chiding some prominent politi cal leaders, gathered in the rain today around the un marked grave of Ngo Dinh Diem, and for the first time since he was overthrown as President eight years ago, pub licly sang his official song, Long Live President Diem,

title: China and Peru Set Ties; Will Exchange Envoys Soon
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 2 (Reu ters)China and Peru estab lished diplomatic relations to day, the Peking radio an nounced. It said the Peruvian Government had recognized the Government of the People's Re public of China as the sole legal Chinese Government.

title: Yugoslav Leader Arrives in Canada After Tour of U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 2 (Reuters President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived in Ottawa tonight amid intense military, and police secu rity precautions at the start of an official sixday visit to Canada.

title: FILES STOLEN, SAY JEWISH ACTIVISTS
description: A rabbi who heads the Jew ish Activist Movement, a new ly formed group said yesterday that the files and correspond ence at the group's headquar ters in Brooklyn had been stolen. He added that he be lieved the burglary might have been the work of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BELFAST BLASTS KILL 2 AND HURT 35
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 2A man and a woman were killed and 35 persons were injured today in two bomb explosions that destroyed a bar and a dress shop on either side of a suburban po lice station in south Belfast.

title: NATIONAL AIRLINES SETS UP NEW CREDIT
description: National Airlines announced yesterday that it had arranged a new $175million revolving credit agreement with a group of banks led by the Chemical Bank.

title: GRANTHAM MULLS TURF PREFERENCE
description: As a linebacker and a player representative, Larry Grantham of the Jets is caught between the devil and the deep blue grass.

title: CELLER REQUESTS BROKERAGE STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Representative Emanuel Celler asked the New York State Attorney General today to look into the possibility that brokerage firms are using their customers' money in ways that violate the laws regarding the responsibilities of fiduciaries.

title: Soledad Brothers' Trial Begins in Tight Security
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 (UPI)The trial of the two Soledad Brothers accused of killing a prison guard, opened today under tight security.

title: DOW UP BY 14.60 FOR 842.58 CLOSE
description: Stock prices rocketed higher yesterday in a sudden burst of optimism as the market posted its best recovery since the recordshattering Nixon Rally of Aug. 16. Leading glamour issues scored hefty gains.

title: 3 Rescued as Yacht Sinks
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 3 (Reuters) Three crewmen were rescued today from the Novia Del Mar, a 90foot racing yacht owned by John Paul Scripps of the La Jolla newspaper family, after she caught fire and sank off, Baja California, 300 miles south of here. The Coast Guard said that the yacht was returning from the Long Beach to Baja California race when the fire started in her engine room.

title: Israel Denies Any Request By Mrs. Meir to See Nixon
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 3Simcha Dinitz, political adviser and chief aide to Premier Golda Meir, denied today that he had requested a meeting with President Nixon for Mrs. Meir last fall when he was visiting Washington.

title: Alaska Test Set Saturday; Secret Papers Released
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Atomic Energy Commission today set Saturday as the date for the controversial Amchitka nuclear test while releasing a set of hitherto secret documents concluding that the blast poses a remote chance of harm.

title: New Indictment Charges Sweig With Accepting $5,000 Bribe
description: Martin Sweig, who was chief administrative aide to former House Speaker John W. McCormack, was indicted yesterday on charges of improperly using the Speaker's office to obtain an early discharge for a Navy lieutenant in Miami.

title: 45 New Relief Fraud Cases Here Referred to District Attorneys
description: Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman yesterday referred to district attorneys 45 new oases involving fraudulent cashing of duplicate welfare checks.

title: BRIBETRIAL STARTING FOR 3 EXTROOPERS
description: A transmitter hidden in a shoe was used to tape conversations that helped indict three former state troopers and seven members of a gambling ring, it was disclosed yesterday in Federal Court here.

title: City Hall Aide Named Deputy Transit Chief
description: Manuel Carballo, a mayoral assistant for the last two years, was appointed yesterday as the city's first Deputy Transportation Administrator.

title: De Almeida Leads Concert Marked by Novelties
description: Antonio de Almeida, the Frenchborn conductor, is a musician who admires 19thcentury romanticism. Thus his program with the American Symphony, in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, reflected his special tastes. And it also showed that Mr. de Almeida has a bit more imagination than some of his colleagues.

title: A Kentucky Colonel Advises Aging to Work at Staying Young
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The nation's older citizens got a bit of advice today from a man who parlayed his first $105 Social Security check into a $2million fortune.

title: Mrs. Gandhi in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (Reuters)Mrs. Gandhi arrived here tonight for talks with President Nixon tomorrow on the crisis between India and Pakistan.

title: Market Place: DualPurpose Fund Pattern
description: You may remember the dualpurpose funds that the Securities and Exchange Commission permitted fund managements to offer the public in 1967. There were seven of these funds, offering both capital shares and income shares.

title: Only Ford Unit Solvent
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 3Three of Israel's four automobile assembly plants went into receivership today.

title: Quest for Competence
description: In the scattered elections around the country Tuesday, voters tended to turn away from oneissue candidates and opt for experience or personal strength, regardless of party label or ideological commitment.

title: Vote Leaves Ohio Democrats Tattered
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 3The surprise victory of the Republican nominee, Ralph J. Perk, in the mayoral election here yesterday was symptomatic of a general collapse of Democratic organizations in Ohio's major cities.

title: But Climb in Consumer Installment Credit Set g Record in Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 The manufacturing sector of the economy continued sluggish in September, new Commerce Department figures disclosed today.

title: Memorex Officers Propose A Breakup Study of I.B.M.
description: The creation of a highlevel public commission to study the breakup of the International Business Machines Corporation was urged yesterday by two top officers of the Memorex Corporation, a manufacturer of peripheral equipment for computers.

title: F.T.C. Terms False the Claim That Listerine Can Cure Colds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 The Federal Trade Commission today accused the maker of Listerine mouthwash of falsely claiming that the product cured, prevented or lessened colds and sore throats.

title: City Investing's Earnings Rise; Other Concerns Report Profits
description: Led by the financial services group plus the housing and land development group, the City Investing Company achieved record operating earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: WALL ST. BACKING DIVIDEND GUIDE
description: The Administration's request that dividend increases next year be held to no more than 4 per cent met yesterday with general, if unenthusiastic, approval from a number of bankers, brokers and economists.

title: Screen:
description: Director Clint Eastwood's first movie is the story of a California disk jockey (Eastwood( who one night meets Evelyn (Jessica Walter), a goodlooking devoted listener who has always called to ask that he play Erroll Garner's Misty for her, and begins what is to be a shortterm casual affair without complications.

title: MARTHA VICKERS, 46, EXFILM ACTRESS
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 4, Thursday (UPI)  Martha Vickers, star of a score of films during the nineteenforties, who began her career as a dead woman in the 1942 thriller Wolf Man, is dead at the sage of 46.

title: Tornado Strikes Virginia
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 3 (UP) A tornado struck the busy Tidewater area today, scooping up housetops, trees and mobile homes. The police estimated that half a dozen persons were injured when trailers were overturned, but there were no known fatalities. The twister did most of its damage in Portsmouth.

title: Mixed Metropolitan Bag
description: From the mixed bag of local election results in the metropolitan area, Democratic sympathizers can extract pleasure over partisan gains in New Jersey and Connecticut, Republicans over their party's all but unbroken grip on Long Island's Nassau and Suffolk Counties and reformers over the end of more than a halfcentury of corrupt boss rule in Jersey City.

title: MICHIGAN PLANS A BUSING APPEAL
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3Gov. William G. Milliken announced tonight that Michigan would appeal a Federal court ruling that could lead to crossbusing among white suburban and black city school children.

title: Mighty Clever, These Chinese Exercises That Don't Make You Sweat
description: Long before the current upsurge of interest in things Chinese, a few people here were deep into an exercise called Tai Chi Chuan (pronounced Tie Jee Chwan). It's usually called simply Tai Chi.

title: 3 Plead Guilty in Death Of Policeman Hit by Car
description: Three men pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to charges arising from the death last February of an offduty patrolman who was dragged to his death by an automobile after he was struck by a gypsy cab.

title: Chess: Soviet Women Triumph In World Title Trials
description: The first round of the women's candidates' matches to determine the next challenger for the world chess title held by Nona Gaprindashvili of the Soviet Union made it plain that the woman's championship would remain in Soviet hands. In a match at Minsk, Alla Kushnir, whom Miss Gaprindashvili defeated in her most recent title match, continued on the road to a second chance at the championship when she downed Maria Satulovska, 54. Both players are from the Soviet Union.

title: Personal Finance
description: Millions of people today are building estates by buying either mutual funds or life insurance. Millions more would love to be able to buy both but find the cost too much of a financial strain.

title: Reelection of Yonkers Mayor Boosts His Stature as Democrat
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 3 Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello's 8,200vote reelection victory in Yonkers yesterday gives him clear title, for the first time, as one of the most important, Democratic figures in West chester County.

title: Screen:
description: Maid in Sweden, which opened at local houses yesterday, has such endearing charms as a small Englishspeaking Swedish cast headed by a noblyendowed, young newcomer, Kristina Lindberg, and gorgeous color photography of Stockholm and its envirous. Unfortunately, its demerits include a story as obvious and bare as Miss Lindberg who spends most most of her time portraying an esctatic introduction to sex.

title: Fiddler' on a Grand Scale:Life-Style of the Aleichem Characters Is Missing Amid Production's Grandeur
description: Somewhere along toward the third hour of "Fiddler on the Roof," the action cuts away from the tiny Russian village of Anatevka  the home of Tevye, the poor dairyman; Golde, his shrewish wife, and their five doweryless daughtersto show us the Czar's cavalry attacking a group of young street revolutionaries in Moscow.In the stage production, this information is relayed to us through a letter, and through a short, funny, very theatrical montage that shows how the contents of the letter get successively more mixed up each time the word is passed from one citizen to another.The movie scene is also short but it's staged with such elaborate realism you could almost call it gilt-ridden. It's also typical of what's wrong not only with this film, but with almost every other movie adaptation of a Broadway show that has been so successful that it's become an industry-within-an-industry.Norman Jewison, the film's director, and Joseph Stein, who adapted for the screen his own stage adaptation of the Sholem Aleichem stories, have not tampered with the text in any obviously reckless way. They have sought only to enlarge the physical frame of the show by setting it in its time (1905) and physical place, in a real village (actually in Yugoslavia) with real houses, in real barns with real animals, in real fields and real landscapes. They want to show us everything, to give us our money's worth. In so doing, they've not just opened up the play, they've let most of the life out of it.Not quite all of the life is gone. The Sheldon Harnick-Jerry Bock score is practically all there, and it's one mixed marriagebetween Tin Pan Alley and Jewish folk music  that really works. There are reminders of the exuberant Jerome Robbins choreography, although, on the screen, it seems to lack the particular focal point that the audience provides the choreographer in the theater.There also are hints of the original wit and wisdom of Aleichem when old Tevye, his optimism almost exhausted, is told that money is the world's curse. "May the Lord smite me with it," says Tevye with a special Yiddish rue, "and may I never recover."However, the gap between the reverential intention of the filmmakers and the film itself is constantly being emphasized by a kind of visual and aural grandeur that is at odds with the poverty and simplicity and faith of the Aleichem characters. Life for the Jews in this shtetl, we are told, is precarious at best, yet it looks and sounds incomparably rich.When the fiddler plays, it's none other than Isaac Stern. When Tevye moves about his barn singing "If I Were a Rich Man," he is accompaniedvery loudlyby what sounds like the entire London Symphony. Close-ups of Tevye, played by the Israeli star Topol, reveal a vigorous young actor who, with no great effort, could probably flatten half of the Czar's troops.Also revealed is a British accent that one might accept in a highly stylized stage production but that doesn't jibe with the realistic circumstances of the film. Nor does it jibe with the various other accents in the movie, some of which, like those of Molly Picon, who is generously and outrageously authentic as the matchmaker, and Leonard Frey, who is the best thing in the film as the timid tailor, do succeed in capturing the sensibility of Yiddish expression.Mr. Jewison is a good director ("The Russians Are Coming, The Russians Are Coming", "The Thomas Crown Affair") not given to arbitrary directional flourishes, and throughout "Fiddler on the Roof" he remains faithful to the literal point of view originally chosen for the film. There is a certain virtue in this, even when the result is much less stylish a film than his "Gaily, Gaily," the Ben Hecht memoire, which, of course, wasn't so intimidating a project.Aside from Miss Picon and Mr. Frey, who are most entertaining, and aside from Topol who, though I feel he's miscast, displays such willingness to please it's almost rude not to respond to him, the performances are surprisingly mechanical and bland, like those of the cast of a stage show that's been playing too long."Fiddler on the Roof," which opened last night at the Rivoli, has traveled a long way from its source, from pre-revolutionary Russia, from the pages of Sholem Aleichem, even from the Broadway stage, and it has become so rich and affluent it seems to have forgotten its humble beginnings in recognizable human experience.I wouldn't go so far as to advise anyone not to see it. After all, it's probably the only "Fiddler on the Roof" that will ever be filmed. Yet it requires its audience to display less in the way of imagination and identification than sheer physical endurance.

title: Synod of Bishops Affirms Celibacy Rule for Priests
description: ROME, Nov. 3The world Synod of Bishops has reaffirmed the principle of celibacy for Roman Catholic priests but has rejected a conservative draft resolution that strongly discourages the ordination of married men in some situations.

title: Million Autos, a Record, Sold in Nation in October
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3Americans bought more than one million new automobiles in October, a onemonth record for the industry, figures made public today disclosed.

title: Amex and Counter Make Best Gains Since Aug. 16
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market came alive yesterday and turned in their best performances since Aug. 16 in steppedup trading.

title: Executive Changes
description: The New England Telephone Company announced yesterday that Allen G. Barry has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company unit. Mr. Barry has served as president since 1963. The utility also announced that William C. Mercer, vice presidentpersonnel of A. T. & T., was elected president, chief operations officer and director of the company. Mr. Barry has served in various assignments with New York Telephone, Wisconsin Telephone, and Michigan Bell Telephone.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in holdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. No report was issued by the New York Stock Exchange this week.

title: Shop Talk
description: Jaeger seems to have chosen the right time to open a shop In New York. The current craze in fashion is for such classics as sweaters, tweeds and blazers  and that's exactly what Jaeger specializes in. Women who have already discovered the monthold shop at 818 Madison Avenue (between 68th and 69th Streets) have been grabbing up the merchandise in such quantities that the stock has to be replenished almost daily. Jaeger is of course, the very same chain of shops that's spread across the British Isles and into Paris. While some of the clothes have been available in department stores here, there has never been the depth or range of offerings one could find in the Jaeger shops abroad.

title: April 1 Time Limit Is Set For a Penn Central Plan
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia extended yesterday until April 1 the time limit for the filing of a reorganization plan for the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company. At the same time he asked the road's trustees to submit recommendations for alternatives if a financial reorganization appears unlikely to succeed.

title: New Miami Beach Mayor Is Elected by a Landslide
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Former Dade County. Mayor Chuck Hall won a landslide victory yesterday for the post of Mayor of Miami Beach, sueceding Jay Dermer, who did not seek reelection.

title: F.D.A. Recalls Crab Meat; Blames Faulty Can Coating
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of 20,000 tins of crab meat that the agency contended were adulterated by faulty interior coating of cans.

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC RAISES SOME PRICES
description: The Western Electric Company announced yesterday that it has raised prices on some of its manufactured products. The action restores the prices to levels that existed before a series of reductions in December, 1970, and February and May, 1971.

title: Eastern College Football
description: Joe Paterno, believing togetherness is strength, has devised the, most powerful front unit in his six years as head coach at Penn State. He converted a substitute quarterback, Bob Parsons, and a good offensive tackle, Bob Rickenbach, to tight, ends, placed them at opposite ends of the line and compressed the unit to eliminate the wide split end. The result is that the unde feated Nittany Lions are blasting their way through tightly packed defenses.

title: Adm. Morison to Sail in the Wake of Magellan
description: NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me.You have the course from Guam to Manila. Now let's plot the route along the Chilean coast, bearing in mind that Magellan did much of the trip at night.

title: U.S. Study of Chinese Medicine Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Dr. John R. Hogness, president of the Institute of Medicine, is working to develop a program for American doctors to go to China to study not only traditional Chinese medical techniques like acupuncture and herb therapy but also developments in modern Chinese public health programs.

title: Schools Face Penalty for Unauthorized Closings
description: The Board of Education is looking into the possibility of charging local school districts for state aid lost by the city because of their unauthorized school closings.

title: U.S. Will Deny Passports To People Balking at Oath
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Secretary of, State William P. Rogers has ruled that United States passports will be denied, those Americans who refuse to take an oath of allegianceto the Constitution: A department spokesman said today that Mr. Rogers had made the decision in a memorandum to the Passport Office after he had been compelled by a Federal judge to decide whether to retain the oath or waive it.

title: AID. LISTS WORK PERILED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Agency for International bevelopment sent to Congress today a long list of the programs it said would come to an end if last Friday's Senate action killing the foreign aid authorization bill is allowed to stand.

title: CANADIENS WIN FROM BLUES, 51
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 3 (UPI)Jacques Lemaire scored once and set up two other goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens spoiled the coaching debut of Bill McCreary by defeating his St. Louis Blues, 51.

title: Erving Leads Squires
description: DALLAS, Nov. 3 (AP)The Virginia Squires, with Julius Erving scoring 29 points, beat the Dallas Chaps, 127117, tonight.

title: News of Dogs
description: Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Powers, for the last halfdozen years, have been prominent figures around the dog show circuit. Before that, we spent a good deal of our leisure time on the golf course, said Mrs. Powers. One day our son asked us to get him a dog. We saw an ad and bought a pup. It happened to be an Irish wolfhound. Little did we realize we were buying the largest and tallest of the coursing hounds [the minimum height for a dog is 32 inches and he should weigh at least 120 pounds]. That was the beginning of the end for golf. We started to spend our weekends at dog shows.

title: Coal Negotiators Meet
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) Negotiators in the monthold coal strike met together today at the request of a Federal mediator, Robert W. Donnahoo. Mr. Donnahoo had met separately yesterday with bargainers for the United Mine Workers of America and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association.

title: Thant, in Hospital, Is Suffering From an Ulcer, U. N. Aide Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3Secretary General Thant is suffering from a bleeding peptic ulcer, a spokesman said today.

title: 2 Correction Guards Indicted and 2 Absolved in Death of a Prisoner
description: Two guards were indicted by a Kings County grand jury yesterday on charges of beating to death a 37yearold inmate of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men. The jury absolved two other guards who had been suspended.

title: Stage: Canadian Export
description: The Canadian musical Love Me, Love My Children, which opened at the MercerO'Casey Theater last night, is one of those creaking youth shows that appear to be geriatric before their time. Robert Swerdlowa Canadian, who produced the book, lyrics and music for the showseems to have found the Generation Gap and stumbled right into it as if it were the Grand Canyon.

title: Earl Lloyd Given TwoYear Contract To Coach Pistons
description: DETROIT, Nov. 3 (AP)Earl Lloyd, who played in the National Basketball Association for 10 seasons, was given a twoyear contract today to coach the Detroit Pistons.

title: Holding Down the Fare
description: The overwhelming defeat of the proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue leaves the State of New York confronting a budgetary crisis of major proportions. Existing taxes have failed to produce as much revenue as expected. Some $300 million in anticipated revenues from the bond issue were unwisely included in Governor Rockefeller's budget in the expectation that the proposition would be approved by the voters. It is probable that state expenditures will now be sharply curtailed. As some 75 per cent of the state budget is allocated to local aid in one form or another, New York City's projected expenditures may have to be reduced as well. Defeat of the Community Development and Sewage Facilities amendments only makes matters worse.

title: 36 Indicted on Gambling by a U.S. fury
description: NEWARK, Nov. 3.A Federal grand jury today indicted eight present or former New York City policemen and 28 alleged gamblingring operators on interstate gambling, conspiracy and bribery charges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GERMANY REPORTS PAYMENTS SURPLUS
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Nov. 3 (Reuters)West Germany's basic balance of payments showed a provisional surplus of 809million marks in September compared with an August surplus of 367million marks and a September, 1970, surplus of 345million marks, the nation's central bank said today.

title: U.N. Assembly Puts Off Arms Debate to Await Arrival of China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3The General Assembly unanimously decided today to postpone its debate on disarmament, one of the most important subjects on its agenda, until after the arrival of the Peking delegation.

title: HEARINGS RESUME ON PLAN BY LILCO
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I.; Nov. 3The Atomic Energy Commission began its second series of hearings today into the Long Island Lighting Company's controversial proposal to build a nuclearpower plant on Long Island Sound at Shoreham.

title: Alioto, Himself the Issue, Gets Vote of Confidence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3With his impressive reelection victory yesterday, Mayor Joseph L. Alioto achieved what he wanted mosta vote of confidence.

title: Canadians Protest
description: TORONTO, Nov. 3From Halifax to Vancouver, tens of thousands of Canadians expressed their opposition today to the Amchitka test.

title: District 2 Drops 14 Truant Officers Despite a Warning
description: The entire staff of 14 attendance teachers who check on truancy is being laid off by the Community School District 2 in Manhattan despite a warning from the central Bureau of. Attendance that such action is illegal.

title: Rickles Discovers Winning Side In Politics Can Be Lonely, Too
description: Robert N. Rickles, the only Lindsay administrative official on the winning side of the transportation bond issue vote, sat, alone and unusually quiet in his office yesterday morning.

title: Advertising:
description: A big, big advertiser increased sales for one of its products in two test markets using outdoor advertising instead of spot TV to support its network television advertising, according to a study released yesterday by the Institute of Outdoor Advertising.

title: N.F.L. CLUB OWNERS APPOINT THOMPSON
description: John Thompson was named yesterday to the newly created post of executive director of the National Football League Player Relations Association by the club owners.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Austin Policemen Gassed
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 3 (Reuters)The Austin police got a whiff of their own tear gas today when two nightduty officers accidentally dropped a gas grenade that they were examining in the police station. The gas was sucked into the airconditioning system, and 12 hours later both the station staff and prisoners were still walking around tearfully sniffling into handkerchiefs.

title: Pentagon Denies U.S. Raid In North Vietnam Near China
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Pentagon categorically denied today a charge by the North Vietnamese Government that the United States Air Force had extended its bombings to include the northern province of Laichau, 160 miles northwest of Hanoi.

title: JORDAN WILL SEEK COUNTYWIDE ROLE
description: JERSEY CITY, Nov. 3Dr. Paul. T. Jordan, the political neophyte Who beat the vaunted but aging Hudson County Democratic machine headed by John V. Kenny in yesterday's special mayoral election, began mapping plans today to forge a strong county political organization.

title: COL HERBERT PUT UNDER NEWS CURB
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3The United States Army instructed Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert today to refrain from speaking with members of the news media without specific permission from his commanding officers.

title: Hawks Down Flyers, 30
description: CHICAGO, Nov, 3 (UPI)Gary Smith recorded his first shutout of the season tonight as the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 30, raising their point total to 20 with 10 victories.

title: 8 Champion Tennis Tourneys To Be Shown on N. B. C. in '72
description: The National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that it will televise live, start ing in February, eight world championship professional tennis tournaments featuring many of the outstanding men players.

title: PAY BOARD BLOCS ASK 5% GUIDELINE ON PHASE 2 RAISES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Public and business members of the Pay Board proposed today a 5 per cent guideline for wage increases during Phase Two of the Nixon Administration's economic program.

title: GEORGE MIKHALAPOV, AN ATOMIC ENGINEER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 George S. Mikhalapov, an engineer who had been active in atomic energy research, was killed today in an automobiletruck collision in Willistown Township, Chester County. He was 65 years old.

title: ExRep. Winfield Denton Dies; Went to NATO Parleys in Paris
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 3 (AP)  Former Representative Winfield K. Denton, who served in the House from 1948 to 1952 and from 1954 to 1966, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: LAIRD, IN VIETNAM, CONFIDENT ON AID
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird arrived here tonight and voiced confidence that Congress would restore the foreign aid program because this is a time to show strength, not weakness.

title: Two U.S. Women Advance
description: ABERAVON, Wales, Nov. 3 (AP)Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., and Julie Heldman of Houston scored secondround victories today in the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament.Miss Hogan eliminated Susan Minford of Northern Ireland, 64, 36, 61, and Miss Heldman beat Glynis Coles of England, 63, 61.

title: Impact of Youth Vote in 1972 Is Unclear
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Newly enfranchised young voters upset the political establishment in a number of scattered communities in yesterday's offyear elections, but party leaders remained unsure about what their collective impact might be next year.

title: State Will Cancel Some Road Projects
description: State officials began yesterday an urgent survey of highway construction to see what projects should be halted because the voters rejected the $2.5billion bond issue.

title: SILVER FUTURES REGISTER RALLY
description: The silver futures market here rallied in response to the sharp rise in the stock market yesterday. Fairly good trade support and speculative short covering also helped the silver futures.

title: SYRACUSE BANK UNIT IS PLANNED BY CHASE
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, which plans to expand its banking operations in New York statewide, announced yesterday its intention to form a new banking subsidiary in Syracuse.

title: Blacks in Congress Will Study Extent Of Military Racism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Congressional Black Caucus said today that it planned to investigate the extent and causes, of racism within the military.

title: BRITISH WILL REDUCE HOME MAIL DELIVERY
description: LONDON, Nov. 3Britons living in residential rural areas will soon have their mail deliveries reduced by half to one a clay, the Post Office announced today.

title: Gravel Case Continued
description: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit granted a continuance today in the senatorial privilege case of Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, who is trying to block subpoenas issued to two associates by a Federal grand jury investigating newspaper publication of portions of the Pentagon Papers. A hearing in the case was rescheduled for next Wednesday.

title: MOUNT MORRIS PARK A HISTORIC DISTRICT
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the Mount Morris Park section of Harlem as a historic district yesterday.

title: Advertising:
description: The latest installment of management movement at J. Walter Thompson is the creation of sort of a double troika to run the New York office under the official title of Operating Committee.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Whether you are a student of botany, an accomplished woodsman or a backyard naturalist, the threevolume paperback edition of Britton and Brown's monumental An Illustrated Flora of the Northern United States and Canada (Dover Publications, Inc., $5 a volume) will provide a lifetime of enjoyment.

title: Two Amendments to the State Constitution Go Down With Defeat of Bond Issue
description: Two proposed amendments to the State Constitution that the Legislature had twice approved went down to defeat Tuesday with the $2.5billion transportation bond issue.

title: The Sinn Fein Oath
description: DUBLINIt seems to be the Karma of Ireland and England that the two countries must always misunderstand and torture each other. In microcosm the conflict and obfuscation may be seen in the pages of a small, highly confidential army manual now being extensively revised by the British authorities in Belfast. I caused it to be revised.

title: Computer on the Blink, Candidates in the Dark
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 (UPI)  Candidates in Hamilton County must wait until Friday to learn how they fared in yesterday's election.

title: Water Commissioner Wins As Salt Lake City Mayor
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 3 (UPI)E. J. Garn, 39yearold Water Commissioner, piled up a 3to1 margin over Parks Chief Conrad B Harrison in the race for Mayor of Salt Lake City.

title: Sacramento Mayor Wins
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 3(UPI)Mayor Richard Marriott won a second term by a landslide over Vice Mayor Milton McGhee last night in the first direct election of a Mayor in California's capital in 60 years. With nearly twothirds of the city's 186 precincts counted, Mr. Marriott had about 63 per cent of the vote in his race with Mr. McGhee, the city's first black Councilman.

title: The Wrong Man
description: Norman Brown was the wrong man. He spent nine months in a cell on Riker's Island, nine months without even being indicted by the grand jury, before the Brooklyn District Attorney's office realized they had arrested the wrong man. Lawrence Torres, arrested with Brown that night, was not as lucky. He died in his cell on Palm Sunday of complications from a gunshot wound in the head he received last August when he was apprehended by the police. He died at 19 after eight months in jail. At the time of his death, he had not been indicted for any crime.

title: Bond Issue Tied to Defeat Of Suffolk Shoreline Plan
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Nov. 3The defeat of a County Charter amendment that would have been a major step toward preserving more than 1,000 miles of Suffolk County's shoreline was attributed to the transportation bond issue.

title: DR. JULES SMOLEROFF
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 3Dr. Jules W. Smoleroff, an ophthalmologist at Manhattan Eye and Ear and Montefiore Hospitals, died at home here today after having suffered heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 446 East Prospect Avenue. He also maintained an office at 565 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: News Analysis
description: With their usual adaptability, the politicians who unanimously supported the transportation bond issue in Tuesday's election were just as united yesterday in deciding why the voters did not agree with them.

title: APPEALS COURT ENDS CURB ON ATTORNEYS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (UPI The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit has ruled that a 1965 United States District Court rule barring attorneys from discussing pending court cases with newsmen violates the First Amendment.

title: Ski Show to Aid U.S. Team
description: The second annual Pedigree ski show to raise funds to support the United States ski team, will be held at the White Plains Hotel tomorrow evening at 7:30.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OTB Lines Up WOR As Its Outlet for TV
description: Televised races from Monticello Raceway in the Catskills will be carried here six nights a week by WOR, Channel 9, the Offtrack Betting Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Screen:
description: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 3 (UPI)John Gavin and the entire slate of 20 guildnominated candidates swept into office by a 2to1 margin yesterday in the first contested election in the 38year history of the Screen Actors Guild.

title: MRS. THOMAS MALLEE
description: Mrs. Ida Rich Mallce, widow of Thomas Malice, former Commissioner of the Board of Elections, and an early suffragette leader, died yesterday after a long illness. She was 82 years old and lived at 262 East 62d Street.

title: Cubs' Jenkins Voted Cy Young Award
description: Ferguson Jenking of the Chicago Cubs, a 20game winner this year for the fifth season in a row, was named the outstanding pitcher in the National League yesterday by a wide margin over Tom Seaver of the New York Mets.

title: Referendums Fail to Reveal a Pattern
description: There was no discernible national pattern Tuesday in referendums on money and other matters.

title: New Jersey Candidate Wins Election by 2 Votes
description: LITTLE FALLS, N. J., Nov, 3 Edward J. Shaara Jr.s election to the Township Committee yesterday was the sort of thing that breathes new life into cliches like the one about the slender margin of victory: Shaara defeated his Republican rival 1,785 to 1,783a twovote margin.

title: Mississippi Election Results Challenged by Scores of Defeated Black Candidates
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3Charles Evers, the black candidate defeated yesterday for Governor of Mississippi, led scores of other black candidates here today in announcing they would challenge the statewide elections in the Federal courts. Mr. Evers called for Federal troops to supervise new elections.

title: Colonels Win, 118111
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 3 (AP) Dan Issel poured in 33 points tonight and the Kentucky Colonels reeled off seven straight points in the final two minutes for a 118111 American Basketball Association victory over the Floridians.

title: INDIA SAYS TROOPS MAY NOT CROSS LINE
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 3A Government spokesman said today that Indian troops had strict orders not to cross the border in their confrontation with Pakistani troops.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
ROGERS ADAMANT AGAINST AID CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers suggested to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the Nixon Administration might accept a ceiling on aid to Cambodia but otherwise refused any compromise with the Senate on a new foreign aid bill.

title: Stars Edge Leafs, 21
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 3 (AP)Lou Nanne converted a powerplay goal early in the third period and the Minnesota North Stars, behind Gump Worsley, defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 21, tonight.

title: City Housing Loan Delays Are Scored
description: A churchsponsored group that applied in 1968 for a municipal loan to rehabilitate two tenements on the Lower East Side has spent $110,000 of church money on the buildings while awaiting the loan, the group's head said yesterday.

title: Seals Win First at Home
description: OAKLAND, Nov. 3 (UPI)Three consecutive goals in the final period by Torn Webster, Joey Johnston and Paul Shmyr lifted California to a 53 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonightthe Seals' first victory at home this season.

title: BIG BOARD MEMBERS APPROVE NEW RATES
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its proposed new commission schedule had been approved by its membership. The vote on amendments to the exchange constitution was 773 to 98.

title: Angela Davis Plans Appeal On Change in Site of Trial
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP)Angela Davis's chief defense attorney says he will appeal an order moving her murderkidnapping trial to nearby San Jose.

title: The Talk of New York
description: More than two million voters said no to Governor Rockefeller's $2.5billion bond issue, but only one went to the bother and expense of sending a financial contribution to the Ad Hoc Committee to Beat the Bond.

title: '71 Conclusion: '72 Still Up for Grabs
description: News Analysis

title: City Hospitals Unit Scored at Hearings
description: A parade of witnesses told a special State Assembly committee yesterday that there has been no improvement in patient care since the municipal hospital system was taken over by the Health and Hospitals Corporation 16 months ago.

title: BULLS BEAT HAWKS FROM FOUL LINE
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls, taking advantage of 18 fouls in the third quarter, broke open a close game tonight and beat Atlanta, 113100, in the National Basketball Association.

title: 5 Days Without Food
description: JAMBU, India, Nov. 3It has been five days since we have had anything to eat, an old man, Bhaga Bathbarman, said to a Government visitor here today.

title: Mrs. Semples 80 for 151 Leads Seniors Golf by Shot
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Nov. 3 (AP)Mrs. Horton S. Semple of Sewickley, Pa., held a onestroke lead after a secondround 80 today in the North and South women's seniors golf tournament at the Pinehurst Country Club.

title: INSURERS CAUTIONED ON PROFIT REPORTS
description: Insurers were warned here yesterday that unless they developed a uniform method of reporting their profits, the state would do it for them.

title: SchoolAid Cuts Forecast; State Limits Its Spending
description: City and state budget experts agreed yesterday that the voters' disapproval of the $2.5billion transportation bond issue would mean retrenchments in state spending on aid to local governments and schools, political donnybrooks in the 1972 Legislature and a state program next year devoid of innovation.

title: 4,200 DEBTORS WIN A SECOND CHANCE
description: More than 4,200 Civil Court default judgments obtained against consumers by an allegedly shady burglaralarm company will be thrown out of court as part of a landmark agreement announced yesterday by Administrative Judge Edward Thompson.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: What's a new word for New York? The Milan Cowboy, Arriving Soon,Advt.

title: Independent Chosen In 3Way Contest For Virginia Post
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 3 (AP) Henry E. Howell Jr., an independent, was a decisive winner in the threeway race for Virginia's lieutenant governorship, defeating George J. Kostel, Democrat, by about 32,000 votes and completely running away, from George R. Shafran, a Republican.

title: Gary McFarland Dead at 38; Jazz Composer, Vibraharpist
description: Gary McFarland, a composer of modern jazz, an arranger, conductor and vibraharpist, died on Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital. The cause of death was not disclosed. He was 38 years old and lived on Ashyre Place, East Hampton, L. I.

title: Ford and Bankers Trust Executives Cast Doubt About Phase 2
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 3 Lee A. Iacocca, president of the Ford Motor Company, and Roy L. Reierson, senior vice president and economist for the Bankers Trust Company, New York, cast serious doubts today on the possibilities of success for Phase Two of the Administration's economic program.

title: U.S. Shying Off From Incentive Welfare
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3New York State's experimental plan for requiring welafre mothers to work for their benefits at public service jobs Iooks like it can be put together, a high Administration official said tonight.

title: TaftHartley Stay Rejected By a U.S. Judge in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (UPI)A Federal judge refused today to grant an 80day TaftHartley, injunction against an affiliate of the International Longshoremen's Association and ruled that the union may resume its strike against six grain elevator companies.

title: TV: Aiming to Put Topical Stories in Perspective
description: N.E.T.'s This Week now has several editions to its credit as one of the more ambitious additions to this season's Public Broadcasting Service schedule. As a laudable attempt to put topical news stories in broader perspective, it misses. But it comes close and seems to be coining closer, enough at least to merit attention.

title: ROCKEFELLER AND LINDSAY DIFFER ON WAYS OF SAVING TRANSIT FARE; BOND LOSS DEEPENS CRISIS
description: Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller prescribed different approaches yesterday to hold down the city's beleaguered transit fare.

title: Leonard J. Savage, Professor Of Statistics at Yale, Is Dead
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3 Leonard J. Savage, a wellknown mathematician who held the Eugene Higgins Professorship of Statistics at Yale University, died today. He was 53 years old and lived at 305 Lawrence Street.

title: Dr. Lucie Adelsberger Is Dead; Linked Virus to Some Cancers
description: Dr. Lucie Adelsberger, one of the first scientists to demonstrate a possible link between virus and certain human cancers, died Tuesday evening at the Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center after a long illness. She was 75 years old and lived at 3530 Rochambeau Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Fresh Alibhai Scores by a Nose and Pays $47 at Aqueduct
description: Fresh Alibhai spurted in the final few strides to take the $34,950 Knickbocker Handicap over a soupy course at Aqueduct yesterday. Johnny Ruane, keeping his mount just off the pace through the running of the 1mile turf event, guided Joseph Nash's representative to success by a nose over Specious of the Elmendorf Farms.

title: JERSEY G.O.P. BARS AID OF IMPERIALE
description: TRENTON, Nov. 3Gov. Wil liam T. Cahill said today that the Republican party would rather yield, control of the State Assembly to the bemocrats than negotiate for he support of Anthony Imperiale, the white militant leader who was elected to the Assembly as, an indePendent yesterday and whose vote apparently could give the Democrats control.

title: INDIAN STORM TM NOW PUT AT 6,000
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 3With some of the stricken areas still cut off, the official death toll rose today to 6,000 in the cyclone and tidal wave that struck the eastern coast of India last weekend.

title: MGM, Branching Out, Tells of Hotel and Ships
description: Two years after taking over the chief executive's slot at Metro  Goldwyn  Mayer, Inc., James T. Aubrey Jr., president of the giant film corporation, came to New York to talk about the next few years.

title: VALENTINE MAKES ITS JOFFREY DEBUT
description: Valentine is a little curio in the City Center Joffrey Ballet's repertory that made its first appearance of the season Tuesday evening. It lists only two dancers but in effect has four performers and is more modern dance than ballet in style.

title: Bridge: Visitors From Rome Lend Cosmopolitan Air to Play
description: The most cosmopolitan bridge game in town this week was played at the Hotel Edison Monday night. The occasion was a visit to New York by a group of players from Rome, the Club Amici Dei Bridge, and they played in a duplicate game with New York enthusiasts.

title: High School Students Hold Rally For War Protest on Saturday
description: Several hundred high school students held a rally on the Central Park Mall in the rain yesterday in preparation for Saturday's March Against the War.

title: HOUSE SUPPORTS GENERAL U.S AID FOR ALL COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 The House of Representatives agreed today to give generalpurpose Federal grants for the first time to every college and university in the country.

title: Villagers Deal Blow For Safety
description: In the battle against street crime, the people who live on Bethune and Bank Streets in the West Village are arming themselves with whistles.

title: Gambino Termed Too Ill to Quit U. S.
description: Carlo Gambino, who was formally told on Monday that he would be deported from the United States tomorrow, was reported to have suffered a heart attack yesterday morning and was taken to Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Synod Draws Priestly and Lay Lobbyists
description: ROME, Nov. 3Shortly after 9 o'clock every weekday morning a dozen people from almost as many countries gathered around a square red table in a fourthfloor room near the Piazza Navona here for an hour of intrigue.

title: Wildenstein Pays $850,000 For a Painting by Seurat
description: A rare canvas by the neoimpressionist painter Georges Seurat, owned by the estate of a California woman, has been sold to Wildenstein & Co., the New York and Paris art dealers, for $850,000. The painting, done in 1888, is titled Gray Weather, Grande Jatte, and depicts an island in the Seine. It was one of a handful of oiloncanvas paintings by Seurat left in private hands.

title: Gisela May Shows A Brecht Repertory Goes Beyond Weill
description: For most Americans, Bertolt Brecht with music means Brecht with Kurt Weill. But there is more to the Brechtian musical repertory, and Gisela May, a member of the Berliner Ensemble who is making her American debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has built a program that draws on the work of several of Brecht's collaborators  Hanns Eisler, Paul Dessau and Joachim Werzlau as well as Weill.

title: RET AILCHAIN SALES CLIMBED IN OCTOBER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co. and several other leading retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in October over the yearago month.

title: ORIOLES WIN BY 70 AS PALMER PITCHES
description: TOKYO, Nov. 3 (AP)Jim Palmer hurled a threehitter and Brooks Robinson and Elrod Hendricks hit home runs as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Japan AllStars, 70, today before 45,000 fans.

title: Phelps Dodge Unit Layoff
description: The Phelps Dodge Refining Corporation, a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, said yesterday that it had permanently closed part of its electrolytic refinery in Maspeth, Queens, and would lay off 300 employes. The company said that the action would reduce refining capacity at the plant by 36,000 tons of copper annually.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: We announce with deep sorrow the death of our beloved friend and founder

title: Mrs. Jessie Donahue Dies; Woolworth's Daughter, 82
description: Mrs. Jessie Woolworth Donahue, widow of James P. Donahue and the last surviving daughter of Frank W. Woolworth, founder of the varietystore chain, died at her home on Monday. She was 82 years old and lived at 834 Fifth Avenue. Her husband died in 1931.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Interest rates again took goodsized stride downhill yesterday, and the yield on highestgrade electric utility bonds reached its lowest level in almost six months.

title: 2 Coin Dealers Arrested; Gold Counterfeits Seized
description: Two coin dealers were arrested here yesterday on charges of possessing 100 counterfeit $1 gold coins seized by Secret Service agents at the Jeweler's Exchange, 21 West 47th Street.

title: Geraldine Page to CoStar
description: Geraldine Page had been signed to costar with Telly Savalas in Sidney and the Werewolf's Widow, the Bill Manhoff comedy opening on Broadway in March. Stanley Prager will direct. Lee Guher and Madeline Lee Gilford are the producers.

title: A Consoling Thought From Little Nelson, 7
description: Governor Rockefeller may have been a little less dejected than might have been expected yesterday over the loss of his transportation bond issue, thanks to some good advice he received early in the day from his 7yearold son.

title: SEXG.I. ADDICTS GET AID IN BRONX DMZ
description: The potholed street near Hunts Point in the Bronx was lined with battered cars, some stripped to their axles.

title: News Analysis
description: LONDON, Nov. 3Political squabbling over the Common Market issue continues at a shrill level in Britain. But if the top people in government or in the Labor party Opposition are asked privately what they consider the most serious problem facing this country, the one most likely to cause political and social disorder, they will all give the same answer: Ireland.

title: San Diego Republican Wins
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP)State Assemblyman Pete Wilson, a Republican who campaigned on the theory that his newness to city government would be an asset rather than a liability, has been elected Mayor of California's second most populous city. Mr. Wilson, 38 years old, won more than 60 per cent of the vote yesterday to defeat former City Attorney Ed Butler.

title: G.M. TO ROOT OUT STAFF ALCOHOLICS.
description: James M. Roche, board chairman of the Geheral Motor Corporation, announced a new company policy yesterday under which employes who are alcoholics could be required to seek treatment or lose their jobs.

title: Ulster to Arm Reserve Police; Strike Threatened by Regulars
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 3In an attempt to head off a threatened strike by policemen, Prime Minister Brian Faulkner today ordered that members of the 1,000  strong Royal Ulster. Constabulary Reserve be armed and that army guards be posted at police stations.

title: UKRAINIAN CHURCH FORMS OWN SYNOD
description: ROME, Nov. 3Josyf Cardinal Slipyj and 15 bishops of the Ukrainian Catholic Church were reported today to have voted to form a permanent synod of five prelates to govern their church.

title: City Accused of Failing to Disperse Housing for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3A civil rights organization charged in Congressional testimony today that the Lindsay administration had flagrantly violated its own commitment to disperse lowincome housing throughout New York City.

title: Citywide Council to Help Indigent Jews Organize to Get Aid Now Denied to Them
description: A citywide coordination council representing major Jewish agencies is being set up to help indigent Jews form neighborhood groups and obtain antipoverty money.

title: Tighter Accounting Urged on Tax Credit
