description: The senior rulemaking body of the accounting profession has proposed a significant tightening of its rules governing the accounting for the proposed 7 per cent investment tax credit, which is now pending before Congress.

title: DETAILS HOLD UP SALE OF YONKERS
description: YONKERS, Nov. 3The sale of Yonkers Raceway to a Pennsylvania family was delayed today. It was said that details remained to be ironed out.

title: Jewish Philanthropies Group Aiming for Goal of $30Million
description: An incapacitated 74yearold widow living in a hovellike basement apartment in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx recently was given a bath for the first time in months and had the knots cut and combed out of her silky gray hair.

title: Criminal Court Judge Scores Laws on Gambling as Archaic
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge criticized the state's gambling laws yesterday and urged, in effect, that such activities as gambling and bookmaking be legalized.

title: Man In the News
description: I've always been a leadership type, Dr. Paul Jordan said yesterday as he recalled his schooldays. People would say, Who wants to do something? and I'd raise my hand.

title: More Bloodshed Predicted
description: LONDON, Nov. 3The Defense Secretary, Lord Carrington, warned today that there would be much more bloodshed in Northern Ireland before peace was restored and even an extension of It to this country.

title: Coal Strike Affects College
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 3 (AP)Indiana University announced today a stringent reduction in the use of campus utilities because of a dwindling coal supply caused by the softcoal strike. The Chancellor, Byrum Carter, said, There is no way of knowing how long the strike might last and we must institute conservation measures while we have something to conserve.

title: Notes on People
description: Somewhat in the manner of two conquering Hannibals, Pennsylvania's Senators, Hugh Scott and Richard S. Schweiker, collected on a World Series bet by riding past the Capitol on the backs of elephants.

title: Bond Backers Continue Secrecy on Ad Finances
description: Officials of Yes for Transportation in New York State, Inc.  the bond issue proponents who received a ringing no from the voters on Tuesday  denied yesterday that as much as $3million had been spent in their effort to stir popular approval.

title: IN THE NATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3An extensive courtordered busing program to desegregate this city's schools got under way this fall, and at their first opportunityyesterday's electionsSan Franciscans showed they didn't like it.

title: International Nickel Sets TopOfficer Realignment
description: Major changes in the top echelon of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., were announced last night to take effect following formal election at a board meeting after the annual shareholder session next April 19.

title: Agricultural Aide Resigns, Hints Bid for U.S. Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) One of the Nixon Administration's top farm program officials has quit his post in the Agriculture Department, reportedly to seek the Republican nomination as United States Senator from Idaho.

title: Hitler's Gift to a Free World
description: The two latest winners of the Nobel Prizes in science, Dr. Dennis Gabor in physics and Dr. Gerhard Herzberg in chemistry, earned their laurels for very different accomplishments, yet an important common factor links them and many other of the most distinguished scientists of the past several decades.

title: Egyptians Go to Polls Again
description: CAIRO, Nov. 3For the sixth time since July 1, Egyptian voters went to polling places today to complete a process of reorganization of the local and national leadership under President Anwar elSadat. Today's elections were held in 141 districts that failed a week ago to produce majority results for People's Assembly candidates.

title: Extension of NoFault Signed by Gov. Sargent
description: BOSTON, Nov. 3 (AP) Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed a bill today extending Massachusetts' nofault automobile insurance concept to include property damage.

title: U.S. and Poles in Road Research Pact
description: WARSAW, Nov. 3  The United States and Poland agreed today to a fiveyear program of research and development in the field of transportation.

title: Egypt Believed Moving Toward Decision on Conflict with Israel
description: CAIRO, Nov. 3Egypt appeared today to be moving toward the stage of decisionmaking in the conflict with Israel after many months of discussion, debate and weighing of alternative lines of policy.

title: DOCK STRIKE TALK IS HEED IN JERSEY
description: A management strategy of using the courts to reopen Atlantic and Gulf ports closed by a dockworkers' job action continued yesterday as stevedore representatives and the International Longshoremen's Association held their first formal meeting since Oct. 1, when the walkout began.

title: Soldiers Kill Man
description: BELFAST, Thursday, Nov. 4 (UPI)  British soldiers searching a house in Belfast early today shot one man to death and wounded another during an exchange of fire, the army said.

title: School Football Player, Injured in Game, Dies
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (UPI)Marco Cervantes, a 17yearold boy who moved from Mexico to live with his older brother and attend school in Chicago, died today of brain damage suffered in a high school football game.

title: 2 Policemen Indicted On Knapp Evidence
description: Two policemen were indicted by a. Federal grand jury here yesterday in the first indictments following the Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption.

title: Senate Panel Refuses to Act On Ambassador Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The nomination of Howard P. Mace, former State Department personnel chief, as Ambassador to Eierra Leone was passed over by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee at a closed session yesterday.

title: Democrats' Gains in Connecticut Exceed G.O.P.'s in Local Votes
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 3  Although Democratic gains exceeded those of Republicans in municipal elections yesterday in Connecticut, veteran politicians said they could see no clear trends in the results.

title: Moldavia Pioneering Factories on the Farm
description: KISHINEV, U.S.S.R., Oct. 28  If you could put the whole population of the world at one long table, every person would have bottle of Moldavian wine, Zhenia Ruvner, a roundfaced, redhaired Intourist guide boasted happily.

title: REV. DR. M. E. FLIPSE
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Nov. 3  The Rev. Dr. M. Eugene Flipse, pastor of the Community Church of Douglaston, Queens, from 1921 to 1966, when he retired, died today in a nursing home. He was 76 years old.

title: 60 Congressmen Demand Oil Drilling Curb in Atlantic
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) A coalition of 60 Eastern Congressmen demanded today that Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton halt Government plans to lease offshore oil drilling sites along the Atlantic Coast.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: No Yak Meat? U.N. Delegates Size Up Food Available in City
description: Sometimes the official United Nations looks in on the unofficial one: the general assembly of international restaurants in Manhattan.

title: KODES TOPS LUTZ IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 3 (AP) Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia eliminated Bob Lutz of Los Angeles, 64, 62, and reached the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Swedish open tennis tournament tonight.

title: U.N. Wrestles Its Ponderosity for 219 Pages and Reaches a Draw
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 3The United Nations has often been called wordy and inefficient, but after this week it can hardly be accused of being insensitive about the accusation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Talks on Berlin Open
description: BERLIN, Nov. 3 (Reuters)The East German Government and the West Berlin Rcity government today began anothe. round of talks on implementing the fourpower Berlin agreement signed on Sept. 3.

title: Mrs. Stravinsky's Paintings on Display
description: In the Paris of the Roaring Twenties, when Russian emigres drove taxicabs or worked as seamstresses amid a frenzied artistic and literary life, one of the celebrated romances that sprang from the emigre colony was that of Igor Stravinsky and Vera de Bosset, a costume designer for Stravinsky's friend and patron, Sergei Diaghilev.

title: Haile Selassie Presses Ethiopian Land Reform
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Nov. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)Emperor Haile Selassie announced landreform measures today to speed Ethiopia's agricultural development and turn the country into the granary for the Middle East.

title: Lebanon, WesternArms Bayer, Makes Soviet Deal
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 3The Lebanese, who have turned to the West until now for their purchases of arms, announced today the conclusion of their first arms deal with the Soviet Union.

title: Suns Top Braves, 10098
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 3 (AP)Dick Van Arsdale got credit for a tiebreaking field goal with 24 seconds remaining tonight on a goaltending violation by Buffalo's Elmore Smith, then sank two free throws with eight seconds left to give the Phoenix Suns a 10098 victory over the Buffalo Braves.

title: Potential Power Shortage Seen At Peak Demand Periods Here
description: The chairman of the State Public Service Commission warned yesterday of a potential shortage of electricity this winter in the face of expected peak demand in New York City and Westchester County.

title: Wichard Has What Pros Like
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 3There was this state fair in Greensboro, N. C., last month, and Gary Wichard wandered over to a booth with rubber tires dangling in the background.

title: Magda Olivero, Italian Soprano, in Debut Here
description: Listening to the cheers at Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night when Magda Olivero came on stage for the first time, one would have htought she was one of the bestknown singers in the world. Actually, she was being greeted, so to speak, by a noisy, but small, coterie of fans who knew and liked her few recordings.

title: ARTHUR SURKAMP OF UNIROYAL DIES
description: EAST MORICHES, L.I., Nov. 3  Arthur Surkamp, formerly vice president, director, and chairman of the finance committee of Uniroyal, Inc., died today apparently of a heart attack in the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital, Patchogue. He was 78 years old.

title: Tariff Body, by 33, Finds A Dumping of Sheet Glass
description: WASHINGTON, My. 3The Tariff Commission, with the full membership voting for the first time in an antidumping case, split 33 today on the question of whether lowprice imports of sheet glass from France, West Germany and Italy were causing injury to the domestic industry.

title: Two Bridges Blocked
description: ANN ARBOR, Nov. 3Four thousand Canadian students blocked two international bridges between southern Michigan and Ontario today in protest of the Atomic Energy Commission's planned nuclear tests on Amchitka Island.

title: OBSERVER
description: The Congressmen and generals who protect us here in the United States from our foreign enemies are having great difficulty these days because nobody can agree who our foreign enemies are.

title: Mayor Names Policeman To Succeed Gottehrer
description: A police sergeant on extended leave was appointed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay as an aide in charge of special community problems. Ile succeeds Barry Gottehrer, who has resigned from the administration effective Nov. 19.

title: Blank Ballots Bring Return of Incumbents
description: EAST JORDAN, Mich., Nov. 3Faced with blank ballots, voters in this northern Michigan hamlet wrote in the names of the incumbent Mayor and three City Councilmen yesterday and reelected them despite the fact that they had not sought to be returned to office.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE JEWISH WRITER IN AMERICA. Assimitation and the Crisis of Identity. By Allen Guttmann. 256 pages. Oxford. $7.95.

title: CHINA THANKS 60 FOR VOTES AT U.N.
description: PEKING, Nov. 3China set a theme tonight for her participation at the United Nations by affirming that she would stand together with all the countries and peoples that love peace. But she left no doubt that she remains committed to world revolution.

title: McMahon Says US. Pledges Indian Ocean Force to Counterbalance Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 Prime Minister William McMahon of Australia said today that he had been assured by President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird that the United States would provide a counterbalancing force to the growing Soviet naval power in the Indian Ocean.

title: Waller Sees Harmony in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 3William L. Waller, who overwhelmingly defeated Charles Evers, his black independent opponent, in yesterday's gubernatorial election, said today that he thought he would have the confidence of most black Mississippians in his new post.

title: Senate Supports Curbs on DamageProne Cars
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Senate passed by an 89to4 vote today legislation to require manufacturers to build automobiles that are less susceptible to costly damage in cfashes and easier to repair than current models.

title: SCHOLAR MAY GET HUMANITIES POST
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3  Dr. Ronald S. Berman, a respected but not widely known scholar whose writings range from Shakespeare to the sixties, is the frontrunner for President Nixon's nomination as chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.Dr. Berman was described in telephone interviews as resilient, both amiable and toughminded and very much his own man, although temperamentally conservatively inclined from his interpretation of literature to his political stance.

title: SHIFT IS BACKED IN ALCOHOL TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The Senate Finance Committee decided today to divert permanently to the Highway Trust Fund some of the money raised by alcohol taxes.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE ROCKETS, 11798, AS FRAZIER STARS
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 3Elvin Hayes and the New York Knickerbockers both came back tonight. Houston's allstar center apparently settled his differences with his club and maintained his perfect record of starting while the Knicks rebounded from a loss to Philadelphia, with an easy 11798 victory over the hapless Rockets.

title: Kashmir Border People Worry About Crops More Than War
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 3 Despite the continuing threat of an IndianPakistani war in Kashmir and a series of midOctober October border clashes that caused alarm and made people flee their homes, surprisingly little tension is noticeable in the villages along the Indian side of the 22yearold ceasefire line in the Kashmir valley.

title: Big Board Issues Active in Counter
description: For the first time since overthecounter volume figures became available on Monday, the stocks of two companies that are listed on the New York Stock Exchange but are also traded in the third market, were among the 10 most actively traded issues yesterday in the counter market.

title: Sayings Bonds' Sales Exceed Redemptions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UPI)  The public bought $95million more Savings Bonds in October than it cashed in, the 13th straight month that sales exceeded redemptions, the Treasury Department said today.

title: PLANNERS FAVOR CITY STADIUM PLAN
description: The city's plan to buy and renovate Yankee Stadium was advanced by the City Planning Commission yesterday in an unscheduled vote at City Hall.

title: Royals End Losing Streak
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 (UPI)Tom Van Arsdale and Johnny Green combined for 60 points tonight as the Cincinnati Royals broke a sixgame losing streak by walloping the Philadelphia 76ers, 124100.

title: BAR PANEL BACKS COURT NOMINEES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3The American Bar Association's judicial evaluation committee unanimously gave its highest rating today to Lewis F. Powell Jr. as a nominee to the Supreme Court. It divided 9 to 3 in giving the same rating to William F. Rehnquist.

title: Pennsylvania House Seat Won By Heir to Heinz Food Fortune
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 3 (AP)H. John Heinz 3d, 33yearold scion of the H.J. Heinz food family, has won Pennsylvania's 18th Congressional Dis trict seat by a landslide.

title: GLADYS V. CLARK
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y. Nov. 3Gladys Voorhees Clark, former president of the Washington Headquarters Association and of the Founders and Patriots, died Monday in New Rochelle Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 3 East Avenue.

title: Korean Talks Still Stalled
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Nov. 3 (AP)North and South Korean Red Cross officials met for two hours today and again disagreed over what should be discussed in a conference on the reunion of Koerans separated since 1945. It was the seventh session of the preliminary talks, which began Sept. 20. Both sides presented detailed views on two agenda proposals made at the meeting a week ago.

title: EMPIRE STATE STOCK SOUGHT BY PELTO OIL
description: The Pelto Oil Company announced yesterday it proposes to acquire 55 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Empire State Oil Company, which is owned or controlled by Husky Oil, Ltd. Pelto is subsidiary of Southdown, Inc.

title: BUFFALO MUSICIANS PLAY MODERN WORKS
description: Parts of Tuesday night's Carnegie Recital Hall program presented by musicians of the State University of Buffalo's Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, would have delighted any decibel collector. But there also was Andrew Stiller's Ctenophores (1967), a mysterious, wispy kind of softcore percussion music with tape and (not very helpful) illustrative slides.

title: Playboy Issue Is Offered
description: The 1,071,567 common shares, of Playboy Enterprises, Inc., offered at $23.50 a share yesterday by underwriters led by Loeb, Rhoades & Co., apparently failed to arouse investor enthusiasm. A. P. Montgomery & Co., a brokerage firm specializing in newissue stocks, quoted the issue at 22, 23.

title: Miss Mann Captures Jump
description: Carol Hofmann of Elmont, L. I., one of the leading riders in the world and a member of the United States Equestrian Team gave a sensational performance at the National Horse Show last night as she took the international class event.

title: A Grand Jury Investigation On Attica Revolt Is Ordered
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday ordered a special grand jury investigation into the rebellion at the Attica Correctional Facility, Fortythree inmates and hostages died during and after the fiveday prisoner revolt, which began last Sept. 9.

title: Foreign Relations Group Yields Ellsberg Seminar Paper to F.B.I.
description: The Council on Foreign Relations, a study group of prominent Americans who analyze international issues under strict rules of confidentiality, has responded to a subpoena by turning over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation a seminar paper delivered last year by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Audi Trading Halted
description: BONN, Nov. 3West German stock exchanges today suspended trading in shares of AudiNSU, a Volkswagen subsidiary, pending an expected VW statement defining the subsidiary's role in future company activities make a new offer thrives on the fact that the new VW president, Rudolf Leiding, directed the Volkswagen AudiNSU division before he took the wheel of the entire VW empire from Kurt Lotz, who resigned last September.

title: Morocco's Folksy Dance Troupe
description: So the Brooklyn Academy of Music's AfroAsian Festival has proved to be a sleeper! After the court refinement of Cambodia's classical dancers and the theatrical vibrancy of the Senegalese, the communal ritualism of the National Dance Company of Morocco this week proves again that this series is one of the city's most unusual current performing events. Variety was to be expected. But quality has come along in rewarding helpings, too.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The transportation bond issue failed at the polls. Representative Edward Koch says 27 major companies are planning to move their headquarters out of Manhattan. Mayor Lindsay seeks a Canadian League football franchise to help push the purchase plan of the Yankee Stadium through a reluctant City Council. The $200million sports complex for the Jersey Meadowlands faces several hurdles inside and outside the courts.

title: G.O.P. in Nassau Jubilant Over Success in Election
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 3 Nassau County Republicans were jubilant today in the wake of yesterday's elections, in Which they not only won almost all the contests but also wrested control of Long Beach from the Democrats for the first time in the history of the city.

title: Stage: German Troupe
description: Friedrich Schiller's Kabale and Liebe (Cabals and Loves), first produced in Germany in 1784, opened in New York Tuesday night in its native tongue at the Barbizon Plaza Theater.

title: Giants' Evans Gets a Break: No Fracture
description: There were a couple of surprises in the life of Charlie Evans, the New York Giants' rookie running back, this week and fortunatly for him, they were both of the pleasant kind.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Win, 71, Extend Streak
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 The New York Rangers recovered from a firstperiod attack of sunny Southern California somnolence to post a 71 victory over the, ineffectual Los Angeles Kings tonight before 7,47 jeering fans at The Forum.

title: Man Who Sheltered Diem Recounts '63 Episode
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 3When I got a call from a secretary in the palace saying that President Ngo Dinh Diem wanted to come to my house to hide, I was very surprised, said Ma Tuyen, a leatheryfaced businessman who was once head of Saigon's large and powerful Chinese community. One does not expect such visitors.

title: Aurelio Criticizes Panel Studying City Operations
description: The state commission investigating the city government was assailed yesterday by Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio for what he said was its failure to respond to city offers of consultation.

title: Columbia Warned On Hiring Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4The Department of Health, Education and Welfare informed Columbia University today that its eligibility for Federal contracts was in jeopardy because it had failed to meet the legal requirements for equal employment opportunity.

title: Big Aluminum Works Completed for Kaiser
description: RAVENSWOOD, W. Va., Nov. 4The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced here today completion of a fouryear, $65million modernization of its aluminum works here. This will give the plant the capability of producing aluminum sheet in widths up to 96 inches and plate in widths up to 150 inches and 120 feet in length.

title: U.S. FUNDS SOUGHT IN LEGAL AID PLAN
description: New York City is seeking Federal financing for a program in which students from law schools in the area would be paid to assist Legal Aid Society attorneys.

title: Executive Changes
description: American Export Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Ellis B. Gardner Jr. as president, chief executive officer and a director of the company. Mr. Gardner previously senior vice president of Litton Industries, Inc., fills the position created by the resignation of Jakob Isbrandtsen as president in June. Mr. Isbrandtsen yesterday resigned as a member of the board of directors. Mr. Gardner at Litton was in charge of the company's marine group of five separate companies, as well as president of the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation. Peter L. Keane, who had assumed the post of chief executive officer in. June, will remain as chairman.

title: Jackson and Yorty to Run In New Hampshire Contest
description: BOSTON, Nov. 4Two rightofcenter candidates are planning fullscale efforts in the New Hampshire Democratic primary the first in the nation, next March 7.

title: Freedom to Worship
description: The sponsors of the constitutional amendment to permit nondenominational prayer in the public schools, on which the House will vote Monday, are trampling on the very principle on which religious freedom is based. They plow ahead against the determined opposition of most leaders of organized religionsProtestant, Catholic and Jewishwho surely cannot be suspected of antireligious leanings.

title: SOVIET JOURNAL SAYS CHINA HAS A SCHEME
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 4 (Reuters) An important Soviet journal has charged that Peking would like to provoke a military conflict between socialism and imperialism and then become the dominant power in a world shattered by war.

title: MARKET RALLIES, THEN FALLS BACK
description: The stock market's latest rally ran out of steam yesterday after a strong and spirited performance.

title: October Wholesale Prices Off Slightly for 2d Month
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 Wholesale prices declined slightly in October, marking the second monthly drop in succession, the Labor Department announced today. The closely watched sector of the index covering industrial commodities was unchanged in October.

title: 8 Inches of Snow Upstate
description: LITTLE VALLEY, N. Y., Nov. 4 (AP)The season's first significant snowfall in the state dumped up to eight inches of wet, heavy, snow on portions of western New York's snow belt. Cattaraugus County sheriff's deputies reported that eight inches had fallen here and smaller accumulations were reported throughout the northcentral portion of the county.

title: 7% CapitalSpending Increase Forecast
description: Capital spending for plant and equipment will reach $87billion next year, an increase of 7 per cent over the estimated $81.4billion invested this year, the McGrawHill Publications Company predicted yesterday.

title: Shell 3Month Profit Off
description: Earnings of the Royal DutchShell Group of Companies fell in the third quarter but advanced in the nine months ended Sept. 30 world's largest nonAmerican business enterprise reported yesterday.

title: Finch Says Vote Backs Fund Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 Robert H. Finch, a counselor to President Nixon and a White House political adviser, said today that Tuesday's elections had strengthened the case for the Administration's revenuesharing proposal. He also said he did not think that Governor Rockefeller's standing with the President had been damaged by the defeat of a proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue in New York.

title: HOUSE BACKS BAN ON BUSING FUNDS; VOTES SCHOOL BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Nov. 5The House of Representatives voted overwhelming opposition late last night to the busing of schoolchildren to obtain racial integration.

title: Details of Expansion Plan Are Disclosed by Hunter
description: The first tentative details of a $76million expansion plan for Hunter College that would include three highrise buildings, aerial walkways, vestpocket parks and a new 68th Street subway station have been drawn up by college officials.

title: Nationalizations Planned
description: SANTIAGO, Nov. 4 (Reuters) The Chilean Government told Congress today that it wanted to nationalize 253 private companies but that newspapers, radio stations, publishing concerns and other news media were not included in its nationalization plans. This statement was contained in a message from Pedro Vuskovic, the Economics Minister.

title: IMPORT AUTHORITY FOR NIXON BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 The Senate Finance Committee voted today to give the President almost unlimited authority to impose import quotas if the United States' international economic position is found to be threatened.

title: Belgium is Reported Planning To Oust or Bar 30 Soviet Aides
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 4 (AP)An informed source reported today that the Belgian Government had decided to expel or bar from Belgium more than 30 Soviet citizens named as spies by a defector, Anatoly Chebotarev.

title: U.S. Puts Week's War Toll at 2, Concedes There Might Be More
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 4The United States command announced today the lowest number of battle deaths for one week for Americans since United States forces started fighting in South Vietnam in 1965.

title: B. & M. Trustees Told to File Bankruptcy Plan by Yearend
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission told the trustees of the Boston & Maine Corporation yesterday that for the sake of the public interest and the interest of concerned groups  employes, shippers, connecting carriers, and creditors a plan of reorganization for that bankrupt railroad should be forthcoming by the end of this year.

title: Cocoa Exchange Elects
description: The New York Cocoa Exchange announced yesterday that John E. Hoch has been reelected to a second tern as president. He is assistant vice president of ACLI International, Inc. Bernard S. Blumenthal, chairman of the board of the Ward Chocolate Company, Inc., has been elected the exchange's vice president, and Warren Heilbron, vice president of Unitrade, Inc., has been elected treasurer.

title: Ann Pennington, Dancing Star, Dies
description: Ann Pennington, the dancing star who was the toast of Broadway in the nineteentwenties, died yesterday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

title: U.S. and U.N.
description: The imminent arrival of a delegation from Peking heralds an uncertain new era for the United Nations. The longoverdue presence of a Government representing onefifth of mankind could significantly enhance the possibility of dealing effectively with a host of international problems. But it could, on the contrary, only accelerate the U.N.'s slump into acrimonious futility.

title: Washington Is Optimistic On EastWest Discussions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Administration officials, pleased with recent European developments but wary of encouraging any public euphoria, believe a series of closely linked EastWest negotiations will reach decisive stages next spring, about the time President Nixon visits the Soviet Union.

title: Capital to Get County Girl
description: A limited engagement of Clifford Odets's drama, The Country Girl, costarring Jason Robards, Maureen Stapleton and George Grizzard, will be presented at the Eisenhower Theater of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, beginning Nov. 16, John Houseman will direct the production, which will run through Dec. 18.

title: Bramson Recital Put Off
description: The recital by Berenice Bramson, soprano, scheduled for tomorrow night in Carnegie Recital Hall has been postponed to Nov. 29 because of illness. Tickets for the original date will be honored at the later one.

title: Attantan's Suit Against Times On War Papers is Dismissed
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 4 (AP)A Federal judge has dismissed lawsuit asking $5million in actual damages and $1billion in punitive damages from The New Times for publishing the Pentagon Papers.

title: JEROME HILTON, 63, CLOTHING EXECUTIVE
description: Jerome Hilton, president of the Hilton Manufacturing Company in Linden, N.J., a producer of clothing, and vice president and chief executive officer of Browning Fifth Avenue, died on Wednesday in Doctors Hospital after a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived on Ridgefield. Road, Wilton, Conn.

title: Jenkins Wins Puissance on Idle Dice and Main Spring
description: If it hadn't been for an old gray mare 17 years ago, Rodney Jenkins wouldn't have ridden Harry Gill's Idle Dice and the Hunting Woods Farm's Main Spring to victory in the puissance stake last night at the National Horse Show. The nation's top professional rider triumphed after three jumpoffs before a crowd of 12,600 at Madison Square Garden in this most exacting jumping test.

title: Coast Judge Finds 2 Sides In Dock Dispute in Contempt
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 (UPI)A Federal judge found longshoremen and shippers on the West Coast in contempt of court today and ordered them to resume shipping during the remainder of an 80day coolingoff period under the TaftHartley Act.

title: EUROPE TO PRESS U.S. ON CURRENCY
description: VERSAILLES, France, Nov. 4 European Common Market finance ministers decided today on a general strategy to try to force the hand of the United States in the monetary crisis.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
SABRES GAIN 44 TIE AFTER TRAILING, 40
description: DETROIT Nov. 4 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres rallied from a fourgoal deficit tonight to tie the Detroit Red Wings, 44, and stay 2 points ahead of the lastplace Wings in the National Hockey League East Division.

title: REV. JOHN COLLIER
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 4The Rev. John W. P. Collier, pastor of Ebenezer American Methodist Episcopal Church here from 1921 until his retirement in 1947, died today in Rahway Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived here.

title: Soviet Ship Opens South Asia Passenger Runs
description: TOKYO, Nov. 4 (UPI)The Russians are inaugurating passengership service in South Asian waters after moving naval units into the same region.

title: 25 STORES SOUGHT BY HARTFIELDZODYS
description: HartfieldZodys, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle with Borman's, Inc., to acquire 25 discount department stores operated by the Yankee Department Stores subsidiary of Borman's for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Baylor Calls It Quits at 37...in Fairness to the Fans
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (AP) Elgin Baylor of the Los Angeles Lakers announced his retirement from pro basketball today after nine games in his 14th season as a forward in the National Basketball Association.

title: 200 CITY SITES LOSE TAXFREE STATUS
description: Nearly 200 pieces of property with a total valuation of $76million have tentatively been placed on the city's tax rolls or restored to them by finance officials under new state and city laws governing propertytax exemption.

title: Welfare Cliental Right. To State Hearing on. Cut
description: A State Supreme Court tice here ruled yesterday a city welfare recipient was titled to a fair hearing at state level before welfare oments could be suspended, duced or ended.

title: China in the United Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Synod Split on ordaining Married Men
description: ROME, Nov. 4After a day of intense ecclesiastical arguI nient, the world Synod of Bishops failed again to reach agree nient on the controversial topic of whether to ordain married men to the Roman Catholic priesthood.

title: Bill Wants Name of Maker On Processed Food Labels
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, introduced legislation to day that would require manufacturers of processed food to list their names and addresses on their products' labels.

title: WATERY MAGNETS TIE UP ASMASHER
description: After suffering a setback that has already led to a fourmonth delay in operations, developers of the world's largest research tool an atom smasher four miles in circumference west of Chicago, believe they are on the way to solving their problem. Having dried out a number of waterlogged magnets they hope to start experiments before the is out.

title: Edith Woodward Bancroft Dies; Damascus Owned by Her Stable
description: GLEN COVE, L .I., Nov, 4Mrs. Edith Woodward Bancroft whose thoroughbred racing stable included Damascus which Was acclaimed. Horse of the Year in 1967, died here yesterday in the Montclair Nursing Home after a long illness. Mrs. Bancroft, who lived at 35 Hoaglands Lane in Old Brookville, was 66 years old.

title: Kate Millett's Film of and by Women Begins Run
description: Kate Millett's "Three Lives" is a moving, proud, calm, aggressively self-contained documentary feature, shot by on all-female crew, about what it's like to be the three very different women who talk about their lives, with feeling and a certain amount of surprise that anyone should be interested, in front of Miss Millett's camera.There is Mallory Millett-Jones, Miss Millett's intense, appealing, recently liberated younger sister  when they were children, Miss Millett once said, "I was smart and ugly" and Mallory "was dumb and beautiful." She's a product of an unhappy middle-class, St. Paul childhood, a short life of bloodless boredom with a husband who was so busy making it in the Philippines he had no time for her ("I was living in this huge Aztec sacrificial altar"), and of a break for freedom that has landed her, among other places, in her blood-sister's movie.There also are Lillian Shreve, an attractive, outgoing, middle-aged woman, a chemist whose parents were Italian immigrants and who describes her marriage as "a very happy 23 years, all told," and Robin Mide, 21, who left Far Rockaway five or six years ago to seek her independence in the theater, in drugs, in sex, and in the exercise of that kind of happy egotism that might pass for searching self-analysis on the Merv Griffin Show: "I'm very happy doing what I want to do.""Three Lives" is a good, simple movie in that it can't be bothered to call attention to itself, only to its three subjects, and to how they grew in the same male-dominated society that Miss Millett, in her "Sexual Politics," so systematically tore apart, shook up, ridiculed and underminedwhile, apparently, tickling it pink. This film is said to be partially financed by Miss Millett's share of the $75,000 Avon paid for the paperback rights.Ordinarily I'm inclined to regard all-female film crews much as I do all-black casts of "Hello, Dolly!," all-convict poetry anthologies and all-children church services. They are essentially well-meaning stunts, like Ina Ray Hutton's all-girl band, which more or less coerce favor not by what they accomplish, but how they do it, and by the very fact that they are doing it at all."Three Lives" is different, a movie that probably could not have been made in any other way without affecting the film's content and in some fashion exploiting it. Although the camera hardly moves, except for an occasional zoom for a tight close-up, and although the movie is limited to informed reminiscence, "Three Lives" is very much a moviethree highly specific novellas about three experiences that are exceptional only because, through some chance of time and circumstance, they happened to find their way to this film.There are definite limits to this sort of filmmaking but because it is a genre that has usually focused on the exhibitionists (like Shirley Clarke's "Jason"), it's refreshing to see what can be done with experiences of a more conventional order.Men, of course, don't fare too well in these stories, even off-screen, being mostly self-centered, unfeeling, fascist pariahs or, at best, like Lillian's husband, a shadowy figure, a seemingly decent man, who once had a nervous breakdown. No explanation is given, but in the context of this film it would seem to be the result of an inability to continue the historical conspiracy. That, I emphasize, is my fantasy."Three Lives" opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema on a bill with Ingmar Bergman's "Persona," which comes very close, I should think, to expressing in fictional terms the kind of women's experience that Miss Millett has sought to express in her film.

title: Wicks Stars as Blazers Defeat Rockets, 112110
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 4 (AP)Sidmey Wicks, a rookie forward, scored 20 secondhalf points tonight, including a 3point play with 15 seconds left, to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to 112110 victory over the Houston Rockets in the National Basketball Association.

title: DR. HENRY A BLAIR. A RADIATION EXPERT
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 4Dr. Henry A. Blair, chairman emeritus of the department of radiation biology in the School of Medicine and Dentistry at the University of Rochester, died today at Strong Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: British Uncover Bomb Cache in Raid on West Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 4  The British Army discovered substantial quantities of explosives today in a Roman Catholic housing project in west Belfast.

title: Advertising: Philip Morris Sponsors Show of U.S. Indian Art
description: An exhibition of the American Indian's art with 20 smoking pipes as a feature will be held at the Whitney Museum of American Art through a grant from Philip Morris, Inc. Although the company has sponsored art shows in the past this will be the first time its grant ineludes money for advertising the exhibition.

title: Brisker Lends Condors
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 4 (AP)John Brisker scored 37 points tonight as the Pittsburgh Condors defeated the Utah Stars, 135129, in the American Basketball Association. It was the Stars' third straight loss at home.

title: Books of The Times
description: Two routes are followed in John Malcolin Brinnin's amiable, informationpacked history of North Atlantic ship crossings. One is the eastwest route between Europe and the United States and Canada. The other is from sailing ship to the computerized Queen Elizabeth 2. The two searoads are intertwined; and one of the intriguing things about, the book is the way the mechanical and domestic changes. are fed into the unending traffic across the northern sea lanes.

title: 10,000 Indians in the City Try Not to Feel Isolated
description: It may come as a surprise to some American Indians living in New York City, but they are not alone.

title: WHEAT PRICES UP ON STRIKE REPORT
description: Prices of wheat futures rose as much as 2 cents a bushel on he Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Corn and soybean futures also advanced, but the gains were trimmed by profit taking.

title: OTC PRICES GAIN; AMEX ENDS MIXED
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market yesterday tried to extend the rally that began on Wednesday but some late profit taking erased many of their earlier gains.

title: POLICEMAN TELLS OF A BRIBE OFFER
description: A state police Investigator testified yesterday that gamblers in Westchester and Rockland Counties had offered him $1,000 a month in 1969 for the protection of their gambling operations.

title: 446466 Wins in Jersey
description: WOODBURY, N.J., Nov. 4 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey Lottery is 446466. The drawing was held in Woodbury as part of the community's 100th anniversary celebration.

title: Insurer Being Acquired
description: The American Financial Corporation announced yesterday the acquisition of the Selective Insurance Company of Cincinnati from the Beneficial Standard Corporation for cash and notes approximating $11million. Selective Insurance is a Cincinnatibased fire and casualty company with assets exceeding $25million.

title: China in the Unified Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrift Units Are Chided For Slow Lending Action
description: The New York State Superintendent of Banks, William T. Dentzer Jr., chided savings banks yesterday for the slowness with which you have moved in using new authority for financing purchases of cooperative apartments.

title: STUDY FINDS MOST LACK TRUST IN U.S.
description: The American people have been losing confidence in the Federal Government over the last six years and now view Washington with more cynicism than ever, a team of University of Michigan social scientists has found after conducting repeated attitude surveys.

title: Mothers Anonymous: Therapy That May Lessen C Abuse
description: LOS ANGELES  Private psychiatric therapy hadn't helped her and she was fearful that what she saw as her killer instinct would overpower her maternal feelings toward her 6yearold daughter.

title: El Topo' Emerges:Jodorowsky's Feature Begins Regular Run
description: During its months of mid-night screenings at the Elgin, Alexandro Jodorowsky's "El Topo" became a secret rite of some importance in New York City. It won what not even the most fashionable success at the East Side art houses has won, genuine followers who depended not on advertising and not, God knows, on influential critical opinion, but on their own needs and their own unaided enthusiasms. Those followersI'm not sure I'd want to call them just an audiencehave also earned a modicum of fame. And some of them, the kids in capes and wide-brimmed hats, the "El Topo" freaks, re-materialized the other night for a sneak preview at the Forum where, yesterday, their movie began its long-awaited full-scale commercial run.During the time of the midnight screenings I asked someone who had seen it what "El Topo" was all about. He answered, "Everything," and now that I've also seen it I know what he meant. "El Topo" (which means "The Mole") is about everything somewhat in the way that, say, William Blake's "The Mental Traveller" is about everythingwhich is to say it comes down heavily on first and last things, and leaves out a lot that might have been in the middle.With its circular patterns of change, with its black-suited, black-haired hero who dies halfway through and is reborn underground, a blond man in white loincloth, with its main events in large part derived from the Bible and its image of man as his own self-sacrifice, "El Topo" resembles not so much a well-made fiction as a prophetic book.It is also full of tests and riddles, and in looking for a fancy comparison, Borges, like Blake, comes too easily to mind. One admiring reviewer calls it, disarmingly, "a work of incomprehensible depth." But it is more nearly a work of incomprehensible breadth, and I am not persuaded that Jodorowsky, any more than the rest of us, altogether knows what he is about.He has made his film a Western of sorts and he has put in more phony gore than maybe 20 years of "The Wild Bunch." Critics have complained that the gore looks unreal, though disgusting. But surely the unreality is its point. It is a part of the self parody that controls the style of "El Topo"to the end that the idea of castration or immolation or decomposition, or whatever horror you will, looms larger than the fact (but not the feeling) and thus supports the essentially intellectual ambitions of the film.About Jodorowsky as a filmmaker I am not sure how I feel. "El Topo" is a good deal more interesting and a good deal less hung up on its own pretensions than all my most intelligent friends had led me to believe. It is vastly better than the same director's "Fando and Lis," but vastly inferior to Arrabal's "Viva La Muerte," a work in the same tradition of surreal violence to which all other works in this tradition must stand comparison.Perhaps the ambivalence was best expressed by a man at the sneak preview who, after the film had ended, stood up and shouted, "Viva El Topa!"finding as if by inspiration just the right combination of youthful fervor and mispronunciation.

title: GRAMERCY PARK GETS RENT STRIKE
description: A group of tenants who live In a fashionable apartment building facing Gramercy Park picketed in the fall sunshine yesterday to protest the living conditions they get in return for rents of $500 or $800 a month.

title: GAMBINO LOSES PLEA FOR STAY OF OUSTER
description: A Federal judge declined yesterday to delay deportation proceedings against Carlo Gambino, setting the stage for, a possible lastditch legal battle today if two cardiologists from the United States Public Health Service determine that the 69yearold alleged underworld Chieftain is fit to travel to his native Italy.

title: Atlantic Richfield Issues Top Oil Bid
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 (AP) The Atlantic Richfield Company's $31,717,717 bid for 1,761 acres in the Gulf of Mexico highlighted an Interior Department sale of offshore oil leases today. The sale drew a total of $96million in high bids.

title: Hussein Urges Final Accord With Palestinian Guerrillas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 4King Hussein of Jordan declared today that he was now ready to press for a final agreement with the Palestinian commandos.

title: Smart's 68 Leads Nicklaus, 2 Others By Shot at Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 4 (AP)Geoff Smart of Australia shot a fourunderpar 68 today for a onestroke lead over Jack Nicklaus and two Australians in the first round of the $28,000 Dunlop international golf tournament.

title: Philippine Outlaws Kill 11
description: MANILA, Nov. 4 (AP) Out laws ambushed a bus in Cotabato Pr(wince, Mindanao, killing 11 persons and stealing their money and valuables, while preelection violence in the Philippines claimed seven more lives, the police reported today. Outlaws have been active in Cotabato for more than a year, and the Government has sent army reinforcements to the area to restore order.

title: Lynch Faces Crucial Vote
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 4 (Reuters)Prime Minister John Lynch scheduled a crucial conficlqnce vote for Wednesday after he lost his majority in the House of Representatives today. The loss came when a dissident member of Mr. Lynch's ruling Finance Fail party resigned.

title: CITY HALL PARLEY IS CALLED ON FARE
description: Mayor Lindsay's committee to save the fare  the group that worked out the fare package that died with defeat of the transportation bond issue on Tuesdaywas scheduled to begin meetings again today at City Hall.

title: State Confirms It Has Dropped Brownie Points Welfare Plan
description: State officials confirmed yesterday that, they had dropped the controversial Brownie point welfare plan after it met with substantial objection from the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A story in the OctoberNovember issue of the National Wildlife magazine carries the information that in 1944 the Louisiana Legislature decreed that the muskrat, within the state's borders at least, should henceforth be called the marsh hare.

title: Market Place: Porteous Views GoGo Funds
description: Talk to whitethatched Douglas K. Porteous about his mutual fundwhich he raised from a pup but which didn't exactly become a dog  and the 70yearold exWall Streeter will tell you that the secret of the Provident Fund For Income, Inc., is in flexibility.

title: Students Walk Out To Back Demands On BusFare Pass
description: Students walked out of number of high schools in the city yesterday morning to back demands for a restoration of reducedfare bus passes.

title: NEW POST FILLED IN INTELLIGENCE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 The Department of Defense has created a new post of Assistant Secretary for Intelligence. The duties include coordination of policy and cost monitoring of the department's intelligence gathering networks.

title: U.N. DEBATE IS ASKED ON MISSION'S SAFETY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 4Six nations have asked the General Assembly to debate the question of security of missions accredited to the United Nations and safety of their personnel.

title: Helping Veterans
description: DeWitt Wallace, cochairman of Reader's Digest, says of the United Service Organzations: As the war in Vietnam winds down, large groups: of our young men are being released from military service in numbers that our economy has been unable to absorb. Thousands of veterans are returning to New York and surrounding communities. This influx poses an urgent challenge and opportunity.

title: House and Senate Conferees Agree on Rhodesian Imports
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4House and Senate conferees agreed today on an amendment permitting the importation of Rhodesian chrome after Jan. 1 in defiance of a United Nations embargo against the whiteruled African nation.

title: Water Standards Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had approved the water quality standards submitted by Pennsylvania and Alaska.

title: Dr. Valencia, ExColombian Leader, Dies at 62
description: Dr. Guillermo Leon Valencia, who served as President of Colombia from 1962 to 1966, died of a heart attack last night at the Belmont Plaza Hotel, where he had taken a room after being stricken outside at 49th Street and Lexington Avenue. Dr. Valencia, who had been staying here at the Drake Hotel, was 62 years old and lived in Popayan, Colombia.

title: Ceausescu Orders Tightening Of Controls Over Intellectuals
description: BUCHAREST, Nov. 4 (AP)President Nicolae Ceausescu set up a system today to tighten control over Rumania's Westernoriented intellectuals. But he blamed himself for some of the country's ideological weakness.

title: A.E.C. Head at Amchitka
description: AMCHITKA, Alaska, Nov. 4  James R. Schlesinger, chairman of the A.E.C., arrived here tonight with members of the House, his wife and two daughters in what he said was a demonstration of confidence that the Cannikan nuclear test could be conducted safely here Saturday.

title: Steal a Dance Triumphs But It Was No Waltz
description: In a tense stretch duel, Herbert Scwartz's Steal a Dance beat the Hickory Stable's Favorecidian at Aqueduct yesterday. The Pair competed in the 1 1/16mile feature turf race that attracted a field of seven, with a crowd of 20,304 on hand.

title: Hewitt Advances in Wales
description: ABERAVON, Wales, Nov. 4 (AP)Topseeded Bob, Hewitt of South Africa rallied s today to overcome Mark. Farrell of Britain, 06, 61, 63, and reach the semifinals of the Dewar Cup tennis tournament. Jaime Filial of Chile gained the semifinals with a 76, 60 victory over George Coven of France.

title: Letter of Intent Signed On Yonkers Track Sale
description: YONKERS, Nov. 4  A memorandum of intent, formally declaring that the five Rooney brothers of Pittsburgh are seeking to buy Yonkers Raceway and that the controlling interests are willing to sell the harness racing track, has been signed by both groups.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The only element of genuine surprise to emerge from the election of Ferguson Jenkins as the National League winner of the Cy Young Award was the fact that one member of the 24than committee did not mark the big Cub pitcher on his ballot, not even for third place. It is an omission that defies comprehension.

title: Job Opportunities Offered Veterans In L.I. Gathering
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 4Part of the harness track at Roosevelt Raceway was turned into a large hiring hall today where more than 40 potential employers from across the country met with unemployed veterans from Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Preliminary interviews were held for some 1,500 jobs whose salaries ranged from a few dollars an hour to $20,000 a year, depending on education and experience.

title: Music: From London
description: Unlike the N.B.C. Symphony, which was forced to disband when financial support was withdrawn, the Philharmonica Orchestra of London managed to stay alive. Its crisis came about seven years ago, when the backers pulled out. So the orchestra renamed itself the New Philharmonia, and struck off on its own as a cooperative body. Grants from various arts councils helped. Many recording dates helped. The magic name of its regular conductor, Otto Klemperer, helped. The orchestra stayed in business.

title: Assembly Deadlock Looms In Jersey Over Imperiale
description: TRENTON, Nov. 4A deadlock for control of the New Jersey Assembly seemed likely here tonight when a black Democratic Assemblyman repudiated his party's state leadership and vowed to block any Democratic efforts to assume control with the vote of Anthony Imperiale.

title: Talks to Be Resumed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 4Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson appealed today to labor and management in the coal strike to resume their negotiations with new urgency.

title: U.S. Population Growth Rate Declines
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4  At a time of wide concern that the population is growing too fast, three important new reports showed today that the rate of the nation's population growth is turning rapidly and dramatically downward.

title: I.T.T. Net Sets a Record;
description: With sales and earnings of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation the highest in its history for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, the company expects to achieve its twelfth consecutive year of record results, Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

title: After Indian Storm: Hunger and Death
description: JAMBU, India, Nov. 3The silt  choked rivers of Orissa State are still carrying the bodies of hundreds of people and cattle down to the sea. No one knows how many were swept away when a cyclonic tidal wave struck a 750squaremile area here Saturday.

title: Invisible Colleges Called in Jeopardy
description: A report prepared for the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education warned yesterday that many of the nation's small, private fouryear colleges, which are encountering stiffening competition from state institutions, are fighting desperately for survival.

title: 10 POLICE NAMED ON BRIBERY COUNT
description: A police lieutenant and eight patrolmen in East Harlem were indicted here yesterday on Federal briberyconspiracy charges resulting from the Knapp Commission investigation.

title: Big October Sales Gain Posted by Retail Chains
description: Strong gains in retail business for October, aided by the opening of new stores during the year, were reported yesterday by a number of the country's largest merchandising chains. However, some achieved less than their volume increases of earlier months of 1971.

title: Nets Sign FiveYear Lease To Play in Nassau Coliseum
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 4The New York Nets of the American Basketball Association signed a fiveyear lease today to play in the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Hempstead.

title: A Soviet Film Portrays End of Hitler
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 4  The last dramatic hours of Hitler in his chancellery bunker and the vast panorama of the battle for Berlin in 1945 have been reenacted in a Soviet film spectacular previewed here today for the foreign press.

title: Gertrud von Le Fort, 95, Dies; Wrote Novels and Short Stories
description: LONDON, Nov. 4Gertrud von Le Fort, a leading German Roman Catholic novelist in the period between the two World Wars, died in Oberstdorf, Bavaria, it was reported here yesterday. She was 95 years old.

title: GOVERNOR REBUTS LINDSAY ON FARE
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that. Mayor Lindsay's comments Wednesday that onry the Governor and the Legislature could save the transit fare had no relation to what the Mayor had told him the same day.

title: Nixon Aide Airs Pension Aims
description: The Nixon Administration yesterday outlined publicly for the first time a series of reforms it favors in the field of private pensions, including a controversial vesting requirement.

title: Breakfast Cereal Critic Cites Wide Improvement
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4 (UPI)Robert B. Choate, the man who told a Senate subcommittee 15 months ago that 40 to 60 of the bestselling breakfast cereals were virtually worthless in nutrients, said today that most of them had improved.

title: There's No M.A. Here
description: We need a Mothers Anonymous group here and the sooner the better, said Mrs. John J. Veronis, a Manhattan housewife who first heard of the West Coast organization from a sister who lives in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Pan Am Picks a President From Unit of RollsRoyce
description: William T. Seawell, a former Air Force general who currently is head of RollsRoyce American subsidiary, has conditionally accepted an offer to become president and chief operating officer of Pan American World Airways.

title: Insurer's Sales Rise 21%
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company said yesterday that new insurance sales in the year's first nine months rose 21 per cent to $1.7billion from $1.4billion year before. Assets rose 5,4 per cent to $6.4billion.

title: Labor Leaders, at Parley Here, Denounce Nixon Wage Policies
description: Labor speakers here attacked President Nixon's wageprice policies yesterday and expressed doubt that workers would be treated equitably in Phase Two of the program.

title: Recital by Perahia Marked by Ability To Change Styles
description: Murray Perahia's ability to shift styles in midrecital gave his piano program a pleasantly jolting quality Wednesday night at the Hunter College Playhouse. At the start, there were pieces originally for harpsichord, delivered with brilliant, pistonlike precision. Handel's Chaconne in G, although hard in tone (partly owing to dry acoustics), bounced along vigorously, the design sharply outlined in each of its variations. Three Scarlatti sonatas, arranged in fastslowfast sequence, stressed glitter and courtly pomp, rather than songs and dances.

title: BRITISH AIDE SURE OF MARKET ENTRY
description: GENEVA, Nov. 4The rearguard resistance threatened by Britain's Labor party will not block Britain's entry into the European Economic Cominupity, Geoffrey Rippon, the Conservative Government's representative who negotiated the terms of entry, said today.

title: U.S. Firm on Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4American official sources said today that the United States had no Intention of offering a devaluation of the dollar through a goldprice increase, as a means of breaking the deadlock over a new pattern of currency exchange rates.

title: JOSEPH G. BERMAN
description: Joseph George Berman of 225 Central Park West, founder and retired head of the Eastern Isles Importing Company, dealers in handicraft embroideries, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. His age was 92.

title: Chiang Rejects Offer By Official to Resign
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 4Foreign Minister Chow Shukai submitted his resignation because of Nationalist China's defeat at the U.N. General Assembly but President Chiang Kaishek has refused to accept it.

title: Advertising:
description: If the O.K. comes in from Stockholm, the Scandinavian Airlines System crowd will start a new program here next weeka program created in just three days and a program that will be implemented just as fast.

title: China in the United Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. BOND HOLDERS DECIDE ON PAYOFF
description: The Treasury announced yesterday afternoon that investors holding 34 per cent of the $3.8billion of Government notes and bonds coming due Nov. 15 decided to get paid off in cash instead of accepting new sevenyear or 15year securities.

title: Knicks' Tickets on Sale
description: Tickets for the 11 New York Knickerbocker National Basketball Association games to be played between Nov. 13 and Dec. 30 at Madison Square Garden will go on sale today at the Felt Forum box office and all Ticketron outlets at 10 A.M. Tickets priced at $6.50 for the second promenade and $4.50 for the mezzanine are the only locations expected to be available.

title: Italian Plane Crash Kills 6
description: RAVENNA, Italy Nov. 4 (AP)A twoengine military plane taking part in an Armed Forces Day holiday caught fire inthe air today and crashed atop six cars on a busy highway. The pilot and five motorists were killed, the police reported.

title: China in the Unified Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: MAX EDGAR KLEE, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: Max Edgar Klee, founder and first head of the United States and Canadian subsidiaries of the diversified chemical concern Farbwerke Hoechst, A. G., of Frankfurt, died Monday at his home in Basel, Switzerland. He was 68 years old.

title: Woman in the News
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 4She has been pictured as physically frail. She has suffered from tuberculosis, low blood pressure, kidney trouble and muscle spasms in the neck.

title: Telegram From Parliament
description: OTTOWA, Nov. 4 (AP)A telegram signed by 100 members of Parliament was sent to President Nixon today, asking him to cancel the scheduled underground nuclear test on Amchitka Island. The telegram carried the names of several mernbesr of Canada's governing Liberal party, including those of Jack Davis, Environment Minister, and Otto Lang, Manpower Minister.

title: REYNOLDS METALS WILL CLOSE PLANT
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it would close the two remaining operating potlines at its aluminum smelter in Troutdale, Ore., which, in effect, will close down the plant beginning Nov. 20. About .450 workers will be affected.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER BLUES BY 61
description: BOSTON, Nov. 4 (AP) Johnny Bucyk and Reggie Leach scored two goals each tonight in powering the Boston Bruins to a 61 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game.

title: Using Fresh Vegetables in Casseroles
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by recipe.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 106.0 from 106.5 last week.

title: OTB Hit by Another Breakdown
description: Handpunched betting slips replaced computerized tickets for four hours in most OTB shops yesterday as the Offtrack Betting Corporation's prime computer system malfunctioned again.

title: SOVIET SAID TO CUT CAIRO ARMS FLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4Soviet shipments of arms and highperformance aircraft to Egypt have dropped off sharply in the last three months, according to American intelli gence sources.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 4The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $788million, up 12 per cent from the yearearlier $701million.

title: A Revenue Man's Mission: Pricing Baby Food Here
description: His name: William A. Somers Jr. His job: Internal Revenue Service agent. His assignment: baby food.

title: Angela Davis Hearing is Set
description: SAN. RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 4 (Reuters)  Judge Richard Aranson of Superior Court today set a hearing for next Thursday to give defense attorney a last chance to persuade him to shift the murder trial of Angela Davis to San Francisco instead of to Santa Clara County. Miss Davis is accused of supplying the guns used during a Marin County Courthouse battle in which five persons, including a Superior. Court judge, were killed.

title: Stulberg Chair Occupied
description: The appointment of Dr. Pauli Murray, educator and women's rights activist, as Louis Stulberg Professor of Law and Politics by Brandeis University was announced yesterday. She is the first to occupy the chair established in the name of the president of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.

title: 2 More Men Are Charged In Kentucky Poll Slaying
description: MANCHESTER, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP)  Two more men have been charged with murder in the shooting of a Republican election judge at the Goose Rock polling place, officials said tonight.

title: DRYER OF GIANTS HARSH ON CRITICS
description: It has been an open secret for some time now that Fred Dryer of the New York Giants hasn't been happy with the criticism the defensive line has been getting. So when the 6foot6inch, 240pound defensive end decides to talk, people listen.

title: IMPERIALE VOWS TO TAKE NO GUFF
description: NEWARK, Nov. 4AssemblymanElect Anthony Imperiale described himself today as a statesman trying to ignore the pressure and insults of showboating Democrats and Republicans who have denounced his election.

title: China in the United Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: DYNAMITE IS FOUND IN 36TH ST. BUILDING
description: Two cardboard boxes containing what the police described as 100 pounds of decomposing, highly volatile dynamite were found yesterday in the storeroom of a tenement at 412 West 36th Street, between Ninth and Dyer Avenues.

title: VW OFFERING SET FOR AUDI SHARES
description: BONN, Nov. 4A week of uncertainty about the value of AudiNSU stock ended today with a Volkswagen announcement offering minority shareholders a cash settlement of 226 marks for each share nominally worth 50 marks.

title: Injured Reed Gets An Armchair View Of Knichs' Victory
description: The Houston Rockets served not only as a remedy for the Knicks, who scored their easiest victory of the season Wednesday night, but also they made Willis Reed forget some of the ache in his left knee.

title: RIESSEN ROUTED BY ASHE, 63, 61
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 3 (AP)Arthur Ashe of Gums Spring, Va., routed Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ili., 63, 61, tonight to gain the quarterfinals of the Stockholm open tennis tournament.

title: Conservative Is Elected As Mayor of Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 4Councilman Wyeth Chandler, backed by a small white majority, won a narrow runoff victory for Mayor tonight.

title: ZAMIR DANCE GROUP GIVES PROGRAM HERE
description: Freedom within limits, a quasidemocratic concept, sets the tone for the Batya Zamir Dance Company, which appeared Wednesday night at the Cubiculo.

title: China in the United Nations
description: To the Editor: Now is the time for the United States to act with maturity. The suggestion that we retaliate against those who did not see eye to eye with us in the matter of Red China, Taiwan and the U.N. even to the extent of endangering the whole peacekeeping machinery and charging those with whom we disagreed with infamy, is the height of irresponsibility.

title: Ruination of the Hills
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.I was born in 1922 in the very heart of the Appalachian Mountains and have been surrounded all my life: by coal mines, coal miners and coal companies. For as long as I can remember I have been profoundly distressed by the ruinous impact of the coal industry on the people who depend upon it and the land from which its product is wrested.

title: Soviet Ends Study of Sunspots; 35 Rockets Launched in 5 Days
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 4The Soviet Union announced today the completion of a fiveday study of the effect of sunspots on magnetic storms. At least 35 meteorological sounding rockets were launched during the study.

title: Notes on People
description: Science is offering man a future far darker than the Utopia it was supposed to create, said Dr. Dennis Gabor, the recent winner of the Nobel Prize for physics. He said at the University of Bridgeport that man is a fighting animal who turns his inventions to destruction and creates more material goods just for the sake of growth. We have already been living in a sort of Utopiaa level of material comfort that was unforeseeable 50 years ago, said Dr. Gabor. The triumph of technology and science has brought us face to face with irrationality. We have to fight not nature but man's nature.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES OWN CANCER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today reported out favorably a bill to expand cancer research that differs sharply from one passed earlier by the Senate with backing from the White House.

title: SADAT TRANSFERS TO MILITARY OFFICE
description: CAIRO, Friday, Nov. 5President Anwar elSadat was reported early today to have moved to the general headquarters of the armed forces on Monday to lead the country through the present decisive stage of the conflict with Israel.

title: Prine Offers a Bill Of Topical Songs At the Bitter End
description: Imitation may be flattering, but I wonder if Bob Dylan, the obvious inspiration behind singer/guitarist John Prine's music, really needs any more accolades. Fortunately, Mr. Prine, who opened Wednesday night at the Bitter End, is a goodenough composer to take his highly topical songs well beyond the limits of mere imitation. Less fortunately, his singing voice is an absolute deadringer for the Dylan sound, circa 196667. He even pronounces his a's with the hard accent so characteristic of Dylan.

title: Stage: The Rothschilds
description: The musical version of Frederic Morton's dynastic biography The Rothschilds has now completed its first year and is into its second at the LuntFontanne Theater, so to call it one of the most underestimated musicals of last season may seem somewhat extravagant. Yet it did seem to be greeted with an admiration rarely more than grudging or a regret that was practically passionate in its sincerity.

title: Many Environment Ads Held Blatantly False
description: Some of the nation's largest corporate advertisers have leapt so eagerly for the environmental bandwagon that they have ended by sprawling in the dust, a business research organization reported yesterday.

title: W. ROBERT JAMES
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 4W. Robert James of 9 Glen Oaks Avenue, meager of government special projects contracting for the Western Electric Company, died here of cancer on Tuesday. His age was 61.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISIt is unusual that a commentator on foreign affairs can find a pleasant or encouraging subject to write about. This is especially true with respect to the U.N., whose latest gyrations Over which China means what and to whom have proven a rather traumatic experience to certain capitals, including Washington. Nevertheless, an exception to this gloomy rule arises in the case of UNESCO, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, which celebrated its 25th birthday yesterday.

title: China in the United Nations
description: To the Editor: Now that the U.N. has welched on its commitment to a foundermember nation, there's no logger anybody to whom a wronged nation may appeal. The United Nations' concern for small nations is revealed for the hypocrisy it is.

title: Rounding Up Shopping Carts That Rustlers Steal
description: LOS ANGELES  Just after midnight about 14 months ago, a caravan of some two dozen trucks, led by a South Korean trained in espionage, pulled up to a lot in Burbank, Calif. They furtively jumped from the truck and began loading their bootyshopping carts.

title: City Preparing Cuts In Services to Off set Loss of Bond Funds
description: The city is preparing to reduce current services in education, health and human resources to conform to expected reductions in state funds as a result of the defeat of the $2,5billion transportation bond issue.

title: COAL STOCKPILES ARE BEING USED UP
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4I After five weeks of the strike by the 100,000 members of the United Mine Workers, it appears that the large stockpiles of coal are beginning to dwindle.

title: Man Dies Here in Blaze, Trapped Behind Antiviolence Shield He Built
description: George Leon Fitzgerald, 29years old, worried about the violence, drugs and generally unsafe conditions on the block where he had reModeled a fifthfloor tenement walkup, at 446 West 58th Street, for his wife and yearold daughter.

title: Jack Johnson,' Black Fighter
description: Time may have a way of vitiating history, but "Jack Johnson" emerges amazingly alive and fascinating in the documentary biography of the black heavyweight boxing champion of more than 60 years ago, which had its local premiere at the Whitney Museum yesterday."I like what I do before a crowd," says Brock Peters as the rich baritone off-screen "voice" of the champ. And through this meticulous composition of vintage footage, stills and many of Johnson's actual words, a viewer, even a nonsporting type, also should get to "like" what Johnson did.As the work of Jim Jacobs and William Cayton, who have already given us careful pugilistic histories in "The Legendary Champions" and "a.k.a. Cassius Clay," this history sticks to facts that do not force sympathy for its hero and that really need no footnotes. These are visual and aural facts that somehow limn a more detailed picture of the controversial fighter than the stage and screen versions of Howard Sacker's play "The Great White Hope."These comparisons are inevitable but not really necessary. What we have in this "(Jack Johnson" is a portrait of a towering figure, who, right or wrong, obviously was before his time. In this case, simply a good deal more of the man is exposed in these vintage films of his fights and his life outside the ring than was revealed in the previous, forceful stage and screen dramatizations.Against a throbbing modern jazz score by Miles Davis, we are given a smiling, 6-foot 200-pound muscular, bald, Texas black man who happily marries three white women in succession against the shibboleths of his day, who chases and finally wrests the championships from Tommy Burns in Australia in 1908 and on, through triumphs and adversity, to his death in 1946.Controversy obviously was the name of Johnson's game through a variety of "white hopes" who sought to dethrone him until that gigantic Kansas farmer, Jess Willard, did it in Havana in 1915. A good many of these scenes turned up in "The Legendary Champions."But there is a profusion of rarely seen shots, toosuch as his thrilling auto race with Barney Oldfield; his Chicago saloon; his life in World War I France; Spain (as an amateur matador); his flight from this country after his trial on morals charges; Russia, where he met Rasputin; his stay in Leaven-worth prison and as an aging but still happy attraction at Hubert's Flea Museum on 42d Street.This, of course, is a special case and a specialized film. But "Jack Johnson" does come through as the picture of a highly unusual, decidedly undefeated man full of life to the end who defiantly stated: "I'm black! They never let me forget it. I'm black all right. I'll never let them forget it!"

title: Big Oil Tanker Sunk as Government Reports a Sharp Rise in Guerrilla Activity in East Pakistan
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 4The Government today reported a sharp increase in Bengali guerrilla activity in: the last 24 hours, including the sinking of a large oil tanker in the East Pakistani port, of Chittagong.

title: Pros Down Pacers
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 4 (AP)Larry Cannon tallied 34 points tonight to lead the Memphis Pros to a 10594 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: The Talk of Roundup
description: ROUNDUP, Mont.It looks like just another of America's declining small townsaging stores set along a wide main street with all its hopes buried somewhere in the past. But looks aren't everything. There are stirrings of a new start in this old cowboy and mining town 55 miles north of Billings: A new doctor in town, a new art bronze foundry, a mushroomraising project beginning to take shape, reawakened interest in the coal mines that were mostly closed in the midnineteenfifties. Some of these may seem like small things but the town, once packing, seems to be gaining again, and the prime mover in much of Roundup's progress, Ralph Gildroy Jr., is alive with the infectious air of a man living in a world that is blossoming.

title: Discrimination Against the Qualified?
description: Every humane and fairminded person must approve of the Presidential Executive Order of 1965 which forbade discrimination with respect to race, religion, national origin or sex by any organization or group that receives financial support from the Government in the course of fulfilling its contractual obligations with it.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Meets Nixon, Asks Pressure on Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4President Nixon and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India conferred at the White House for slightly more than two hours today, in what spokesmen called an atmosphere oft friendliness.

title: 10 Jersey Towns Get U. S. Warning On Sludge Dumping
description: NEWARK, Nov. 4  The Federal Government wants New Jersey shore towns to end their 40year practice of discharging untreated sewage sludge into the Atlantic Ocean before Dec, 15.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4It is now just a year before the Presidential election of 1972, and President Nixon finds himself in a very odd situation.
