Dusan Makavejev came to America a few years ago from Yugoslavia, with the alleged purpose of making a film about Wilhelm Reich, the controversial psychiatrist who died in 1957. Makavejev interviewed relatives of Reich, doctors who currently use his methods of therapy, and various people who he thought represented aspects of the sexual changes taking place in America. Edited into this is a political comedy located in Yugoslavia, based on a girl who, we are led to believe, is a follower and admirer of Reich's views and sees his theories as helpful to the growth of Yugoslavian Communism. (It should be noted quickly however, that the girl's understanding of Reich is so simplistic and distorted that she hardly represents what Reich believed at all, although the director would like us to think so.)For a final touch, there is footage of an old Russian film on Stalin plus assorted other film tidbits, all rather freely (but not without conscious design) edited together. Unfortunately, the intent of the editing is not to make the connection between these disparate scenes clearer but, more often than not, to obscure and often misrepresent what is really going on.It is here that the problem of the film comes into focus. For under the guise of artistic license, Makavejev takes bits of reality and truth and distorts them through the use of editing tricks, subliminal visual associations and Reich's own words used out of the context and spirit in which they were written. Such techniques of character assassination and audience manipulation are not new in film, but rarely have they been used in such a devious way.Take, for example, this use of editing. We are shown a scene of a conscious man actually being given shock treatment in a hospital. A piece of cloth is jammed in his mouth and the electric shock administered. His body writhes in pain and involuntary muscle contractions. It is a pathetic sight, Makavejev cuts from this scene of almost utter horror to a Reichian therapy workshop where people are screaming and going through strange body movements. The distinct impression caused by this scene, especially when immediately preceded by the shock therapy sequence, is that these patients are undergoing a similar experience. Although it is hard to know exactly what Makavejev meant by juxtaposing these two scenes, their effect is to present a ludicrous and negative picture of Reichian therapy.Makavejev does not bother to explain that the screaming and yelling in the workshop are a therapeutic means of getting in touch with one's anger and negativity by direct vocal expression. He does not bother to explain that the strange body movements are very specific positions used to break down tension blocks (or armor, as Reich described it) in the body so that good feelings can flow more easily.So while Makavejev, on the surface, seems to be praising Reich, the actual content of the film mocks and maligns him. Makavejev then cloaks these distortions in a web of comedy and "avant garde" ambiguity. It is an old trick. Hide the poison in sugar. And Makavejev's film is just that. He gives us so much sugar (off-beat poet Tuli Kupferberg, transvestite Jackie Curtis, sex scenes, music, comedy, plus political pokes at the United States and Russia) that our senses get clouded and we forget, indeed can hardly decipher what the film is about. We think it must be about Reich since he is quoted, talked about and seen so much. But in point of fact, the film bears as much resemblance to Reich and his work as Coke does to "the real thing" or Pepsi to Living and Giving (You've got a lot to Live and Pepsi's got a lot to Give).Some people prefer to stop at this point and ask why Reich should even be discussed in an appraisal of the film. Can't the film be judged on esthetic grounds alone?To bring the issue closer to the hearts of most film lovers, let me offer this analogy. Imagine that 30 years from now Franois Truffaut has become a relatively obscure film director. A film is made titled, "FT-Mysteries of the Cinematic Process." We are led to believe that the film will be a sympathetic re-discovery of Truffaut's work. The film consists in good part of scenes from Hitchcock, Renoir and Truffaut films, showing the influence of these masters on his filmmaking. But instead of explaining that part of Truffaut's esthetic was a continual homage to these filmmakers, the film deviously presents Truffaut as just a rank imitator.By not explaining Truffaut's own esthetic accurately, by taking scenes out of context, or juxtaposing them so as to downgrade him, the film totally misrepresents Truffaut. I wonder how many film lovers would elect to dismiss any comparison with the real Truffaut as being unimportant to the meaning and critical appraisal of the hypothetical film I have outlined. Yet it is this type of cinematic logic that I have found quite prevalent when Makavejev's film is discussed.In order to determine if my own feelings were true that Makavejev had misrepresented not only Reich's views but those of the Bioenergetic doctors depicted in the film, I spoke to Drs. John Pierrakos and Alexander Lowen; they brought up many objections to Makavejev's use of Reich. But foremost was Makavejev's misinterpretation, and therefore distortion, of Reich's views on sexuality."Reich believed, and in all his writings stressed, that sexuality should be based on feelings of love," Dr. Pierrakos said. "But Makavejev makes no distinction between healthy sexuality and libertinism. Ho disassociates sex from love. Almost all of Makavejev's references to sex in the film show it as either a mechanical act, masturbatory or perverse. By leaving the feelings of love out of sexuality, Makavejev distorts Reich's views. Mr. Makavejev is entitled to disagree with Reich, but he is not entitled to put his views in the mouth of Reich or to identify them with our work in Bioenergetics."The question inevitably arises  if the film is not about Reich, or is a conscious misrepresentation of Reich, what is it really about? I submit that instead of being a tribute to Reich, "WR-Mysteries of the Organism" is little more than a putdown of practically everything it touches. It uses Reich as a device, to show the repressive nature of the United States government, and to show what unbridled sexual "freedom" might lead to. There is hardly a scene shot in America which does not seek to focus on either the bizarre or perverse, except those scenes which mock, in one way or another, Reich.By the association of Reich's theories with these scenes of current-day America, Makevejev implies that the two are connected. And as for Russia, Stalin is given his due in scenes which epitomize his stiffness and inhumanity.By contrast, the only joyful place is an apartment in Yugoslavia where two beautiful girls romp around, proclaim a sexual revolution (which has much to do with sex; but little with love) and generally make merry. These scenes are usually comic and lighthearted  especially when juxtaposed with the perversity in America and the authoritarianism of Russia. The two superpowers have gone astray, each in its own way.This seems to be the message of Makavejev's film and no doubt there is truth in it. But I question if, in the name of freedom and fun, Makavejev has not grossly misused his directorial powers. If a film is pure fiction, then all praise to the director who lets his imagination run rampant. But when the actual lives of people, both living and dead, are represented in a quasi-documentary which is supposed to be "about them," the test of reality and truth must also enter into an understanding and appraisal of the film.The film certainly fails this test and, unfortunately for Makavejev, "WR-Mysteries of the Organism" fails also as comedy and satire. For any film based on an essentially dishonest approach toward its subject must eventually go sour. It is no wonder then that the film, which begins by proclaiming that life should be joyful, turns out to be one of the gloomiest of recent memory.

title: Pros Overtime Victors
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 6 (AP)Larry Cannon's two free throws with 22 seconds left tonight gave the Memphis Pros a 122121 overtime victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: FIGHTING CONTINUES AT CAMBODIAN POST
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6 (AP)A general lull in combat in South Vietnam was nearly a week long today. But in eastern Cambodia sharp fighting continued around Government garrison besieged by North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops, and the South Vietnamese command announced a new operation just inside Cambodia.

title: Tokyo Giants, On Homerin 10th, Earn Third Tie With Orioles, 99
description: TOKYO, Nov. 6 (AP)In a battle of home runs, the Baltimore Orioles and the Yomiuri Giants of Tokyo played to a 99 tie in 10 innings today. It was the third tie between the teams on the Orioles' tour of Japan, The Orioles are unbeaten.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: About Pro Football
description: Watch Earl Morrall tomorrow night when the Baltimore Colts play the Los Angeles Rams over Channel 7. Earl, now 37 years old and in his 16th pro season, is at the peak of his game and ranks right at the top among pro football's quarterbacks in the opinion of this longtime Morrall  watcher. Deft, precise and quick describe Morrall's ballhandling and movements. His playcalling is confident and imaginative, with more of his passes on the mark than heretofore.

title: Once upon a time, three famous men came into the nursery...
description: Let us now praise famous men: Switzerland's Jean Piaget for his pioneering psychological investigations into the child's own construction of reality; New York's Donald Barthelme for diving clean through the polished surface of conventional verbiage into a new undercurrent of narrative truth; and France's Eugene Ionesco for imbuing the banalities of everyday happenstance with cosmic dramatic significance.

title: Cook Snares 3 Scoring Passes As Fordham Prep Wins, 200
description: Howie Cook scored all three touchdowns yesterday as Fordham Prep crushed Brooklyn Prep, 200, at Fordham Prep. It was the sixth victory for the unbeaten Little Rams, the fourth in the Metropolitan High School Football League.

title: CARL S. HALLAUER OF BAUSCH & LOMB
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 6 (AP)Carl S. Hallauer, a retired board chairman of Bausch & Lomb, Inc., the optical company, and a former Republican national committeeman, died today of heart attack while vacationing in Hiltonhead, S.C. He was 77 years old.

title: Hamilton Harriers Win Title
description: CLINTON, N.Y., Nov. 6 Hamilton won the New York State Collegiate Coaches Conference crosscountry championship today with 85 points. Second was Union with 94 points and Rochester with 128.

title: Tito Visits Halifax
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 6 (UPI)President Tito of Yugoslavia came to Halifax today for a 20hour visit. He is scheduled to receive an honorary degree from Dalhousie University and to attend a state dinner given by Premier Gerald Regan. President Tito is due to fly to London Sunday morning.

title: The Island of YapPlenty of Big Wheels But Few Big Spenders
description: YAP, Caroline IslandsThe modest maidens of these western Pacific islands would never dream of wearing miniskirts or hot pants. They consider exposed thighs to be improper, and their grass skirts go well below the knee. But an American admiral who tried not long ago to prevent his sailors from being distracted by the barebreasted Yapese lovelies issued regulation white Tshirts to the young ladies only to see them cut two holes in the front for comfort.

title: Et Al.
description: A straightforward story of an adolescent's descent into drug addiction and finally his death of OD, told pseudonymously by his mother in a rather novelistic style. The melodrama is almost justified.

title: 14 Denied Access Ta Graham Fete Sue in U.S. Court
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 6  Fourteen people have charged in a class action lawsuit that Secret Service agents and local policemen refused to honor their tickets to a rally honoring Billy Grahm that was attended by President Nixon.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONMore than 7 million Americans are captives of a consumer market that is one of the largestand easily the strangestin the nation. Customers spend billions of dollars for everything from beer to automobiles to baby food, prices are generally much lower than those in civiitan stores and the system's profits are largely returned to the customers military men and their familiesin the form of recreational programs and other extras.

title: Et Al.
description: Twentyfive years later Eric Newby recounts his adventures in Italian P.O.W. camps. He was captured after an abortive cloakanddagger mission he calls Operation Whynot; one day he just walked away from his captors, to be hidden and cared for by friendly Italians. Mr. Newby's memoir may be unique because of its wry, understated humor in the mode of Mr. Roberts and similar war novels. Highly diverting.

title: New York Tech Wins, 430
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I,, Nov. 6  Bob Levine passed for two touchdowns and ran for one to lead New York Tech's undefeated club football team to its seventh victory, 430, today against New York State Maritime College.

title: Sales Jobs For the Aged
description: FORT WORTH, Tex.Kelly Williamson sells lubricants to the petroleum industry outside of Anchorage, Alaska.

title: HOLY CROSS UPSET By UMASS, 38 TO 27
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 6 (AP)Paul Metallo, a junior hafback, ran for 258 yards and four touchdowns today as the University of Massachusetts football team upset Holy Cross, 3827.

title: Preps
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 6Kent remained undefeated today, winning its sixth game, with a 3314 romp over Hotchkiss.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I was surprised to note that James Reston, in his column of Oct. 31, writes that the other day ... Britain, France and finally the U.N. itself defied Washington by bringing Communist China into the United Nations. Mr. Reston's mistake was, I am sure, inadvertent. Nevertheless, it should be pointed out to your readers that this year the Nixon Administration did not oppose bringing Communist China into the U.N. As a matter of fact, the resolution it advanced provided for the U.N. Security Council seat going to Peking. Washington did, however, strongly oppose the expulsion of Taiwan from the General Assembly.

title: Pittsburghers Led By Steinberg Play New Barber Work
description: As music director of both the Boston Symhpony and the Pittsburgh Symphony, William Steinberg makes more appearances in New York than most visiting conductors. Last week he opened the Bostonians' series in Philharmonic Hall; on Friday night it was the Pittsburghers' turn in Carnegie Hall.

title: Third World Voices For Children Edited by Robert E. McDowell and Edward Lavitt. Illustrated by Barbara Kohn Isaac. 149 pp. New York: The Third Press. Distributed by The Viking Press. $5.95.
description: Third World Voices for Children, a highly entertaining collection, has a definitive and worthwhile motive which it executes splendidly. One of the best ways to learn about the lives of people, it says in the introduction is to study their art works and their literature. In the four sections presenting works from Africa, the Caribbean, the Southern U.S. and the South Pacific (we might have expected South America rather than the South Pacific, Brazil rather than New Guinea and Papua  nonetheless ...) the reader becomes very much acquainted with the lives and thoughts of the people through tales, stories, poems and songs. The genesis tales reveal how our early ancestors sought to explain creation, the universe, the heavens, natural phenomena. The animal fables clue us into values and ethics. The snatches from autobiographies document the experience of slavery, of the American frontier, of visits with the elders who have conserved the old ways and the old tales, of the struggle to maintain allegiance with the traditions that sustains a people while it attempts to master the technics of the modern West. But mostly there are the songs.

title: Nassau South
description: Berner rebounded from its upset by Lawrence last week to capture the South Shore Division I championship with a dramatic 86 overtime victory over previously undefeated Massapequa yesterday.

title: Long Island Awaits Bid From N.H.L.
description: After months of apprehension, rumors and charges in the world of hockey, the National Hockey League begins a twoday meeting here tomorrow that is expected to end with theawarding of franchises for Long Island and Atlanta.

title: Shanker Courting Teachers On Island
description: The tall figure of Albert Shanker, a dominant force in New York City school affairs for the last seven years, will soon be casting its shadow across the Long Island school scene.

title: Mississippi Poll Watchers Say Harassment Barred Fair Tally
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 6Incidents of widespread violence, harassment and intimidation, it is being charged here, kept many black candidates and their racially mixed outofstate supporters from counting votes cast in the general election on Tuesday.

title: 4 Counties in California Moving To Outlaw the Lead in Gasoline
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 6 Here in Southern California, where eyeburning, choking smog has long been a way of life, bold steps are being taken to outlaw the sale of gasoline containing lead:

title: Home Improvement
description: PORTABLE electric sanders can save the doityourselfer a great deal of time and effort on many different kinds of smoothing and finishing jobs particularly on tough surfaces or when there is really a considerable amount of sanding required. It is for this reason that most home handymen and furniturefinishing enthusiasts find that the addition of one or more of these machines soon assumes a high priority on their list of mostwanted tools.

title: MIG's Reported Over Sinai
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 6 (AP)An Israeli military spokesman said that two Sovietbuilt MIG23 fighter aircraft flew over the Israeliheld Sinai peninsula at a high altitude and a great speed today.

title: Kennedy Again Says He Won't Ran in '72
description: ST. PAUL, Nov. 6 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy said again today there were no circumstances under which he would seek the Presidency in 1972.

title: Gardens
description: THE end of summer is not an ending really, but a beginning. There is always another spring eagerly awaited throughout the long winter.

title: Liner Here Struck by Crew
description: Unloading of the liner Cristoforo Colombo was delayed for more than an hour yesterday morning when the crew struck for more money. The demands were granted and baggage was sent ashore by the crew, but at a slow rate. The ship, owned by the Italian Line, docked at 8 A.M. with 531 passengers at Pier 90, at the foot of West 50th Street.

title: World
description: WASHINGTONOver the years the foreign aid program has provided the annual cliffhanger for the end of the Congressional session. But this year the actors on Capitol Hill have almost lost control of the drama.

title: William H. vom Rath, Official Of General Aniline, Dies at 84
description: GENEVA, Nov. 6  William Herbert vom Rath, a principal operating executive of the General Aniline and Film Corporation of New York until its seizure as enemyowned property during World War II, died yesterday at Glion. He was 84 years old and lived in Kronberg, Germany, and formerly in Washington.

title: British Say Bomb Factory Is Found in Ulster Village
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov, 6 (AP)British Army headquarters today reported the discovery of what it said was a bomb factory in the tiny village of Carrickmore, in Ulster's County Tyrone.

title: Preps
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 6Andover's 16game winning streak was ended today when the Dartmouth B freshmen team rallied from a 140 deficit to win, 4828.

title: Phone System Set Up. To Report Pollution
description: A 24houraday telephone system for reporting oil, spills, fishkills and the dis covery of hazardoils materials in all waters of New York State and New Jersey has been started by the Environmental Protection Agency of the Federal Government.

title: NEW U.S. MISSILE BEING PRODUCED
description: Maverick, an airborne missile guided to surface targets by a television camera in its nose cone, has gone into production under a $69.9million contract and will be delivered to the Air Force late next year.

title: The World
description: LONDONAt a Common Market meeting recently the Netherlands Foreign Minister, Norbert Schmelzer, denounced what he termed the divideandrule tactics of the United States in the trade and monetary crisis. A high official of the market's commissing remarked: Until lust now I would not have believed that a Dutchman would ever make an antiAmerican statement.

title: Picture Books
description: TRAIN RIDE. Written and illustrated by John Steptoe. Harper & Row. $3.95. Ages 6 to 10. Rouaultlike static paintings belie the energy and enterprise of the kids in this book. A trip from Brooklyn to Times Square reveals a wonderland of lights, giant signs, a penny arcade, strange looking men in blonde wigs. Confrontation and interaction are the stuff of life and a whipping is accepted as fair price for a boss time.

title: Tennessee Wins, 356
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 6 (AP)Pass interceptions by Bobby Majors led to two Tennessee touchdowns and Tennessee ran back two others for scores today as the Vols bowledover South Carolina, 35.6, in a homecoming game.

title: SEX DISCRIMINATION FOUND IN STORE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) A Federal court has ruled that a nationwide retail chain illegally paid its salesmen more than its saleswomen and its male tailors more than its female tailors, and that it must give the women raises and back pay plus interest, the Labor Department reports.

title: The West of Architecture On Long Island This Year
description: A dramatically cantilevered building with stark surfaces of concrete and bronzed aluminum has won this year's grand award for architectural excellence at the annual Long Island Architectural Awards Recognition Dinner.

title: F.A.A. Approves Grant
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration has approved a $34,700 grant for the development of airport master plans for James D. O'Brien Field at Worcester, Mass.

title: BASIS CONTRACT WITH GREECE OFF
description: ATHENS, Nov. 6A dispute between the Greek Government and Aristotle S. Onassis ended today when the parties, by mutual consent, agreed to scrap their $600million investment contract.

title: The Vote
description: Everybody was for the Transportation Bond issue: the Governor, the Mayor, good government groups, businessmen, labor unions, both major parties. Everybody but the voters.

title: Status of The Movement: The Energy Levels Are Low
description: WASHINGTON.

title: COLONELS SUBDUE NETS BY 102 TO 97
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 6 (AP)  Dan Issel scored 36 points, 18 in each half, and Artis Gilmore grabbed 22 rebounds tonight to pace the Kentucky Colonels to a 10297 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets.

title: HBOMB IS TESTED IN THE ALEUTIANS DESPITE PROTEST
description: AMCHITKA ISLAND, Alaska, Nov. 6The controversial Cannikin bomb test was executed today at 5 P.M., Eastern standard time, after the Supreme Court refused to order a delay.

title: Characters that are, or become, moral men
description: For me, reading a new book by Robert Penn Warren (this is his ninth novel) is like encountering once again a stouthearted fatherfigure as dependable (which is not to say predictable) as the day is long. I know ahead of time that the bookwhether novel, poems, stories or essayswill be authentic, gritty with felt life. Approaching a new novel, I know, or think I know, it will have some of the virtues of the conventional popular novelrecognizable and accessible plot and shape, for instance. The setting will be rural, the action tangled and bloody, the characters country people. The tone of the prose used to dramatize their lives might be in turn lyrical, elegiac, satirical. In that prose, that narrative, will float certain obsessive images, certain brooding abstractions which will, in the fullness of the table.

title: Officials of pities Praising President New Aid Plan
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 6The Nixon Administration, which has been widely accused of neglecting urban needs, appears to be winning strong support among city officials because of the authority and resources it is promising them under the Model Cities program.

title: Lafayette Beats Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 (UPI)Lafayette beat Gettysburg at the Bullets' Homecoming game for the first time in 30 years, 27.12, today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The following is not really a Washington Report. It is, rather, a sort of cautionary tale from England, whore this reporter recently spent part of a vacation, away from London.

title: Two New Papers, Resisting a Trend, Publish in Canada
description: TORONTO, Nov. 6Resisting the North American trend toward fewer bigcity newspapers, two dailies began publishing this week in Canada.

title: Owen Nee Jr. to Wed Amber Wong
description: Miss Amber Wong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. WoonNam Wong of Hong Kong, and Owen Dawes Nee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nee of Rye, N. Y., plan to be married on Dec. 11 in the Presbyterian Church of Rye.

title: The World
description: SAIGONSecretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird stepped off his plane here last Wednesday and fumbled briefly for something to tell the waiting reporters. When he took office, he began, there were 549,500 American troops in Vietnam; today there are fewer than 200,000.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE PENDULUM of stockmarket sentiment, which has swung steadily toward pessimism since midSeptember, suddenly stopped and moved in the opposite direction last week after the market had reached a low for the year on Monday. It hasn't traveled very far on the new path as yet.

title: Soviet and NATO in a Dispute Over Naval Rights in the Baltic
description: BONN, Nov. 6A Soviet publication has demanded that the Baltic Sea be closed to the naval units of all nonBaltic powers, and this development is reported to have aroused concern in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization this week.

title: Oil Executive Scores Nader
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 6 (UN)C. Howard Hardesty Jr., senior vice president of the Continental Oil Company, contends that Ralph Nadar, the consumer advocate, is doing an injustice to the United States in saying that oil companies mislead Americans. In a speech last week in Houston, Mr. Nader denied that the nation faced a fuel shortage. Mr. Hardesty spoke here Thursday at the annual meeting of the South Carolina Petroleum Council.

title: Mary Susan Stare To Be Wed Dec. 30
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Nov. 6 Dr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Stare have announced the engagement of Dr. Stare's daughter, Miss Mary Susan Stare, to Bradford W. Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert T. Wilkinson of Weston.

title: Neglected Red Hook Takes On the City
description: Red Hook is a Brooklyn community that says it resents being used as a dumping ground by the city across the river.

title: Investment Banker Is Slain in Cross Fire Between Police and Two Robbery Suspects on Fifth Avenue
description: A 33  year  old investment banker was shot to death near 40th Street and Fifth Avenue late Friday night when he was caught in a cross fire between the police and a pair of robbery suspects.

title: Nixon Trip Here Tuesday Is a Prelude to 1972 Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6President Nixon's plans to visit two Republican fundraising dinners next Tuesday  with hors d'oeuvres in New York and dessert in Chicago  provide new evidence that his campaign for a second term is well under way.

title: All Roads Next Weekencl Lead To S. C. C. A Convention Here
description: About Motor Sports

title: CONGRESSMAN HEADS 16 LOUISIANA RIVALS!
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sunday, Nov. 6 (AP)A threeterm Congressman, Edwin W. Edwards, who had actively sought the black vote, kept the lead today in the 17man race for the Democratic nomination for Governor with votes from half the state's precincts counted.

title: Miss Feather Has Nuptials
description: PELHAM, N. Y., Nov. 6Miss Kimberly Battle Feather and Dwight Everard Lowell 2d were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the rector, Rev. David S. Hoag.

title: NEW BLACK MAYOR PUSHING FOR UNITY
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. The stocky, 54yearold pastor of the Galilee United Methodist Church here said today that his election this week as the first black Mayor of this middle  class, predominantly white community will serve somewhat as a safety valve.

title: Open Letter
description: On June 15, 1970, when Zhores Medvedev was confined in a mental hospital, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the Soviet novelist and Nobel Prize winner, wrote the following letter, which was soon widely circulated among the Moscow intelligentsia:

title: The Nation
description: The President has got one weapon, and the labor people know it. If they torpedo the Pay Board before Phase Two gets under way, he can reimpose the freeze.

title: ARKANSAS, RICE PLAY TO 2424 TIE
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 6 (AP)Bill McClard kicked a 45yard field goal as time ran out to give the Arkansas Razorbacks a 2424 tie with Rice today. The Owls had taken a secondhalf lead on two touchdown passes by Bruce Gadd.

title: For Dr. Cohen, Seminary Is Like Home
description: When Gerson D. Cohen was in a French class at City College, the professor called students by number instead of by name. Because he was fifth on the row, Mr. Cohen was addressed as Monsieur Cinq.

title: Lad as a Wasp In Dog's Clothing
description: As a child I had a passion for Albert Payson Terhune's dog stories. I was 8 or 9 when I began to read incessantly. When the weather was fair I carried my book up to a little platform in the buttonwood tree in our backyard. At night I crouched in bed with the covers pulled over my head and a lamp under with me nearly burning off my eyebrows. That was to keep the light from showing under the door and alerting my parents. I read dozens of bookssome Mark Twain, Toby Tyler and the Circus, wartime junk like Yank in the R.A.F.hut only Terhune's tales of noble collies remained in my memory past childhood.

title: KALIADES IS HERO
description: A 34yard field goal by Paul Kaliades with 54 seconds to play gave Columbia a 3129 victory at Baker Field yesterday and ended Dartmouth's 15game winning streak, and stretched to improbable length the cliffhanger sagas both teams have been creating all season.

title: Et Al.
description: England's distinguished critic is best known in America for his books on modern literature; but he started, and continues, to work in the English Renaissance. Among his essays in this collection are a fine one on Milton, and a splendid study of the topos, or theme, of the Banquet of Sense. The pieces are written with such clarity and force that the nonspecialist can share in their learning.

title: Music
description: ARROGANT? Jesus, was I arrogant, violinist Pinchas Zukerman mumbles in between mouthfuls of scrambled eggs and toasted bagels served by his wife. Eugenia. But I had a reason to be, I guess. It was put in my head that I was good and, of course, after a while you start believing it. I didnt have the emotional support to know there was so much I had to learn.

title: Fire Delays Opera
description: A small, smoky fire in a telephone booth interrupted last night's performance of The Barber of Seville at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. The fire, which occurred at 9:30 P.M. and was quickly put out, briefly forced the patrons out of the third balcony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbia Soccer Winner
description: Francis N'jie, a Columbia cocaptain, scored all of his team's goals to pace the Lions to a 32 soccer victory over Dartmouth yesterday. Columbia's triumph raised its Ivy League wonlost record to 23. Dartmouth dropped its fifth league contest without a victory.

title: Lassie
description: In 1938, shortly after poor health had put an end to Albert Payson Terhune's collie stories, The Saturday Evening Post published a short story by Eric Knight called Lassie ComeHome. The book version appeared in 1940 and has now been reissued (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $4.95) in an attractive 30thanniversary edition.

title: Miss Cohen Plans Bridal
description: Miss Rebecca Cohen and Bernard Berk plan to be married next August.

title: Education
description: The state Board of Regents seems to have set the stage for a thorough review of the control structure of New York City's sprawling, decentralized school system.

title: EssexUnion
description: Walt Beriont, a slick quarterback with an accurate arm, increased his touchdownpass total for 1971 to 15 yesterday as he sparked unbeatenbuttied Linden to a 218 victory over victoryless Clark Regional at Clark.

title: Shop Talk
description: Today's casual way of dressing calls for a new kind of jewelry, and jewelers are ready to fill the demand. Both Georg Jensen and Van Cleef & Arpels have collections of chunky gold pieces that would go as well with sweaters and skirts as with tailored eyeing garb. The Jensen group, called Leogryph (after a mythological animal of ancient Persia), consists of antiquities in modern settings of 22karat gold. They have been devised by a 31yearold designer named Helen Woodhull who has been a collector since she was 7 years old.

title: Floridians Rout Condors
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 6 (AP) Ron Franz, who had not played in five games and did not play in the first half, tallied 17 secondhalf points as the Floridians downed the Pittsburgh Condors, 136121, tonight.

title: A Question Of Madsess
description: IN early May, 1970, I was asked by the director of the Obninsk Psychiatric Clinic, Y. V. Kiryushin, to come for a talk about my elder son, Aleksandr. (Having reached the socalled awkward age, Aleksandr's conduct both at school and at home had, for the last couple of years, decidedly changed for the worse. His general behavior was what would be called hippy abroad.) Since I had previously consulted with Kiryushin about Aleksandr and since the director had every reason to check on the boy's development, I was not par

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Much consumer discontent across the country can be laid on the doorsteps of advertising that promises more than a product can deliver.

title: An Energy Threat?
description: What national problem is more pressing than the energy crisis? Why not assemble leaders of the electric, gas, oil, coal and nuclear industries along with top Administration spokesmen to talk things over informally?

title: John Franklin Campbell, Editor, Dies
description: JohnnFranklin Campbell, the 31yearold managing editor of Foreign Policy magazine and author of The Foreign Affairs 1Fudge Factory, died last night in St. Vincent's Hospital of an obstruction in his throat. There Were no further immediate details of the circumstances of the death. Mr. Campbell lived at 44 Horatio Street.

title: IN THE NATION
description: OAKLAND, Calif.You can send a girl to Vassar for less than you can send her to Ventura, says Robert Keidgord of the Bay Area Social Planning Council. So what? So Ventura happens to be a training center for young women offenders in California, which operates the thirdlargest prison system in the world.

title: Americans in Italy
description: MILAN, ItayWhen 24yearold Renata Angelini sat down with a sheaf of papers before an electronic calculator in the staff room of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. one recent morning, the firm's accountants watched with a mixture of delight and wonder.

title: Union Upsets Middlebury As Albano Excels, 21 to 12
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 6An undermanned Union team upset Middlebury, 2112, today on a windy and chilly field.

title: Health Care Delivery: New Medical School Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Officials of the nation's financially strapped medical schools, having decided to end what they view as the ivory tower isolation of medical education, grappled in 168 sessions last week with ways to improve the system by which their physician graduates prescribe medical care for Americans.

title: The venereal disease pandemic
description: LOS ANGELES.

title: Spain Arrests 8 Rightistg After Raid on Picasso Exhibit
description: MADRID, Nov. 6The Spanish police made eight arrests early this morning lifter an extreme rightwing group raided an art gallery last night, destroying or stealing 24 Picasso engravings.

title: Can Monkey escape Prof. McWhirter, the animal collector?
description: Many are the recent adult novels that seem to have been written with a calculating eye on Hollywood. Now here is a new children's book by the author of Mary Poppins, and I couldn't help thinking of its cinematic possibilities.

title: Arab Group Offers Jackson $1Million if He Shifts stand
description: An ArabAmerican organization said yesterday that it would give Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, $1million in campaign funds if he shifted his position on the Middle East from proIsrael to a stand for better AmericanArab relations, The Associated Press reported.

title: Stanford Professor May Face Ouster
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 6After a sixweek hearing, seven senior professors at Stanford. University are deciding if they should recommend the dismissal of a tenured faculty colleague accused by the university of fomenting disorder.

title: Television
description: THE talk shows, trying to raise their beerdrinking viewers to the ginandtonic level, are bringing more and more authors before the viewing public. However, those authors who get to talk to Johnny and Mery and Dick and David aren't exactly threats to crack even the humblest of the Great Books reading lists. Suppose, instead of trading oneliners with the likes of Jacqueline Susann, Erich Segal and Dr. David Reuben, the hosts had to interview real authors? They might find it a little more challenging to handle the heavies. Imagine:

title: Amtrak Will Dedicate Metropark in Jersey
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe and Amtrak's president, Roger Lewis, have announced plans to dedicate Metropark, a suburban parkandride railroad station along the route of the Metroliners in northern New Jersey, this Thursday.

title: A pizza of your own
description: Storebought pizza has its points, but if you make a pie of your own at home, you not only impress your friends and family, but you can take advantage of the situation a cook too. You're in charge, which means that you can pick quality ingredientsItalian tomatoes, fresh basil, cheeseand you can pick any topping your fantasy suggests.

title: Local
description: Alert defensive play was the key yesterday as powerful Bayside, untied and unscored upon, notched its sixth victory of the season in turning back John Adams, 160, in a Public Schools Athletic League Division I game at Wilson Field, Baisley Park, Queens.

title: PROXMIRE STATES HE WILL NOT RUN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov, 6 Senator William Proxmire announced today that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for President.

title: He fought the enemies of the establishment
description: Adrian Mitchell adds himself to a growing list of writers who are cautious prophets foretelling the near future. The Bodyguard, set in the Britain of Orwell's 1984, purports to be the ramblings of the title character  a secular age's most ardent disciple  though that announcement is the author's. washing of the hands, leaving us to decide the fate of the book's botched prose.

title: Two Goats Thrive in Test Of Living Beneath Ocean
description: MARSEILLES, France, Nov. 4  A goat named Kiwi took its daily ration of one cigarette from Dr. Jacques Chouteau and swallowed it with evident pleasure. Its fine appetite, and that of a stablemate feeding nearby, marked the success of an experiment aimed to increase man's ability to live and work far under the sea.

title: In Sothebyland the graphs go up
description: Remember when art appreciation meant simply the study of art for itsyou should pardon the expressionesthetic value? Well today, thanks in no small part to the efforts of Sotheby & Co., the international art auction house, the term now also refers to the monetary value of artthat is, its propensity to rise in price. (In Sothebyland, the graphs always go up.)

title: Reader's Report
description: The better to understand contemporary West German society, the protagonist of this dadaistic novel has his brain amputated. Hehehe!as they say in the horror comics. Mr. Herhaus is full of terminal jokes like this. Clemens Blumenschein, the chap who surrenders his brain, enters the world with the immediate ability to talk. His mother's reaction is instinctive. (Get him out of the house.) Clemens shows few other signs of genius, but eventually becomes an advertising man and a corporate executive.

title: Temple Romps by 4013
description: KINGSTON, R. I., Nov. 6 (AP) Temple scored touchdowns the first five times it had the ball and coasted to a 4013 victory over Rhode Island today.

title: CHINESE GIVE THANT DETAILS ON ARRIVAL
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6United Nations spokesmen today said that Secretary General Thant was informed in a cablegram from Peking this morning of the time and place at which Kua Liang, the head of a sixman advance party, will arrive in New York City Monday.

title: Suit Planned To Compel Housing at Mitchel Field
description: MINEOLA, L. LA court suit to force Nassau. County and the Town of Hempstead to develop a comprehensive plan for the development of Mitchel Field that will include substantial housing will be filed by a group that was responsible for a recent New Jersey court ruling voiding an entire local zoning ordinance in Madison Township.

title: TENANTS PREPARE A NATIONAL DRIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6In the early afternoon, delegates to the annual convention of the National Tenants Organization unexpectedly took to the streets in a noisy demonstration.

title: Du Pont May Cede Control of Papers
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6 Recent activity indicates that the du Pont family may be ready to loosen its centurylong grip on this city's two newspapers, the most influential in Delaware.

title: More High Unemployment?
description: Unemployment, which has been one of the nagging problems of the Nixon economic stabilization program, seems likely to continue at relatively high levels for several months, according to a cross section of economists, opinion researchers and placement officials.

title: TOLEDO CAPTURES 32D IN ROW, 238
description: DEKALB, Ill., Nov. 6 (AP)The quarterback, Chuck Ealey, raced to a 72yard touchdown on the first play of the second half today to erase a 60 deficit and lead Toledo to the second longest collegiate football winning streak, 32 games, with a triumph over stubborn Northern Illinois.

title: Preps
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass., Nov. 6  Gil Timm, Williston's quarterback, put on a aerial show today as Williston handed WilbrahamMonson its first defeat, 5630.

title: Et Al.
description: A young defense lawyer's account of five cases (he participated in them all) that touch on aspects of civil libertiesfreedom of expression, the right to vote, the rights of welfare recipients. Among the defendants were Timothy Leary and Lenny Bruce. Garbus writes smoothly and generally has overcome the traditional stiffness of courtroom narrative; moreover, although the book lacks cohesiveness, each account has its legal and human interest. On the whole, entertaining and illuminating.

title: Et AL
description: Yes, Virginia, there is a Mafia; and if you don't know by now what they do, turn to Nicholas Gage's book. A veteran investigative reporter, now with The Times, Gage names names and figures. This is a nononsense, nosentimentality picture of the octopuslike organization that reaches not only into narcotics, loansharking and numbers but legitimate businesses as well. Mr. Gage gives the impression of a man who knows what he is talking about. A good antidote to Honor Thy Father.

title: The first Congressman from Harlem
description: The political style of America's black leaders varies as much as the style of its white leaders. It ranges from the softspoken businesslike pragmatist to the exhibitionistic, backslapping demagogue, with infinite variation between these polar extremes. White leadership in this century has had numerous examples of the exhibitionistic demagogue, especially among the urban ethnic politicians (Irish, Jewish, Italian, Polish) and among whiteracist, Protestant leaders in the South. This type has also existed among Negro leaders in this century, primarily among those who emanate from the racially segregated urban quarters thatdeveloped outside the. South consequent to the mass migration of Southern blacks from World War I onward.

title: Thant Gets Transfusions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 6 (AP)Secretary General Thant has received blood transfusions for a bleeding duodenal ulcer, the United Nations reported today. A bulletin also said he was making good progress and that intestinal bleeding has stopped. Mr. Thant has been in Leroy Hospital since Tuesday.

title: Speidels Have Child
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6A daughter was born on Oct. 20 to Dr. and Mrs. John Joseph Speidel in the George Washington University Hospital here. Mrs. Speidel Is the former Miss Brook Seawell, daughter of Donald Seawell, president of The Denver Post, and Mrs. Seawell of New York and Denver. The child has been named Sabrina Brett. Her father is a physician.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONSThe mood here last week was a mixture of suspense and pentup emotion as the delegates awaited the arrival of the Communist Chinese delegation.

title: Pakistani Officials Continue Meeting With Chou Enlai
description: PEKING, Nov. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)  Premier Chou Enlai held a second round of talks today with a Pakistani delegation headed by Zulfikar All Bhutto, special envoy of President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan.

title: Israel: The Impossible'
description: JERUSALEM, IsraelThe three million citizens of Israel face economic problems of staggering dimensions, but Government and business leaders believe that whatever happens, the future can never be as grim as the past.

title: The Leaf
description: The leaves come down, the glory of the autumn trees drifting across lawn and meadow, rustling at the roadside. For a time that unnegotiable wealth of gold and rubies will gleam and glint in the sunlight and whisper in the breeze. Then frost and rain will dull the colors and still the restlessness. The leaves will blanket the earth and slowly become again a part of the soil from which they grew.

title: Et Al.
description: Except for declaring Paris to be worth a Mass and promulgating the Edict of Nantes, France's Henry IV is little known, or cared about by Englishspeaking people. To the French, however, he's in a class with Napoleon, a warm character about whom legends have clustered, the man who laid the groundwork for the Bourbon years (the most glorious in France's history). Because works on Henry in English are few, this book is useful; because Desmond Seward writes well and uses his many sources carefully, it is important.

title: Science
description: It was Halloween, and last Sunday radio station WKBW in Buffalo presented an appropriately chilling newscast. Its reporters, seemingly in the field, described in frightening detail the depredations of a band of hideous Martians who allegedly had landed in the Buffalo suburb of Grand Island.

title: Seminar Aloft for Envoys Urges Hijacking Treaties
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 6In one of the most unusual flights in airline history, United Nations delegates from more than 80 countries. and 18 airline crew members who have experienced hijackings were flown here today in a chartered jumbo jet in an effort to stimulate effective world action against hijacking and sabotage.

title: SEOUL ANNOUNCES VIETNAM PULLOUT
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 6 President Park Chung Hee announced today that 10,000 South Korean troops would be brought home from South Vietnam, beginning next month. The withdrawal of these troops, is scheduled to be completed by next June, in the first phase of a plan to withdraw all 48,000 South Koreans now stationed in that country.

title: Farewell Party Runs 2d
description: Tinajero, Rafael Escudero's excellent campaigner, impressed the crowd of 40,859 at Aqueduct yesterday with his speed and courage.

title: A decent man, but not a big one
description: Whether or not Estes Kefauver was, as Joseph Bruce Gorman claims, the most authenticand most successfulmaverick in American political history, the late Senator from Tennessee can at least be judged a good public servant. So perhapsbut only perhapshe deserves a biography. If serving one's country well is sufficient cause for biographical attention, then writers should get busy with the lives of Ralph Yarborough, Wild Bill Langer, Albert Gore, Paul Douglas, Wayne Morsein fact, when you start making the list, it's amazing to recall how many men of strong and reasonably high character have served in our time in that ignoble clot called Congress.

title: A County in California Offers Divorce by Mail
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., Nov. 6 (UPI)You now can get a divorce by mail in Contra Costa County.

title: Buddy and Angela have trouble and each other
description: This book begins: You be different from the dead. All them tombstones tearing up the ground, look like a little city, like a small Manhattan . . . Cemetery let them lie there belly close. . . .

title: Chile Prepares for Castro
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 6 (AP)A dozen bodyguards and the protocol officer of the Cuban Foreign Ministry have arrived in Santiago to prepare for the imminent visit to Chile of Prime Minister Fidel Castro.

title: ROME SYNOD ENDS INA 10787 SPLITON CELIBACY ISSUE
description: ROME, Nov. 6  The third Synod of Bishops ended here today with a refusal by delegates to close the door to the possibility of ordaining married men as Roman Catholic priests.

title: Two Calls on One Phone
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 (AP)The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania will offer a service that will tell a person talking on his phone that he has a call waitingfor $3amonth extra. Under the new service a person already on the phone receives a signal alerting him to an incoming call. He can then depress the hook to put the first party on hold and answer the second call, and can alternate back and forth between parties by using the hook in the same manner.

title: Clashes at U.S. Consulate
description: ST. JOHN'S Newfoundland, Sunday, Nov. 7 (Reuters)Hundreds of demonstrators clashed with the police tonight on the grounds of the United States Consulate.

title: Claudio Bruno to Wed Miss Claudia Lazzaro
description: Miss Claudia Lazzaro and Claudio Bruno, who are studying for doctorates at Princeton University, will be married Dec. 18 in the university chapel.

title: Idaho Upsets Weber State On Lateral in Last Minute
description: OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 6 (UN)Idaho capitalized on a 64yard razzledazzle play with 43 seconds remaining today to knock 10thrated. Weber State out of the Big Sky title picture with a 2420 victory.

title: Penn State Soccer Victor
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 6Penn State all but clinched a National Collegiate soccer tournament bid today with a 90 rout of Temple. Rick Allen and Chris Bahr each netted three goals. Bahr is the son of Temple's coach, Walter Bahr.

title: Juilliard and Manhattan Present New Sessions and Haieff Works
description: Since the Juilliard School moved to Lincoln Center and the Manhattan School of Music took over the Claremont Avenue premises vacated by Juilliard, both have expanded their presentations of concerts and operas and have have given premieres of several new works.

title: Lunokhod Data Expected To Help Define Moon's Age
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6 (AP)A Russian scientist says that Lunokhod 1, the Soviet robot moon car, has collected valuable data that will help determine the moon's age.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A Friend of the Small Retailer
description: Louis Russek, chairman of Healthtex, Inc., a prestigious infant and children's wear manufacturer, does not envision himself as a champion of the small merchant, but it appears that he is a good friend of the Mama and Papa stores, specialty stores and others competing with the giant chains and discount stores.

title: Medical Center Grants
description: The Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn has received $2,247,566 for research and training grants. Funds will provide for eight new projects, 30 renewals and 14 supplements of existing programs. The projects include research on cancer, coronary thrombosis, and arthritis as well as training in such specializations as radiology, endrocrinology and psychiatry.

title: Educational Academy To Run Brooklyn Council
description: The Academy for Educational Development, a nonprofit research and consulting company, has been hired to operate the Brooklyn Institutional Council.

title: Nassau North
description: Farmingdale indicated yesterday that it would be one of the teams to beat in the Nassau County football playoffs when it crushed previously undefeated Port Washington, 266. The victory gave Farmingdale (60) the championship of North Shore Division I. Port claimed the second spot with a 51 wonlost record.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Criminals At Large
description: The thing about Tony Hillerman's THE FLY ON THE WALL (Harper & Row, $5.95) is this: here is a working newspaperman who does not Brink, who does not put a press pass in his hatband and yell Cotton of the Tribune, who does not play poker in 24hour stretches, who does not have girls dangling from each finger of both hands, and who does not doublecross the opposition to get a story.

title: Ali's Goodwill Trip A Smashing Failure
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 6 (AP)  Some 15,000 fight fans booed and hooted after the former world heavyweight champion, Muhammad Ali, sparred 10 rounds Friday night.

title: ARMY CONTINUES ITS RUTGERS HEX
description: WEST POINT, Nov. 6 Three field goals by Jim Barclay, a sophomore kicker from Chattanooga, Tenn., helped Army gain a 30747 victory Byer. Rutgers today before 39,841 chilled fans in Miehie Stadium.

title: Profit Sought From Error
description: The corporation's draft prospectus asserts that no member of the board has any expertise in the field in which it will work.

title: Earth Day Activists Here Still at Work
description: Every day is Earth Day in the attic of 235 East 49th Street. Under high, sloping ceilings and a haze of cigarette smoke, some young people who want to do more about pollution than hold the yearly spectacular have been planning projects and getting action, at their rented headquarters on the 12th floor of the New York Theological Seminary.

title: PAY PACT SIGNED BY PENNSYLYANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 6 Pennsylvania has signed its first collective bargaining contract with a union representing 17,500 bluecollar workers, most of them in highway maintenance. The move apparently ends political patronage as a factor in employment.

title: OREGON CONQUERS AIR FORCE, 2314
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Cole., Nov. 6 (UPI)Oregon used a combination of scoring methods today to overtake and defeat the Air Force Academy, 2314.

title: Anne Goodwin Sykes Engaged To Anthony MacLeod Hoffman
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 6 The engagement of Miss Anne Goodwin Sykes to Anthony MacLeod Hoffman, son of Carl T. Hoffman of New York and Livingston Manor, N. Y., and Mrs. Janet Hoffman of Sands Point, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Macrae Sykes of Glen Cove.

title: Albert L. Fairbanks, Dies; Radio and TV Entertainer
description: NUTLEY, N. J., Nov. 6Albert L. (Tiny) Fairbanks, former radio and television entertainer, died yesterday at his home, 449 Kingsland Avenue. His age was 65.

title: MISTAKES COSTLY
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6 Eric (The Flea) Allen scored twice on short plunges as Michigan State turned two Ohio State errors into touchdowns today to upset the Buckeyes, 1710, in a cold, steady rain.

title: Fran Ellen needs to love and be loved in return
description: When it comes to children, there are some situations most of us would rather not contemplate. Such as what does a 10yearold girl do in order to withstand the stress that difficult life situations places on her? Adults create what psychologists call escape mechanisms, emotional insulation; children (and this is perhaps frightening) can create them too. This is what The Bears' House is about.

title: U.S.C. RUNS TOPPLE WASH. STATE, 3020
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (UPI) Lou Harris returned a kickoff 84 yards for a score and added two more touchdowns today to carry the University of Southern California to a 3020. Pacific8 victory over Washington State.

title: Books:
description: THE FUNNY MONEY GAME. By Andrew Tobias. 219 pages. Playboy Press. $6.95.

title: M'CAREY IS TIMED IN 12:25 FOR RUN
description: Kevin McCarey of Cathedral Prep posted the second fastest time ever run at Van Cortlandt Park when he captured the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association crosscountry title by 90 yards yesterday.

title: Preps
description: EXETER, N. H., Nov. 6 Exeter ran up a 3713 lead early in the fourth period today and then coasted to a 3731 victory over the Tufts Freshmen. It was Exeter's fifth victory in six games.

title: Aussie Having Troubles
description: ABERAVON, Wales, Nov. 6 (Reuters)Bob Hewitt of South Africa and England's Virginia Wade took the finals of the third Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today.

title: AROUND THE
description: A word on tree transplanting. Postpone moving of thinbarked trees such as beech, Japanese maple, dogwood and birch until spring. Otherwise, any of the deciduous trees can be moved now that the leaves are dropping. Move lilacs, forsythia, viburnum, weigela, privet, too.

title: Preps
description: SOUTH BYFIELD, Mass., Nov. 6Kim Burns and Chris Grundberg scored touchdowns today as St. Mark's used a lastperiod score to edge Gov. Dummer, 147.

title: Nixon, in Gallup Poll, Increases Lead Over Muskie to 43%45%
description: President Nixon holds a clear and widening lead in the latest Gallup poll over Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, who is widely regarded as the leading contender for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Mississippi Wins, 2827
description: TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 6 (AP)Tampa's Buddy Carter threw passes of 93 and 40 yards to Mark Wakefield in the late moments of the game tonight, but then missed a pass for 2 extra points as Mississippi gained a 2827 victory.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Few Postcards, Plenty of Sights, And No Guided Tours in Kinshasa
description: REMEMBER when Volkswagen owners used to honk at each other like members of a select fraternity? Being a tourist here in Kinshasa inspires the same sort of camaraderie.. Therearen't many of you, and the sight of a map in someone's pocket at the next table in a restaurant is all the invitation one needs to strike up a conversation and swap stories about canceled reservations, boats that left without you and hotel rooms without toilet seats.

title: 8OAR ROWING WON BY COAST GUARD
description: The United, States Coast Guard Academy of New London, Conn., swept to victory in all three eightoared events today in the election weekend regatta of the New York Rowing Association. Th race course was rowed from Orchard Beach in the Bronx to the lower New Rochelle harbor because of windy conditions with the finish at Glen Island.

title: OKLAHOMA DOWNS MISSOURI BY 203
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 6 (UPI) Highscoring Oklahoma was held to its lowest point production of the season today by an inspired Missouri defensive team. In winning, 203, the Sooners took advantage of a 70yard return with a blocked field goal attempt and a 44yard pass for a touchdown.

title: Coins
description: A MEDALLION honoring Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Visiting Nurse Service and the Henry Street Settlement, has been issued by the Hall of Fame for Great Americans at New York University. The medal is the 76th released in a continuing series commemorating the work of outstanding Americans. Part of the proceeds from the sale of these commemoratives is used to help maintain the shrine on the N.Y.U. campus.

title: The Last Word: A Nobel for Neruda
description: A spot check on Oct. 22 at just one of the leading bookstores on Fifth Avenue produced very little evidence of excitement over the award of the Nobel Prize for Literature to the greet Chileen poet Pablo Neruda. Specifically: The paperback section offered two copies of one translation under the translator's name and one very tom and battered copy of another under Neruda's. In the hardcover section: nothing. And no display whatsoever.

title: State Leaders Weigh Cuts in Services
description: Governor Rockefeller and leaders of the Republicancontrolled Legislature agreed yesterday that the state's fiscal crisis might require cuts in state services and state aid to schools and local governments and/or increased revenues.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Pushing the Town Around
description: YOU don't have to go back 28 years to admire On the Town. It's not more than 12 spice it turned up in a modest Off Broadway production and seemed a charmer. At the Imperial, though, they haven't been nice enough to it.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DUBLIN, Nov. 6 (AP)A bomb was hurled from an automobile today at an apartment building here owned by a British Insurance company. People were thrown from their beds by the explosion and windows were shattered, but there were no injuries.

title: The Vote
description: Lo, the manyvoiced oracle has spoken in polling booths across the nation and now the politicians have come forth to offer their interpretations. Out of the chaos of hundreds of races with contradictory results, these pragmatic men examine the Delphic decrees for trends and omens of the Presidential election in the wings. And what in their view did last Tuesday on Mount Parnassus really mean? Here is what some of them were saying:

title: Thomas Brills Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Emil Austin Brill of Manhatan on Oct. 28 in University Hospital. Mrs. Brill is the former Miss Carol Ann Braverman. The child, whose father is treasurer of Centrex, Inc., optics distributor and exporter in New York, is named Jeffrey Austin.

title: NICKLAUS SLUMPS TO 73, LEADS BY 5
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 6 (AP)Jack Nicklaus held a fivestroke lead today after shooting a oneoverpar 73 in the third round for a 54hole total of 204 in the $28,000 Dunlop international golf tournament.

title: WALL STREET
description: If some of those new 1971 low prices in the stock market last week looked familiar, there was a good reason. A lot of them matched, or were under, the lows set at the bottom of the 1970 bear market, numbers many investors didn't expect to see again.

title: Weathercock to Race Aussie Boat
description: Weathercock, a 25foot Class C catamaran owned by Harry Noble of New Canaan, Conn., has qualified to challenge Australia for the Little America's Cup next February.

title: Ashe Beats Gimeno and Kodes Tops Dreysdale in Swedish Semifinal
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 6 (Reuters)  Arthur Ashe and Jan Kodes moved into the final of the $50,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament today with victories of a widely contrasting character.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: T.C.U. WINS, 17 TO 6, FROM TEXAS TECH
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 6 (AP)Texas Christian, its stadium flag at half staff in respect to its late coach, Jim Pittman, recorded a 176 Southwest Conference triumph today over Texas Tech.

title: TEST SUCCESSFUL, NIXON IS INFORMED
description: KEYBISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 6 Minutes after the controversial underground nuclear testi on Amchitka Island today word was flashed to President Nixon at his weekend home here that there had been no complications.

title: Coins
description: THE third medal of the Indian Tribal Series honoring American Indians was released recently. The date of issue coincided with the 100th anniversary of the White Mountain Fort Apache Reservation in Arizona, air event being celebrated by a colorful program this year. Apache headquarters is in Whiteriver.

title: AUBURN CONQUERS MISS. STATE, 3021
description: AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 6 (AP) Pat Sullivan teamed with Terry Beasley for two touchdown passes and threw another to Dick Schmalz today to give Auburn a 1021 football victory over Mississippi State, the team with the best pass defense in the Southeastern Conference.

title: Westchester
description: John Jay won its 18th straight football game and Pleasantville its 16th in a row yesterday to extend the county's two longest winning streaks.

title: Text of the Vatican Synod's Document Reaffirming the Doctrine of Celibacy for Priests
description: ROME, Nov. 6Following is an unofficial translation from Latin of the section of the document on the priesthood voted on by the third Synod of Bishops that explains the delegates' reasons for reaffirming the tradition of celibacy for LatinRite priests.

title: Stanford Rolls to Rose Bowl Assignment With a 209 Conquest of U.C.L.A.
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 6 (UPI)Don Bunce ran for one touchdown and passed for another today as Stanford defeated the University of California, Los Angeles, 209, and won a Rose Bowl berth for the second straight year.

title: KINGS POINT BEATS HOFSTRA TEAM, 177
description: KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 6  The Merchant Marine Academy scored on two pass plays and a field goal to defeat Hofstra, 177, before 5,400 fans today.

title: ECHOES OF NADER HEARD IN MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6Two Soviet Ralph Nader have read the fine print in the contracts under which service industries cater to the public and have found that the consumer is virtually helpless under the law.

title: 2 Escaped Convicts Surrender in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Nov. 6 (UPI)Two armed escaped convicts surrendered to the police today in an apartment where they had taken three hostages, raising to 13 the number of hostages they took and then released since their escape from prison Thursday.

title: Preps
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Nov. 6  Ed Kuchar, the Choate quarterback, took to the air in the second half today to rally his team from 250 deficit to a 2825 decision over Lawrenceville. Kuchar hit Ralph DeLucia on five consecutive passes to drive his team to a touchdown on the final play of the game.

title: Panel to Select L.I.U. Head
description: A 15member panel has been assembled by the chancellor pf Long Island University, Albert BushBrown, to screen and select candidates for the presidency of the university's main campus in Brooklyn.

title: A Grocery Owner In Williamsburg Slays 2 in Holdup
description: The owner of a grocery in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn shot and killed two holdup men last night after wresting a revolver from one of them.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn 1959, William H. Rehnquist wrote that the Senate should thoroughly inform itself of the judicial philosophy of a Supreme Court nominee before voting to confirm him. Now an Assistant Attorney General and one of President Nixon's two nominees to fill vacancies on the Supreme Court, Mr. Rehnquist spent last Wednesday and Thursday proving to the Senate Judiciary Committee that it is impossible to find out about a nominee's judicial philosophy by crossexamining him.

title: National Notes
description: When the Knapp Commission adjourned its public hearings into police corruption a week ago, its counsel, Michael Armstrong, said that he fully expected a string of indictments to follow. In two separate actions last week, a Federal grand jury indicted a dozen New York City policemen.

title: Mexico, Land of the Pistolero, Plans a Strict GunControl Law
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6 Tho Mexican Government has proposed a tough new guncontrol law aimed at curbing a wave of crimes and ridding the country of its pistolero image.

title: Daily Double Doubled By L.I. Bridge Players
description: WESTBURY, L. I.Roosevelt Raceway resounded last weekend with talk of doubles and screams about fixes, but the performers were human, not equine. Contracts were doubled and players were fixed by the fates, and the occasion was the annual Long Island Regional Championships, the biggest bridge event ever staged in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Pompidou to Visit Africa
description: PARIS, Nov. 6 (Reuters)President Pompidou of France will pay official visits to the African republics of Niger and Chad from Jan. 24 to 28, a presidential spokesman has announced:

title: Anniversary Speech in Moscow Hails Trips Abroad by Kremlin's Leaders
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6A, member of the ruling Soviet Politburo, in a traditional speech today for the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Voiced confidence that recent foreign visits and consultations by Kremlin leaders had strengthened the international position of the Soviet Union and its allies.

title: NORTHWESTERN TOPS MINNESOTA, 41 TO 20
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 6 (AP) Al Robinson and Randy Anderson scored two touchdowns each today in powering Northwestern to a 4120 homecoming victory over Minnesota.

title: Cadbury Schweppes
description: Since their merger in March 1969, two Englishbased companies, the Cadbury Group, Ltd., founded in 1824, and Schweppes, Ltd., which began operations in 1794, have increased their revenue overseas and expect the trend to accelerate, despite the United States import surcharge.

title: Eleanor Clarkson Hall Is Married
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 6Miss Eleanor Clarkson Hall and Bruce Stuart Clevenger were married here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Michael Kendall.

title: A Goulash of Ghouls
description: There is a subtle witchery to a child's experience. The curious child sees and hears what he may never be. It's an almost psychotic hallucinatory spell of exploration and sensory encounter through which children are always reorganizing themselves. They will remain sensate, or else they will be lost. They must be observant, or they might disappear. Each step forward into nature is a trip, an initiation. The Shades, for readers 9 to 12, is a superior children's story on a magical theme. The privacy of the momentary, the secret of a small soul's awakening to the possibilities within himself are what Betty Brock's book depicts so neatly. It is not accomplished on broomsticks or under dunce caps, but is a series if imaginary truths accumulated and accrued, as palpable as light mists on early morning grass, and as subtle as the late September sunlight across a lawn. Its protagonist is Hollis, 8 years old. He would like to be friendly, but his parents have gone off to Europe for the summer and packed him away to the dilapidated Connecticut estate of his mother's former college roommate, Emily, an artist.

title: CORNELL TOPS IVY BY BEATING BROWN
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 6Cornell moved into the Ivy League football lead today by defeating Brown, 217, in a game that had an unusual sequence.

title: So You Are Another Alice
description: Alice in Wonderland was Lewis Carroll's first book for children and some think the greatest children's book ever written. What is more, the way it came into being is almost as entrancing as the book itself. On a golden afternoon in 1862, a shy Oxford don, the Rev. Charles Lutwidge Dodgson (Lewis Carroll's real name) took the three little daughters of his college dean on a boat trip. As they rowed languidly along in the bright sunlight, he created the world of wonderland for their amusement. Later, his favorite of the three, Alice Liddell, asked him to write the story down. He did, and ultimately published a somewhat enlarged version of it, transforming the inspiration of an idle summer hour into a literary classic.

title: When a Wife Becomes Addicted To Bazaars
description: Do you know what a bazaar woman is? No. No, she's not a weirdo. She's just the kind of a gal who can't pass that kind of a funraising activity by.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: A Fluttering Weather Vane
description: If corrugated box sales are up, can the economy be far behind?

title: $10,900 Harbison Awards Are Given to 10 Teachers
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 6The Danforth Foundation bestowed tonight Harbison Awards of $10,000 to each of 10 scholars for excellence in teaching.

title: Roughriders Win, Gain Final
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, Nov. 6 (UPI)George Reed scored twice on 1yard plunges and Ron Lancaster threw three touchdown passes today as the Saskatchewan Roughriders defeated the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, 3423, to reach the final of Canada's Western Football Conference.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: E.N. Kaplan Fiance Of Susan Workman
description: TEANECK, N. J., Nov. 6Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Workman of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Workman, to Eugene Neal Kaplan, son of Civil Court Judge and Mrs. Louis I. Kaplan of New York and Atlantic Beach, L. I.

title: Reform Study Says Synagogue Lacks a Sense of Community
description: LOS ANGELES; Nov. 6A comprehensive study of problems affecting American Reform Judaism says that the synagogue, instead of providing a sense of Jewish community is playing the role of a service station that simply dispenses rites and ceremonies.

title: Preps
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 6St. George's scored in every period today to defeat Portsrnouth Abbey, 3620, and earri its first victory of the season after five defeats. Eric McFadden scored twice in the first period to get the Dragons started.

title: LAIRD CONCLUDES VISIT TO VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 6Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird concluded three days of meetings here today and indicated that the United States, was ready to accelerate the pace of its troop withdrawals.

title: Elizabeth Grubb Wed To Peter Lumb of Navy
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 6  Miss Elizabeth Bodden Grubb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Grubb, and Damage Controlman Peter Beaumont Lumb, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. James Lumb, also of this city, were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. William Weinhauer.

title: GEORGIA TECH HANDS NAVY 3421 SETBACK
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (UPI)Jeff Ford, setting a school record for career interceptions, sparked Georgia Tech's defense today as the Yellow Jackets beat Navy, 3421, and rose above the .500 mark for the first time this season.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Two great forces are at work in the world today, one driving the nations together and the other setting them apart. Everywhere it is obviousit is almost clichethat no nation can by itself control the problems of war, the arms race, money, overpopulation, hunger, disease, the drug traffic or pollution. but at the same time the spirit of nationalism and protectionism is rising, and the institutions for world cooperation like the United Nations are under severe attack.

title: Mining of U.N. Ship Laid to Pakistani Rebels
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 6Reliable sources here reported tonight that a United Nations vessel loaded with wheat intended for East Pakistani storm victims had been heavily damaged by a mine.

title: Connecticut
description: Stamford and New Canaan each notched their eighth victories without defeat yesterday and will meet for the third straight time in the Fairfield County Conference championship playoff game Nov. 20 in Stamford's Michael A. Boyle Stadium.

title: Skiing ColoradoA Fast, Easy litz From Aspen to Vail
description: DENVERI didn't come out here for two weeks of skiing in Colorado, but to ski Colorado a very different idea. Most people do it wrong: they pick one area, usually Aspen or Vail, and spend virtually all of their time at that spot with a few daytrips elsewhere. In short, they bring all of their regimentation hangups west with them. A ski vacation should be like skiing itself: loose, free and flowing.

title: 2, BAY. STATE SEATS IN HOUSE IN PERIL
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6  Gov, Francis W. Sargent is expected to sign next week a Congres. sional redistricting bill that could endanger the reelection chances of two of the state's 12 United States Representatives.

title: Let Me Tell You About New Hampshire
description: ALL New Hampshire is divided into three parts: Massachusetts, Maine and Vermont. And into two seasons: winter and fall.

title: Miss Margaret Anne Devine Wed
description: Miss Margaret Anne Devine, a financial analyst with Esso International, was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert Emmett Moore, who returned from service as an Army lieutenant in Vietnam in September and is enrolled at the Columbia University Graduate. School of Business.

title: Preps
description: SAXTONS RIVER, Vt., Nov. 6John Flynn scored today on a 70yard punt return and 96yard run, to pace Vermont Academy to a 2216 victory over Mount Hermon. It was the third victory in six games for Vermont. Walt Herbert did the scoring for the loser.

title: Carolina Black Named Judge
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 6 (UPI) Sammie Chess Jr., 37 years old, a black lawyer from High Point who estimates he has represented blacks in about 3,000 civil rights cases, was one of three men named to Superior Court judgeships this week. His appointment by Gov. Robert W. Scott Thursday makes him the highest black judicial official in North Carolina in modern times.

title: 2YEAROLD HOUND IS SELECTED BEST
description: WILKEBARRE, Pa., Nov. 6A 2yearold Afghan hound was best in show among 1,058 entries today at the 26th annual dog show of the Back Mountain Kennel Show at the Pocono Downs race track.

title: AMHERST WINS, 4229; MURPHY IS STANDOUT
description: AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 6Rick Muphy threw four touchdown passes and ran for a fifth today as Amherst boosted its wonlost record to 61 with a 4229 victory over Trinity.

title: Son Born to Mrs. Beane
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Beane of Scarsdale, N. Y., on Oct. 27 in the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. Mrs. Beane is the former Miss Eva Abramowitz of New York. The child, whose father is a labor lawyer with the firm of Poletti, Freiden, Prashker, Feldman & Gartner in New York, is named Eric Scott.

title: HOSPITALS LAGGING ON NEW PROGRAMS
description: Despite a directive by its board of directors to do so, the city hospital system has made no move to reduce patient waiting time, to testing all child patients for lead poisoning or to test all black youngsters for sickle cell anemia.
