description: NUREMBERG, Nov. 6 (Reuters)Unemployment in West Germany rose to 0.8 per cent of the work force in October from 0.7 per cent in September and 0.5 per cent in October of last year, the Federal Labor Office said. Meanwhile, Economics Minister Karl Schiller said in Berlin that West Germany could expect only modest economic growth next year, but need not fear serious unemployment.

title: Royals Beat Suns, 11095
description: CINCINATI, Nov. 6 (AP)Sam Lacey, who has been hampered by injuries, scored 17 points and pulled down 18 rebounds to pace the Cincinnati Royals to victory over the Phoenix Suns, 11095, tonight.

title: Bucks Rout Pistons, 10678
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 6 (AP)The Milwaukee Bucks, with Kareem Abdul Jabbar scoring 29 points, shook off a slow start tonight to win, 10678, from the Detroit Pistons.

title: Instant dressing
description: One of Giorgio di Sant'Angelo's newest bodysuits (far left) is of black Antron nylon and Lycra with a red, bide and yellow sunrise appliqued on the front. The other, in the same fabric, has a zippedup 6nt and an appliqud red and blue wave design. $80 each. In the S'fari Room, fourth floor, Bonwit's. The black opaque tights are by Hanes.

title: Boston U. Raises Tuition
description: BOSTON, Nov. 6 (AP)Boston University announced this week a 16 per cent increase in tuition for the 197273 academic year. Fulltime tuition will be increased from $2,090 to $2,490 for all schools and colleges except graduate dentistry and medicine.

title: DRIVE IS PLANNED ON BREAST CANCER
description: The American Cancer Society, disturbed by the continued high death rate from breast cancer, said yesterday that it would begin a major national effort to make widely available screening techniques that can detect breast cancer at its earliest, most curable stage.

title: Deputies Quell Disturbance At Los Angeles Jail Facility
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 (Reuters)Unarmed sheriff's deputies quelled a disturbance today in the Los Angeles Hall of Justice, where almost 200 prisoners had set fires and smashed fixtures in a fivehour protest over the food served at breakfast.

title: BEAM RELEASES LOANPLAN AUDIT
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that if the city's controversial Municipal Loan Program was to be continued, the Housing and Development Administration should adopt 28 recommendations contained in a management audit of the pregram conducted by his department.

title: Court Order and Dissents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Following are the order of the, Supreme Court denying the application for injunction to block the Amchitka nuclear test, a dissent by Justice William O. Douglas, and a statement on the position of Justices William J. Brennan Jr. and Thurgood Marshall:

title: the traveler's world.
description: OUTSIDE CAMP DAVID, Md. President Nixon helicoptered in here the Friday night of the weekend we had chosen to explore Catoctin National Park, which may help explain the unusual dateline. We rubbed shoulders against the No Trespassing signs and the triple fences that enclose Camp David, the official Presidential hideaway in the center and at the highest point of Catoctin Park. We saw from the highway the seemingly unmanned entrance gates and sentry box, and some of the electronic protective devices that insure Presidential privacy; and we spoke with the official who is responsible for security up to the outermost gate where the Army's selected guard units and the Secret Service take over.

title: Irish Find an Offense and Bury Pitt, 56 to 7
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6Nothing seems to rejuvenate Notre Dame faster than a football trip East.

title: GEORGETOWN VICTOR OVER FORDHAM, 309
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 Georgetown handily defeated Fordham, 30.9, today in the 31st football meeting of the teams in a series that began in 1890.

title: For those who feel the American dream has become a nightmare
description: Whether the American dream of equality, liberty and the pursuit and achievement of happiness will ever become a reality will be largely determined by the interests, vision and energy of today's young. The prospect is not promising. Because of the failure of American leadership and institutions to meet the needs of society and the just demands of its people in both domestic and foreign policy, a large segment of America's young are growing increasingly frustrated and disillusioned. They are turning either to strident rhetoric, quasi  revolutionary activity, sloganeering and sporadic violence or are dropping out into lives of private solitude and personal enjoyment. There is a clear and present danger that the needed energies for the social and political reconstruction of America will be burned out or unavailable at a time when those energies were never more needed.

title: Susan's Girl Is Next
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 6 Numbered Account, the huge 2yearold daughter of Buckpasser, raced to her eighth victory in nine starts today with a 2length victory over Susan's Girl in the $184,375 Gardenia Stakes at Garden State Park.

title: City judicial System Is Makin Little Progress in Preparing for SpeedyTrial Rule's Effective Date
description: Six months after the state's judicial leaders announced a speedytrial rulewith an effective date of May 1, 1972, to give the criminal justice system time to prepare for itthe courts and courtrelated agencies in New York City have made almost no progress in obtaining the facilities or staff members they will need to comply with it.

title: Funds for Idle Granted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) The Labor Department on Thursday followed up September's $200million emergency public service jobs allocation with a supplementary $9.9million allocation to 104 areas. The new allocations go to areas, with 6 per cent or higher unemployment.

title: Stamp
description: THE POSTAL SERVICE means business in 1972! More than 20 stamps and an unspecified number of postal cards are scheduled for issuance next year. Packages, or sets, of stamps are included in the tentative program outlined by Postmaster General Winton M. Blount, several, days before he resigned on Oct. 29.

title: TRIBESMEN GAIN IN LIBERIAN LIFE
description: MONROVIA, LiberiaOn a street corner in Monrovia there is a monument commemorating Matilda Newport, the heroine of the freed American slaves who came to West Africa in 1822 to found a new home caller Liberia.

title: Sandra Lo Grosby Plans Nuptials
description: ST. PAUL, Nov. 6Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grosby have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Lois Grosby, to Daniel Tep litz, son of Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz and Mrs. Teplitz of Woodmere, L. I.

title: Wyoming Wins, 3129, As Fox Sets Pass Mark
description: LOGAN, Utah, Nov. 6 (UPI) Gary Fox passed for two touchdowns and Randy Rudman kicked three fieldgoals today to give Wyomi a 3129 victory over Utah State.

title: Gyrocopter Popularity Soaring
description: BROOKHAVEN, L. I. They flew through the air with the greatest of ease on what looked like large metal tricycles.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: On July 12 Public Law 9254, the Emergency Employment Act, took effect. One month later the first of fiscal 1972 funds, which will total $1billion, were in the pipeline from the Department of Labor's Manpower Administration to states, cities and counties.

title: SOPHOMORES STAR IN COLGATE ROMP
description: HAMMILTON, N.Y., Nov. 6 (UPI)Tom Parr and Mark Van Eeghen, sophomores, combined for five touchdowns today and worked Colgate's wishboneT option to perfection to lead the Red Raiders to a 4724 victory over Bucknell.

title: Chess
description: IT is widely, acknowledged that the Soviet Union has by far the largest number of chessplayers of any country in the world. To estimate approximately how many they have, however, it is first necessary to define just what we mean by a chessplayer. In the United States, for example, it is estimated that there are 15,000,000 chemplayersa mysterious figure, suggested, in some way, by the number of chess sets sold. This, of course, is about as reliable a method as the.attempt would be to estimate the number of devout Mohammedans in this country through the sale of the Koran.

title: Miss Dorothy Whitmore Bride in Jersey
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Nov. 6Miss Dorothy Whitmore of Mount Tabor and James Merrill Macfarland of Roswell, N. M., a retired. Woodruff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Boetzel Woodruff, a senior at Skidmore, to Timothy Reardon McGill, a senior at Union College and the son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. title: In the Alentejo: Where the Trees Dance a Saraband Of Infinite Grace
description: MILFONTES, PortugalWhile bargainhunting for castles on your next trip abroad, you might keep your eye peeled in Portugal. There's a castle now operating as a guesthouse here whose owner snapped it up for a cool $250 back in the 1930's. For that amount today, you can move in and live like a king for about two weeks.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Fieldston rallied to defeat St. Paul's, 2214, yesterday at Fieldston. Jeff Liebster, a halfback, threw an option pass to Roger Furman for a 63yard touchdown to tie the game and then Keith Wright ran 7 yards with 1:14 remaining for the winning score. Fieldston is now 51. St. Paul's has not won.

description: MINNEAPOLIS  A severe test lies just ahead for the proposition that executive talent will flourish no matter what business a man is given to run.

title: VERMONT TRIUMPHS OVER MAINE, 1713

title: Gardens
description: THERE'S nothing more exasperating, come spring, than to discover that the equipment you stored away, with a sigh of relief last fall is dull, rusty, broken or otherwise unready for use. The time to avoid this headache is right now. The following checklist may help.

description: ATLANTA, Nov. 6 (AP)The National Alliance of Businessmen has found jobs for 720,000 disadvantaged youths during the last three years and hopes to place another 225,000 on the payroll of member companies by the end of next June.

title: BQLI Mailbag

title: WESLEYAN DEFEATED BY WILLIAMS, 27 TO 14

The Williams quarterback, John Murray, rushed for 80 yards and passed for 138 in leading the Ephmen to their sixth victory in seven games.

Lincoln College was establishedin 1865 and has an enrollment of 600. Mr. Stoltz succeeds Earl Hargett who died July 1, the day he became the school's new president.

Malle, associate dean of faculty for open admissions; Dr. Murray S. Plissner, associate dean of students; Sidney Helfant, assistant dean of the college, and Fred B. Malamet, assistant dean of faculty for evening studies, continuing education and summer session.

title: AUTO ACCIDENTS LISTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 6A high Soviet motor vehicle official, joining the growing public discussion of problems of the automobile age, has disclosed ordinarily secret figures on traffic accidents and fatalities.

title: ILLINOIS DOWNS INDIAN, 22 TO 21
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. (AP)Illinois drove for two touchdowns in the last period and ran in a 2point conversion after the last one to earn a 2221 Big Ten victory over Indiana today.

title: Young heroes and heroines as political creatures and fictional creations
description: All over the country smart sensitive young teens are waking to contemporary political reality, catching on to school as a sortingout place (greasers here, preppies thhere, freaks in the cellar, black kids nowhere), leaning toward fighting The System on behalf of an ideal. But ft's a rare child who's conquered every doubt and uncertainty. How much really, does injustice matter? If you're only a kid, what can you hope to accomplish by political action? Will a reputation as a high school rebel wreck you with Ivy Admissions deans? Should you give a damn if it does? People need help with such questionsand the recent determination of some authors of problem juveniles to try to provide it is, on the whole, admirable. Civilization begins anew with every child, and so, too, does the idea of social justice, and not to care how it begins is an act against life itself.

title: COLORADO BEATS KANSAS BY 3514
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 6 (AP)Cliff Branch, who didn't start the game because of a bruised knee, raced 85 yards on the second play of the fourth quarter today to snap a tie and spark sluggish Colorado to a 3514 victory over Kansas.

title: Black Social Workers Assail Agencies
description: Black social workers charged yesterday that the child welfare field was dominated by private agencies that were not accountable to the people they serve and that the agencies operated programs that only helped to perpetuate the institutions.

title: More process than product, more politics than philosophy
description: One of the riskiest of all literary enterprises is the book that attempts to describe and judge a President who is little more than halfway through his term in office. It would be hard enough to write such a book about a man whose philosophical and political principles were clear and firmly rooted, and who acted on these principles with a reasonable degree of consistency. It is doubly difficult, and twice as risky, to attempt such an enterprise when the subject at hand is Richard Nixon, self  described pragmatist whose domestic objectives when he came to office were at best ambiguous and who, in the last few months alone, has dramatically reversed course (much to the surprise of his allies abroad and political friends at home) on China and the economy.

title: Art
description: THE career of Morris Kantor, who is this year observing his 75th birthday, is not one that is easy to follow in the available histories of American painting. Our art historians, when they turn their attention to recent events, tend to be guided by the values of the art market and the glare of publicity  an unfortunate practice, but an understandable one. About artists who have made it, in the market and publicity sense, the materials are abundant and readily accessible. They offer no impediments to the easy flow of generalization and compartmentalization, and there is no need to risk an individual or an unpopular judgment. Our art histories simply ratify opinions lately established in the higher altitudes of salesmanship and art journalism, consigning everything else to the limbo of future research.

title: PATH Discontinuing Tokens for Cash
description: The Port of New York Authority's commuter railroad, PATH, which instituted a token system for fares in 1965, is switching back to cash.

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: North Bimini: Noboy Here But Us Bonefish
description: ALICE TOWN, North Bimini, Bahama IslandsThe End of the World bar caught my eye as I passed it on my way up King's Highwaythe dusty, palmlined main street, with wooden, pastelcolored houses that seemed blinding in the sun. After a while I worked my way back to the bar, which was once the stomping ground of Adam Clayton Powell. For old time's sake, I thought, I have to stop in. When I approached the door, though, I discovered it was padlocked. Times have changed.

title: Middle Japan Takes Dollar Shock Calmly but Fears Hard Times Lie Ahead
description: MOKA, Japan I'm not mad at President Nixon for trying to defend the dollar, the elderly innkeeper said. After all, if you're going bankrupt, you've got to do something.

title: The Best of the Illustrated Books

In this, the twentieth annual award, are two previous winners: Edward Gorey, named twice before, and Tomi Ungerer, once before.

title: Kerr on Unlikely Heroes: 3 Mill Hoar Stories

The Plymouth now houses an evening called Unlikely Heroes: 3 Philip Roth Stories, and the third of the short tales that Larry Arrick has adapted for the stage is a deeply troubling suburban nightmare in which one Eli Peck, a young lawyer, is commissioned by the other Jewish families of the community to oust a teacher and his gaggle of youngsters because they are just too Jewjsh.

title: Travel Notes: The Tourist Surtax, A Playboy Hotel, Tour for Sybarites
description: PRESIDENT NIXON'S new economic policies are hitting some tourists where it hurts the most in the pocketbook. The 10 per cent surtax on imports that went into effect Aug. 16 does not apply to travelers who restrict their purchases abroad to $100, but it does affect those who exceed this dutyfree allowance. Under the new rules, not only is the regular duty applied to all items over the $100 limit, but the 10 per cent surcharge is added. All articles should be declared at the full retail value. The duty is assessed on the wholesale value of the merchandise as determined by the examining officer, but custommade and madetoorder items are taxed at their full retail value, plus the surcharge. For example, if a tourist bought a still camera with a standard lens for $200 at retail in Japan, he would be taxed on the portion that exceeded his $100 exemption after a 40 per cent discount allowance to bring the price down to the dutiable wholesale level ($200 minus the $100 exemption leaves $100; less 40 per cent equals $60). Since the rate of duty on such cameras is 9 per cent, the initial tax would be $5.40, but the 10 per cent surtax would bring the total to $11.40. In other words, he would be paying $6 more as a result of the surtax.

title: Defeat of Ramos Is Assailed in Madrid

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6Senator George McGovern has not succeeded, if the opinion polls are to be believed, in igniting popular support for his Democratic Presidential candidacy. Now he has a new wrinkle. The objective, he is telling potential supporters, is not so much his own nomination as the liberalization of his opposition. I am writing to ask your help, not for myself, but because I have reason to believe that you and I are disturbed about the same problems and want the same solutions, the Senator declared in letters mailed last week to thousands of possible contributors.

title: Labor's PriceWatchers Here Strongly Oppose All Increases
description: The heads of the New York Central Labor Council's pricewatch organization have adopted a hard line toward President Nixon's economic stabilization program, insisting that any price increases, legal or not, are violations of the spirit of the freeze.

Based on photographs, with layout created by Jan Magnusson, the stamps were produced by photogravure by the British stamp printers, Harrison & Sons, at their High Wycombe plant.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP)  Several freshman Senators have protested the system under which money is allotted for their offices. They want more.

description: Members of the Harlem, Congress of Racial Equality, demanding the legalization of numbers betting in their community, temporarily closed down the 125th Street Offtrack Betting Corporation office yesterday.

title: Editorial Cartoon 5  No Title
description: Letters:

title: An old friend of Tom, and he had known Vivien!
description: Eliot, the generation now in college May need informing, was for 25 years what the author of Waiting for Godot is now, the deviser of a time's central myth of itself. And more: he presided over its way of receiving past literature; the custodian, therefore, of active verbal memory. And the man was inscrutable, impenetrable: a weighty, grave voice merely, but a voice not actually heard; a voice that rose and gathered in the air above printed pages, affirming the Unreal City and the burning and the huddled crowds; a voice weighing its syllables, since to slur syllable or connive at solecisms is to abandon in a dissolving time what is very nearly our last stay.

title: A Lonely Death Closes A Wornan's Lonely Life
description: June Nector died in Roosevelt Hospital last week. When she died, she was alone, and a doctor said that she had really just wasted away.

title: Voice of the Children Is Stilled
description: With all my heart, I wish the voices of these children peace and power.

title: Students See Why They Need Such Things as Decimals and Fractions
description: DENVER, Nov. 6 (AP)  Under their own corporations, students from Denver's Manual High School are running a gasoline station, remodeling a dilapidated twostory house, designing miniparks for an urban renewal area and putting down more than two miles of sidewalks.

C., and Nashville, Tenn.and he charts a sleazy itinerary for Ruby Red Jamison, who heads from her job with the Southern Bell Telephone Company for a career as a yokel troubador.

title: Et Al.
description: An English historian takes a careful look at the Robert Oppenheimer security hearings. Professor Major judiciously weighs the evidence, noting that much of the story may never be told. He concludes, not surprisingly, That Oppenheimer was a victim of antiCommunist hysteria and America's obsession with the hydrogen bomb as a guarantor of its security. Despite the painstaking research and balanced appraisal, Major's book does not add anything to Philip Stern's study or Nuell P. Davis's Lawrence and Oppenheimer.

title: Law
description: Grand juries are our only security, inasmuch as our lives cannot be drawn into jeopardy by all the malicious crafts of the devil, unless such a number of our honest countrymen shall be satisfied in the truth of the accusations.

description: Sometimes when I think about what's going on with fiction these days I'm hit with the same feeling I get entering a new time zone driving crosscountrythe time has changed but nothing has happened. A pause for orientation follows, then suddenly I realize that a lot has happened, and what has happened is precisely a change in position.

title: Bridge: Garazzo and Belladonna Top Lists for Play and Travel

This year, their activities have included an American tour, a world tour and a multitude of tournament appearances in and near Europe.

title: Girl Raped in Central Park
description: A 15yearold girl told the police yesterday that she had been forced into Central Park and raped by an armed assailant, then held at gunpoint for more than three hours, the police reported. The girl told the police that she was accosted by a youth about 18 of medium height and build, at 100th Street and Central Park West at about 1 A.M. and was forced at gunpoint to walk into the park, where she was raped.

title: I Simply Can't Agree With Ambassador Yost
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.Recent comments by my predecessor at the United Nations, Ambassador Charles W. Yost, regarding the outcome of the U.N. vote on the China admission question need rebuttal, although I am normally reluctant to engage in this sort of debate.

title: Harvey Captures Rally
description: ALMA, Mich., Nov. 7Scott Harvey of Rochester, Mich., won the Press On Regardless road rally today for the third consecutive year. Harvey, driving a Plymouth Cricket, and his navigator, Tom King, completed the grueling 1,500mile, threenight event with a 3,566point advantage. The brother team of Guy and Gilles Vanier of Quebec finished second in a Datsun.

title: End of the Line
description: They call it the weary Erie. The old ErieLackawanna's coach cars creak and sway and shudder as they brink thousands of New, Jersey commuters into New York City via Hoboken every day. These are cars with splintered rattan seats and so many years of grease and dust on the globed interior lights that they give off a mellow, brindlebrown glow. As if out of an early Wild West film, these are cars that seem to have just rattled in from witnessing the driving of the golden spike at Promontory.

title: Shop Talk

But perhaps the most exotic of all is the new Tibetan Arts and Crafts shop at 693 Madi son Avenue. The shop near 62d Street is sponsored by a corporation made up of several Tibetan families (there are only about 100 such families in the United States). In charge of the place, are Tsering Dorje and Mr. and Mrs. Lobsang Sanden. All three speak fluent English learned at school in India or during stays in Europe.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 7 (AP)Gunmen firing from a speeding car killed an offduty British soldier and seriously wounded another soldier today. The ambush occurred at Lurgan, southeast of Belfast.

title: Pakistan Politician Slain
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 7A rightwing politician recently narned by Pakistani authorities as a member of the future East Pakistan Provincial Assembly was assassinated today, allegedly by guerrillas with submachine guns.

title: Gallardo Wins Golf by Shot
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 (AP)Angel Gallardo of Spain rolled in a 22foot birdie putt on the final hole to win the Mexican Open golf tournament today and shatter Lee Trevino's attempt to take a fourth national title.

title: Construction Contracts In September Rose 26%
description: Reflecting a healthy continuing increase in building activity that became noticeable last May, the total value of contracts awarded for all kinds of construction work throughout the country in September increased 26 per cent over a year ago, the F. W. Dodge, division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported over the weekend.

title: Great Pyrenees Is Best in Show For Fifth Time
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 7Ch. Soleil Pierre de Blu Crest, the nation's topwinning Great Pyrenees, added a fifth bestinshow award to his impressive record tonight by taking the Union County Kennel Club's 32d event in the National Guard Armory. He beat out 682 other dogs.

title: 12 Artists to Play Tonight
description: A concert in celebration of the Metropolitan Museum's annual Young Artists series, will be given at the museum at 8 P.M. tonight The 12 participants, all of whom have been presented in the series since its inception in 1956, are Edward Auer, David BarIllan, Richard Goode, Erick Friedman, Joseph Kalichstein, Michael Oelbaum, Murray Perahia, Paula Robison, Arnold Steinhardt, Michael Tree, Blanca Uribe and Paul Zukofsky.

title: NIXON URGES USE OF U.S. JOB FUNDS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 7President Nixon urged the nation's governors, mayors and county officials today to act swiftly to fill 70,000 public service jobs provided for under the Emergency Employment Act of 1971.

title: Two Louisiana Reformers Win Runoff Spots in a 17Man Race for Democratic Gubernatorial Nomination
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7Two newcomers to statewide politics who ran as reform candidates and racial moderates won the runoff spots in yesterday's 17man race for the Louisiana Democratic Gubernatorial nomination.

title: NO LETUP IS SEEN IN BONDRATE DROP
description: The credit markets last week continued to work their way toward lower interest rates and investment bankers see no significant developments that will interrupt the trend this week.

title: Scott Vanquishes Turner In Tennis Final, 76, 63
description: Gene Scott, the No. 2ranked player in the East, won the Jungle Tennis Club's invitation indoor tournament yesterday by defeating Steve Turner, 76, 63, in the final at Bill's Indoor Tennis in Harlem. First prize was $500.

title: Col. John S. Dwinnell, 69, Dies; Military Lawyer for 40 Years
description: Col. John S. Dwinnell, U.S.A., retired, a lawyer with the Judge Advocate General's Corps and a member of the military court that convicted Ilse Koch of murder at the Buchenwald concentration camp in Germany, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital on First Avenue. He was 69 years old; and lived at 98 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

title: Supplementary OverCounter List
description: The following is a supplementary list of overthecounter stocks prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. It consists of securities less widely held or those that, for other reasons, do not appear on the daily OvertheCounter list. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Chess: Grandmaster Requirements Subject to Frequent Shifts
description: The first international chess tournament ever held in Luxembourg was concluded last month with a Yugoslav grandmaster, Alexander Matanovich, and a Hungarian International master, Imre Dely, tying for first place at 72. Third was Grandmaster Bruno Parma of Yugoslavia, with 62.

title: South African Interracial Group Seeks to Ease Apartheid Strain
description: STELLENBOSCH, South AfricaA new highlevel interracial group that is seeking to ease the strains of apartheid has its basis, surprisingly enough, in this placid university city 30 miles east of Capetown, that is a gem of Dutch colonial architecture and a citadel of the Afrikaner intelligentsia.

title: Theater: A Most Gifted Playwright
description: David Rabe is a young playwright who is as talented as he is lucky, or perhaps just as lucky as he is talented. He already has the remarkable drama The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel playing at the Newman Theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. Last night this was joined at the Public's Anspacher Theater by his new play, Sticks and Bones, which is also clearly the work of a most gifted playwright.

title: EXTREMISTS GAIN IN BELGIAN VOTE
description: BRUSSELS, Monday, Nov. 8 (AP)  Extremist parties that favor dividing Belgium on language lines gained strength in nationwide parliamentary elections yesterday, but Premier Gaston Eysken's moderate coalition retained a dominant position.

title: Holyoke Art Building Sparks Parley on Museums
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 7I very much fear that museums often set sail downwind and go wherever. it is comfortable, commented Charles Parkhurst, assistant director of the National Gallery of Art, referring to the growing social pressures on museums. This is not a very admirable role.

title: Reform Leaders Concerned Over the Lack of Awareness by American Jewish Youth of the Nazi Holocaust
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7Spiritual leaders of American Reform Judaism expressed concern today over the attitude of American Jewish youth who view the Nazi holocaust as ancient history without meaning for them.

title: To Kill a Cousin
description: Dolphins and porpoises are man's first cousins in the animal kingdom. Like human beings, they are warmblooded and bear their children one at a time. Highly intelligent and capable of complex forms of communication, they have been called the intellectuals of the sea.

title: City Moves to Make Advertisers Stop Hiding Any Extra Charges
description: A new regulation designed to make hidden charges in advertisements readily visible to the consumer was proposed yesterday by Bess Myerson, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.

title: Ali, Back From Argentina, Boxes 16 Rounds in Drill
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)Muhammad Ali, answering critics who said that he is out of shape and taking his Nov. 17 fight with Buster Mathis lightly, worked the equivalent of 16 rounds in a gym today.

title: Caule, Tranquil Village in a Harsh War
description: CAULE, Portuguese Guinea Caule Iooks like a typically peaceful West African village rings of round wicker huts threaded together by dusty paths, women chopping wood and grinding meal, chickens skipping out of the way of barefoot children.

title: Student Zeal at Yale Switches From Politics to Learning
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7The closest thing to a student uprising at Yale University this fall has been a determined, campaign for longer library hours.

title: $1Million in Drugs And 24 Suspects Are Seized Here
description: A cache of what is believed to he heroin and cocaine with a street value of close to $1million was seized and 24 persons were arrested by the police early yesterday in an apartment on Manhattan's upper West Side.

title: Unfreezing Soviet Grain Trade
description: Disclosure by the White House that arrangements have been completed for sale of $136 million in American feed grains to the Soviet Union represents a welcome break in the recent pattern of joint action by industry, labor and Government in Washington to curb the free flow of world trade.

title: DR. ARTHUR POST
description: Dr. Arthur Post, assistant professor of radiology at New York University Medical Center, died here yesterday. He was 60 years old and lived at 25 Central Park West.

title: Symington Gets Award
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 7The Mizrachi Women's Organization of America gave its annual America Israel Friendship Award tonight to Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, for his support of United States aid to Isreal.

title: Party Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, Nov. 7Six Chinese diplomats, the advance party of the Chinese delegation to the United Nations, arrived here tonight on the way to New York. The six, who were dressed in darkblue, Maostyle suits, Were met by three men from the Chinese Embassy. They refused to answer newsmen's questions.

title: Seals Rout Leafs
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 7 (UPI)The California Golden Seals bombarded Jacques Plante with 40 shots tonight en route to an 81 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Austerity Drive in Israel May Force Military Cuts
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 7Israel's military budget, huge but customarily sacrosanct, is coming under pressure in a Governmentwide austerity drive.

title: A Game of Cosmic Roulette
description: The following is an interview with Jacques Monod, 1965 Nobel Prize winner in biology and author of Chance and Necessity.

title: FREEZE NEARS END; RESULTS DISPUTED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The country entered today the final week of the first phase of President Nixon's economic stabilization program. The results of the 90day freeze were a subject of disagreement in the nation's capital.

title: Egypt to Defer General Assembly Debate
description: CAIRO, Nov. 7Egypt has decided to postpone a debate in the United Nations General Assembly on the ArabIsraeli dispute, it was announced here today.

title: Proxmire Reports Huge Oil Reserves In Southern Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7Senator William Proxmire, Wisconsin Democrat, said today that the southern coast of Alaska holds vast oil reserves, even larger than those on the North Slope. He said the south coast oil could be shipped to the West Coast of the United States without having to use the controversial proposed transAlaska pipeline.

title: Frustration Bedevils City's Community Plan Boards
description: I have to tell you what's the Board of Education? Martin Lederman asked his fellow members of Queens Community Planning Board 10.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: THE DALLAS COWBOY is coming to the canyons of New York Thursday.Advt.

title: Cities and Villages, Defying Developers, Are Hastening to Preserve and Exhibit Their Historic Sites
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7  What does an abandoned railroad siding in Colorado have in common with an aged iron smelter in Missouri or an unused music hall in Philadelphia?

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Is Better
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 7 (UPI)  Mrs. Mamie Eisenhower, who came down with a mild bronchial inflamation last week, has responded well to treatment, a spokesman for Brooke Army Hospital said today. She is in very good condition, Lieut. Tom Mathews said. She is now undergoing some evaluations. Lieutenant Mathews said doctors have not announced how much longer Mrs. Eisenhower, who will be 75 years old next Sunday is to remain in the hospital.

title: GOTTSCHEE BEATS CLARKSTOWN, 31.
description: Despite the absence, of Siggy Stritzl, Gottschee played like old times yesterday to post its first GermanAmerican Soccer League victory this year, a 3to1 triumph over Clarkstown.

title: McMahon Arrives in London
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP) Prime Minister William McMahon of Australia arrived tonight from Washington for a week of high level talks on world affairs and the implications of Britain's proposed entry into the Common Market.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT ROCKETS 109106
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)Jack Marin scored 42 points to lead, the Baltimore Bullets to 109106 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight, the Bullets' first road triumph of the season.

title: Ashe, Down by 14 in 5th Set, Overcomes Kodes in Net Final
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 7 (UPI)  Arthur Ashe of Gum Springs, Va., fought back from the brink of defeat today and captured the men's singles title in the $50,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament.

title: Australian Combat Role Ends in South Vietnam
description: NUIDAT, South Vietnam Nov. 7 (Reuters)Australia's combat role in the Vietnam war ended today when 1,100 men of the Fourth Battalion withdrew from Nuidat, which has been the main Australian base in Vietnam for five years.

title: Miss Davis's Eyes Worry Her Physician
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 7 Angela Davis's personal physician has joined her lawyers and family in asserting that the imprisoned black activist is in failing health.

title: NICKLAUS, AT 274, WINS BY 7 SHOTS
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 7 (AP)Jack Nicklaus, battling heavy winds most of the way, shot a twounderpar 70 today to win the $28,000 Dunlop international golf tournament. His fourround total was 274, 14 under par.

title: Four Arrested on Charge Of Offering Police Bribes
description: Over the weekend, policemen made four arrests in three boroughs of suspects who allegedly tried to bribe them to avoid prosecution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY SHOWS U.S. PRESSES AIR WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7  A comprehensive study of the air war in Indochina by a Cornel University group concludes that while the Nixon Administration drastically curtailed American ground combat, it is maintaining a high level of bombing and, in Cambodia and Laos, has in fact intensified the air war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Muskie Car Is Pelted
description: ALAHAMBRA, Calif., Nov. 7 (UPI)  The car carrying Senator Muskie from a reception was pelted today with eggs thrown from a group of demonstrators. Nobody was hit. Mr. Muskie, Richard Alatorre, Democratic Assembly candidate, and members of their party, were confroited by 50 demonstrators from La Raza Unidai a militant Chicago organization that has criticized Mr. Alatorre as an Uncle Tom. Spokesman for the Senator said the eggs were directed at Mr. Alatorre and not Mr. Muskie.

title: Laos Devalues Kip 21%
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 7 (AP)  The Government announced today a go per cent devaluation of the Laotian currency, the kip.

title: In Portuguese Guinea, Time Is Rebels' Ally
description: CAMPEANE, Portuguese Guinea  This swampy little corner of West Africa is being torn apart by one of the world's last colonial wars. Here, in an area twice the size of New Jersey, Portugal is trying to defend a land that her explorers discovered 500 years ago against a growing force of black guerrillas.

title: 60 Handcraftsmen Show Works at Bear Mountain
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Nov. 7An exhibition of the works of some 60 handcraftsmen from Rockland, Ulster and Orange Counties is on display at the Bear Mountain Inn here.

title: Cavaliers Score, 12099
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 7 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers, paced by Bobby Smith's 26 points and Rick Roberson's teamrecord 23 rebounds, defeated the Portland Trail Blazers, 12099, today.

title: Tito, Arriving in London, Overlooks Waiting Heath
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (Reuters) President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived in London tonight for talks with Prime Minister Health, after visits to the United States and Canada.

title: Ruth Klein Married To Fred Schwalbe
description: Miss Ruth Klein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Klein of New York, was married at the Plaza last evening to Fred Schwalbe, son of Mrs. Leon Schwalbe, also of New York, and the late Mr. Schwalbe. Rabbis Emmanuel Backman, Arthur Schneier and Meir Abramowitz officiated.

title: One of the Reasons Coaches Don't Like to See Their Quarterbacks Run
description: Since cutting their hair, the Philadelphia Eagles have turned into veritable Samsons.

title: CABOOSE IN JERSEY MAY BE DERAILED
description: MORGANVILLE, N. J., Nov. 7, It never occurred to me that anybody could dislike a little red caboose, said Mrs. Florence Besthorne, a 34yearold housewife here who believes that The world could do with a little brightening up.

title: 49ers Wear Down Vikings' Defense To Triumph, 139
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 6The burden of playing without an effective offense became too much today for the Purple Gang, the gallant defensive unit of the Minnesota Vikings. On the field for 67 plays by the 49ers, 42 in the Viking half of the field, the Minnesota defenders finally gave up a touchdown in the fourth quarter and thus lost to San Francisco 139, in a rugged game between two of the best teams in the National Football League.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
James Fingeroth Weds Patricia London
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 7Miss Patricia Sue London and James Nahum Fingeroth were married this evening at the Jewish Community Center of. West Hempstead by Rabbi Abraham M. Moseson. Cantor Haskel Rosenbloom assisted.

title: Giants Rout Chargers, 3517
description: Fine work by both units, their recently strengthened offense and recently realigned defense, brought the New York Giants a 3517 victory over San Diego at Yankee Stadium yesterday, and ended their fourgame losing streak.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Faraci's Spaniel Wins
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., Nov. 7Mountain View's Blaze, a 1yearold owned and handled by Edward R. Faraci of Middletown, Conn., won the English Springer Spaniel puppy stake at the 38th annual field trials sponsored by the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association today at Clay Hill Shooting Preserve.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON, Monday, Nov. 8 (AP)  Amnesty International said, today that it had received personal statements and affidavits accusing British troops in Northern Ireland of torture and beatings. It called for an international inquiry. The nongovernmental organization said that the British Government had rejected a call for its own commission to investigate the complaints.

title: Nixon Aide Asks Unions Here to Report Price Rises
description: President Nixon's consumer counsel has asked labor officials here for information they have on possible violations of the price freeze in the New York City area and the action the Internal Revenue Service has taken in those cases.

title: Networks Scored By Sander Vanocur As Propagandistic
description: Sander Vanocur, the former National Broadcasting Company news commentator, charged the broadcast media with being a part of the selling process of governmental propaganda in an article in The Center magazine published today.

title: Perry Price Joins City Opera Barber In Role of Almaviva
description: Busy as it is, the New York City Opera's production of Rossini's Il Barbiere di Siviglia did not supply all the action in the New York State Theater on Saturday night.

title: Central America Trade Bloc Falters
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7The Central American Common Market, a model for economic integration among developing nations, is hovering on the point of collapse because of continuing political and economic differences among its five members.

title: Anne Chamberlain Grives Piana Recital
description: Anne Chamberlain, a pianist with the technical tools Arid intellectual acuity necessary to Play 20thcentury music well, did not let her century down yesterday afternoon in her recital at Alice Tully Hall. Early (Debussy and Ravel), or late (Raoul Pleskow, Stefan Welpe and Howard Rovics), composers found in the tall, young artist a persuasive advocate.

title: BUY STONE MIXES SONGS AND HUMOR
description: Elly Stone's remarkable voice a clear, pure, wideopen soprano that swells like an organ as, she projects more strongly proved to be an ideal vehicle for the songs of Jacques Brel when she helped to launch Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris almost five years ago. And the Brel songs, with their opportunities for varied dramatic shadings, were the high points of her recital Saturday evening to a cheering, bravoing audience that filled Carnegie Hall.

title: Morality and Price Control
description: Prof. Milton Friedman, the noted University of. Chicago economist, has attacked the wageprice freeze and the coming Phase Two controls as deeply and inherently immoral for interfering with the operation of free markets and individual freedom.

title: JAMES L. BROWN
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 7Jatnes L. Brown, an executive of the American Broadcasting Company until his, retirement six years ago, died here today in the Medicenter Nursing Home. He was 76 years old and had been a resident of North Bergen, and Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Youths Who Love Football Meet Women Who Know a Lot About It
description: Mark Torronce, 13 Years old, sat in the aimostempty stands of Shea Stadium talking earnestly to Enez Boozer.

title: LITTLE U.N. MEETS AT TRADE CENTER
description: A little United Nations of young businessmen and government officials has been in session for two months at the new World Trade Institute in the north tower of the World Trade Center.

title: Women of Hindu Sect in India Live Out Their Lives Behind Wall of 20Acre Compound
description: SRIVAIKUNTAM, India The women living in the Fort of Pillaimars, a 20acre mudwalled compound in the middle of this bustling south Indian town, have never heard of the women's liberation movement.

title: Soviet Anniversary: Arms Show and Quiet Feasting
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 7At 10 sharp this morning, Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, the Soviet Defense Minister, emerged from the ancient, redwalled Kremlin fortress in a winddriven Snow to review phalanxes of troops massed in Red Square. Their cheers to, him echoed off the Kremlin walls as he made his rouns in an open car, signaling the start of Moscow's annual parade honoring the Bolshevik, Revolution.

title: Graffman to Tour Soviet
description: Gary Graffman, the pianist, will open a threeweek tour of the Soviet Union on Saturday. He will perform with orchestra and in recital in Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev and Novosibirsk. This will be the pianist's second tour of the Soviet Union in three years.

title: EXOFFICERS OF I.O.S. ARE SUED FOR FRAUD
description: GENEVA, Nov. 7  Thirty directors and executives of Investors Overseas Services when the mutual fund empire was ruled by Bernard Cornfeld, its founder, have been accused of fraud in a complaint filed with the Geneva public prosecutor, it was learned today.

title: Madrid: 3 Pablos Amidst the Ghosts
description: Arts Abroad

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Police in Windsor, Ont., Halt Protesters Against Blast
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press)  Policemen wearing riot helmets and carrying billy clubs stopped 1,500 demonstrators against the United States Amchitka nuclear blast from marching yesterday on to the Ambassador Bridge.

title: Schools and Courts Ignoring Prayer Ban as the House Prepares to Vote on the Issue
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 7A House vote is scheduled tomorrow on a constitutional amendment aimed at resolving the problem of prayers in the schools, but school officials in many parts of the country have already found a solution of sorts: They are simply Ignoring the prayer ban, and Federal courts seem reluctant to punish them.

title: STEEL MILLS LOOK TO JANUARY SURGE
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 7Steel producers were waiting anxiously for their first January orders last week.

title: Giants Get Good Mileage From 2 Taxi Squadmen
description: When you want to get some place in a hurry, you call a taxi, and so the Giants, called on two former members of the taxi squad yesterday to help them beat the San Diego Chargers for their first home victory of the season.

title: RANGERS FLY HIGH WITH BEST RECORD
description: Following a smashing threegame trip on which they scored one of their most decisive victories away from home, the Rangers returned last night with the best record in the National Hockey League.

title: $1MILLION SETTLES JETLINER CRASH SUIT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 7 (UPI) Under the terms of an outofcourt settlement disclosed today, the Boeing Aircraft Corporation agreed to pay $1,110,000 to the families of four Pan American Airways crew members killed in a crash of a jetliner eight years ago, the lawyer for the families annunced.

title: Tel Aviv Is Upset By Festival Week Of German Culture
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 7A culture week sponsored by the West German Embassy here opened last night and touched off an eruption of hostility.

title: O'DONNELL ISELIN, A COAL EXECUTIVE
description: O'Donnell Iselin, a New York sportsman and businessman, and a member of an old New York family, died here yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 104 East 71st Street.

title: EUGENE KLABER, 88, AN ARCHITECT, DIES
description: SELLERSVILLE, Pa. Nov. 7Eugene Henry Klaber, an architect and expert in city planning, died here yesterday in Grand ViewHospital. He was 88 years old and had lived in Quakertown sincs 1950.

title: Victoria M. Clark Is Wed in Hong Kong
description: Miss Victoria Marie Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Clark of Brookfield, Conn., was married in Hong Kong yesterday to David Fitzgerald Beauchamp, son of Brig. Rex Beauchamp; British Army, retired, of Redlynch, England, and Mrs. W. Ogilvie Pentland of Kinross, Scotland.

title: U.S. WILL CANCEL LICENSES TO SHIP ARMS TO PAKISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The United States has decided to cancel licenses for, the export of more than $3million worth,. of military equipment to Pakistan.. Official announcement of the cancellation is expected toMorrow.

title: PARKLAND FUNDS OFFERED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6Richard J. Sullivan, New Jersey's Environmental Protection Commissioner, has invited local officials to begin requesting a share of the $80million Green Acres bond issue approved by the voters Tuesday.

title: China Pledges Aid to Pakistan
description: PEKING, Nov. 7China called on India and Pakistan yesterday to find a peaceful solution to their frontier dispute, but warned that it would resolutely support Pakistan in the event of war.

title: Johnson Helps to Sell Copies of His New Book
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 7Former President Lyndon B. Johnson formally presented the first copy of his memoirs, The Vantage Point, to the Lyndon B. Johnson Library today, and 9,271 people came, to see him and buy his new book.

title: Waiter Chalaire, Lawyer, Dies; ExHead of N.Y.U. Law Alumni
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Nov. 7 Waite Chalaire, an international corporation and estate lawyer, died Friday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 76 years old and lived here at 2 Sussex Road.

title: Beaumont Troupe Fetes Benefactors
description: It takes a clever host to mix Ethel. Merman, Mary Stuart, Queen Elizabeth and Perle yesta, together in the same room, but Bernard Relin is at least at clever as that, for his party last night for the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center had fabulous characters from two centuriesthe 16th and the 20thin it.

title: Congress Pay Cut Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (UPI) Representative George Mahon, Democrat of Texas, who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, suggested today that Congress take a pay cut to help fight inflation. He said that Congress undercut the battle against inflation in 1969 when it raised members' salaries by 42 per centfrom $30,000 a year to $42,000and gave the President a 100 per cent pay raise, to $200,000 a year.

title: 62 Community Boards Are Strictly Advisory
description: The 62 community boards are panels of up to 50 unpaid citizens each appointed by the Borough President to advise on, plan, and investigate, through monthly meetings, development of 62 neighborhood districts throughout city.

title: Wild Oil Well Contained
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 7 (AP) One of four wild wells feeding a fire at an offshore oil platform has apparently been checked off, Amoco Production Company officials said today. The fire started in the Gulf of Mexico on Oct. 16.

title: LAKERS HOLD OFF KNICKS AT FINISH TO WIN BY 10396
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7With Willis Reed, their captain and center sitting on the bench and missing his fourth game in a row since suffering another attack of tendonitis in his left knee, the New York Knicks bowed to the Los Angeles Lakers, 10396, at the Forum tonight.

title: ARKANSAS BLACKS VOICE COMPLAINTS
description: WEST MEMPHIS, Ark., Nov. 7  The Arkansas Advisory Committee to the United States Civil Rights Commission listened to charges here Friday and yesterday that numerous Federal programs for the poor had only a slight impact on blacks in eastern Arkansas because of indifference or harassment by program officials and local white leaders and policemen.

title: VALENTI SPARKLES AS HARPSICHORDIST
description: Hunter College's Virtuoso Harpsichord series found Fernando Valenti at the keyboard Saturday night for a program of predominantly classical items: suites by Purcell, Handel and Bach and a handful of sonatas by Soler and Scarletti.

title: It Was Cold Last Night
description: The temperature at 2 A.M. was 34 and falling, and the forecast warned that today would be cold and windy. Details on Page 78.

title: Elated A.E.C. Planning to Quit Aleutians
description: AMCHITKA, Alaska, Nov. In their elation over the apparent success of the Cannikin bomb test, high officials of the Atomic Energy Commission have almost committed themselves to abandoning their nuclear weapons testing ground on this Aleutian island.

title: Sahara Balloon Trip Set
description: LONDON, Nov. 7 (AP)Two Americans and two Britons today announced plans to take off next Jan. 28 on the first balloon crossing of the Sahara. Jack Le Vien of New York and John Gardey of Tulsa, Okla., a meteorologist, with Felix Pole of Newbury, England, and Don Cameron of Bristol, the pilot's, hope to make the 2,300mile crossing in five weeks.

title: Ceylon Plans Dollar Link
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 7 (AP)Ceylon has decided to link her currency, the rupee, to the United States dollar, breaking the traditional tie with British sterling. Ceylon's central bank said today the value of the rupee would remain unchanged at 5.95 to the dollar.

title: FORD EXPRESSES PHASE 2 DOUBTS
description: DETROIT, Nov. 7  Henry Ford 2d said today that he was uncertain whether the second phase of President Nixon's economic program would bring down unemployment and restore consumer confidence.

title: JAMES E. HARTY
description: James E. Harty, who retired five years ago as chief of he economics division of the Mobil Oil Corporation, with which he had served 38 years died Friday in Pompano Beach. He was 69 years old and formerly lived in North Tarrytown, N. Y.

title: Rent Cuts Threatened If Landlords Foul Air
description: Tenants in rentcontrolled buildings will be eligible next year for rent reductions, if their landlords violate the city's Air Pollution Code, city Rent and Housing Maintenance Administrator Benjamin Altman said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pampered Life Ends as Steak at $14 a Pound
description: MATSUZAKA, Japan The blackhaired beauties around here get the best food and drink, never work, take morning sunbaths and are massaged. But all this pampering doesn't last long, for after three or four years they are slaughtered and the result is what might be the best beef in the world.

title: GarbageTruck Noise Breaks Proposed Law
description: The Sanitation Department's 395 new garbage trucks make so much noise, according to a spokesman for the department, that they would be illegal under the Environmental Protection Administration's proposed noisepollution code.

title: Minorities Step Up Action on Broadcast Licenses
description: The television and radio industries are experiencing a new element of regulation. Challenges against the renewal or transfer of station licenses are being filed by minority groups with the Federal Communications Commission. Subsequent negotiations then frequently afford blacks and Spanishspeaking Americans greater access to the airwaves and expanded employment opportunities in broadcasting.

title: CANADIENS WIN FROM BRUINS, 32
description: BOSTON, Nov. 7 (UPI)Ken Dryden's brilliant goaltending and Frank Mahovlich's thirdperiod powerplay goal lifted the Montreal Canadiens to 32 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

title: Jets' Field Goal Tops Chiefs, 1310;
description: In a chilling wind that swayed the yellow goal posts as well as the outcome, the Jets registered a remarkable 1310 upset of the Kansas City Chiefs yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Tight Security Set for Arrival of Chinese Party
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 7A New York City, police spokesman said tonight that very extensive security precautions were planned for the arrival tomorrow of the sixman advance party of the Chinese delegation to the United Nations.

title: Environmental Security
description: No severely detrimental effects on the environment have yet been reported as a result of the Cannikin underground nuclear test on Amchitka, and for that we Americans, our Canadian neighbors and the citizens the world at large must be grateful.

title: Alabama, Penn State and Michigan Elevens Bolster Chances for Bowl Bids
description: Alabama's 147 victory over Louisiana State, Michigan State's 1710 upset of Ohio State and the continuing success of undefeated Penn State, Georgia, Oklahoma and Nebraska on Saturday brought the bowl situation into sharper focus.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For a team that might have just blown $25,000 per man in the cyclones of Shea Stadium, the Kansas City Chiefs Were remarkably calm yesterday, They had arrived in town twatouchdown favoritea, they were playing the limping remnants of the New York Jets, they, were peering ahead to the really big games against Detroiti, San Francisco and Oakland. And now they had been decked, 1310, and the road to the Super Bowl suddenly seemed long and friendless.

title: PHILIPPINES HOLDING OFFYEAR ELECTIONS
description: MANILA, Nov. 7The Philippines, ending one of the bloodiest campaigns in her volatile political history, holds offyear elections tomorrow on the issue of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's performance in the last six years.

title: Israel's Dovish Finance Minister
description: Man in the News

title: Environmental Conference Scheduled for Tarrytown
description: A twoday conference aimed at accommodating the often conflicting environmental views of industrialist, government officials and conservationists will be held at Tarrytown House, the conference center in Tarrytown, on Nov. 19 and 20.

title: State Receives Grant to Hire More Minority Prison Guards
description: Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday a new Federal grant to the state's Department of Correctional Servnumber of black and Puerto Rican prison guards.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Imposes Suspension On an Investment Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP)  Analytical Investment Decisions Systems, Inc., of Bellevue, Wash., has been suspended by the Securities and Exchange Commission from engaging in the invetment advisory business for 30 days, the commission announced today.

title: Equity for Federal Employes
description: The foundation for any successful postfreeze stabilization program must be fairness in treatment of all classes of workers and consumers. No one can yet be sure how adequately that test will be inet in the Phase Two rules being formulated by the Pay Board and the Price Commission. However, the Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee last week Look a needed step toward assuring that Federal employes will not arbitrarily be excluded from equitable treatment.

title: 3 KILLED IN BLAZE IN BROOKLYN HOUSE
description: At least three persons died last night in a fire in a threestory frame house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. Their identity was not immediately known.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Missing Off Long Island
description: EAST SETAUKET, L. I., Nov. 7The Coast Guard and police maritime units searched Long Island Sound today for an East Williston, L. I., father and his daughter, reported missing late yesterday and feared drowned. The police said that Howard Weinstein, aged 42 years old, and his daughter Joy 15, of 212 Bengyfield drive, East Williston, had, launched their boat here yesterday morning. It was found late yesterday in the Sound off Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Stars Down Flyers, 30
description: PHILADELPHIA, No. 7 (UPI) The Minnesota North Stars, scoring a goal in every period, remained in at least a tie for the West Division lead with a 3.0 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight.

title: Mills Says Pay Board Mast Honor Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the President's Pay Board would have to recognize the validity of wage contracts negotiated before Aug. 15.

title: Mill Reef Is Selected British Horse of Year
description: LONDON, Nov. 7, (Reuters) Mill Reef, the fine threeyearold colt owned by Paul Mellon of Pittsburgh has been voted Britain's horse of the year for 1971. The British Race Course Association an pounced the selection today.

title: EARNINGS HERE ROSE SINCE FREEZE BEGAN
description: During September, the first full month of the President's wageprize freeze, the average gross weekly earnings of factory workers in the greater metropolitan area rose by $2.26, the regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said Yesterday.

title: ENVIRONMENT UNIT SCORED ON POLICY
description: The opposition of top Fedoral environmental officials to restrictions on nonreturnable containers has stirred concern among environmentalists who have been backing such legislation across the country as a means of controlling mounting waste problems.

title: Many at U. N. Find Guru's Message Brings Peace
description: Every Tuesday at noon about 100 men and women, some dressed in Costumes of distant homelands, file into the quiet chapel of the Interdenominational Church Center, just across the street from the United Nations.

title: Sabres, Red Wings Tie
description: BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 7 (AP) Doug Barrie's goal on a low, hard shot from the blue line at 16:43 of the third period gave the Buffalo Sabres a 3.3 tie with the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: Orioles Belt Four Homers In 70 Triumph in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Nov. 7 (AP)Brooks Robinson clouted two home runs and Frank Robinson and Andy Etchebarren also connected as the Baltimore Orioles routed the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants, 70, today in a game shortened to five innings by rain.

title: Keeping a Tight Lid on Costs Is Main Aim
description: Costs of labor and textiles, often the determining factors in the pricing policies of the domestic apparel industry, have stabilized in recent weeks, easing the industry's pricing pangs under the wage price freeze.

title: Hawks Top Penguins, 41
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UPI)The Chicago Black Hawks scored four goals in the second period, three in less than three minutes, to defeat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 41, tonight.

title: White House Opens A Drive to Redraft Senate's Water Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7The White House has begun an intensive campaign among state governments to get support against the extremely tough water pollution control bill passed by the Senate last week by a vote of 86 to 0.

title: Tudor City Residents Here Fight to Save Their Parks
description: About 200 residents of Tudor City huddled in the cold yesterday in one of their two small parks as they formulated plans to try to save the parks, which are being taken for buildings.

title: East Pakistan Area Search Finds No Cyclone Fatalities
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 7Pakistani authorities said today that apparently no one on the East Pakistani mainland was killed by the cyclone that sideswiped the coastal region yesterday before passing into Burma. The statement was issued following an aerial inspection of the area.

title: FREUND FORECASTS AN ECONOMIC PICKUP
description: Next year will see a more vigorous pace of economic activity, lower rates of unemployment, higher corporate profits and less intense price inflation, according to a summary of leading economic opinion reeased yesterday by Dr. William C. Freund, vice president and economist of the New York Stock Exchange, Inc.

title: BLACKS CHANGING RATING OF LINDSAY
description: Blacks who are active in community affairsfrom block workers to businessmen are now deeply divided in their appraisals of Mayor Lindsay, the man who won their allegiance by walking in shirtsleeves through their angry streets.

title: DR. VICTOR SZANTON ALLERGIES EXPERT
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7 Victor L. Szanton, associate Clinical professor of pediatrics and allergy at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine New York, died today of cancer in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 66 years old and practiced Derby. His home was in Ansonia.

title: Books of The Times
description: AN OLDFASHIONED DARLING. By Charles Simmons. 202 pages. Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $5.95.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 7 (AP)The Golden State Warriors reeled off 14 straight points in the second quarter to take the lead and go on to beat the Seattle SuperSonics tonight.

title: Fast Credit Checks Help Apparel Trade
description: Instant replay is the rule at Credit Clearing House, a division of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., concerned with credit conditions of the apparel trade.

title: Blind Teacher of Electronics Overcomes Handicap
description: Milton Liljestrand, slender and silverhaired, walked briskly into his class in advanced electronics technology and erased the blackboard.

title: 6% of Employable Welfare Clients Put to Work
description: Jobs were found for 6 per cent of relief clients required to pick up checks in person as employables during September, according to a report by state welfare and labor officials.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Nov. 7Two columns in this space last month contrasted British and American medical care. They were commenting on a charge by the president of the American Medical Association, Dr. Wesley Hall, that standards under Britain's National Health Service were tragic. The articles pointed out that health standards had risen dramatically here during the twenty years of the service and more than comparable American figures.

title: 75 J.D.L. MEMBERS ARE ARRESTED HERE
description: The police arrested 75 members of the Jewish Defense League yesterday as they staged a sitdown on Third Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets. The sitdown grew out of their disappointment with the turnout for a protest they held earlier against the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Ragtime Leads Ocean Race
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 7 (AP)Ragtinie, a 62foot sloop owned by six members of the Long Beach Yacht Club, took the lead today after one day of the Long Beach to LaPaz, Mexico yacht race. The leader had covered 110 of the 970 miles at noon. A 33boat fleet left here yesterday afternoon.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Mayor Lindsay calls them headhunters  the talent scouts in his administration and these days they have fallen upon hard times.

title: Delegates Leave Vatican Synod in Disagreement on Its Impact
description: ROME, Nov. 7  Pope Paul VI hailed the third Synod of Bishops today as an important event that is certainly destined to have a great impact on the life of the church and also on that of the world.

title: Miss Jermain Duncan Is Bride Here of David Russell Graham
description: The marriage of Miss Jermain Duncan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dyson Duncan of Mount Kisco and Upper Regis, N. Y., to David Russell Graham of Wickenburg, Ariz., took place here yesterday morning. The bridegroom, who was ordained last year as a minister of the United Church of Christ and is working in electronic communications, is the son of the Rev, and Mrs. George Russell Graham of Claremont, Calif.

title: N.Y. Beaten in Volleyball
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 7 (Canadian Press)Hamilton's men's team took top honors yesterday in the Quebec international volleyball open, downing New York West Side, 155 and 1511. Connecticut Clippers won the women's final with a 15.6 and 15.9 victories over Toronto A.A.E.

title: Advertising:
description: One of the hairier moments in the everyday life of an ad agency is the copy crisis.

title: U.S Planes North of DMZ Attack Antiaircraft Guns
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7 (AP)The United States command announced that four American fighterbombers today attacked an antiaircraft site near North Vietnam's Donghoi air base, 40 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

title: Psychiatrist Marries Mrs. Harriet Lesnik
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Nov. 7 Mrs. Harriet Menkes Lesnik of Short Hills, widow of Milton J. Lesnik, was married here at noon today to Dr. Herman S. Alpert, assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8How good are your relations with J. Edgar Hoover, a justice De* pertinent official was asked. No better and no wise than they have ever been, he replied.

title: National
description: Results of the 90day freeze caused disagreement in Washington as the first phase of President Nixon's economic stability program entered its final week. There was general agreement that statistics had indicated that the freeze, which ends next weekend, had brought the inflationary wageprice spiral nearly to a halt. But beyond that, opinions varied among Administration officials, labor leaders, economists and consumer groups. Administration officials are describing Phase ?? as virtually an unqualified success. However, labor and consumer groups cite inequities and lack of progress in alleviating unemployment and reinvigorating the economy. Other observers, including some economists, described the results as inconclusive.

title: DELAYS IN JUSTICE LAID TO TYPISTS
description: For 609 people convicted in State, Supreme Court in Brooklyn over the last halfyear, the roost decisive member of the criminal justice system has become not the judge, prosecutor Or the defense lawyer, but the typist.

title: SUFFOLK WINNER PHONED BY NIXON
description: BLUE POINT, L. I., Nov. 8 President Nixon personally telephoned congratulations last week to John V. N. Klein, the successful Republican mididate for Suffolk County Executive, Republican officials reported today.

title: Excerpts From Text of Chou's Interview With Tokyo Editor
description: TOKYO, Nov. 8  Following are excerpts from the official record of an interview given bey. Premier Chou Enlai of China to Moto Goto, managing editor of. Asahi Shimbun, in Peking on Oct. 28. An English translation of the transcript appeared in The Asahi Evening News here today. Explanatory passages were provided by The New York Times in excerpting the text.

title: RED SHOES VICTOR BY 5 LENGTHS
description: Red Shoes carried the silks of Mrs. Adele Rand to an easy triumph in the feature seventh race at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against nine rivals in the 1116mile turf event for older fillies and mares, Red Shoes scored a 5length triumph. Her success shared the spotlight with an exacta payoff of $520.80 in the following race.

title: Mount Holyoke Gets Grant
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP)Mount Holyoke College announced today that it had received a $750,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to establish a professorship in the humanities. The college said the grant was the largest ever received by the institution to endow a professorial chair, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation Chair in the Humanities.

title: Sports of The Times
description: That's what makes pro football, such a great spectator sport, jubilantly said Weeb Ewbank yesterday. Teams that aren't supposed to win are still able to win, and that's why the one over Kansas City was particularly gratifying.

title: Senate Panel Ends Its Questioning of Powell With No Apparent Opposition to His Court Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8In a friendly five hours of questioning, the Senate Judiciary Committee completed its interrogation today of Lewis F. Powell Jr. with no Senator indicating opposition to his Supreme Court nomination.

title: Bradshaw Status in Doubt
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (UPI) Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steelers' injured quarterback, said today that he expected to play in Sunday's game against the Miami Dolphins, but Coach Chuck Noll was not so sure. burgh Steelers' injured quarterback, said today that he expected to play in Sunday's game against the Miami Dolphins, but Coach Chuck Noll was not so sure.

title: Drunkenness Bill Passed
description: BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP)Bills eliminating the crime of public drunkenness and recodifying the state's drug laws were passed by the legislature today and sent to Gov. Francis W. Sargent. He is expected to sign them.

title: Two Distinguished Nominations
description: WASHINGTONThe Senate is now considering William H. Rehnquist and Lewis F. Powell Jr. for the Supreme Court. A special genius of the American people has been a commitment to the rule of law, not of men; the Senate fulfills a Sacred duty in advisiing and consenting to the nominations submitted by the President.

title: JAMES L. BROWN
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 7James L. Brown, an executive of the American Broadcasting Company until his retirement six years ag, died here Sunday in the Medicenter Nursing Home. He was 76 years old and had been a resident of North Bergen, and Bronxville, N.Y.

title: SURGES BY COLTS IN FOURTH PERIOD BEAT RAMS, 2417
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 8Mike Curtis, who likes to hit persons hard, slammed his 232 pounds into Larry Smith, the Ram running back, and the football popped into the air. Fumblel Ted Hendricks, the everpresent Baltimore linebacker, grabbed the ball and streaked 31 yards into the end zone for a touchdown.

title: Castro Will Arrive in Chile Tomorrow
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 8Chile and Cuba announced today that Premier Fidel Castro would arrive here from Havana on Wednesday on his first to South America in more than 11 years.

title: SENATE APPROVES A CONSUMER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8The Senate pissed a bill tonight to establish Federal standards of fairness and clarity for warranties covering consumer products. The vote was 76 to 2.

title: A Collection of Native Arts On Display Before Auction
description: A large collection of native arts, in essence an index of American design of the past and of collecting tastes today, is on exhibition before auction sale on Friday and Saturday at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. All but about two score of the 473 sale items are reproduced in the most fully illustrated catalogue yet issued by the galleries.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: THOUGHTFUL GIFT  for someone with limited vision. The New York Times Large Type Weekly. Call 5361143. Advt.

title: New Sergeants Urged to Fight Graft
description: Mayor Lindsay told a group of newly promoted police sergeants yesterday that despite the difficult and even painful disclosures made by the Knapp Commission they must expose corruption and take whatever steps are necessary to end it.

title: Eddie Egan, Detective Here, Connects as an Actor.
description: Some people are born actors. It took 13 hours in a coma and four months on sick leave to convince Eddie Egan that he was one.

title: ExpressBus Service Here Is Popular
description: Until last week, Mrs. Winona Ellis got to work from her home in the Soundview area of the Bronx by walking to a bus, transferring to a subway in Parkchester, then enduring 40 minutes of pushing and jostling on the ride to Grand Central Terminal.

title: Letters to the Editor;...Capdy From a Baby
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFETY OF MISSIONS PUT ON U.N. AGENDA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 8Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet delegate to the United Nations, charged today in the General Assembly that violent attacks of foreign diplomatic missions here not only are becoming more frequent but that they are becoming better organized.

title: Gravel Urges Moratorium
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP)  Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, urged President Nixon today to declare a moratorium on all further nuclear explosions. Senator Gravel called Saturday's nuclear test a reckless gamble that still could have harmful environmental results.

title: Tolbert Will Change Liberia; Question Is, How Much?
description: MONROVIA, LiberiaLocal and foreign observers are already convinced that the new President of Liberia, William R. Tolbert Jr., represents a break with the past. But no one is quite sure how much political change he will bring to this West African nation.

title: GUSTAV KAISER
description: Gustav Kaiser, a vice president and account executive of the Hazard Advertising Company, died Saturday in Bridgeport (Conn.) General Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Blinky Palermo Released
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 8 (UPI)  Frank (Blinky) Palermo of Philadelphia, a former prominent figure in the boxing world, was released from prison today after serving 7 years for conviction of conspiracy and extortion.

title: Merger News
description: International Utilities, Inc., a, holding company that owns Ryder Truck Lines, Inc., was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to acquire the Pacific Intermountain Express Company in a share exchange involving about $40million. I.U. now owns more than 254,000 shares of Pacific Intermountain's 1.6 million shares of common stock. The commission, in authorizing the acquisition of the rest of the stock, gave I.U. a year in which to file a plan for merging the two trucking companies. The consolidated system would be the second largest in the trucking industry and would have annual revenues of $262million.

title: DR. VICTOR SZANTON, ALLERGIES EXPERT
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7Dr. Victor L. Szanton, associate clinical professor of pediatrics and allergy at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine in New York, died today or cancer in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 66 years old and practiced in Derby. His home was in Ansonia.

title: Women Shareholders Get Mixed Views
description: There has been some letting up of the letdown, David. L. Grove said yesterday as an introduction to his keynote talk before the Federation of Wornen Shareholders in American Business, meeting at the WaldorfAstoria. Mr. Grove is a vice president and chief economist of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: A Summary of Action Taken by Pay Board
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) Here is a summary of the Pay Board's action tonight:

title: STATE AIDE WINS FRAUDSUIT ROUND
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) In an important interpretation of federal securities law the Supreme Court authorized today a lawsuit against five New York concerns involving stock transaction of the Manhattan Casualty Company which is hi liquidation.
