description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 10 (AP)  The Detroit Red Wings, with Mickey Redmond and Nick Levitt scoring goals, beat the Minnesota North Stars, 21, tonight. It was the first National Hockey League victory for the Wings' new coach, Johnny Wilson.

title: SENATE ENDORSES OKINAWA TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Senate approved today, l?y, a vote of 84 to 6, a treaty that would return Okinawa to the administrative control of Japan, thus ending United States occupation of the territory of its World War II enemy.

title: TV: City Opera's Coq d'Or on Cable in Manhattan
description: The New York City Opera's production of RimskyKorsakov's Le Coq d'Or was carried live from Lincoln Center's State Theater Tuesday evening to cabletelevision subscribers in Manhattan. Scramble the elements of that fact any way you want, and you still wind up with a breakthrough of possibly significant proportions.

title: TOP VATICAN AIDE GOES TO POLAND
description: WARSAW, Nov. 10  The Most Rev. Agostino Casaroli, Pope Paul's foreign minister and an architect of the Vatican's new links with Communist states, arrived today in Poland for talks with Government leaders.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a report this week.

title: F.B.I. Investigates Schorr of C.B.S.; Reason Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Daniel Schorr, a Washington television correspondent who has often been at odds with White House aides, has been under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: PROJECTS TO GET MORE PROTECTION
description: Residents of public housing on the Lower East Side were assured by police and Housing Authority officials last night that police protection would be increased.

title: Ritual Acrobats Reflect Iran's Ancient Traditions
description: The King of Denmark, the Queen of the Netherlands, Premier Aleksei Kosygin. Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Dr. Christiaan A. Barnard have seen them. Now you can too.

title: STARS VANQUISH NETS BY 127110
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 10 (AP)Jimmy Jones scored 12 points in the final six minutes tonight to lead the Utah Stars to their first home victory of the season, a 127110 American Basketball Association triumph over the New York Nets.

title: MILTON KNIGHT, 65, GLASS EXECUTIVE
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 10Milton Knight, board chairman of Libbey  Owens  Ford Company and former president and board chairman of the First National Bank of Toledo, died today in Methodist Hospital. He was 65 years old.

title: Charlie Manna, Comedian, Dies; Known for Spoof of Astronauts
description: Charlie Manna, the comedian, died of cancer on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 60 West 57th Street.

title: Pollution Control Methods Marketed by Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it had started marketing two new air pollution control processes for the nitric acid and sulphuric acid industries.

title: School Board Plans Appeal
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10 (UPI) The Detroit Board of Education voted yesterday to appeal a Federal judge's ruling that the city's public schools had been deliberately segregated. The action, on an 84 vote, followed a similar decision by Gov. William G. Milliken last week. United States District Judge Stephen J. Roth has ruled that Detroit public schools are segregated as a result of deliberate lithe action. He has ordered the board to devise an integration plan.

title: Girl Riding in Cab Here Robbed of $25 by Driver
description: An 18yearold girl reported that she was held up yesterday by the driver of the taxicab in which she was riding, robbed of her purse and $25, and forced out of the cab.

title: El Shafel Beats Maud
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Nov. 10 (UPI)  Ismail El Shafei of Egypt and Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia advanced in the Bologna open tennis tournament today.

title: U.S. REJECTS 2 BIDS FOR OFFSHORE SITES
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 10 (AP)Two of the 13 high bids on offshore oil and gas leases auctioned last week have been rejected and a third is still under consideration, a spokesman for the United States Bureau of Land Management said today.

title: WORK PLAN OPPOSED FOR RELIEF MOTHERS
description: A coalition of labor, religious and community groups as well as the organized poor vowed yesterday to oppose a proposal by the State Department of Social Services to put some welfare mothers to work and to place the children of the working mothers in the care of others.

title: 3 School Bus Concerns Threaten To Curtail Services on Monday
description: Murry Bergtraum, a member of the Board of Education, suggested yesterday that the board get out of the transportation business and turn over school bus matters to an outside agency.

title: HENDERSON TRIAL HEARS CHAPLAIN
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 10  An Army chaplain who served with the Americal Division in Vietnam said today that he had received a complaint about unnecessary shooting in the hamlet of Mylai 4 and had passed it on to highranking officers.

title: Alston Gets 19th Pact To Manage Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (UPI)Walter Alston, baseball's oldest manager in point of service, has been given his 19th oneyear contract to boss the Los Angeles Dodgers, the club announced today.

title: Woman Held Up in School On Way to P.T.A. Meeting
description: A woman on her way to attend a ParentTeacher Association meeting was held up and assaulted last night in a hallway of a school building on East 19th Street.

title: Phone Strike Here Is Keeping 100,000 Customers Off the Line
description: With the strike of telephone installers now in its 17th week, close to 100,000 people who want phones are living without them in the city that has been called the communications capital of the world.

title: Muskie Group Names Head
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) Gov. Robert W. Scott of North Carolina was named state chairman of the committee for the Democratic Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: ATLANTA APPROVES A TRANSIT TAX PLAN
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 10Voters in this city and in a suburban county narrowly approved a onecent regional sales tax yesterday and gave their approval to a $1.4billion rapid transit system.

title: 2 SENATORS ATTACK NEW KISSINGER ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (UPI) Senators Stuart Symington and J. W. Fuibright said today that President Nixon had reshaped the nation's intelligence network to vest more control in the hands of Henry A. Kissinger, his adviser for national security affairs, without obtaining Congressional advice.

title: U.S. Drug Aide Retiring
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) John Finlator, deputy director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs since 1969, will retire Jan. 1. He is 60 years old and a native of Raleigh, N. C.

title: Books of The Times
description: The Family Is an attempt to relate Charles Manson and his followers to the freak cults that flourish in California: the devilworshipers; the drinkers of dog blood; the doompresagers, aciddroppers, occultists, bike gangs and porn lovers. The author, Ed Sandersa poet and former leader of a rock group called The Fugsspent a year and a half investigating Manson and the context out of which he came. He conducted 400 to 500 interviews, compiled 50 subject files, read all the transcripts of the cases, visited the sites of the crimes and of the family's camps. He risked his life to write the book, he says, since most of Manson's associates are partisans of violence. Piously asserting that he has played down the more sensational aspects of the Manson story, Mr. Sanders proceeds to drown us in a garbagetruckload of data. Manson was a nomad and we are obliged to follow him not only all over California, but also from room to room, from car to car as he wears them out, girl to girl. We hear what he allegedly said and did, down to the most meaningless minutiae. By the end of the book, we know everything about him except what kind of person he was, why he acted as he did and how he was able to influence so many people.

title: John Service Calls Taiwan Key Issue for Nixon
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 10John Stewart Service, a specialist in Chinese affairs and former State Department officer arrived here today after six, weeks in China and a talk with Premier Chou Enlai, and predicted that Taiwan would be the toughest issue on the agenda when President Nixon meets, Chinese officials in Peking next year.

title: RENT LAWS HEED SPUR TO HOUSING
description: A remarkable increase in new private housing starts in the city was attributed yesterday to the state's newly enacted rent decontrol laws by Charles J. Urstadt, the State Housing Commissioner.

title: Environmentalist's View
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) The top scientist of an environmental group that has fought DDT for nine years said, today that Dr. Norman E. Borlaug was one or two decades out of date in advocating its continued use.

title: Connally Sets Major Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (Reuters)Treasury Secretary John B. Connally plans to make a major speech on international economic affairs next Tuesday to the Economic Club in New York, a Treasury spokesman said today.

title: More Vitamin C Pills Are Recalled by F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had recalled during the last halfyear about 105 million vitamin C pills that it said were inadequately labeled and posed a threat to heart patients trying to ward off colds.

title: GAC Properties Laying Off About 200 of Its Personnel
description: GAC Properties, Inc., a Florida land developer and subsidiary of the GAC Corporation, announced yesterday that it was laying off about 200 employes, or about 8 per cent of its work orce.

title: LABOR PARTY VOTE GIVES JENKINS LEAD
description: LONDON, Nov. 10Roy Jenkins took a commanding lead today in the election for deputy leader of the warring Labor party, but the left wing and forces opposed to entry into the Common Market made big gains.

title: MISS HOGAN GETS A TENNIS SCOLDING
description: TORQUAY, England, Nov. 10 (UPI)Patti Hogan, America's fifthranked tennis player from La Jolla, Calif., was rebuked by referee Mike Gibson after losing to Penny Moor of Exeter, 61, 63, in the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament at the Palace Hotel today.

title: CHARLES J. SCHLESINGER
description: Charles J. Schlesinger, president of Van Diner & Schlesinger, an analytical laboratory, died of cancer yesterday at his home after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: JOHN CURRY HOVER, A LAWYER 40 YEARS
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Nov. 10John Curry Hover, a lawyer who for more than 40 years had specialized in fiduciary law, wills and the settlement of estates in New York, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 70 years old and lived at 276 Hobart Avenue.

title: GROUND IS BROKEN FOR A COURTHOUSE
description: Mayor Lindsay and other public officials broke ground for a new Family and Criminal Courts Building in the Bronx yesterday. The building is one of severalsome have already been builtin a $200million project.

title: For Mrs. Meir, a Hasidic Evening
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10The last of the benefit audience had left and the stagehands were striking the sets but the 73yearold Premier and the troupe of Israeli performers a third her age lingered backstage last night in heated and mellow discussion of the meaning of Hasidism and the Nazi holocaust to the Jews of today.

title: McGovern Suggests InflationProof Federal Bonds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 Senator George McGovern proposed today that the Governmerit create a new set of inflationproof bonds whose dollar value would rise quarterly to keep pace with consumer prices.

title: Orioles, Led by Buford, Win From Japanese Team, 42
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Nov. 10 (AP)Don Buford hit a tworun home run in the fifth inning to break a scoreless tie and drove in another run later as the Baltimore Orioles defeated a combined Japan Central League team, 42, today.

title: 3TIERED SYSTEM SET UP TO MONITOR PRICES IN PHASE 2
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10The Cost of Living Council disclosed today its threetiered system for monitoring postfreeze pay and prices and, at the same time, announced its first exemptions from the controls.

title: For Job He Wants, an Unusual Resume
description: H. McAlpin Whitney: St. Paul's, Yale, Social Register, world traveler, coordinator of a wartime construction project in Iran, State Department employe in Kabul and Paris; speaks Farsi, Arabic, French and a smattering of college. German; gourmet cook, grandson of an Andrew Carnegie partner. Unemployed.

title: HOWARD E. BORCK, ONCE TRACK STAR
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10Howard E. Borck, a track star during the late thirties and long a high school coach, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Agnes Hospital here. He was 57 years old and for the last three years had lived at 25 Intervale Avenue, North White Plains.

title: Retirement Under Pressure
description: Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, though undaunted by two wars and eight injuries on the battlefield, has surrendered to what he considered intolerable pressure on him and his family by the Army which he has served with distinction for over twenty years. His decision to retire in February was taken despite the fact that he had been officially cleared of a slanderous efficiency report and, more recently, been promoted to his permanent regular rank of major.

title: U.S. Will Use British Ball in World Cup Golf
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 10  Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino, the United States team, will play the smaller British golf ball, illegal for regular tourneys in this country but sanctioned in international competition, as they bid for World Cup honors beginning tomorrow.

title: Notes on People
description: At ceremonies opening the sale of two new 8cent Christmas postage stamps, Winton M. Blount, the former Postmaster General, observed that this Christmas season, for the first time in 25 years, the credo Peace on Earth now seems justified. Also present was Mrs. Julie Nixon Eisenhower, who said that President Nixon hopes, as I do, and all of us do, the ideals symbolized in these designs will become more than merely seasonal. One of the stamps, depicting a partridge in a pear tree, is the work of Jamie Wyeth, who was present for the ceremonies at the National Gallery of Art Theater. The other is a nativity scene, Adoration of the Shepherds, by the Italian painter Giorgioni. The stamps go on sale across the nation today.

title: Royals Turn Back Knicks, 99 to 85
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 10 Despite the return to action of Willis Reed for onequarter of playing time, the New York Knicks failed to find an inspiration for a good performance and were routed, 9985, by the Cincinnati Royals tonight in a sloppy National Basketball Association game at Cincinnati Gardens.

title: Policeman Killed in Naha
description: NAHA, Okinawa, (UPI)Masked students broke a bottle of gasoline on a policeman, set him afire and then beat him to death today. At least 80 other policemen were injured in clashes with demonstrators protesting the planned retention by the United States of military bases here.

title: Advertising:
description: Carter Products is turning Grey smiles to white, with the assignment of Pearl Drops liquid tooth polish to Grey. Advertising.

title: Advertising:
description: It looks as though McCannErickson is holding on to the Westinghouse majorappliance accountat least for a while.

title: Finch, on the Eve Of Tour, Defends Nixon's Latin Aims.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10Robert H. Finch, counselor to President Nixon, charged here today that President Franklin) D. Roosevelt's Good Neighbor policy and the Alliance for Progress under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson lumped the LatinAmerican countries together as banana republics.

title: CANADIENS WIN FRONT LEAFS, 5 TO 2
description: TORONTO, Nov. 10 (UPI)Frank Mahovlich scored his 15th goal in 14 games and assisted on Jacques Lemaire's secondperiod goal to lead the Montreal. Canadiens to a 52 victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALFRED RUBIN
description: PENNSAUKEN, N.J., Nov, 10 (UPI)Alfred Rubin, former assistant managing editor of The Philadelphia Daily News, died today at his home here. He was 55 years old.

title: Hawks Stop Bruins, 31
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (UPI)Bobby and Dennis Hull scored powerplay goals in the second period tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 31 victory over the Boston Bruins. It was the Hawks' sixth home triumph without a 16ss this season.

title: Prosecution Rests Case In Yablonski Murder Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 10 (UPI)The prosecution rested its case today in the trial of Aubran Martin, one of five persons charged with the murder of a United Mine Workers official, Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.

title: SICKS PLIIMMET ON A BROAD FRONT
description: Selling pressure drove a wedge into the stock market yesterday and sent prices scuttling to within a whisker of their 1971 lows.

title: Nigeria Oil Study Started
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a fullscale marine geophysical program on a 736,000acre concession offshore Nigeria. This is in preparation for drilling activities expected to begin during the first quarter of 1972.

title: Stevens Chooses Board Head
description: Frederick L. Bissinger, president of Allied Chemical Corporation, was elected chairman of the board of trustees of Stevens Institute of Technology yesterday, the board announced. Mr. Bissinger, 60 years old, will succeed Dr. Willis H. Taylor Jr., who has been chairman of the board since 1949. Dr. Taylor will remain a member of the board.

title: Soviet Said to Plan Trial Soon For Dissident Held 7 Months
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 10The secret police were reported today to have said that the Government was planning to put on trial soon a young Russian dissident, Vladimir A. Bukovsky, whose arrest and detention incommunicado since last March has become a minor cause celebre among Soviet dissidents and intellectuals concerned with human rights.

title: Jets on the Mend: Philbin Ready, Atkinson Almost
description: Slowly the Jets are regrouping. Gerry Philbin will return to defensive end Sunday against the Baltimore Colts. Al Atkinson might return at middle linebacker. At quarterback, Joe Namath has progressed to impersonating the opponent's, passer to test the defensive unit.

title: Copper Futures Lower at Finish; Silver Prices Off
description: The copper industry was a very good buyer in the trading of copper futures here yesterday. Prices of the futures rallied and closed steady, though nominally lower. The December, 1971, contract reached a low of 46.90 cents a pound, and closed at 47.15 cents.

title: Pistons' Coach Wins in Debut
description: DETROIT, Nov. 10 (AP)The Detroit Pistons gave their new coach, Earl Lloyd, a happy debut tonight by crushing the Portland Trail Blazers, 139122.

title: BRANDT WINS VOTE IN PARLIAMENT TEST
description: BONN, Nov. 10  Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government narrowly won a test vote in the federal parliament today, strengthening hope that it can eventually obtain ratification of its goodwill treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: Shiner Story: A Gamble Makes Him No. 1 Falcon
description: Dick Shiner, who has led Atlanta to as many victories the last three weeks as the Giants have accumulated all season, believes he'd still be a Giant if he hadn't walked out of camp last August.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: GREAT GIFT IDEA FOR ANY OCCASION.

title: Major Film union Here Accepts Pact
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that an agreement had been reached between five New York motion picture companies and a key union representing movie industry employes.

title: REVELERS SINGING AT THE GAY 90'S
description: Way back before the Beatles, before Elvis Presley, before Frank Sinatra, before Benny Goodman, before Rudy Vallee, there were the Revelers. The Revelers, a singing quartet, were one of the most popular recording and radio groups of the 20's and early 30's although they started in 1916 (as the Shannon Four) and continued to perform with one the founding members, Wilfred Glenn, until 1.953.

title: Panel Told of Vain Wait for City Loan
description: A contractor, a church official and a church lawyer told a City Council committee yesterday about their frustrated attempts to obtain a municipal loan to renovate two apartment buildings.

title: Anthems of Handel Furnish the Base For Series at Church
description: As paymaster  general for Britain's forces abroad during the early part of the 18th century, the first Duke of Chandos made a lot of money. As far as history is concerned, his wealth mattered only because it made it possible for him to hire Handel as a composerinresidence. The result included such durable masterpieces as the 12 Chandos Anthems.

title: Neighborhoods: First Tenants of Parkchester Have Grown Old
description: The fate of the Parkchester pioneers is written in a quavering hand in Rose Jordan's notebook.

title: Deposit Inflow Is Higher At Mutual Savings Banks
description: Deposits in the nation's mutual savings banks rose an estimated $250million in October, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday, up from a gain of $138million in October last year. Savings banks in New York State accounted for $159million of the increase.

title: Screen: Cruel Illusion:' Jennifer on My Mind' at Number of Houses
description: What can you say about a young girl who died? That she was beautiful. And blond. And that although she has been dead for a while, she is still occupying the plastic easy chair in the living room."I wonder how she would feel now, sealed inside the frame of an 18th-century harpsichord?," muses Marcus, having found a hiding place for Jennifer, whom he has recently eased to her death with a gratefully accepted overdose of heroin. Of course the harpsichord won't do forever, and getting rid of Jennifer becomes the action, or at least one-half the action of "Jennifer on My Mind," which opened yesterday at several local theaters.Marcus (Michael Brandon), a nice, rich, Jewish boy from New York, meets and falls in love with Jennifer (Tippy Walker), a rich and not very nice and awfully non-Jewish girl from Oyster Bay, while they are both in Venice. He pursues her through the canals of Venice and to her home on Long Island and ultimately to the top of a high-rise on the New Jersey Palisades, where she lets him kill her and where he begins the romantic reminiscence in extended flashbacks, that so oddly counterpoints the hapless removal of her remains.Noel Black ("Pretty Poison") directed the film, and Erich Segal wrote it (after a novel by Roger Simon), and in the contest between Black's black humor and Segal's languorous humors both sides lose. In form, and indeed in content, "Jennifer on My Mind" resembles nothing so much as a satyr play to "Love Story," if one were needed. But I am not sure the effect was intended, and with its hackneyed invention and incredible dialogue (and more incredible interior monologues), the film belongs to that desperate class of comedy that is almost never funny except when it doesn't mean to be.And yet there is a degree of interest in the film if only for its theme, which is not drug addiction but rather that nightmare fragment of the American dream in which the eager alien breaks his head and his heart in winning the native shores to find the countryside a desert and the inhabitants a mirage. Marcus is the last refinement of alien awareness, and Jennifer is not so much on his mind as in it. She is its last and cruelest illusion, carrying her perfect inaccessibility to the point of death. In an odd way, "Jennifer on My Mind" is about aspirations rather than relations, and on that level it very nearly evades its absurdities to come round almost to the point of admiration.

But, even before enactment, planners inside the Administration and the appropriations committees are talking about releasing only a modest fraction of such amountsa totally inadequate response to a crisis that threatens hundreds of institutions.

title: Film: Frank Zappa's Surrealist '200 Motels'
description: No self-proclaimed surrealistic documentary can be all bad when it has a score composed by Frank Zappa, the Orson Welles of the rock music world, played by Zappa's Mothers of Invention and the Royal Philharmonic, as well as some extraordinarily clever visual effects, achieved by the use of videotape, and a title like "200 Motels."The title is, perhaps, the best thing about the film that opened yesterday at the Plaza Theater. It cheerily evokes the image of groupies, warm beer, cheeseburgers, overflowing ash trays, efficient plumbing and inefficient air-conditioning, which freezes the air without cleaning it, in an endless chain of identical bed-sitters that are the homes-away-from-home for the members of a touring rock group."200 Motels" is not all bad, but because it's a movie with so many things going on simultaneously, it becomes too quickly exhaustingin actual effect, soporific.At its heart, "200 Motets" is a subjective "A Hard Day's Night" in desperate need of the early Beatles. It is Zappa's somewhat put-on, but mostly put-down, vision of what it's like to be Frank Zappa (played by Ringo Starr) and the Mothers of Invention while touring through a universe that is one big Centerville, U.S.A. ("a real nice place to raise your kids up"). It is a place of dim-witted slogans, loneliness and aggressive girls with nicotine-stained fingers.There are terrible sight gags, a very funny cartoon sequence ("Dental Hygiene Dilemma") in which a bored, motel-bound musician is reduced (if I remember correctly) to smoking a stolen towel, an outrageous oratorio dedicated to all those men and women who don't measure up (in one way or another), bits and pieces of choreography, references to Stanley Kubrick's "2001," and at least several dozen potentially funny ideas that are never developed, since the movie has the attention span of a speed freak.The nonstop visual effects are initially stunning, as when the black-and-white zebra stripes on a floor seem to break loose and wrap themselves around a body, when a blob of blue dances around the frame of the film, finally attaching itself to someone's nose, and when a conventionally photographed face dissolves into a kind of line-drawing of the same face. I have no idea how these things are done but they are quite marvelous.However, they are also immensely distracting in case you have any interest in the score. The music, which includes some of the most ambitious material ever written by Zappa, tends to go into one head and out the other, as if in flight from the almost predatory optical tricks.Being easily intimidated myself, I found it impossible to respond to or even to identify the various Mothers, who move in and out of the movie like pale blobs of color, or to Ringo Starr, who is easily recognizable but always slightly ill-at-ease. Theodore Bikel also is recognizableand ridiculousas a kind of Lucifer figure who wanders across the screen dispensing hamburgers from a fuming briefcase.Like a light show, "200 Motels" has no particular focal point, being principally an anthology of poor jokes and spectacular audio-visual effects, a few of which might expand the mind, but all of which, taken together, are like an overdose of Novocain.

title: Head of Film Rating Group Assailed on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10Recent practices of the Code and Rating Administration of the Motion Picture Association of America came under attack here yesterday.

title: Personal Finance
description: One of the least understood factors in buying a house is an item called closing costs.

title: CABLE TV WEIGHS WHITE HOUSE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 The intricate puzzle of cable television policy appears once again to be on the verge of falling or being hammered, into shape in industry meetings tonight and tomorrow.

title: Butler Aviation Charges ExChief Misused Funds
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 10 (UPI)  Butler Aviation International, Inc., said today it had sued its former chairman, Paul S. Dopp, in New Jersey Superior Court on charges of misusing $600,000 in company funds.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) Heads of several large Wall Street firms appealed to the Securities and Exchange Commission today not to open membership in the New York Stock Exchange to mutual funds and other institutions.

title: HAROLD F. BULKLEY, UNION CARBIDE AIDE
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Nov. 11Harold F. Bulkley, retired director of public relations of the Union Carbide Corporation, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, of a heart attack. He was 76 years old and lived at 648 Ely Avenue.

title: Neighborhoods: Briarwood Reassures Black Family
description: The friendliness was unmistakable between the black and white schoolgirls leaving Junior High School 217, in the Briarwood section of Queens. They were obviously accustomed to walking from school together and speaking freely about almost anything.

title: Star Envoy Takes Feature
description: The main Aqueduct event yesterday was won by Lloyd Miller's Star Envoy, with Jean Cruguet riding. Star Envoy finished 2 lengths ahead of Admirals Fate, with the favored Pollution third in the field of, six. Timed in 1:53, Star Envoy paid $6.40 for $2 straight.

title: A Zest for Life
description: Renowned as a droll wit and writer for the humor magazine Punch, A. P. Herbert was more than a mere funny man. He was also a crusading reformer, a conservationist, a novelist, a barrister who never practiced law, a Member of Parliament, a writer of musical comedies and a thoroughgoing English character.

title: RABBI GOLDFINE, 56, SERVED 2 COLLEGES
description: Rabbi Marvin J. Goldfine, chaplain of the B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation at Hunter and Baruch Colleges since 1956 and Jewish chaplain of the Presbyterian Hospital, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center since 1955, died yesterday at the center. He was 56 years old and lived at 41 Fifth Avenue.

description: TOKYO, Nov. 11  A senior Japanese leader disclosed today that Japan had made a first official overture to China intended to lead toward diplomatic relations.

title: Advertising:
description: Like so many of us these days, Stanley C. Gillette, the president of the Van Heusen Company, is being educated by one of his children.

title: Drop in Jobs Reported In Area in September
description: Employment in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area declined by 23,000 in September, as a 43,000 drop in the area's governmental payrolls counteracted a seasonal rise of 20,000 jobs in thou private sector, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Stallworth and Riordan Sent to Baltimore
description: Caught in the frustrating grip of an early season slump that had dragged them down into a tie for last place in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division, the New York Knickerbockers yesterday made a trade designed to add to their offensive firepower.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 11President Salvador Allende Gossens submitted to Congress today a catchall proposal for constitutional reforms that include replacement of the present Legislature, controlled by the opposition, by a onechamber People's Assembly.

title: Gallup Says U.S. Public Rates U.N. Prestige at a Record Low
description: The prestige of the United Nations has dropped to an alltime low in the United States, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: The Talk of Marin County
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 11From highway 101 on the slope of the mountains just north of the Golden Gate bridge the clump of faded yellowing buildings that make up San Quentin prison rise on the distant horizon. They sit there on the edge of the blue waters of San Francisco Bay, all but lost in the shadow of Mount Tamalpais and the split level homes that are lodged in the hills nearby.

title: PROTESTANTS HOLD BELFAST PROTEST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 11  Twenty thousand Protestants marched silently in downtown Belfast today in an outpouring of anger and feat over looming political changes in Northern Ireland.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER SEALS, 52
description: BOSTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)Phil Esposito scored two goals and assisted on one tonight to help the Boston Bruins to a 52 victory over the California Golden Seals.

title: Quiet Day at Nationalist Offices Here
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11It was a quiet day at the offices of the Chinese Nationalists.

title: Tale Is Now Familiar
description: The year was 1885. The place was Bridger's Wells, Nev., a shabby cow town. There, one spring night, 28 men rode out and, in a Sierra pass called the OxBow, found three sleeping men with 50 head of cattle of a murdered rancher. Through the night, the mob talked of cowardice and concience and justice; and in the morning, they hanged three innocent men.

title: State Is Enjoined on Medicaid Cut for 660,000
description: A massive reduction of the state's Medicaid program was blocked in Federal Court here yesterday. The reduction would have affected 660,000 New Yorkers.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 106.1 from 106 last week.

title: Peking Delegation in U.S. Greets a Great People
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11Peking's delegation to the United Nations arrived in New York today, 16 days after the General Assembly had overwhelmingly voted to admit the mainland Government as the only legitimate representative of China.

title: Antilitter Award to Michigan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Keep America Beautiful, a nationwide antilitter organization, presented its 1971 state award today to Michigan.

title: A Medical Center To Serve Children To Be Built on L.I.
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 11  A comprehensive children's medical center will be built at a cost of $10million on the grounds of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, it was announced here today.

title: WOMAN, 48, GETS LIFE FOR PERJURY
description: MIAMI, Nov. 11  Criminal Court Judge Alfonso C. Sepe today sentenced a 48yearold woman, Mrs. Irene Maxcy Wells, to life imprisonment for perjury in the trial of the man who allegedly arranged the murder of her husband.

description: Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told an extraordinary meeting of Wall Street leaders yesterday that President Nixon's economic program gave him powerful reasons for expecting economic recovery to accelerate and corporate profits to rise.

title: Engrossing Show Is Offered at Pace
description: An extraordinary show of modern masters has opened at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, marking both a new orientation for the gallery (which has hitherto concentrated on new art by living artists) and a significant expansion of its exhibition space. Called Galerie Beyeler at Pace, the show consists of 49 worksmost of them of top museum quality from the stock of the Galerie Beyeler in Basel, Switzerland, one of Europe's leading dealers in the classics of modern art. Among the artists represented are Monet, Mondrian, Picasso, Leger and Bonnard.

title: Woman Has Worked for 20 Years to Save America's Vanishing Wild Horse
description: RENO, Nev.Judy Lynn, the country and Western singer, was working the crowd in the lounge at Harrah's gambling casino, dressed in white hot pants embroidered with heavily sequined red roses.

title: Gain Is Reported Here On Issue in Port Strike
description: The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association were said to be close to a possible agreement last night on a major issue that has divided them since the union closed down most major Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports on Oct. 1the guaranteed annual income.

title: F.P.C. HEARS FOES OF POWER PLANT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Opponents of the controversial $350million Blue Ridge hydroelectric project, including the states of Virginia, West Virginia and North Carolina, argued before the Federal Power Commission today that a license for the project, as now planned, would be illegal.

title: Books of The Times
description: We are raising a generation that doesn't know how to leave home, is the Handlins' considered judgment in Facing Life, conclusion they come to after tracing for more than 300 years the changing contours of a revealing triangle, made up of lines that lead from the family unit to the economic situation to the school. As one alters, the relationship of the others alters too. The key to understanding these changes is the answer to the question, When does the family let its offspring go? It is surprising how much the answer will tell us about the bonds that unite the family, the economic conditions under which it flourishes, the state of the schools and what they are expected to teach and the value judgments of society.

title: CONVERSION OF COAL TO GAS IS SPURRED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Government signed today a contract aimed at overcoming the growing shortage of natural, gas.

title: S.C.C.A. Division Convention Will Begin Here Tonight
description: A film on road racing has been added to tonight's informal program of the annual convention of the Northeast Division of the Sports Car Club of America at the Biltmore Hotel. Registration begins at 5 o'clock and the movie, sponsored by British Leyland Motors, is scheduled for 8 o'clock preceding a meeting of the Division officials.

title: Behind Police Corruption
description: The ugly secret is out. After years of pretending that the heroin traffic was an unavoidable if tragic blight, a kind of Harlem Dutchelm disease, we have been forced to face the truth. The narcotics that kill thousands of New York's children each year, that make much of the city a jungle as junkies steal and mug for the price of a fixthe traffic in these drugs is protected by police, is participated in by police, has become the largest source of illicit police income. Obviously, high police commanders have been either involved or incompetent. It is the department that is rotten.

title: Taipei Drops Tie to Beirut
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  The Nationalist Government suspended diplomatic relations with Lebanon today, the Central News Agency reported. Beirut and Peking announced the establishment of diplomatic ties yesterday.

description: Firefighters here decided yesterday to adhere strictly to the rule book to put pressure on the city for a contract settlement.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayorelect Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia says he doesn't like the term Mafia  because other ethnic groups are involved in organized crimebut, he declared: It is true that the top men are Italian.

title: Two Lenny Lipton Films Are Shown at the Whitney
description: The charm of home movies is more often in the will of the maker than in the eye of the beholder. But at least one of the two highly professional homemovie type films of Lenny Lipton now showing at the Whitney Museum should satisfy anyone open to the pleasure of seeing a world of friends and neighbors on the screen.

title: Hamilton Will Seek Rise in Productivity By City's Employes
description: Edward K. Hamilton has said that the top priority in his first month as Deputy Mayor will be an effort to get city employes to do measurably more work for their money.

title: North American Rockwell Earnings Show Increase as Others Issue Reports
description: Improved profits of its aerospace and electronics groups plus lower interest costs were primarily responsible for lifting earnings of the North American Rockwell Corporation in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 by 6 per cent from the former fiscal year.

title: CEILINGS CHANGED ON FOREIGN LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11voluntary program governThe Federal Reserve Board announced today revisions of its ling bank lending to foreigners, to reflect the Congressional mandate that all export credits be exempt from the program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: William V. Shannon's Oct. 21 column Notes on Violence, using a quote from Sartre about putting one's body as well as one's mind on the line as a launching point for a gratuitous sermon, was quite amazing to me. Sartre needs no defense from me, but the interpretation of using one's body as a call to violence seems to abrogate much of the First Amendment.

title: Unions May Seek ShortTerm Pacts
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 11Labor leaders warned today that they might seek oneyear contracts in an attempt to recoup wage gains lost as a result of the new Federal wage controls.

title: Text of Price Commission's Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Following is the text of the initial statement by the Price Commission explaining some policies in the next phase of the economic program:

title: Japanese Fishermen Fined
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 11 (AP)A Japanese captain and his fishing boat have been fined $115,000 for illegally fishing within the United States 12mile limit. The fines were announced today by G. Kent Edwards, United States Attorney for Alaska, who said the fine was the largest penalty ever imposed for such a violation.

title: Watson Formally Sentenced To Death for Tate Murder
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 (Reuters)  Superior Court Judge Adolph Alexander formally sentenced Charles Watson to death today but said that if he had tried the case alone without a jury he might have brought in a different verdict against the slayer of Sharon Tate.

title: S.A.S. Plans $208 Fare For Its RoundTrip Flights
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System became the latest airline yesterday to propose its own fares across the Atlantic starting Feb. I, when the existing fare accord of the scheduled airline expires.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 STEEL MAKERS PLAN SHUTDOWNS
description: The United States Steel Corporation and the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation annouced yesterday shutdowns of steel operations that would affect more than 2,800 workers.

title: Students Riot in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Rioting students burned cars and buses in the center of Caracas for a second day in a row today as the police and troops surrounded high schools to try to halt violence.

title: Production and Marketing Called Textile Profit Key
description: The textile industry can make a comeback in profits now that imports from the Far East have been stabilized through the recent quota agreements, Frederick B. Dent, president of Mayfair Mills, said yesterday.

title: HELP IS PRESSED FOR WILD HORSES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) House and Senate conferees agreed today on what Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, called a good compromise to protect the freeroaming wild horses of the West from harassment by man.

title: Digital to Raise Output
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday at Maynard, Mass., that it plans to increase production of its PDP11 computer line by 40 per cent over the next five months. Output is presently at around 100 to 120 units a month, a spokesman said.

title: Philippine Diplomat Seized Here as Heroin Smuggler
description: Tailed by a Federal agent halfway around the world, a Philippine diplomat and Bangkok merchant were arrested here yesterday on charges that they had smuggled 413million worth of heroin into the United States.

title: Medina Aide Testifies at Mylai Trial of Colonel
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 11  The former executive officer of the infantry company that swept through the hamlet of Mylai 4 said today that, despite his close relationship with men in the unit, he never heard a word about the killing of unarmed civilians.

title: House Unit Votes to Curb MassTransit Fare Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The House Banking and Currency Committee, continuing its extensive revision of the Nixon Administration's Phase Two economic legislation, moved today to tighten controls on utility rates and mass transit fares.

title: M.T.A. Says the L.I.R. Is Really the L.I.R.R.
description: The L.L.R, has become the L.I.R.R. again.

title: A Loss to Foreign Policy
description: John Franklin Campbell was an intellectual pixy who was not above writing an April Fool's Day spoof of the State Department's top secret daily summary. But he was also a brilliant Foreign Service officer who wrote the most penetrating critique in years of the way American foreign policy is made and administered.

title: Chile Acquires Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Chile has acquired the Santiago offices of the First National City Bank of New York, the Chilean Embassy announced.

title: Castro Adamant on O.A.S.
description: SANTIAGO, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Premier Castro of Cuba today reiterated that his Government would never rejoin the Organization of American States even if all member nations requested it. Cuba was expelled from the organization in 1964.

title: PLOT TO RELEASE BROWN REPORTED
description: An apparent plot to free H. Rap Brown, the black militant, from police custody at Roosevelt Hospital and remove him to another country while hostage was held to insure his unimpeded passage was reported yesterday by the Bronx District Attorney, Burton B. Roberts.

title: SONICS INFLICT LOSS ON CAVALIERS, 11091
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 11 (AP)The Seattle Supersonics continued their domination of Cleveland with a 11091 National Basketball Association victory tonight, their fifth straight over the Cavaliers in two years.

title: Ban on X Movie Ads Urged
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 11 (UPI)The City Council has voted to ask The Providence Journal and The Pawtucket: Times to cease printing advertisements for Xrated movies.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, Nov. 11  A new American policy has been evident at the Vietnam peace talks since the arrival of William J. Porter two months ago as chief United States negotiator.

title: Bel Canto Opera Stirs Jersey Symphony Audience
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Henry Lewis, gave a Carnegie Hall concert Wednesday evening. On the program, up to the intermission, was Brahms, and everybody listened politely and applauded politelyor even more than politely at the end of the Alto Rhapsody, with Marilyn Horne as soloist. She got a great hand.

title: A. P. Herbert Dead at 81 Wit Was Also Reformer
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 A. P. Herbert, the British author, humorist and social reformer both in and out of Parliament, died in his sleep today at his home in West London. The 81yearold writer, often called the wittiest man of his time, had been in poor health for nearly a year after suffering a stroke.

title: Israeli Confirms Report
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Israel's Ambassador to Washington, Maj. Gen Itzhak Rabin, today indirectly confirmed a report in today's issue of The New York Times that Israel had discussed the possibility of reopening the Suez Canal with the United States.

title: A PUMP IMITATES THE HUMAN HEART
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 11A team of physicians and scientists at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn has brought the development of an artificial heart a step forward by devising a rough model of a heart pump that closely imitates the way the human heart works.

title: Kings End Loss Streak
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 11 (UPI)Jean Potvin scored an unassisted goal after 9 minutes 53 seconds of the third period tonight and Bill Flett added an insurance goal into an empty net with 10 seconds left as the Los Angeles Kings ended a sevengame losing skein with a 42 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Bulaich: Scared but Confident
description: When Norm Bulaich learned he had been drafted by the Baltimore Colts last year, he was waiting for his mother at a Dallas airport. He was so excited he stopped a startled stranger and said, I'm Norm Bulaich. I just got drafted in the first round by the Baltimore Colts.

title: To Marinaro, Snowy Saturdays Can Try Men's Soles
description: Ivy League Roundup

title: Bridge: Caribbean Tournament Won By Jamaica on Last Round
description: Jamaica snatched a lastminute victory in the Caribbean Championships played in Barbados last weekend.

title: Justice Postel, at Persica Trial, Warns Reporters on Coverage
description: The judge in the extortion trial of Carmine J. Persico warned reporters yesterday that he would hold them in contempt of court if they included in their accounts of the case anything that did not transpire in the courtroom.

title: U.S. Extends China's U.N. Group Treatment Equal to Soviet's on Travel Curbs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11The Nixon Admin??tration acted today to accord the Chinese delegation to the United Nations treatment equal to that granted the Soviet Union, although Washington and Peking do not have diplomatic relations.

title: Lindsay Impresses Party's Big Contributors During Formal Washington Visit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11Mayor Lindsay made his first formal appearance today before an arm of the Democratic National Committee, and many said later that they were impressed.

title: 1971 MOBIL OUTLAYS PUT AT $900MILLION
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation's capital and exploration outlays will be over $900million this year and at least that much for several years to come, William P. Tavoulareas, president, told yesterday's special meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

title: Aide of Politicians Is Dead An Author and Editor
description: Josef Berger, the author of a score of books and a formerspeech writer for leading political figures, died yesterday at the Columbia  Presbyterian Medical. Center after a brief illness. He was 67 years old and lived on Shelter Island, L.I.

title: Questions and Answers on Price Panel's Rulings
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Following are some questions compiled by The New York Times about the policies an nounced today by the Price Commission and tentative answers obtained from mem bers of the commission and other sources:

title: CABLE TV ACCORD SETS ITS GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The broadcasting and cable television industries appeared today to have resolved a fiveyear struggle over the future of electronic communications.

title: A ParkandRide Rail Station Is Dedicated in Jersey
description: Metropark, a new parkandride rail station in Woodbridge, N. J., and the first project to use highway trustfund dollars for nonhighway purposes, was dedicated yesterday and will handle its first revenue passengers Sunday.

title: 1971 Corn Harvest Seen as a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) The nation's corn crop is estimated at a recordhurdling 5,551,769,000 bushels, 35 per cent more than last year and 3 per cent more than forecast in October, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 HELD IN SLAYING IN QUEENS PROJECT
description: Two teenagers were arrested last night in the mugging death of an 80yearold woman at a city housing development in Queens.

title: Schoendienst Rehired For 8th Cards' Season
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Red Schoendienst has signed his 1972 contract to manage the St. Louis Cardinals, the general manager, Bing Devine, announced today. It will be his eighth season as manager.

title: SILVER FUTURES CLIMB IN PRICE
description: The silverfutures market here was buoyed by a bill introduced yesterday by Representative James McClure, Republican of Idaho, the biggest silver producing state, that would allow the Treasury to purchase newly mined domestic silver at a price higher than $1.25 a troy ounce.

title: U.S. Against the Charter
description: In cavalier fashion the House of Representatives has now joined the Senate in approving an amendment the military procurement bill that would deal a savage blow at the United Nations and place the United States in flagrant violation of its pledges. The provision would require Washington to breach unilaterally the sanctions twice invoked by the United Nations Security Council against the white racist regime in Rhodesia.

title: Twins Name Worthington
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 11 (AP)Al Worthington, former relief hurler, was named pitching coach today for the Twins, succeeding Mary Grissom, who retired.

title: CONTAINER TAX VOIDED BY COURT
description: The city's special 2cent tax on plastic containers, which it said would have eased wastedisposal and airpollution problems here, was ruled unconstitutional yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Text of Peking Delegate's Greeting
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11Following is a transcript of the remarks made at Kennedy Airport today by Chiao Kuanhua, the chief Chinese delegate, as translated by his delegation:

title: Walter Van Tilburg Clark Dies; Wrote The OxBow Incident
description: RENO, Nov. 11Walter Van Tilburg Clark, author of The OxBow Incident and other books, died of cancer yesterday. His age was 62.

title: U.S.O. Aids Veterans, Too
description: After 30 years of providing for the recreational, welfare, and morale needs of American men and women in uniform, the U.S.O. is extending its services to the returning veteran.

title: 3,000 Students Demonstrate To Protest BusPass Cuts
description: Thousands of high school students, some carrying placards reading, Divided we walk, united we ride and No passes no classes, massed near City Hall yesterday morning and then marched across the Brooklyn Bridge for a fourhour demonstration outside Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Executive Changes
description: Federated Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Frank Mayans as senior vice president for personnel and organization development. Mr. Mayans, who has been vice president of research, succeeds the late John Paul Jones.

title: Woodcock Speaks at Lasker Research Award Lunch
description: Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, said yesterday that systematic and secure national funding by the Federal Government was necessary to liberate medical care from the tyranny of wildly escalating costs and assure every family of new opportunities for preventive care, early diagnosis of illness and effective therapy and rehabilitation.

title: Lawyers Rushing to Draft Price Rules for Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Federal lawyers worked late tonight preparing price regulations that must go to the printter tomorrow morning in order to be ready when they go into effect Sunday morning.

title: INDIA ANSWERS PRESS ON TRAVEL REQUEST
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 11The Indian Government said today that it had taken note of foreign newsmen's requests to travel to the tense border areas of East Pakistan, but said its recent ban was necessary to insure the safety of foreign guests.

title: Market Place: Why the Decline By Delta Corp.?
description: If you were Melvin Schmidt in this drooping market, you'd have a hard time keeping your balance. The position of his firm, Hornblower & Weeks Hemphill, Noyes, is that, sure the market is a question mark, but if the investor is in good stocks, he'll be fairly well protected.

title: VW Expects to Cut Dividend
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, Nov. 11 (Reuters)Volkswagenwerk, A. G., said today a sizable cut in its dividend was inevitable this year, because of wage and cost pressures and problems arising out of the international monetary situation. The company paid an unchanged 18.5 per cent dividend in 1970 on parent company net profit, which declined 42 per cent to 198million marks.

title: Birrell Surrenders to Start A 2Year Term for Fraud
description: Lowell McAfee Birrell, a 64yearold man whose fortunes seesawed from control of 40 corporations to Federal criminal convictions for unlawful stock sales, was imprisoned again yesterday. His persistent appeals were exhausted.

title: Illegal Franchise Actions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Federal Trade Commission today accused the Chock full o'Nuts Corporation of illegally dictating prices and purchasing practices to the operators of its franchised restaurants. The commission announced that it intended to issue a formal complaint against the company unless a settlement could be negotiated. The proposed complaint would strike at practices that are so common as to be considered standard in the multibillion dollar franchising industry.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: VIENNAA lurid footnote has been appended to the history of both World War II and the cold war by Gen. Reinhard Gehlen, once Hitler's military espionage boss for Soviet affairs and subsequently, until 1968, head of West German intelligence.

title: GEN. FRANK C. HAROLD
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11 (UPI) Brig. Gen. Frank C. Harold, commanding general of the 2291st Army Reserve Hospital, died on Tuesday at his home here. His age was 55.

title: For the Christmas Shopper . . .
description: If there's a baby on your Christmas list, consider the Flying Angel. It's a flaxenhaired doll, 8 inches long, that swings from a coil that may be hung from the ceiling over a baby's crib. The coil, which is 15 inches long, stretches to about 5 feet when suspended and bounces nicely when the doll is touched. Two little bells tied around the angel's neck jangle as the doll moves. The noise, plus the flapping of the gauzy wings, should fascinate a baby after the holidays have passed.

title: COUGARS DEFEAT CONDORS, 127109
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 (AP) Jim McDaniels scored 39 points tonight to lead the Carolina Cougars to a 127109 victory over the Pittsburgh Condors in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: National Strike Asked
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (AP) Delegates to the Philadelphia Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations adopted last night a motion to back a nationwide strike to end all unfair aspects of the wageprice freeze.

title: Community Leaders in Bronx Score 2Year Hospital Delay
description: Community leaders and health officials in the central Bronx reacted angrily yesterday to news that funds for of new municipal hospital would be held up at least two years.

title: 15 Japanese Are Killed During Landslide Test
description: YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 11 (Reuters)An experiment by Japanese Government scientists to determine the cause of landslides ended in disaster here today when 15 people were killed beneath a mass of mud and boulders.

title: Weekend Suggestion: Shrimp Creole
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by recipe.

title: Orioles Top Yomiuri Giants With Two Runs in 11th, 20
description: MATSUYAMA, Japan, Nov. 11 (AP)The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Yomiuri Giants, 20, today when Ellie Hendricks singled home Dave Johnson and Paul Blair scored on a wild pitch in the 11th inning.

title: Newton III, Trial Delayed
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP)Testimony in the manslaughter trial of Huey P. Newton was recessed today until Monday after a doctor said the Black Panther leader was ill. Dr. Tolbert Small, who said he was Newton's personal physician, told Superior Court the Panther minister of defense had a bad case of the flu.

title: Screen: Violent 'Haunted Samurai'
description: Zap! Bam! Powie! That's what you'll find in "The Haunted Samurai," the new sword-swinger from Japan at the Bijou Theater.Severed hands and arms fly upward. A crunching sound of steel into human flesh dominates the sound track. There's one huge close-up of a human eyeball skewered by a knife. Even a poor, squealing mouse gets it, at random.All this is cited simply to warn the unwary about the traditional chopped-hamburger aspect of many medieval adventures of Old Japan, as served up by the new one. You'd better have a strong stomach if you go to see this one.A fair-to-medium film such as this, with no particular interest or profundity, is best suited to Japanese audiences or scholars. Equipped with skittish English titles, the story follows a guilt-ridden samurai deserter who does furtive penance as a farmer and then chops up most of the cast by way of further expiation. At least that's what we see, to hi-fi wailing, grunting and yowling on all sides.Hideki Takahashi is definitely a swinger, Masako Izumi makes a pretty, doe-eyed heroine and Isao Natsuyagi is a murderously limber spy out to nail the deserter.Our favorite portion came early as the stalwart hero, lured by a cooing beach girl, finds himself on a coral island surrounded by a murderous band of briefly-clad cuties. Zap! Bam! Powie! Like electric eels, they rain death at him, even chasing him underwater. One of them, with a whooshing sound James Bond might have envied, even spits a dagger straight at him a good forty feet or so away. Indeed, the whole sequence suggests good old "Thunderball."However, Operator 007 has no cause to worry. Score yesterday's adventure at about 002.

title: Holding the Price Line
description: The broad principles laid down by the Price Commission yesterday to hold postfreeze price increases within a 2.5 per cent annual average are an admirable complement to the standards set earlier this week for checking wage inflation.

title: Bill Macy in Box Step
description: Bill Macy has been engaged for a featured role in Murray Sehisgal's new comedy, The Box Step, opening on Broadway Feb. 17th. Alan Alda and Marcia Rodd are costarred.

title: Hardin Out as Farm Chief; President to Keep Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11President Nixon, in political trouble with the nation's farmers, replaced the Secretary of Agriculture today and declared that he had changed his mind about trying to abolish the Department of Agriculture.

title: RIESSEN AND LUTZ CAIN AT BOLOGNA
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Nov. 11 (UPI)Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill, and Bob Lutz of Los Angeles moved into the quarterfinal round of the Bologna open tennis tournament today. The tourney is the last of World Championship Tennis events.

title: Halaby of Pan Am Seeking Power for New Executive
description: Najeeb Halaby, chief execuI five officer of Pan American World Airways, said in a telephone interview yesterday that I he is very anxious that the Pan Am board delegate to whomever it picks as president and chief operating officer all the authority and responsibility that is necessary to conduct the operations of the airline.

title: S. Africa Gains 3Shot World Cup Lead
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 11  South Africa's team of Gary Player and Harold Henning led by three strokes in the opening round of the World Cup golf tournament today while Jack Nicklaus had the individual low of 68 in a round that took 6 hours 8 minutes to complete.

title: POLISH CONCERN BUYS RIGHTS FOR CORFAM
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., which announced last March that it was quitting the Corfam shoematerial business, said yesterday that a Polish company had purchased du Pont's technology for making the poromeric material.

title: Lindsay Joins in a Tribute To Representative Chisholm
description: Mayor Lindsay had a lot of nice things to say about Representative Shirley Chisholm yesterday, but despite the fact that he was wearing a Chisholm for President button, he stopped short of endorsing her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Presidency.

title: Prices Tumble in Bond Market
description: What has become a glut of corporate and taxexempt bonds for sale weighed heavily on the market for fixedincome securities yesterday, and prices tumbled across a broad spectrum.

title: OATH FOR TEACHERS IN STATE IS UPHELD
description: SYRACUSE, Nov. 11 (AP)The constitutionality of New York State's law requiring teachers to, take a loyalty oath has been upheld by a threejudge panel of the United States District Court.

title: Me Nobody Knows Closing
description: The Me Nobody Knows, the longrunning musical, will end its run after Sunday's matinee at the Longacre Theater, unless business picks up, according to a spokesman for the show. It will have given 571 performances.

title: A REIN ON PROFITS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Price Commission proclaimed today a goal of limiting price increases to an average of 2.5 per cent a year and issued a comprehensive set of guidelines forbidding all price rises except those justified by higher costs. It also limited profit margins, but not total profits.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Industrials Off 11.24 To 814.91, Lowest of '71
description: Stock market prices continued to reel downward in moderate trading yesterday. Some market observers attributed the slide to the new pricing standards announced yesterday by the Price Commission while others blamed the strength of the growing bearish sentiment within the investment community.

title: WAGE RISES CITED
description: Some businessmen reacted unhappily yesterday to the news, 2.5 per cent average ceiling on price increases and to the profit restrictions imposed on them by the Nixon Administration's Price Commission.

title: Retail Sales Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The Department of Commerce reported today that departmentstore sales for the week ended Nov. 6 were an estimated $871million, an increase of 12 per cent from $779million the corresponding week last year. Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $8.2billion, an increase of 13 per cent from $7.3billion last year.

title: EXHEAD START AIDE FACES 3 CHARGES
description: A 34yearold assistant director of five Head Start centers in Brooklyn was accused yesterday of accepting pay for two fulltime jobs, although she worked only parttime on each, pretending she needed time to to school.

title: U. S. URGES TOKYO TO END TRADE GAP
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11John B. Connally, the Secretary of the Treasury, made clear today that the Nixon Administration expects the Japanese Government to reverse a $3billion deficit in its balance of trade with Japan.

title: Morality and Controls: A Dissent
description: If Prof. Milton Friedman had criticized Government controls on economic grounds, I would leave it to economists to answer him. But he has attacked the new wageprice controls as deeply and inherently immoral and as a basic violation of the rule of law as developed in Western civilization. It is on his chosen ground as a moral and legal philosopher that I venture to challenge Milton Friedman's notions of economic morality and of the rule of law.

title: Skelton Files for Divorce
description: INDIO, Calif., Nov. 11 (AP)Red Skelton filed for divorce today from his wife of 26 years, officials of Riverside County Superior Court reported.

title: NANCY TOPF DANCES OUTDOOR PROGRAM
description: Summer congealed into winter this week catching Nancy Topf dancing outdoors at various locales in Manhattan, including Battery Park on Tuesday and Wednesday. The dancer was willing but attendance was weakened by the cool air, although those who observed Miss Topf and her accompanist Jon Gibson, were treated to the experience of a real collaboration between artists and their location.

title: Flyers Down Canucks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 (UPI)  Simon Nolet, equaling his goal output of last season, scored an unassisted goal at 14:40 of the third period to earn the Philadelphia Flyers a 43 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: Peking Backers Here Stage Welcome
description: As China's delegation to the United Nations alighted here yesterday, some 250 demonstrators chanted Maoist slogans and waved red banners, dramatizing the recent emergence of a proPeking coalition in the United States.

title: SENATE, 65 TO 24, VOTES $1.5BILLION FOR MILITARY AID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11The Senate approved a $1.5billion authorization for foreign military aid today after restoring a $318million cut by the Foreign Relations Committee from the Administration's request.

title: INJURED RUNNERS DIM GIANTS' HOPES
description: The slow recoveries of Ron Johnson and Tucker Frederickson from leg injuries and the departure of Bob Lurtsema, ostensibly to be replaced by Vernon Vanoy, are increasing the hazards the New York Giants will face in Atlanta Sunday.

title: First Stretch Is Completed In TanzaniaZambia Line
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Nov. 11 (Reuters)The first 313mile stretch of the Chinesebacked railroad linking Tanzania and Zambia was completed today, Ministers of both countries wtached as the final rail was laid.

title: Clean Water Ahead?
description: If the water pollution control bill unanimously passed by the Senate last week remains in more or less its present form, there may be hope that by 1985 the country's deteriorated waterways will once again become fit for human use. Senator Muskie of Maine, the bill's sponsor, concedes that the date fixed for a complete end to pollution is a policy target rather than an enforceable deadline, but even this will be totally unrealizable if the Administration succeeds in its obvious effort to pressure the House into gutting the Muskie bill.

title: CYCLE BY SCHUBERT SUNG BY KAWAMURA
description: Schubert's Die Winterreise, his great cycle of 24 songs, is so demanding in so many ways that it is seldom sung in recitals here, but a Japanese baritone, Eishi Kawamura, chose it for his American debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night and interpreted it beautifully.

title: JOFFREY COMPANY GIVES KETTENT ANZ
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet, a true ensemble company, does not have second casts so much as it has interchangeable casts. Wednesday night at the City Center, in a performance of Gerald Arpino's newest ballet, Kettentanz, Denise Jackson made her debut in the role created by Sue Loyd, and Charthel Arthur appeared for the first time in the role previously danced by Donna Silva. Certainly, this new cast was not second in quality.

title: RAIL TRAFFIC DIPS; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Nov. 6 was considerably below volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the period registered an increase.

title: New York Club Hits Bottom in Its Division
description: A sensational shooting performance by the Golden State Warriors at Madison Square Garden last night frustrated any plans for jubilation harbored by a capacity crowd of 19,588, who saw the Knicks lose their fourth straight game, 112103, and drop into fourth and last place in the National Basketball Association Atlantic Division.

title: SADAT TIES ACCORD TO ISRAELI PLEDGE
description: CAIRO, Nov. 11President Anwar elSadat indicated tonight that an interim agreement between Egypt and Israel for a reopening of the Suez Canal could be achieved if Israel would reply affirmatively to a query last February from Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, about Israeli willingness ultimately to withdraw from all the occupied Sinai Peninsula.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11  With the arrival of the Peking diplomats in New York, the Nixon Administration is beginning to put aside its disappointment over the Taiwan issue and adjust to the new realities of dealing with mainland China.

title: Tree Rustlers Ride Plains
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 11A new kind of rustler is riding the Great Plains.

title: Week's U.S. Wounded Lowest in 6 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11 (AP)The number of Americans wounded in combat last week decreased to 13, a fifth of the number the week before and the lowest total in more than six and a half years, the United States command announced today.

title: HOMEMADE ARMS FOUND IN PRISONS
description: A spokesman for the State Department of Correctional Services said yesterday that recent searches of two state prisons had turned up a formidable array of homemade weapons, but the superintendents of both institutions disputed his assessment of the quantity and character of the weapons found.

title: A Lonely Job With Rewards of Its Own
description: For Imodale Burnett, R.N., life is West Side story. Every weekday you can see her walking with her little black bag in the seamy environs west of Central Park, a nurse who earns her living making house calls.

title: India Denies Major Attack
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 11 (AP)  An Indian Government spokesman today denied reports by Pakistan of a major Indian offensive in the Belonia area of East Pakistan. He said that the fight was between Pakistani troops and East Pakistani forces, not Indian Army battalions.

title: WELFARE STUDY APPROVED HERE
description: Because welfare figure predictions often proved elusive, upsetting efforts to fashion an accurate municipal budget, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved a $220.000 contract for a computer study of poverty level populations.

title: Fashions From Africa That Look at Home in City
description: Shop Talk

title: NIXON AIDE TELLS OF F.B.I. INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 The White House acknowledged today that it had ordered the Federal, Bureau of Investigation to conduct a background check on Daniel Schorr, a correspondent, here for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: 3DAY JOB FAIR OPENS FOR VETERANS HERE
description: A threeday job fair for veterans opened here yesterday at the 69th Infantry Armory, at 68 Lexington Avenue, near 25th Street, amid raucous demonstrations by two veterans groups and conflicting reports on the availability of jobs at the fair.

title: U.S. Urges India and Pakistan to Avoid an AllOut War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 Alarmed by what one official described as a dramatic escalation of fighting along the IndianPakistani border in the last few days, the United States has called on the two sides to avoid allout war.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md. Hunters at the Remington Arms Company's 3,067acre farm and wildlife management area on Maryland's eastern shore took part earlier this week in an experiment to test the effectiveness of shotgun shells loaded with steel pellets.

title: Agriculture Nominee
description: Man in the News

title: Frederick Morris 3d, 66, Dies; Philadelphia Investment Banker
description: PLYMOUTH MEETING. Pa., Nov. 11  Frederick Wistar Morris 3d, long prominent in Philadelphia financial circles, died at his home here last evening after a long illness. His age was 66.

title: MURPHY SUSPENDS A POLICE CAPTAIN
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy suspended police captain yesterday on charges of failing to properly pursue an investigation of allegations of corruption among his men.

title: U.N. Unit Votes Plan on Paying For Damage by a Space Object
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11  An international treaty providing payment for damages caused by objects launched into space was approved on unanimous vote today by the General Assembly's Political Committee.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The impulse was irresistible of recent weeks to rap the knuckles of those few lodge brothers in the Baseball Writers Association who had made incomprehensible omissions in the voting for the outstanding pitchers in the two leagues. The committees of electors were eminently correct in choosing Vida Blue and Ferguson Jenkins as Cy Young Award winners. That was all to their credit.

title: DEFERMENT CHOICE OFFERED IN DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) Curtis W. Tarr, the director of Selective Service, has told draft boards nationwide to allow men who have been deferred to drop their deferments if they choose to do so by Dec. 31.

title: WESTINGHOUSE SETS VOTE ON STOCK SPLIT
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation mailed proxies yesterday to its 155,000 stockholders for a special meeting to vote on the proposed 2for1 split of the common stock. The meeting will be held Nov. 29 at the company's research laboratory in Churchill Borough, near Pittsburgh. The proposal calls for an increase in the number of common shares to 120 million from the present 50 million. Stockholders of record Nov. will be eligible to vote.

title: Soviet Says Aquanauts Failed in Bid for Record
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 11The Soviet Union announced today that an attempt by aquanauts to set a record for underwater isolation had been cut short after 52 days by a violent Black Sea storm that broke the power and communications cables of the submarine chamber.

title: The Life of a Child
description: Hearings before a State Assembly Select Committee have turned up the horrifying statistic that fifty children died last year in this city from physical abuse in their own homes and 34 so far this yearmost of them at the hand of a parent. The number who died of extreme neglect is much higher and the number of those reported be suffering, short of death, from beating, burning and other forms of atrocious assault is far higher still and apparently rising.

title: JAILED PUBLISHER RELEASED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 11One of South Vietnam's most widely known political prisoners, Nguyen Lau, a former newspaper publisher, was released from prison tonight after serving two years and seven months.

title: Ali, Mathis Pronounced Fit, But Buster's Pulse Is High
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 11 (AP)Muhammad Ali and Buster Mathis preparing for their scheduled 12round Astrodome fight next Wednesday, were pronounced in good physical condition today.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO KEEP PEKING OUT OF I.L.O.
description: GENEVA, Nov. 11The United States announced today that it would oppose any attempt to give to the Peking Government the Chinese seat now held by the Nationalists on the governing body of the International Labor Organization. The issue will come up when the governing body meets here Tuesday.

title: Steeplechase Racing to Be Dropped Here Next Year
description: Steeplechase racing, a thoroughbred fixture in this state for 75 years, will not be presented at Aqueduct or Belmont Park next season.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mariner Transmits Photos of a Hazy, Dusty Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov, 11Television pictures of a hazy, dustcovered Mars were transmitted tonight by Mariner 9, the unmanned American spacecraft that is scheduled on Saturday to become the first manmade object to orbit another planet.

title: Where They Know How to Cook Pasta
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: ST. JOHN PASSION IN A NEW VERSION
