description: Bach's setting of The Passion According to St. John, in a new edition by Benjamin Britten and newly translated into English by Peter Pears and Imogen Hoist, was given its first American performance at Philharmonic Hall Wednesday night, in the American Bible Society's annual benefit concert. It was conducted by Meredith Davies, who was making his New York debut.

title: Angela Lansbury in 'Bedknobs and Broomsticks'
description: To the three tiny refugees from the London blitz who come to live with her, Miss Eglantine Price (Angela Lansbury) seems, at first, to be just another eccentric country spinster who drives a motorcycle (that runs on sulphur) and eats nauseating things like roots and nettles.That night, however, they spy her attempting to ride her first broom, side-saddle. ("Technically," say the instructions, "a witch is always a lady.") Miss Price does a couple of barrel rolls, then a nose dive, and crashes, heaplike, into a hedge, whereupon the children decide to blackmail the woman into serving them sausages and fries and into giving them pocket money as well.One needn't worry too much about the children's readiness to blackmail since, almost immediately, they come to love and cherish Miss Price for what she is, an apprentice witch dedicated to helping Winston Churchill save England from the Nazi invasion."Bedknobs and Broomsticks," based on a story by Mary Norton, is a tricky, cheerful, aggressively friendly Walt Disney fantasy for children who still find enchantment in pop-up books, plush animals by Steiff and dreams of independent flight. One of the more attractive props in the film is a brass bed on which Miss Price, the three children and Prof. Emelius Browne (David Tomlinson), the head of the Correspondence College of Witchcraft, fly to the cartoon land of Naboombu in search of the ultimate spell.I suspect the movie will be something of a long, uninterrupted sit for the very children for whom it's intended, and an even longer one for those parents and guardians (both adults and teen-age) who will probably accompany them. Yet, its morals are as unimpeachable as its technical facilityand there really aren't many movies about which you can say that these days.The loveliest part of the filmand the section that can renew one's appreciation of the special gifts of the Disney peopleis the live-action-plus-cartoon sequence in Naboombu featuring, among other things, a tumultuous soccer game, played by cartoon animals and refereed by Tomlinson, and an underwater ballet in which Miss Lansbury and Tomlinson dance in slow-motion surrounded by cartoon fish. It recalls the best of Disney, going all the way back to the first Silly Symphonies.If, aside from its technical wizardry, Disney fantasy has any truly distinguishing feature I would say it is the kind of frigid perfection represented by Julie Andrews in "Mary Poppins." If "Bedknobs and Broomsticks" is somewhat less successful than that film, it also benefits from the presence of Miss Lansbury, who is neither an especially winning singer nor dancer, but who can't help projecting a certain healthy sensuality, even in the most proper Disney circumstances.Robert Stevenson directed the movie and Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman wrote the music and lyrics, none of which I can remember."Bedknobs and Broomsticks" opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, where it will be the Christmas attractionsix weeks before Christmas. It is rushing the big buying season, gently and harmlessly.

title: 665 Pounds of Marijuana And 2 Men Seized in Jersey
description: VINELAND, N. J., Nov. 11 (UPI)Federal customs agents seized 665 pounds of marijuana today from a twinengine turboprop plane from Mexico and arrested two men on smuggling and conspiracy charges.

title: SECURITY IS LIGHT FOR CHINESE GROUP
description: From the point of view of security officials, the entry of the main body of the mainland Chinese delegation into the city yesterday was unpretentious and without complication.

title: 031046 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 11 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 031046. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400; and the last three, $40. Holders of tickets with the last two numbers matching those of the winning number become eligible for a millionaire's drawing later this year.

title: Student Editor Denies Guilt
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 11 (UPI)  Ron Sachs, 21yearold editor of the University of Florida newspaper, The Alligator, pleaded not guilty today to charges of violating Florida's centuryold abortion laws by publishing a list of abortionreferral agencies.

title: Nixon Lays a Wreath At Tomb of Unknown
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11President Nixon today placed a red, white and blue floral wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Stage: Creeping Paranoia and Crawling Malaise
description: Masochism and not basketball is New York's favorite sport. We clearly revel in tales of urban blight and civic incivility. Stalled traffic, trapped elevators, the diurnal tally of petty tragedy that is the New Yorker's lot, the mugging and the pollution, andbest of allthe rueful complaint, that special beefonwry, these all help provide the battle scars that go to make the New Yorker.

title: Jets to Regain 3 Regulars for Colts' Contest; Tarkenton Facing Atlanta Jinx Again Sunday
description: About Pro Football

title: Fighting Is Reported Sporadic but Intense en Pakistan Border
description: AGARTALA, India, Nov. 11 Along the 500mile frontier of Tripura, a pearshaped Indian territory that juts into East Pakistan, Indian troops are actively involved in sporadic but intense battles with Pakistani forces.

title: Senate Vote on Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate today approved a new $1.5billion foreign military aid bill:

title: RANGERS ARE 124 IN N. H. L. SCORING
description: Coach Emile Francis of the New York Rangers, who had just supervised a 75minute team workout at New Hyde Park, LI, had a question when he got to his Madison Square Garden office yesterday.

title: War Hasn't Changed for the Men Who Stay Behind
description: QUANGNAM PROVINCE, South Vietnam, Nov. 9Mrs. Billy Roddie of Brady, Tex., thinks her husband, an infantryman, is coming home from Vietnam because his division, the Americal, is leaving. But he is not: he is here, where he has been nearly every day for the last three months, on a combat patrol in the elephant grass 10 miles west of Danang.

title: Bank Declines to Comment
description: Officials of the First National City Bank said yesterday that they had no immediate comment on the report that tenta tive agreement had been reached to sell the bank's operations in Chile to the Chilean Government.

title: OFFICIAL OF CORE IS ARRESTED HERE
description: The chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality was arrested in the executive offices of the OffTrack Betting Corporation on trespassing charges yesterday after he and fellow CORE members tried to protest a magazine article about their group.

title: MINTON CRONKITE, 79, SHORTWAVE PIONEER
description: Minton Cronkite, who operated the amateur wireless station IBCG in Greenwich, Conn., from which the first shortwave message to span the Atlantic Ocean was sent on Dec. 11, 1921, died Thursday in La Jolla, Calif. He was 79 years old and lived in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: City Plans a Meeting With U.S. On How Phase 2 Affects Fares
description: City officials will meet with representatives of the Federal Government next week in an effort to determine what the most recent wage and price control rulings mean for mass transit here.

title: Richey Defeats Moore
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 12 (Reuters)Topseeded Cliff Richey of San Antonio, Tex., dropped a set then fought back and beat Ray Moore of South Africa, the seventhseeded player today in the Clows tennis tournament. The scores were 46, 64, 62.

title: Mariner 9 Ready to Orbit Mars Tonight
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 12  After a quiet, 248million mile voyage through the blackness of space, Mariner 9 was reported tonight to be on course and ready to rocket into an orbit of Mars tomorrow night.

title: Utilities Feel Left Out in Cold by the Price Guidelines
description: Utility executives feel left out in the cold by the price guidelines. They had expected and felt entitled toexemption from regulation by the Price Commission in Phase Two.

title: 2 UNION MEN SEIZED IN SHAKEDOWN PLOT
description: A chief union shop steward and a steward were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to shake down two maintenance employes of the City Urban Renewal Management Corporation.

title: U.S. GUNSHIPS KILL 8 SAIGON SOLDIERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP)The United States command said yesterday that American helicopter gunships supporting a South Vietnamese army battalion had accidentally killed Government soldiers and wounded 21.

title: REA Express Hit By Wildcat Strikes; Walkouts in 7 Cities
description: Members of the Railway and Airline Clerks' Brotherhood staged wildcat strikes yesterday against REA Express in seven cities, including New York.

title: 2 New Works and Revival On City Ballet's Schedule
description: Two new ballets, a revival and a revised work will be presented during the New York City Ballet season that opens Tuesday at the State Theater. The engagement will end Feb. 20.

title: Utility Group to Expand
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 11 (UPI) The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said today the Central Area Power Coordinating Group, of which it is a member, is planning a $200million addition to the Bruce Mansfeld Generating Station at shippensport, Pa.

title: 3 Boroughs Solicited For Old Newspapers
description: A drive in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens will be made today by the Environmental Action Coalition and the Salvation Army to collect large quantities of old newspapers.

title: Soviet Foreign Aid Estimated at $2.2Billion a Year
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 12  With the American aid program hanging in the balance, Soviet economic and military foreign aid, including that to Cuba and North Vietnam, is now running at about $2.2billion a year, with little likelihood of any serious reduction soon, according to Western specialists.

title: Bridge 5Day Regional Tournament Drew a Total of 2,698 Tables
description: One of the biggest regional tournaments ever held was played last weekend at Host Farm, Lancaster, Pa. In five days there were 2,698 tables in play, an average of 270 a session.

title: Music: Rhythmic Vitality
description: The first oldfashioned program that the New York Philharmonic has given this season also drew one of the few capacity audiences. It was all 19thcentury romanticism with the exception of the opening piece, C.P.E. Bach's Sinfonie for Orchestra in D.

title: Halliburton Profits Increase In Quarter and Nine Months
description: Reflecting substantially larger revenues, earnings of the Halliburton Company in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 rose over those of the year earlier periods, it was reported yesterday by the diversified industrial company.

title: Coal Negotiators Hoping for a Weekend Settlement
description: Negotiators for the coal operators and mine workers pressed their efforts yesterday to reach a settlement that would end a 43day strike.

title: Air Force Sergeant Given 15 Years in Secrets Case
description: ANDERSON AIR FORCE BASE, Guam, Nov. 12 (AP)M. Sgt. Raymond de Champlain of the Air Force was found guilty today of having passed classified military documents to foreign agents and was sentenced to 15 years at hard labor.

title: Judicial Censorship ...
description: Neither the press nor the bar has a blameless record in the delicate matters of trial publicity and of fairness in the process of the trial itself. Sensational reporting has on some occasions given rise to legitimate concern that the independent and unbiased judgment of jurors might be undermined. But there are also instances where justice would have been denied to defendants but for the disclosure by the press of improper actions on the part of police or prosecution.

title: MICHAEL CARACAPPA, 42 YEARS WITH TIMES
description: Michael C. Caracappa, a copy editor on the culture news desk of The New York Times, diod of a heart attack at his home yesterday afternoon. He was 53 years old and lived at 12330 83d Avenue, Kew Gardens, Queens.

title: GUARDS IN QUEENS TO FACE CHARGES
description: Federal Judge Orrin G. Judd ordered the city yesterday to press charges against prison guards whom his own magistrate had absolved of charges of brutality and using excessive force to quell rioting at the Queens House of Detention 13 months ago.

title: ALFRED LINDAU, 73, AN EXMAGISTRATE
description: Alfred M. Lindau, a city magistrate from 1933 to 1947, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 262 Central Park West.

title: Cigar Is a Smoke, But Women Found Better
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 12 Rudyard Kipling was the loser tonight and women the winners as Yale and Princeton clashed in their annual humorous debate.

title: Jet Defensive Unit Regaining That Familiar Look
description: With Gerry Philbin, Al Atkinson and Earlie Thomas returning against Baltimore Sunday, the Jets will have more members of their planned 1971 starting defensive unit in the lineup than at any time since the fourth game of the season.

title: Sales of Interstate Stores Drop as Neisner's Advance
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., and Neisner Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday a decline and a small gain, respectively, in October sales against the same 1970 month.

title: TOTAL ON WELFARE DROPS ACROSS U. S.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)A net total of 84,000 persons were dropped from state welfare rolls in July, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FRANK S. BERGIN, FOOTBALL COACH
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 12 Frank S. Bergin, a wellknown college football referee who had served as a Connecticut State Senator and as a chairman of the Liquor Control Commission, died yesterday at the age of 85.

title: GORDON LIGHTFOOT GIVES CONCERT HERE
description: Gordon Lightfoot's appearance at Carnegie Hall Thursday was a disturbing study in contrasts. The Canadian folk singer/songwriter has written some superb songs, a few of which have hit the upper limits of the American popularity charts; he plays fine guitar. sings in a distinctive baritone voice, and is gooklooking enough to be a film star.

title: U.S. Agrees to Lend Peru $31Million
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 12 (AP)Robert H. Finch, adviser to President Nixon, signed agreements today providing for United States loans of $31million to finance lowcost housing and community development for survivors of Peru's devastating earthquake of May, 1970.

title: INVESTING CURBS URGED IN CANADA
description: TORONTO, Nov. 12A taskforce report that the Canadian Government has refused to publish recommends creation of an agency to regulate new foreign investment in Canada and expansion of existing foreigncontrolled companies.

title: U.A.W., on Eve of Meeting, Narrowing Its Social Role
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12  The United Automobile Workers was never just a union; part of it was always a cause.

title: U.S. Agency Accused in Plant Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Dr. Willard F. Mueller, who served as the chief economist of the Federal Trade Commission for eight years, today accused the Office of Management and Budget of being an errand boy of the advocates of corporate secrecy.

title: South Africans Keep 3Shot Golf Lead
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12Describing his golf as almost perfect, Gary Player scored a 67 in the World Cup tournament today to take the individual lead and keep South Africa ahead in the team race.

title: State Panel Says Newark Is Being Run Inefficiently
description: TRENTON, Nov. 12The State Task Force on Urban Programs has charged that the Newark administration Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson is riddled with inefficiency, noshow jobs, wasteful duplication and purchasing practices and bad planning.

title: Carroll French Dies at 81; A Sculptor and Painter
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 12Carroll French, a sculptor and painter, was found dead yesterday in the pond at the home of a neighbor, Alan Anderson, the son of the late Maxwell Anderson, the playwright. He was 82 years old and lived on South Mountain Road here.

title: 76ers Trim Pistons, 115101;
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers scored 8 straight points early in the fourth quarter tonight to break open a tight game and defeat the Detroit Pistons, 115101.

title: After Many Years, a Seligmann Show
description: So far as the visual arts are concerned, surrealism was a movement divided against itself. On the one hand, it promoted an interest in extreme states of consciousness in a radical eroticism and even political radicalismthat sometimes led to significant artistic innovations. On the other, it was often content to deal with its new images in the most traditional and academic manner. Surrealist art was often, indeed, an academic art in avantgarde disguise.

title: Vinyl Group Name Change
description: The Vinyl Fabrics Institute, whose membership includes producers of various types of vinyl materials, will change its name to the Chemical Fabrics and Film Association on Jan. 1.

title: Notes on People
description: Premier Elsaku Sato of Japan invited Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally to his Tokyo residence, and one of the things they talked about had nothing to do with Mr. Connally's fourday official visit. The Premier asked Mr. Connally about the events of Nov. 23, 1963, when Mr. Connally, then Governor of Texas, was wounded and President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in the same car in a motorcade in Dallas. Mr. Sato said he had long wanted to extend his condolences to Mr., Connally for his injury.

title: Critics of Godfather Game Are Making a Racket
description: Once upon a time people put violins in violin cases. Then they put machine guns in violin cases. When they put an item called The Godfather Game in a violin case and offered it for sale, this is what happened:

title: Stage: Revival of Park
description: There is nothing painful about the Equity Library Theater's revival of Park, a fourcharacter musical that played 10 performances on Broadway last year. Nor is there cause for rejoicing, except for the policy of plucky professionalism at the uptown showcase.

title: SIGN TO FOE SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12President Nixon announced today that he would withdraw 45,000 more American soldiers from South Vietnam by Feb. 1, retaining a force of 139,000 men to strengthen his hand in seeking a negotiated settlement of the war.

title: Antiques
description: Kazak rugs are latterday antiques but their beauty goes before their age, as their growing popularity among collectors indicatesparticularly in the current exhibition of 40 examples organized by the New York Rug Society at the Finch College Museum.

title: Dr. Huldah B. Kerner Dies; Internist in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 Dr. Huldah Bender Kerner, specialist in internal medicine, died yesterday in Graduate Hospital after a long illness. She was 50 years old and lived at 1919 Chestnut Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: VW SAYS NEW MODEL DID NOT FIT POLICY
description: WOLFBURG, West Germany, Nov. 12 (AP)  Volkswagenwerke, A. G., said today it had abandoned well advanced plans for a successor to its massproduced beetle sedan. It said the proposed new car would not fit into the West German automobile manufacturer's longrange model policy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Quits in Disaster
description: TOKYO, Nov. 12 (UPI)Wataru Hiraizumi, director of an experiment that ended in a landslide that killed 15 persons, took full responsibility for the accident today and handed in his resignation to Premier Eisaku Sato.

title: BANKS WON'T CHANGE THEIR FLOATING RATE
description: The First National City Bank, the Irving Trust Company and the First National Bank of Bostonthe three largest banks with floating minimum charges on business loans announced yesterday that their rates would remain unchanged next week at 5 per cent.

title: RETAIL SALES UP BY THIN MARGIN
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 12Retail sales rose only slightly in October, according to preliminary figures, the Census Bureau disclosed today.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12A communications systems to be patented Nov. 23 permits one microwave transmitter to broadcast as many as 18 television channels at once. Community antenna television stations plan to use Airlink equipment to relay their programs. Ira Kamen, chairman and president of the Laser Link Corporation, Woodbury, L. I., and Dr. Joseph H. Vogelman, senior vice president and research director, will be granted Patent 3,623,105.

title: FRANCE ANDISRAEL MEET ON IMPASSE
description: PARIS, Nov. 12France and Israel, once allies and now political adversaries, have begun important talks here on ways of improving their relations.

title: Adelphi Head Is Injured By Explosion on Stairwell
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 12 Randall P. McIntyre, the acting president of Adelphi University, was slightly injured today when an explosive device went off inside a metal cabinet on a stairwell, causing the door to fly off and strike him in the head.

title: Dutch Sailor, 18, Slain in Belfast Dentist's Office
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 12  Gunmen wearing hoods burst into the crowded waiting room of a dentist's office here today and shot to death an 18yearold Dutch sailor.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On Thursday, Earl Monroe, a professional basketball player of allstar status, accepted with pleasure being traded to the New York Knicks by the Baltimore Bullets, for whom he had refused to play three weeks ago.

title: 100 GUARDSMEN TO RECLAIM PARK
description: A company of 100 Army National Guard troops with shovels and, entrenching tools at the ready will invade Inwood Hill Park in northern Manhattan to day to begin reclaiming over grown woodlands that the shortstaffed Parks Administration has long been unable to clear.

title: Senate, 4037, Votes Rise In Tax Exemption to $800
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Senate voted 40 to 37 today for a further tax cut of $1.9billion for individuals. The reduction, effective next year, would come in the form of an increase to $800 in the personal exemption.

title: Pirates' Stargell Undergoes Successful Surgery on Knee
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (UPI) Willie Stargell of the Pittsburgh Pirates, the major leagues' home run leader, underwent what was described as successful surgery today to repair a torn cartilage in his left knee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: First Step to Day Care
description: The federallyaided day care plan that has emerged from SenateHouse conference represents a major advance toward a realistic policy of dealing with young children of working mothers. The measure's most obvious flaw is that the cutoff point for free services, set at family incomes of $4,320, is so low that virtually only welfare recipients will be eligible. But the schedule of fees, which rise according to family earnings, is reasonable the lower brackets.

title: CHRISCRAFT GROUP ASKS MEETING DELAY
description: The Chancery Court in Philadelphia reserved judgment yesterday on a petition by dissident stockholder group in ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., for postpcnement of a Dec. meeting.

title: ROBERT BEALS, 57, LED COMPUTICKET
description: Robert Diggs Beals, a financial executive, who retired in 1968 as president of the Computicket Corporation, a ticket vending organization and subsidiary of the Computer Sciences Corporation, died Thursday in an auto accident in Parsippany, N. J. He was 57 years old and lived at 15 Old Sleepy Hollow Road, Briarcliff Manor, N. Y.

title: Virginian Runs for Senate
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 12 (UPI)Representative William L. Scott. Republican of Virginia, announced today that he would seek his party's nomination to run for the Senate next year, almost certainly against Senator William B. Spong Jr., the incumbent who is a Democrat.

title: MRS. DANIEL B. FREY
description: Mrs. Ruth Jacobus Frey, the wife of Daniel B. Frey, executive vice president of Harry Winston, Inc., the jewelry concern, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. She was 59 years old and lived at the Beresford, Central Park West at 81st Street.

title: Youth Gets 5 Life Terms
description: SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Nov. 12 (AP)Douglas Dean, 19 years old, of Sheboygan, was sentenced today to five consecutive terms of life in prison for the murders of his mother and the mother and three brothers of a girl friend. Wisconsin law does not provide for capital punishment.

title: STRIKE SET SUNDAY AGAINST GREYHOUND
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 (UPI)  The Amalgamated Transit Union called a strike today, effective at noon Sunday, against Greyhound Lines, Inc. But union members in at least one Ohio city walked off their jobs immediately.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ADVENTURES OF MAO ON THE LONG MARCH. By Frederic Tuten. 121 pages. Richard Kasah Book. Citadel. $5.95.

title: Theater Critic Position Is Vacant at Channel 4
description: WNBCTV has been without the services of a theater critic since last Sunday.

title: DEAN WITTER FILES A PUBLIC OFFERING
description: William M. Witter, chairman and chief executive of Dean Witter & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that the company had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of 1,550,000 shares of its common stock to the public.

title: The Talk of The U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov 12The waitresses, the barbers, the sweepers at United Nations headquarters the working men and womenfeel a bit removed from the fine statements, the flashbulbs and the comings and goings of manicured diplomats in the corridors.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Prices of soybean futures fell under heavy selling pressure on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The decline by the daily limit of 10 cents a bushel was the fifth consecutive day of lower soybean prices, producing a total loss of 18 cents since last Friday's close.

title: Nixon Inching Closer To Stating Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)President Nixon inched closer today to announcing his candidacy for a second term.

title: Pakistani Rebels Say Force Is Strong and Gaining
description: AGARTALA, India, Nov. 11, The Sector 3 headquarters of the guerrilla forces fighting the Pakistani Army for the independence of East Pakistan is an idyll of wooded hills and streams that straddles the border between East Pakistan and the Indian territory of Tripura.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert S. Leventhal has been appointed senior vice president of the Engelhard Industries Division and vice president of the Engelhard Minerals & Chemical Corporation.

title: OTC and Amex Prices Drop
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market ended mostly lower yesterday, although an afternoon rally managed to erase many of the earlier losses.

title: LILCO IS PLANNING A NEW GENERATOR
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., Nov. 12 The Long Island Lighting Company said today that public hearings for its proposed nuclear power plant in Shoreham had been so protracted that a fourth oilburning generator would have to be built at its plant here.

title: Elizabeth to Visit France
description: PARIS, Nov. 12 (Reuters)Queen Elizabeth II of Britain will pay an official visit to France from May 15 to 19 at the invitation of President Pompidou, the Elyse Palace announced today. She last made a state visit to France in 1957.

title: Russian Will Pay Lobsterman $89,000
description: WESTPORT, Mass., Nov. 12 The Soviet fishing fleet and an American lobster company agreed today on an $89,000 settlement resulting from damage done to American equipment by Russian trawlers.

title: SQUIRES VANQUISH NETS IN OVERTIME
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 12  Julius Erving came home tonight and helped draw the largest home crowd in the New York Nets' twoyear history. But it was his teammate, Charlie Scott, who scored 42 points to lead the Virginia Squires to a 127123 victory in overtime.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP AS TRADING GAINS
description: Stock prices stumbled down a step yesterday to reach a new low level for 1971. The Dow Jones industrial average finished 1.97 points lower at 812.94.

title: EUROPEAN STEELS KEEP ADVANTAGE
description: PARIS, Nov. 12  Even after taking into account the effects of the 10 per cent import surcharge and the upward currency adjustments of foreign countries, a number of foreign steel products laid down at United States ports are substantially cheaper than American steel.

title: Cincinnati Group Offers Exciting Musical Blend
description: The noontime jazz sessions that Jazz Adventures has been presenting every Friday since last January took a slightly different turn yesterday. A group from Cincinnati that mixes jazz, rock, pop and a strong dollop of soul, Dee Felice and the Mixed Feelings, made its New York debut at Jazz Adventures' new location, the Maisonette of the St. RegisSheraton Hotel, and, for the first time, brought something beside a straight jazz outlook to the sessions.

title: 3 Bus Lines Agree To Carry Children For 2 More Weeks
description: The city's three major school bus operators agreed yesterday to continue service to 108,500 public and parochial school pupils for at least the next two weeks while the Internal Revenue Service determines the price the companies should get.

title: HERBERT IS ACCUSED OF BEATING CIVILIANS
description: PHOENIX, Arix., Nov. 12 (UPI)The Arizona Republic, of Phoenix, and The Chicago SunTimes printed interviews with Maj. Gen. John Barnes today in which he accused Lieut Col. Anthony Herbert of beating unarmed Vietnamese villagers and conducting himself like a coldblooded killer.

title: HOBEAU ENTRY 21 IN BIG A FEATURE
description: A threehorse entry representing the Hobeau Farm is the overnight 21 favorite in the 1mile Queens County Handicap, the feature event at Aqueduct today. Peace Corps, at 117 pounds, is the top weight in the group, and he will he teamed with Tunex and Coup Landing, each at 116.

title: Kretchmer to Play Major Role in Lindsay Campaign
description: Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, will assume a leading role in Mayor Lindsay's drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Saigon Upholds Decision
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13 (AP)The South Vietnamese Government said today that President Nixon's decision to cut United States troop strength by 45,000 over the next two months was based on improved security.

title: Times Director Is Named Trustee at Rockefeller U.
description: The election of Mrs. Marian S. Heiskell, director of special activities of The New York Times, as a trustee of the Rockefeller University was announced yesterday.

title: Social Health Group Says Syphilis Cases Rise 15.6%
description: The number of reported syphilis cases in the United States increased 15.6 per cent in the fiscal year 1971 over the year before, Dr. Bruce Webster, president of the American Social Health Association, said here yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: Gunman Hijacks Jet With 124, Captured After Third Landing
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., Saturday, Nov. 13A gunman who hijacked an Air Canada jetliner carrying 124 persons collapsed early today after it landed in Calgary, Alberta, after a sixandahalfhour hijacking in which he received an undisclosed amount of money in ransom and caused the plane to change directions several times.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Democratic Congressional delegation from New York was building a pretty good record for getting together a couple of times a month to talk about mutual problems until last Wednesday, when some of the Representatives found out who was coming to lunch. It was City Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens County Demo cratic leader who disinvited Mayor Lindsay to a Queens dinner for Senator Edward M. Kennedy last month, and who is supporting Senator George McGovern for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Grand Prix Loses Backer
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (UPI) The International Lawn Tennis Federation said today PepsiCola had withdrawn its sponsorship of the Grand Prix circuit, but that a new sponsor had been found for 1972.

title: The U.N. Deserves A Decent Burial
description: This is not the time for cynicism, observed Secretary General Thant a few days before the ouster of Taiwan from the U.N. This is the time when member states should honor their pledges. . . .

title: DR. JOHN SCHMITT, EDUCATOR, 42, DEAD
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12Dr. John A. Schmitt, professor and former associate dean of the Boston College School of Education, died Monday after a long illness. He was 42 years old.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Nov. 12It began with a letter from the Ardoyne, a Roman Catholic ghetto of Belfast.

title: Market Place:
description: Some observers who have watched President Nixon wrestle with inflation wonder why a man so flexible as he is hasn't adopted a business valueadded tax.

title: U.S. ASSAILED IN U.N. ON RHODESIA ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 12Representatives of developing countries condemned the United States today for its plans to import chrome from Rhodesia in the face of United Nations trade sanctions against her.

title: Exchange Punishes A Former Partner Of Orvis Brothers
description: The New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had disciplined a former partner in Orvis Brothers, one of the member firms that collapsed last year, on charges that he had engaged in fraudulent acts.

title: Fordham U. Retires Rameses 23
description: The left horn on Rameses 23, Fordham University's ram mascot, was growing into the animal's eye, partially blinding it, so yesterday Fordham turned the ram over to the which will try to find a home for him on a farm or at the Bronx Zoo, or some other zoo, probably one for children.

title: JOHN ROWLES PLAYS THE PERSIAN ROOM
description: John Rowles has arrived at the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel trailing a skyglow of acclaimsuccess in Las Vegas and Honolulu, an accolade from Bob Hope and reports that put him in a sexuality race with Tom Jones and Engelbert Humperdinck.

title: MRS. DAVID KARNOFSKY
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 12 Mrs. Elesa Addis Karnofsky, widow of Dr. David A. Karnofsky, chief of the medical oncology service at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases and chief of chemotherapy research at the SloanKettering Institute for Cancer Research, died last evening at her home, 45 Larchmont Avenue. She was in her fifties.

title: JEFFERSON ELEVEN WINS DIVISION TITLE
description: The high  scoring Jefferson football team clinched the Brooklyn Division Public Schools Athletic League championship yesterday by routing Wingate, 4414, at Boys High Field. It was the eighth victory for the unbeaten Jeffs, the sixth in league play.

title: New FireSafety Rules Are Postponed
description: New firesafety regulations for highrise office buildings, which were supposed to go into effect today, were postponed until further notice yesterday by the Fire Department.

title: Districting Law in Bay State
description: BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP)Al bill realigning the state's 12 Congressional districts was signed today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: Students in Chile Hear Castro on the Revolution
description: ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, Nov. 12Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba held the fascinated attendon of about 1,000 university students today with an account of the hardships and triumphs of the Cuban revolution.

title: GeorgiaAuburn Key Game
description: Vince Dooley was just a sophomore, secondstring quarterhack for Auburn 20 years ago but he got into the game with Georgia that year and completed both of his lategame passes, including a touchdown toss. He was unhappy as Georgia whipped Auburn, 4614, in Shug Jordan's first year as head coach at Auburn.

title: He Took Hobby and Made It Pay
description: When Malcolm S. Forbes, the millionaire former State Senator from New Jersey and onetime candidate for Governor, got interested in motorcycles several years ago, he had two problems. One was how he could buy the bikes wholesale as purchases for himself and his family mounted. The other was how to get them properly serviced in a minimum amount of time.

title: Researchers Seek Clue to One of Nature's Forces
description: Using research tools that challenge the most sophisticated engineering technology, scientists at Argonne National Laboratory, southwest of Chicago, are probing some of the innermost secrets of nature with a beam of nothingsthe insubstantial particles known as neutrinos.

title: British Officials in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)Two British officials arrived in Salisbury this morning to prepare for the visit Monday of the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, who will discuss a Rhodesian settlement with Premier Ian D. Smith.

title: John E. Boda Dies at GO; Vice President of P.G.A.
description: METHUEN, Mass., Nov. 12 (AP)John E. Boda, national vice president of the Professional Golf Association, died yesterday at New England Medical Center in Boston after a brief illness. He was 60 years old and lived in Methuen.

title: LSD and Heroin Found Helpful In Treatment of Terminally Ill
description: A distinct supportive role exists for the use of mindaffecting, painkilling and other drugseven heroin and LSD for some patientsin the care of :people terminally ill with cancer and other diseases, a group of doctors reported yesterday at an international symposium on drug cam of the dying.

title: S.D.R.'s Seen as Solution For World Money Crisis
description: PARIS, Nov. 12  As the world monetary crisis drags on, there is increasing talk that the final break may come with devaluation of the dollar in terms of Special Drawing Rights.

title: NIXON FORECASTS TEMPORARY BULGE IN PHASE 2 PRICES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Government's new economic control agencies issued their first detailed regulations for Phase Two today while President Nixon forecast a temporary bulge when the freeze ends.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Crime Insurance Found Failing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12The Federal Government's new crime insurance program, designed to arrest decay in the central cities, has proved so far to be unsuccessful, according to many involved with it.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 For the first time in his long and agonizing program of withdrawal from Vietnam, President Nixon felt free enough from the pressures at home to address his troopcut announcement today primarily to the Communist leaders in Hanoi, Moscow and Peking. He wants to make a deal. at least of limited proportions, and he wants to see whether the final acts of disengage ment can buy a bargain.

title: Some Wise Impulse
description: Washington's urgent appeal to India and Pakistan to refrain from a conflict that has already begun erupt along the long IndoPak borders is inadequate response to a perilous situation that Administration policy has helped to aggravate.

title: FIVE CATALONIANS ARRESTED IN SPAIN
description: MADRID, Nov. 12The police have arrested at least five persons in connection with last Sunday's clandestine meeting in Barcelona of some 300 members of the opposition.

title: NEW ISSUES PRICES DIP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Prices of new issues traced a mixed pattern early this week, then buckled under the weight of the general stock market decline, specialists said yesterday. Trading, however, was relatively light.

title: Vote of Tariff Body Is Called Irregular
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 A member of the Tariff Commission has charged in a letter to President Nixon that there were irregularities and possible illegality in the commission's 4to2 vote this week to grant adjustment assistance to a Georgia textile company and its workers.

title: Complaints on Freeze For U.S. Zone Tallied
description: The wageprice freeze generated 7,409 complaints from the public through Nov. 9 in the Federal region that embraces New York, New Jersey and Puerto Rico, the Office of Emergency Preparedness here said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions and Answers On Economic Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 Following are some questions compiled by The New York Times about the new economic control regulations and tentative answers obtained from Government officials and other sources:

title: 3 Prison Aides Promoted; 1 Will Head Unit at Rikers
description: George F. McGrath, the City, Commissioner of Correction, announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Essie O. Murph as commanding officer of the New York City Correctional Institution for Women at Rikers Island.

title: ROCKETS BEATEN BY BUCKS, 111102
description: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 12 (AP)  Jon McGlocklin scored 13 of his 17 points in the fourth quarter tonight, breaking open a close game, and sparking the Milwaukee Bucks to a 111102 victory over the Houston Rockets in the National Basketball Association.

title: ...F.B.I. Pressure?
description: The F.B.I.'s field investigation of a radiotelevision newsman has been described as routine by the White House because he was supposedly under consideration for a high Federal job in the environmental area. This enabled the investigators to check his neighbors, working associates, former employers and present executives of CBS News, of which Daniel Schorr is a wellknown correspondent. His beat includes Federal agencies and programs that have been questioned and occasionally criticized. Complaints about his coverage have been made before when deemed unfriendly toward Government.

title: Riva Ridge Even Money In $293,890 Carden State
description: The button with the blue letetring says: I LIKE THE KING.

title: ZELIG SHER, AUTHOR AND JOURNALIST, 83
description: GARRETT PARK, Md., Nov. 12Zelig Sher, Yiddish author and former labor editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, died yesterday in Silver Spring. He was 83 years old and lived here and formerly in New York.

title: 7 Americans Charged in London in Theft of Stock
description: LONDON, Nov. 12 (AP)Seven Americans and a Briton were charged today with conspiring to sell securities from a multimilliondollar Chicago stock theft. The prosecution sought to link them to a crimiinal ring based in Los Angeles.

title: STUDY LINKS DIET TO HEART ATTACKS
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Nov. 12University of Chicago researchers have produced what is perhaps the best experimental evidence to date that the typical American diet fosters the development of severe hardening of the arteries, the main cause of heart attacks.

title: Screen: Deep Slumber
description: Her name was Mary DiNapoli, and she was a prostitute who lived and worked on Mulberry Street. One night somebody killed her, and that would have been the end of it ifif it weren't for Mickey Isadore (Red Buttons), former lightweight boxing champion, currently retired, and diabetic, and rich. Mickey reads about Mary's murder In the paper and he sets out to solve it for the sole, simple (and unsatisfactory) reason that nowadays nobody cares anymore.

title: Virtual War, Pakistani Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12The Pakistani Foreign Secretary, Sultan Mohammad Khan, said today that there is a virtual state of war with India along the borders of Pakistan.

title: Veterans View Job Fair With an Air of Cynicism
description: James M. Houston protected Marine truck convoys near South Vietnam's Ashau Valley 18 months ago, while Donato Napoli cruised the Mediterranean on a guidedmissile destroyer and Michael Rivera serviced heavy Army tanks on a hot, dusty Texas proving ground.

title: Turkey on Tap if Giants Bag Falcons in Atlanta Homecoming
description: After winning their first home game of the season last week against San Diego, the New York Giants will be away from home tomorrow to play the Falcons in Atlanta. But it still will be a kind of homecoming game for some of those on the team.

title: Merger News
description: The Utilities and Industries Corporation announced yesterday it has completed the previously announced acquisition of 61 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Colonial Sand and Stone Company, Inc. Utilities and Industries also indicated that it would seek to acquire all remain ing shares of Colonial Sand. The $20.2million acquisition could be reversed due to court action.

title: ALEXANDER SCHIFFER
description: Alexander Schiffer, who had been a real estate and insurance broker in the Yorkville area of Manhattan for 35 years, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 325 East 80th Street. He was 61 years old.

title: Rehnquist Role in Election Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12An Arizona Republican leader confirmed today that William. H. Rehnquist one of President Nixon's nominees to the Supreme Court, was an official in 1960 and 1964 of a Republican program to challenge voters at polling places in Phoenix.

title: 6 Killed and 9 Hurt as Auto Jumps Curb in Youngstown
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP)Six persons were killed and nine injured today by an automobile that jumped a curb and careened down a crowded sidewalk in the heart of Youngstown's business district.

title: 3 AUTO CONCERNS TO ASK PRICE RISE
description: Fifty per cent of the automotive industry moved quickly yesterday to obtain increases in the prices of 1972 models.

title: Hearing on City Loan Scandal Begins and Ends in Commotion
description: The longawaited appearance before a city Council committee of an undercover agent placed in the Municipal Loan Program by Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin began and ended in a flurry of excitement and debate yesterday.

title: U.S. Sources in Saigon Say Americans Will Continue to Fight
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Nov. 13Military sources said today that President Nixon's statement that American ground combat offensive operations had ended in Vietnam did not mean that American troops would stop fighting or dying.

title: Tennessee Asks Time to Act
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) Tennessee, citing unavoidable delays, asked the Federal Government today for more time to comply with provisions of the 1965 Highway Beautification Act. The request came at a Department of Transportation hearing on whether the Government should cut back highway funds to the state by 10 per cent.

title: She Won't Leave China Floor at Hotel
description: A grayhaired widow is thwarting one of China's plans for its temporary mission in the Roosevelt Hotel.

title: Big Board Margin Debt Up $20Million in Month
description: Stockmargin debt rose $20million in October to a total of $4.95billion, New York Stock Exchange members reported yesterday. It was the smallest of nine consecutive monthly increases.

title: Accord on Growth of Cable TV Unlikely to Affect City Soon
description: Broadcasters and cable television system operators agreed yesterday that Thursday's accord on cable's growth would have little immediate effect in New York City. More complications, notably copyright legislation and the roles of the city and state, could delay cable for several years, except for Teleprompter and Sterling Manhattan Cable, holders of the major franchises in Manhattan.

title: Hawks Beat Warriors, 106104
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) Lou Hudson scored 28 points as the Atlanta Hawks defeated the Golden State Warriors, 106104, tonight.

title: Suns Dim Celtics, 128119
description: PHOENIX, Ariz. (AP)The Phoenix Suns defeated the Boston Celtics, 128119, tonight.

title: MRS. HENRY BUNKER
description: Mrs. Katherine Roeder Bunker, who had been a psychiatric social worker, died of cancer at the home of a daughter in Claremont, Calif., on Nov. 5. She was 77 years old and formerly had lived in Ashland, Mass., and Scarsdale, N. Y. Her husband, Dr. Henry A. Bunker, a psychiatrist, died in 1953.

title: Reagan and Democrats Agree on Redistricting Plan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 11  The California Legislature's Democratic leaders and Gov. Ronald Reagan, a Republican, have agreed on a Congressional reapportionment plan designed to preserve the seats of all 38 incumbents including two blacks  and to provide for at least one more black seat.

title: 2 Chileans Are Held Here In a DrugSmuggling Case
description: The arrest of two Chilean citizens for allegedly attempting to smuggle into the United States four pounds of cocaine having a street value of $1million was announced yesterday by Commissioner of Customs Myles J. Ambrose.

title: ROGERS EXPRESSES FEAR OF FULL WAR BY INDIA, PAKISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Secretary of State William P. Rogers expressed the Administration's growing concern today that the border clashes between India and Pakistan might lead to an allout war.

title: Division and Crisis Rack Italian Democracy
description: ROME, Nov. 12Cracks have appeared recently en the walls of the 17thcentury Palazzo Montecitorio, which houses the Italian Parliament, and some politicians feel that the erosion extends to the political system at well.

title: Drawings by Lichtenstein Stress Pop
description: Nowadays the reputations of artists topple as fast as they are made. The reputation of Roy Lichtenstein has by no means toppled but it has been cracking here and there since his retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum. The current exhibition of drawings by Mr. Lichtenstein at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street, does nothing to arrest the deterioration process.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Harold Fleming, 71, Dead; Monitor Financial Editor
description: Harold M. Fleming, a freelance writer on business and financial subjects who had been financial editor of The Christian Science Monitor, died on Wednesday in Peterborough, N. H. He was 71 years old and lived in Antrim, N. H.

title: Publisher of Valley of Dolls Asks Time to Pay Debts
description: Bernard Geis, who applied the creed that it takes a buck to make a buck to shake the genteel bookpublishing world with big promotional budgets, asked the Federal Court here yesterday to rescue him from possible bankruptcy.

title: Transcript of President Nixon's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12Following, as made available by the White House, is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference today:

title: Car Output 7.5 Million
description: DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) Auto production so far in 1971 reached 7.5 million units this week and might go to 8 million by the end of the month, the trade publication Automotive News reported yesterday.

title: Shop Talk
description: When Miguel Lopez Lecube, who used to be Argentina's Consul General here, took his American bride, Kathy, to South America to meet his family several years ago, she loved the life on her inlaws' estancia. She was also greatly taken by a leathermaking factory in Buenos Aires. A fashion callsultan in New York, she had hero thinking of going into some phase of the fashion business. And leather was just then taking off in popularity in the United States. Soon after that visit to the factory in Buenos Aires, the company called Estancia Luggage was born, with Michael De Leo, who had been in marketing for several years, becoming a partner in the enterprise with Kathy Lopez Lecube. Their aim: to fill the gap between ordinary, inexpensive luggage and the distinctive expensive stuff.

title: Surendra Bahadur, Kite Flyer Who Spurred Sport Here, Dies
description: Surendra Bahadur, who turned a childhood love of flying kites into an international business, died last Saturday in Jamaica, West Indies, while on a selling tour of the Caribbean. He was 44 years old and lived at 324 West 88th Street.

title: Justice Denied
description: This article was written by Doris Krause, Sarah Scheuer, Florence Schroeder and Elaine Miller, the mothers of the four Kent State students killed by National Guardsmen May 4, 1970.

title: They Said Their Prayers on First and Ten
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va.When the Jets bested the Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl, those who looked upon the game from Joe Namath's point of view tended to hail it good naturedly as a victory over clean living and all that stuff. Few saw it as the darkest day of the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.

title: Delay Asked in Ohio Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)Attorneys for 25 persons indicted in the 1970 disorders at Kent State University asked Justice Potter Stewart of the Supreme Court today to block their trial until they can appeal to the high court. The trial is scheduled to begin Nov. 22 in Ravenna, Ohio, and run until all 25 cases are completed. The defense contends that it has been damaged by a report issued by a special grand jury, which exonerated members of the National Guard who fired a volley on the Kent State campus, killing four students and wounding nine others.

title: JOHN J. MEENAHAN, BROOKLYN DETECTIVE
description: John J. Meenahan, a retired lieutenant of the Police Department, who as an acting captain of the Brooklyn West Homicide Squad from 1940 to 1959 was instrumental in solving a number of murder cases, died. Thursday at his home, 9 Kildare Walk, Breezy Point, Queens. He was 71 years old.

title: Fund to Improve Jewish Life Is Voted
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 Leaders of Jewish federations and welfare funds throughout the country and Canada approved today a risk capital fund of $2.25million to develop innovative projects to strengthen the quality of Jewish life.

title: Dayton Votes Tax Increase To Let Services Reopen
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 12 (AP) Dayton voters approved today a special school tax, permitting the city'sh schools to reopen Monday.

title: SALEM JUMP VICTOR AT CANADIAN SHOW
description: TORONTO, Nov. 12  Carol Hofmann rode Salem to victory in the Rothmann Stakes and in the process beat out her United States Equestrian teammate, Frank Chapot, up on Good Twist, tonight at the Royal Winter Fair horse show.

title: SERVICE UNITS SUING COMPUTER CONCERNS
description: W. Henry du Pont and three affiliated computer service companies filed a civil antitrust suit yesterday in the Federal District Court at Philadelphia against the University Computing Company of Dallas, and the Univac division of the Sperry Rand Corporation. The three plaintiff companies are SciTek, Inc., in which Mr. du Pont is the sole shareholder, and the United Software Corporation and SpeedPak, a joint venture of SciTek and United Software.

title: LICENSING GROUP DOES SOVIET STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 The Licensing Executives Society, Inc., an organization representing 400 American companies and others abroad, has issued a primer on the exchange of Technology with the Soviet Union.

title: COUPLE IN PROJECT SUE ON WATCHDOG
description: A couple living in Baruch Houses, the Lower East Side Housing project that has been the scene of recent killings and violent attacks on residents, filed suit yesterday to bar the City Housing Authority from forcing them to get rid of their watchdog or be evicted.

title: Rumlong Siege Continues
description: PNOMPENH Cambodia. Nov. 12 (AP)  Cambodian troops trying to relieve the beseiged garrison at Rumlong, 50 miles northeast of the capital, still were reported blocked today.

title: MRS. ADDISON VAN TINE
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Gunn Van Tine, who contributed verse to magazines and newspapers. died yesterday at her home in Bernardsville, N. J. Her age was 76. She was the widow of Addison Van Tine, a New York lawyer.

title: Sanitationmen's Pact Reported Near
description: The city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association were reported to be close to agreement on a new contract yesterday.

title: First Yablonski Case Defendant Convicted on 3 Murder Counts
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 12 The first defendant to stand trial in the 1969 fatal shootings of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers leader, and his wife and daughter, was convicted on three counts of firstdegree murder late this afternoon.

title: An Appraisal
description: The exhibition of student architectural projects from the School of Art and Architecture at Cooper Union opening today ought to have a sign at the entrance, Danger: Fast Curve. Because a fast curve is what this New York school is throwing the architecture profession, educationally, at a time when the training of the architect is in a state of revolutionary upheaval trying to plug into a changing society.

title: NIXON SHIFTS RULES ON NEWJOB INQUIRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) President Nixon, embarrassed by widespread publicity over an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of Daniel Schorr, the television newsman, has ordered changes in White House talent hunt procedures, the White House press secretary said today.

title: Braniff Airways Planning To Form Holding Company
description: DALLAS, Nov. 12 (UPI)Braniff Airways announced plans today to form a holding company to include the airline and its hotel subsidiary. The holding company would enable Braniff to diversify in areas other than air travel.

title: MICHIGAN STATUTE ON EATS UPHELD
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 12 (AP)A Federal judge said today that a stiff Michigan meat packaging law covering such products as hot dogs and sausages took precedence over a more lenient Federal law.

title: LYRICISM AT PIANO DISPLAYED BY AYBAR
description: If previous judgments of Francisco Aybar's recitals here are correct, then his performances in Tully Hall Thursday night indicate artistic growth. The pianist has always been praised for his technique, and he can still stir up a lot of excitement in the finale of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7, as he did this time. But time after time, he showed that he now knows how to build a movement and sustain its structure in the most musical fashion.

title: TEACHERS TO GET DELAYED RAISES
description: The city's 60,000 teachers will get their delayed pay rises, amounting to $950 annually, when the 90day Federal wageprice freeze ends at midnight tonight.

title: JEROME M. PINES, 56, QUEENS PROSECUTOR
description: Jerome M. Pines, an assistant district attorney in Queens, died Thursday night at his home at 104.40 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Queens. He was 56 years old.

title: Hewitt, Battrick Advance
description: TORQUAY, England, Nov 12 (UPI)  Bob Hewitt of South Africa and Gerald Battrick of England qualified today for their third final round in four Dewar Cup tennis tournaments.

title: Pros Down Chaparrals
description: DALLAS, Nov. 12 (AP) The Memphis Pros gained the lead in the fading minutes tonight to post a 107103 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals.

title: Freed After 44 Years
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 12 (AP)  Melvin Whittum, who spent 44 years in the maximum security section of a state mental institution, walked out today. Whittum, 66 years old, will live at a boarding home. In 1927, he was transferred to the hospital from the Maine state prison, where he had served a threeyear sentence on a burglary charge. He should have been released in 1930, but a hospital official said he had been kept in the hospital because of clerical errors in his hospital records.

title: ALEX WALKER JR.
description: Alex Walker Jr., a retired textile sales executive, died on Wednesday in Seattle after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan, Quogue, L. I., and Key Colony Beach, Fla.

title: Leyland to Acquire 40% Of German Distributor
description: LONDON, Nov 12 (UPI) The British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ltd., today announced it was acquiring a 40 per cent interest in its German distributor of Austin Morris cars, the A. Bruggemann concern.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 When Donald Rumsfeld gave up a safe House seat in 1969 to head the Office of Economic Opportunity, it was alarming to supporters of the antipoverty agency, who referred to the Illinois Representative as the undertaker assigned by President Nixon to bury O.E.O. Reacting in a Who, me? manner, Mr. Rumsfeld repudiated the accusa tion and proceeded to take what he considered progressive steps to change the agency into one that experimented with, rather than operated, programs for the poor.

title: One for the Road
description: The Senate Finance Committee is up to its old tricks. Without public hearings or any discussion, it slipped into the Administration tax bill an amendment to divert permanently 7 per cent of all Federal taxes on whisky to the highway trust fund. This would amount to about $350 million a year, or slightly more than the amount lost to the trust fund by the bill's repeal of the 10 per cent excise tax on light trucks.

title: Fight at Teleprompter Seen Despite Kahn Shift
description: A proxy fight for control of the Teleprompter Corporation loomed yesterday despite the resignation earlier in the day by Irving B. Kahn as chairman.

title: Theater: Success in a Great but Difficult Work
description: Schiller's Mary Stuart is one of the craggily moral plays of the European theater. It was last given in New York by Berlin's Schiller Theater itself in an effortlessly authoritative performance. It was a performance with that special grace of acknowledged tradition about it. Things happened with a rightness, speeches were pitched on an effably correct emotional key, the work, in short, worked.

title: Pullout Plan Stirs Praise And Concern in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12President Nixon drew applause from both sides of Capitol Hill today for accelerating troop withdrawals, but Congressional doves expressed concern that the Administration was becoming committed to maintaining a residual force in South Vietnam.

title: Atlanta Discount Rate Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (Reuters)  The Federal Reserve Board announced today it had approved action by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta to cut its discount rate to 4 per cent from 5 per cent. Only the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has not lowered its rate.

title: Group Fare Plan Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board gave Western Air Lines permission today to put into effect immediately a oneway nonaffinity group fare of $73 between California and Hawaii for groups as small as 70 persons. The current minimum number of persons, not members of clubs or other affinity groups, required to qualify for the low fare is 154.

title: WALTER SHAPIRO, 58, COOKY'S COFOUNDER
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Nov. 12 Walter Shapiro, president and cofounder of Cooky's Steak Pubs, Inc., an 11unit restaurant and catering chain in Brooklyn, Long Island and Westchester, died of cancer today in Long Beach Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 1496 Bay Boulevard, Atlantic Beach.

title: Tear Gas Quells Outbreak In Wisconsin Reformatory
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 12 (AP)The authorities at the Green Bay Reformatory fired tear gas at prisoners and discharged shotguns as warning shots today in quelling what Warden Don Quatsoe called a fullscale riot.

title: South African Aides Warn Blacks' Lot Must Improve
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 12Cabinet Ministers have warned white South Africans in unusually blunt language during the last few days that they must give a far better economic deal to the country's blacks.

title: A U.S. Agency Here Bows Out, 2d Steps Into WagePrice Scene
description: As the 90day wageprice freeze drew to a close, the Office of Emergency Preparedness here toasted the end of Phase One with a highspirited party, while the Internal Revenue Service ushered in Phase Two with a sober news conference.

title: STARKER SHOWS CELLO WIZARDRY
description: Janos Starker makes playing the cello look as easy as falling off a log but sound much better. The Hungarian wizard, with his countryman and longtime partner Gyorgy Sebok as pianist, put on an astonishing display of unruffled mastery Thursday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: ASHE ELIMINATES OKKER IN TENNIS
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Nov. 12 (AP)Arthur Ashe upset secondseeded Tom Okker of the Netherlands today and moved into the semifinal round of the Italian international open tennis tournament.

title: CHINA SEES DELAY IN FULL U.N. ROLE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12Peking's chief delegate to the United Nations, Chiao Kuanhua, said here today that the Chinese delegation might not be able to participate as actively as expected in the current GeneralAssembly because it did not have many members and was not yet familiar with the situation here.

title: Brooklyn Catholic Diocese Names Education Secretary
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero yesterday announced the appointment of the Rev. Michael J. Dempsey as secretary for education in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: The Lurking Dangers of Phase Two
description: PHILADELPHIAIt is not too early to assess Phase Two of President Nixon's new economic policy. The ninetyday pricewage freeze, now passing into history, must on balance be adjudged a success although over the longrun its rigidity would condemn it. For the short interval it served to brake the uninterrupted price trend.

title: What Is Sportswear, Anyway? Designers Give Their Answers
description: Sportswear, which put a lot of the cheer back into the fashion business this fall, is off and running again for spring. Always loath to let a good thing go, designerseven those whose specialties are dresses or coats and suitshave plunged more deeply into the sportswear field.

title: Vietnam Troop Totals Since '69
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)Following are statistics tracing increases and decreases in United States military manpower during the Vietnam war:

title: Art: The Special World of Broderson
description: Morris Broderson, whose latest oneman show opened this week at Staempfli, 47 East 77th Street, was introduced to New York 11 years ago as one of the 30 artists in the Whitney's Young America1960. He had been a youthful prodigy whose drawings from the model would have drawn huzzahs from the masters of the Ecole des Beaux Arts in the 19th century, but had rejected the possibilities of that direction for a somewhat Picassold style that, shortly after the Whitney show, he also abandoned.

title: Dock Strike Talks Here Recessed Until Wednesday
description: Talks between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping. Association have been recessed until Wednesday, a Federal mediator said yesterday.

title: New Directions in Aid
description: The Senate has moved with unusual dispatch this week to resurrect the shattered foreign assistance program with two bills authorizing $1.1 billion for economic assistance and $1.5 billion for military and related aid.

title: Testifies at Trial Here That Fong's Aide Took Cash
description: A Federal agent testified yesterday that he had seen Robert T. Carson, administrative aide to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii, accept $2,500 in cash as part of a bribe to kill stockfraud investigations.

title: WEST VA. TROUNCES V.M.I. TEAM, 283
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 13 (AP)West Virginia floundered in its mistakes today but managed to grind out three long drives for a 283 victory over outmanned Virginia Military Institute.

title: PIER AND SEA JOBS SPURNED IN SOVIET
description: ODESSA, U.S.S.R., Nov. 1The lure of the sea is no longer attracting enough young men to keep up with the ambitious expansion of Soviet ports and the merchant fleet, and this is causing problems for the men who run them.

title: HUE PACES SCHOOL TO HARRIER TITLES
description: SOUTH ONONDAGA, N.Y., Nov. 13Kevin McLee sacrificed personal gains for team success today and was rewarded with a threeway triumph in the New York State Public High Schools Athletic Association intersectional crosscountry championships.

title: What's New in Theater?
description: STICKS AND BONES, the New York Shakespeare Festival production of a play by David Pahe, won praise from ten critics who covered it (Barnes, Times; Watt. News: Watts, Post; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Oppenheimer, Newsday; Glover, AP; Botto, NBCTV; Sanders, ABCTV; Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan, WPIX).

title: PANEL TO SAFEGUARD CANDIDATES NAMED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) With the 1972 elections a year away, Thomas H. Kuchel, a former Republican Senator from California, has been named to the fivemember advisory commitee that will name major Presidential and VicePresidential candidates who will be eligibile for Secret Service protection.

title: EssexUnion
description: Unbeaten Westfield, despite injuries that sidelined three members of its starting backfield, stretched New Jersey's second longest unbeaten streak to 32 games yesterday with a 216 victory over Hillside that locked up its third straight Watchung Conference championship.

title: AURELIO TAKES ISSUE WITH TIMES ARTICLE
description: Richard R. Aurelio, the outgoing deputy mayor, took issue yesterday with an article in Saturday's New York Times about city administration officials who will be working on Mayor Lindsay's undeclared campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Books:
description: Perhaps too many books have been written on investments and investors may need a breathing spell. There are books for the young investor, for the woman investor, for the unsophisticated investor, for the supersophisticated investor and for the young investor who really doesn't know much but wants to be a speculator.

title: Laver Downs Pasarell in 5 Sets, Ashe Beats Rose wall in Italian Semifinals
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP)  Topseeded Rod Laver won a gruelling threehour, match from Charlie Pasarell, 46, 60, 63, 67, 76, to reach the final of the( Italian international open tennis tournament today.

title: In 2 Years' Absence, Donovan Hasn't Changed All That Much
description: Donovan returned to New York Friday night, nearly two years after his last appearance in this area. Despite the lengthy hiatusor, perhaps, because of itMadison Square Garden was not sold out. Obviously, the magnetic powers of attraction Donovan once generated so easily have diminished.

title: Franklin and Marshall Tops Muhlenberg Eleven, 3013
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Nov. 13The hard running of Jay Baumgarner and the precision passing of Larry Shadek, a quarterback, led Franklin and Marshall to a 3013 victory today over Muhlenberg in a Middle Atlantic Conference game.

title: Nicklaus, U.S. Lead In World Cup Golf
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14They call Lee Trevino the SuperMex. But today his partner, Jack Nicklaus, was the superstar as he scored a record 63 that put him and the United States team at the top in the World Cup Golf Tourney.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: SENATE VOTES END OF 10% EXCISE TAX ON TRANSIT BUSES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 The Senate voted today to repeal the 10 per cent excise tax on buses that are used by urban mass transit systems.

title: AN AFRICAN TELLS OF HIS LONG WAR
description: CASSEBETCHE, Portuguese GuineaJos Arajo Iaid his Sovietmade automatic rifle against a mossy tree trunk and slipped down into the cool shade of a coconut palm. He unbuttoned his damp shirt with one hand and gestured toward the surrounding green swamp with the other hand.

title: Salisbury Evens Record
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Nov. 13 Salisbury concluded its season by evening its record in eight games with a 2513 victory over Berkshire today. John Coste and Duncan McClelland highlighted Salisbury's rugged defense by returning intercepted passes for touchdowns.

title: WOMAN AND SON, 6, DIE IN HOUSE FIRE
description: A woman and her 6yearold son died last night in a threealarm fire in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the Fire Department said.

title: The Nation
description: BOSTONIt was a classic case of environmental buck passing. For seven years, the J. J. O'Donnell Woolens Company had been under pressure from Massachusetts officials to stop pouring dyes and soapy waste water into the vile Blackstone River in Grafton.

title: Stamps
description: JAMES A. CONLON, director of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Washington, is honoring the 23d National Postage Stamp Show, opening at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 19, with a souvenir card reproducing vignettes of the three 1930 United States airpost stamps issued for use on the inaugural EuropeanPan American roundtrip flight of the German dirigible Graf Zeppelin. The vignettes will be in the colors of the original horizontal stamps, quite rare to many collectors.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We should be prepared for an economic situation other than the one anticipated in the first rush of enthusiasm for the inflation freeze. In August, inflation seemed to be a product of psychological inertia propelling Us along a wageinflation costpush trajectory which many believed could be diverted by a brief wageprice freeze. It will not have that effect at all.

title: U.S.Supported School in Lebanon Adds Campus
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 13At a time of uncertainty and tension In the Middle East, American educators have made a major investment in the future generations of this part of the world.

title: The Road to Peking, or, How Does This Kissinger Do It?
description: WASHINGTON. ROBERT SILVER, a good editor in New York, finds himself one night at a Washington dinner party. He is standing across the room staring almost rudely at what seems to be a very nondescript, middleaged Jewish man with eyeglasses and wavy hair, named Henry Kissinger. Kissinger is deep in conversation with this astonishingly beautiful girl, and the girl is looking at him transfixed. How can this be? wonders Silver. How does this Kissinger do it?

title: THOMSON IS GIVEN CITY'S TOP AWARD
description: August Heckscher had just presented to him the Handel Medallion, the city's highest award for achievement in the arts, when Virgil Thomson, whom no one in the composer's nearly 75 years ever accused of excessive humility, turned to the audience and, in his highpitched, flutey voice, said:

title: Kareem Abdul Jabbar Is a Popular Name in France
description: PARIS, Nov. 13Sight unseen, Kareem Abdul Jabbar has become the Champion du Mois for October in France.

title: On the load with the New York Rangers
description: THE scene was the Montreal Forum, and the hometown Canadiens were in the process of smearing the visiting New York Rangers all over the hockey rink. Nevertheless, a small enclave of screamingly enthusiastic foreigners from New York were still enjoying themselves as the final seconds ticked off.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: AROUND THE
description: Carry on; finish bulb planting.... Transplant deciduous trees and shrubs, except thin barked kind.... It's too early to apply winter mulch. ... Keep after the leaves; rake them up ... If the lawn is long and straggly, give it one more mowing; clean and store the mower for winter.

title: Sheepshead Bay Plugging for a Town Center
description: Picturesque Sheepshead Bay, with its ramshackle atmosphere, its dirt and its smells, has vanished from the earth. In its place lies a new Sheepshead Bay, clean, tidy, practically odorlessa modern symphony of simple and orderly safety.  Brooklyn Eagle, Aug. 21, 1937.

title: Emilio Von Hofmannsthal, International Lawyer, 86
description: Dr. Von Hofmannsthal was also a journalist and a member of the Foreign Press Association of the United Nations. He was correspondent for the SchweizerHandelszeitung in Zurich and for the Furche in Vienna.

title: Canadians Rout North Stars
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Nov. 13 (AP)Three goals by Marc Tardif and two by Claude Larose combined with a superlative goaltending job by Ken Dryden carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 51 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight.

title: Clothing as the accomplice of nakedness
description: Man (including woman) is constantly working on himself. He is an artist who uses his body as a medium to create an effect. He flattens or peaks his skull, paints his head or covers it with wigs, dwarfs or deforms his feet, squeezes his torso into odd shapes, enlarges or shrinks his organs, hides his face behind masks, veils or natural or artificial beards. He projects his form into gods and monsters by combining it with segments of animals, producing men whose heads belong to lions or their hind parts to horses, and women whose bodies birds fish.

title: Texas Defeats Texas Christian, 310, as Wigginton, Replacing Phillips, Excels
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP) Texas took air on the Cotton Bowl today, shaking off several errors and another injury to its starting quarterback, Eddie Phillips, to down Texas Christian University, 310.

title: PATROLMAN SLAYS DRUGSALE SUSPECT
description: A plainclothes patrolman shot and killed a suspected heroin dealer in the Bronx last night after the suspect allegedly lunged at him with a knife.

title: Colonial Cup Steeplechase Unites Tweedy Set, OTB
description: Racing's tweedy steeplechase set will join forces with OTB this week in what the Offtrack Betting Corporation calls a great example of creative cooperation.

title: MOOD IS HOSTILE AT NEWTON TRIAL
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 13In an atmosphere of deep hostility, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, went on trail here again this week for the fatal shooting of an Oakland policeman.

title: COLGATE TROUNCES LAFAYETTE, 5114
description: EASTON, Pa., Nov. 13 (AP)Colgate capitalized on Lafayette mistakes and rolled over the Leopards, 5114, today.

title: Local
description: Ray Doyle, a Port Richmond tailback, ran for 88 yards and a touchdown on 16 attempts and gained 53 more on two passes yesterday as he led the Staten Islanders to a 166 P.S.A.L. Division I victory over Flushing at Port Richmond.

title: Rabbit returns; Updike was always thereit's time we noticed
description: In 1939 Thomas Mann sent his brother a fan letter. Heinrich's new novel, he wrote, is great in love, in art, boldness, freedom, wisdom, kindness, exceedingly rich in intelligence, wit, imagination and feelinga great and beautiful thing, synthesis and resume of your life and your personality. Though fulsome and obviously written in the first flush of enthusiasm for Heinrich's now all but forgotten book, these are the hyperboles that come to mind after reading John Updike's new novel, Rabbit Redux.
