It must be said, Mann continues, that such growth such transformation of the static to the dynamic, such perseverance, and such a harvesting is peculiarly European. Here in America the writers are shortlived; they write one good book, follow it with two and then are finished.

title: Finch Visits Quake Area
description: YUNGAY, Peru, Nov. 13 (AP) Robert H. Finch, an adviser to President Nixon, toured an Andean mountain valley today to inspect temporary housing and reconstruction projects, aided by United States and other international donations, for victims of an earthquake on May 31, 1970, that left 70,000 ??ead or missing and more than half a million homeless.

title: Judge Halts the Building of a Coast Freevvay
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13A Federal District Court judge ordered work halted this week on a $100million freeway east of San Francisco Bay. Legal experts said that the decision could help force government agencies in many areas to be more concerned about the impact of highways on the environment and local residents.

title: Hanoi Reported Massing Supplies for Major Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 13Military sources reported today that the enemy was massing supplies in North Vietnam in preparation for a major push down the Ho Chi Minh Trail network and into Cambodia and Laos.

title: The Gay Militants
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALD P. HESS
description: LONGMEADOW, Mass Nov. 13Donald P. Hess, retired president of the American Bosch Company and former chairman of the board of Van Norman Industries, died at his home Thursday.

title: Yablonski Defendant Sentenced To Death for Three Murders
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 13 (UPI)Aubran W. Martin, 23 years old, was sentenced today to death in the electric chair for his part in the New Year's Eve, 1969, slaying of Joseph A. Yablonski, his wife and daughter.

title: New School Head Named
description: DENVER, Nov. 13 (AP)Dr. Robert R. Martin, president of Eastern Kentucky University at Richmond, has been elected president of the 286member American Association of State Colleges and Universities at its ?? annual meeting here.

title: PassaicHudson
description: Barringer staged a spectacular offensive display yesterday as its swept to a 500 victory over Paterson Eastside for its eighth victory in as many contests.

title: WILLIAM J. TRACY
description: William J. Tracy, who retired last year as assistant general manager of ti New York branch of Mitsui O S K Lines, Ltd., a shipping concern, died here Thursday of a heart ailment. He was 72 years old and lived in Brightwaters, L. I.

title: Political Corn
description: President Nixon's decision to ease out Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin is another political maneuver in a long history of mismanagement of farm affairs by both political parties.

title: Penn Drops Sixth in Row
description: Columbia's cliffhanging Lions scored two touchdowns in the third quarter yesterday to defeat Pennsylvania, 173, and clinched their first winning season in 10 years.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 129Day Summer Racing Season Over, Florida Set for 138Day Winter Meet
description: MIAMI, Nov. 13South Florida horseplayers are a hardy breed. They have to be. Having struggled through a 129day summer session at Calder Race Course, the players have exactly eight days respite before plunging back against the mutuel machines for 138day winter session that opens at Tropical Park next Saturday.

title: N.Y.U. Beats Bridgeport, 41, For Ninth Soccer Triumph
description: New York University kept its slim hopes alive for a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament yesterday with a 41 triumph over Bridgeport at Ohio Field in the Bronx. It was the ninth victory for the Violet.

title: Conferees on Environment To Have the Use of Bicycles
description: GENEVA, Nov. 13Delegates to the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm next June will be able to make a personal contribution toward keeping the air of the Swedish capital smogfree.

title: Movies
description: AT 32, Peter Bogdanovich commands in reality what he has yearned for so often in fantasy.

title: NO. ILLINOIS LOSES TO BOSTON COLLEGE
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP)Ray Rippman brought Boston College back from a sluggish first period today and guided the Eagles to a 2010 victory over Northern Illinois.

title: Results of French Traffic Tests Fair to Muddling
description: MONTPELLIER, FranceTwo cities of southern France are trying audacious schemes to fight the traffic that is choking them. But critics insist that the daring of their concept is threatened by the timidity of their execution.

title: Local
description: Evander won Its sixth straight game since tying Clinton in its season opener by defeating Monroe, 2212, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division I game at Evander. The Eagles lost their sixth game in seven starts.

title: Lefkowitz Checks Liquor Maker's Ploy With Chess Pieces
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that the manufacturer and distributors of Old Crow whisky had rooked their customers by making only incomplete sets of ceramic bottles shaped like chess figures.

title: Dance
description: THE ethnic season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has proved very successful  indeed it has proved surprisingly successful even for people like myself, for whom a little ethnic dance goes a dangerously long way. After the Khmer Ballet from Cambodia opened the season  and I wrote about this company a couple of weeks ago  we had the National Dance Theater of Morocco, the Senegalese National Dance Company, and finishing tonight the Ritual Acrobats of Persia. Next Tuesday this AfroAsian dance festival is brought to its final phase with a week's season by the Sierra Leone National Dance Company.

title: Et Al.
description: A howto driving manual for mothers, prepared by members of the staff of the Boston Children's Medical Center. The book is based on wide research and offers a wealth of tips to mothers who have to drive with their children.

title: Campfire Girls Going Coed After 61 Years
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 13 (Reuters)The National Council of Campfire Girls, Inc., has decided to make the 61yearold organization coed.

title: Nassau North
description: Farmingdale and Westbury had to wait until the final day of the regular season to win their respective divisional titles, but both teams made short work of their opposition in yesterday's North Shore football playoffs. Farmingdale crushed Plainview, 316, and Westbury gave Locust Valley its first defeat, 4014.

title: New Postmaster Authority
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) Postmasters have been given immediate authority to improve mail delivery service to mobile home subdivisions, parks and trailer courts, the, United States Postal. Service announced this week.

title: Something Beautiful For God
description: Time was when biographies of saints were staples on the religious market. Malcolm Muggeridge revives the genre for a living person. The wonder is not that the book is written apart from its natural time but that it is so compelling now.

title: Bergen
description: Sal DiMauro, a 5foot10inch, 170pound senior halfback, engineered a major upset yesterday as he scored four firsthalf touchdowns to lead Wayne Valley to a 2915 victory over previously unbeaten Hackensack.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13In the last few months, the Administration has been putting the cops on the Washington reporters again, and there is a lot of talk around here, most of it a lath: melodramatic, about some dark Administration plot intimidate its critics in the press and the networks.

title: Shoemaker Breaks Hartack's Record for Stakes Victories in a Single Year
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI)Willie Shoemaker became horse racing's top stakes winner in a single year today by capturing the $20,000 added Junipero Serra Stakes aboard Royal Owl at Bay Meadows. It was Shoemaker's 44th stakes triumph of 1971, eclipsing by one the record set in 1957 by Bill Hartack.

title: Episcopalians Ordain Two Women
description: Two women were ordained yesterday as the first women deacons In the Episcopal Diocese of New York. Until last year, the office of deacon was traditionally reserved for men only.

title: U.A.W. HEAD CALLS RAISES PROTECTED
description: DETROIT, Nov. 13Leonard Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that labor had succeeded in protecting the raises and benefits of its members under the new economic controls.

title: American Party Picks Toledo for Convention
description: MEMPHIS, Nov. 13 (AP)Toledo, Ohio, will he the site of the 1972 Ameerican Independent party convention, the party's central committee decided tonight.

title: The best things in life are free, or you can build them yourself
description: Is anyone not interested in communes these days? Even the young who are neither living in a commune nor thinking about it seem to need reasons at the ready for not doing so. Older folks in their thirties, forties or beyond seem interested either because of their alarm over their children's interest in communes or because they themselves have been gripped in midcourse by one or another of the varieties of Harry Kellerman's diseaseexistential discontent, ennui, alienation, desperation. (Will anyone come to my funeral?) Crises of meaning are then produced in their lives, perhaps rupturing their marriages and careers, and sending them lurching about the Underground Subcultures of America are seeking solutionsin eroticism, in drugs, in mysticism, in community, in anything that promises transcendence of the lonely and insatiable self. Communes represent an attempt at one comprehensive solution.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (UPI) Ken Schinkel and Bryan Hex all registered two goals and wo assists each tonight to lead he Pittsburgh Penguins to a 14 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: OKLAHOMA ROUTS KANSAS, 56 TO 10
description: NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 13 (UPI)  Jack Mildren engineered seven firsthalf touchdowns to pace No. 2 ranked Oklahoma to a 5610 victory over Kansas today, setting the stage for the Sooners' dream game against top  rated Nebraska on Thanksgiving Day.

title: TAIWANESE EXILES MORE OPTIMISTIC
description: TOKYO, Nov. 11Taiwanese nationalists in exile here believe recent international developments involving their home island have improved prospects for an independent Taiwan.

title: Marilyn Borer Affianced
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Nov. 13The engagement of Miss Marilyn Borer to Andrew Stephen Edson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Edson of New York, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herman Borer. The wedding will take place in July.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I thought for a brief moment, as I read John Canaday's article, that he was joining forces with a growing group of artists and concerned citizens who are trying to add a sense of joy and renewed life to our city. As he wrote ... a giant painting in brilliant colors now covers what used to be a brick wall facing the spot where 19th Street comes to a messy death under the West Side highway and that indeed the end of West 19th Street is a decayed and ruptured bit of cityscape that can use a lot of brightening, I rejoiced that he got the point. But then I realized that Canaday did indeed miss the point of what City Walls Inc.'s program is all about.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Waterfowl Work 4Day Week
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md. Winnowing the clear air of the sunset sky with their great wings and singing their haunting song, huge flocks of Canada geese passed overhead. Then, responding to the cries of their brethern in the broad, cornstubble field before me, they wheeled into the cold notrthwest wind and decended to earth.

title: Sunami, 86, Photographer For Modern Art Museum
description: Soichi Sunami, a staff photographer for the Museum of Modern Art for three decades until his retirement in 1968, died Thursday in the New York Infirmary. He was 86 years old and lived at 231 West 21st Street.

title: Music at Graz
description: IN the West Hanns Eisler's name faded into limbo after his appearance before the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities in 1947. A distinctly unpopular figure with the committee, he was, on the intervention of a list of mighty names headed by Albert Einstein, Thomas Mann and Igor Stravinsky, finally allowed, or rather obliged, to leave the country.

title: Michigan Victory Gains Rose Bowl
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 13 Dana Coin booted his second field goal with 43 seconds left today to squeeze unbeaten Michigan to a 2017 victory over Purdue, the Big Ten title and the Wolverines' second Rose Bowl trip in three years.

title: $5,000 Fines for Pollution
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP)The president of a woolen company and his company have each been fined $2,500 in Federal court on charges of dumping industrial waste into the Blackstone River. J. J. O'Donnell Woolens, Inc., of South Grafton and its president, J. J. O'Donnell, were given one month to pay the fine. The presiding judge was W. Arthur Garrity Jr.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Vincent Canby characterizes the dialogue in Frank D. Gilroy's Desperate Characters as great chunks of theatrical exchanges and monologues, a description which has more to do with the faot that Gilroy is a Pulitzer Prize playwrighta fact which seems to bug Canbythan with the film's actual dialogue, which is full of wonderfully true examples of the ways people use words to fend each other off and unconsciously reveal themselves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader's Report
description: This is a novel that I found hard to pick up. (Weakened by laughter, I kept dropping the book to the floor.)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Jerome Siegel's article on Laurelton [Oct. 24] was a step in the right direction but It was incomplete and therefore somewhat misleading.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: The condescension in Peter Schjeldahl's piece on Westbeth could be cut with a knife. Also, a number of facts were wrong.

title: Local
description: Bayside clinched the Public Schools Athletic League Division I championship last night by downing Clinton, 100 at Bayside Field. It was the seventh victory for the unbeaten Commodores, who have not allowed a point this season. Bayside has scored 182 points.

title: Tigers Beaten, 10 to 6
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13That Big Three crown Princeton was about to place on its noble head for the first time since 1966 disintegrated into ashes today as a firedup Yale team stunned the Tigers, 106, behind the sizzling runs of Dick Jauron.

title: Ford Increases Price on the Pinto $109
description: DETROIT, Nov. 13The Ford Motor Company raised today the price of the Pinto $109, or almost 6 per cent, the first major price increase on new cars in the automobile industry.

title: Gas Rate Rise Held Up
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (AP) The 8 per cent increase in Philadelphia Electric Company rates approved by the Public Utility Commission will have to be submitted to the Cost of Living Council, the Internal Revenue Service ruled yesterday.

title: The World
description: TOKYO In 12thcentury Japan, as the tale goes, a warrior chief named TairanoKiyomori once donned full armor to meet his son, who was coming to dissuade him from ordering brutal attack. To soften his appearance, Kiyomori slipped the rope of priest's garb over his armor and listened to his son's plea. He relented momentarily, but then went forward to a victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We want to endorse the positive attitude that Alan V. Tishman conveyed so strongly in the face of constant denigration of our city [City Will Turn Tide of Urban Sickness, Point of View, Oct. 10].

title: Local
description: Brooklyn Tech evened its wonlost record at 33 yesterday by defeating Boys 2214, in a P.S.A.L. Brooklyn division game at Boys. Tech ran up a 160 lead before Boys scored in the fourth quarter. Phil Bellino's touchdown with 45 seconds remaining iced the game for the Engineers. The Kangaroos record is now 231.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: With Goeran Gentele soon to take over the management of the Metropolitan Opera House, wouldn't it be feasible for him to mount at least one contemporary opera a season which has proved its artistic superiority and durability? Instead of offering such spurious, perishable stuff as Antony and Cleopatra or Mourning Becomes Electra, the new manager might draw from a list of operas that put the lie to the hasty judgment that the form died in the early part of our century, or that audience response is passive to these important works: An iara, Lulu, Die Dreigroschenoper, The Crucible, Porgy and Bess, Bluebeard's Castle, The Devils of Loudon, Dialogues des Carmelites, The Makropoulos Affair, Mathis der Maier, War and Peace.

title: Poly Prep Extends Hex
description: Poly Prep continued its domination of St. Paul's School, its traditional rival, by beating the Garden City, L. I., team, 408, yesterday at Poly Prep. It was the 68th meeting in the series and Poly scored its 20th consecutive victory and its 44th overall. St. Paul's has won 23 and one game ended in a tie.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Nov. 13Tim Briggs, the tailback in the Lawrenceville singlewing attack, scored three touchdowns and passed for a 2point conversion today in leading his team to a 40.6 victory over its traditional rival, The Hill.

title: McBryde of Manhattan Triple Jumps 50Feet4
description: Ken McBryde, a 155pound Manhattan College freshman, set a track triplejump record 50 feet 4 inches in the third and final St. John's University fall fieldevent development meet in Hillcrest, Queens, yesterday. McBryde, 18, was representing the New York Pioneer Club.

title: Canucks Tie Leafs
description: TORONTO, Nov. 13 (UPI)Wayne Maki's powerplay goal at 10:21 of the third period gave the Vancouver Canucks a 22 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

title: HANOI DENOUNCES NIXON TROOP PLAN
description: PARIS, Nov. 13North Vietnam today denounced President Nixon's announcement of further American troop withdrawals from South Vietnam.

title: Rockland
description: Jimmy Brechbiel kicked field goal and ran for a touchdown yesterday to break his Rockland County Public Schools Athletic League season, scoring record as North Rockland raised its unbeaten and untied streak to 17 with a 100 victory over Clarkstown.

title: HARVEY W. PEACE JR.
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Nov. 13Harvey W. Peace Jr. of 353 Trinity Place, retired vice president of the National State Bank in Elizabeth, died yesterday in the Alexian Brothers Hospital, Elizabeth. He was 63 years old.

title: Douglas A. Campbell to Marry Allegra Kent Taylor in London
description: Miss Allegra Kent Taylor and Douglas Argyll Campbell, an investment banker with offices in New York, Los Angeles and London, plan to be married in London on Dec. 15. The ceremony will take place in the Old Chelsea Anglican Church.

title: Connecticut
description: New Canaan and Stamford, Fairfield County Conference championship playoff opponents next Saturday, posted their ninth victories of the year without defeat yesterday.

title: LESTER GIBSON
description: HILLSIDE, N. J., Nov. 13Lester Gibson, who retired in 1961 as public relations director for the American Bankers Association after 18 years with the group, died yesterday at his home in Leisure Village. He was 80 years old and lived at 423A Chatham Court.

title: U.S.O. Gets Tribute
description: It is a privilege to pay tribute to the U.S.O., General of the Army Omar N. Bradley stated. For 30 years this splendid on ganization has been providing a home away from home for our young men and women in uniform. The many kindnesses extended will long be remembered by those of us who have enjoyed those benefits.

title: Memoirs Of A DogTired Foreign Correspondent
description: MY Paris concierge, whose idea of a major expedition is a bus trip from the 7th to the 15th arrondissement to see her daughterinlaw, invariably greets my return from assignments in foreign parts with a deep sigh and Ah! how lucky you are to see so much of the world. One never argues with one's concierge, but I have been tempted to tell Madame Pichon what it is really like to be traveling correspondentalways pressed for time, compelled to take off for places no sane person would ever visit from choice and forced to function without regard to climate, time of year, available accommodations or the degree of hostility of those he ventures to report on.

title: Pop
description: IAN & SYLVIA: Ian & Sylvia (Columbia). According to old wives' tales, events occur in threes. Two fellow Canadian artists, Joni Mitchell and Gordon Lightfoot, have already attained hitrecord status, so it should be the turn of Ian & Sylvia Tyson, the very talented husband and wife duo who have always had an enthusiastic following here.

title: CONSUMER BILLS SEEN FLOURISHING
description: An overwhelming amount of consumerprotection legislation is pending in the 50 states, Lee H. Bloom, administrative vice president and general counsel of Lever Brothers Company, reported last week.

title: Florida, Paced by Alvarez, Defeats Kentucky, 35 to 24
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 13 (AP)Carlos Alvarez ended his college career today by scoring one touchdown on 56yard pass and setting up another with a 22yard reception as Florida recorded a 3524.victory over Kentucky.

title: MAX FINEGOLD
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Nov. 13Max Finegold, former president of the Monmouth County Bar Association, who had practiced law here for half a century, died Thursday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. He was 77 years old.

title: Muriel Kirkland 190371
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Address by McGovern Free Speech Exercise
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 13 (UPI)  While Senator George McGovern was criticizing American politics because of high campaign costs he was informed yesterday that his campaign would not receive an expected $1.500.

title: A.E.C. Plans a Public Hearing On Maine Power Plant License
description: WISCASSET, Me., Nov. 13The Atomic Energy Commission has authorized a public hearing on the granting of the operating license of the Maine Yankee Atomic Power Plant here, and also has given three conservation groups permission to intervene in the hearing.

title: San Jose State Upsets Stanford, 1312, as Garcia Misses on Four Field Goals
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 13. (AP)San Jose State's defense, led by Dave Chaney, set up two touchdowns and turned back numerous Stanford scoring threats today as the Spartans upset the Rose Bowlbound Indians, 1312.

title: Near Saigon, Ghostly Legends Grow Around Statue of a Grieving Soldier
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 12The most haunting war memorial in Vietnama 13foot statue of a seated soldier grieving for the dead has become a shrine for many Vietnamese.

title: the traveler's world
description: A RECENT drive deep into Maryland to visit Catoctin National Park served also to introduce us to one of the few remaining regions of only slightly changed and still unspoiled rural America. Immediately across the Delaware Memorial Bridge at the end of the New Jersey Turnpike we turned southeast on U.S. 301 because a friend had touted us onto the early American quaintness of Chestertown, a circular detour off the main highway through rolling horse and farming country both pretty and refreshing in warm autumn colors.

title: 96 Patrolmen to Be Shifted To City's High Crime Areas
description: Ninety  six city patrolmen from station houses throughout the city will be transferred tomorrow to five precincts in high crime areas.

title: Sutherland Sold to Wings
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13 (AP) The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League said today they had sold Bill Sutherland to the Detroit Red Wings. Sutherland, 37 years old, was obtained from Buffalo last season and scored 19 goals.

title: Redskins Brown Still Out
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) Larry Brown, the Washington Redskins' leading rusher, is still hospitalized with a contusion below the right knee, and will miss tomorrow's National Football League game at Chicago, a club spokesman said today.

title: Bel canto was his stockintrade
description: Few figures in the arts led quite so dreary a life as did Vincenzo Bellini. His career followed a steady, rising line from obscurity to acclaim. Whatever time he had left from his work as a composer was skillfully spent in the kind of machinations every artistic creator must conduct. Not many people liked him, and he liked even fewer; he assembled a circle of intimates from the people who could do him the most good. He bullied most of his colleagues, connived with no great brilliance against his rivals. Of genuine emotional involvements he knew next to nothing. He loved a girl in his days as a poor student, and was turned away by her family as a bad risk. By the time he proved worthy of her hand, he had lost interest in such distractions. He died, respected and prosperous at the early age of 33, having led a thoroughly uninteresting life marked at its high points by moments of despicability.

title: A Rinascimento on L. I.
description: Festa Italiana! Festa Italiana! Be Italian This Week proclaim the red white and green banners. Red is the fire of love, white is the joy and purity of the soul, and green is hope. Il russo, bianco e verde gonfalons, posters and flags crowd the eye! Where are we? Are we at the Palio in Siena's Piazza del Campo watching the races on buffaloes, the bullfights, and swarthy knights jousting? Are we in the Colosseum where gladiators bloody the sand and die for real and toothy lions keep vigorous on a diet of Christians? Are we with a million devoted religious at St. Peter's where the Fisherman lives Vaticanly? Are we on Mulberry Street, maybe at the Feast of San Gennaro?

title: Federal Agency to Display New steam Bus This Week
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 13 The Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration will show members of Congress next Wednesday, one of the first fruits of its programs for developing low pollution and low noise transporta steam bus.

title: POLITICS TAUGHT TO BUSINESSMEN
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13Businessmen are learning how to run grassroots political campaigns so they can play a greater role in the 1972 elections.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I cannot imagine what John Gruen had in mind when, in his article on Samuel Barber, he spoke of Leontyne Price as a black Cleopatra.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: SHEER COMEDY

title: ALGERIA PUSHING CUT IN VINEYARDS
description: ROUIBA, AlgeriaThe last wine harvest in Rouiba began like any other.

title: Pacers Down Colonels
description: LOUISVILLE, Nov. 13 (AP)A rookie, George McGinnis, scored a careerhigh 30 points tonight to lead the Indiana Pacers to a 116111 American Basketball Association victory over the Kentucky Colonels.

title: Art
description: MODERN Irish painting is not a subject that looms very largeexcept to the Irish perhapsin any serious consideration of 20thcentury art. In Ireland, all the talent seems to have gone into literature and the theater or else (if abundant witnesses are to be believed) into sheer talk. Shaw, Yeats, Joyce, Beckettthese are names that have no counterpart in the visual arts. Or do they? From time to time a single figure is advanced by this or that spokesman as a possible candidate for this high office, and his very name, alas, compounds the difficulty we have in arriving at a very precise evaluation of his work.

title: Harvard Topples Brown On Crone's Pass, 24 to 19
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 13 Eric Crone, the Harvard quarterback, dropped back smartly from the Brown 9yard line and whipped a pass right over the middle to Rich Gatto, his wingback, who caught the ball in full stride at the 2 and scored two steps later. That touchdown gave the Crimson a 2419, victory here today over the Bruins, who thus lost their eighth straight game.

title: POLICE A KEY ISSUE IN HOUSTON RACE
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 13The police department has become the major issue in a Mayor's race that has been given added spice by radicals running for public office here for the first time.

title: Brooklyn College Conquers Fairleigh Dickinson, 63
description: TEANECK, N.J.. Nov. 13 Brooklyn College defeated Fairleigh Dickinson in club football today, 63, on Hutch Cohen's 6yard run for a touchdown in the second period.

title: Preps
description: SOUTHBORO, Mass., Nov. 13 St. Mark's rallied to upset unbeaten Groton, 2827, today. The schools now have faced each other 82 times, with Groton leading the series, 4929, with four ties.

title: Montclair State Wins, 1714; Clincher New Jersey Title
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 13Scoring in the last 27 seconds on a 26yard pass from Glen Morschauser to John Daily, Montclair State College won its third straight New Jersey State College Conference football championship at Sprague Field tonight by downing Glassboro State, 1714.

title: Horse Show News
description: Joe Fargis, one of the United States Equestrian Team's young riders with a world of potential, was terrified the first time he saw a European jumper course.

title: CHARGES AGAINST 63 ORDERED BY MARCOS
description: MANILLA, Nov, 13President Ferdinand E. Marcos today directed that 63 persons mostly youth activists, be charged with subversion, a capital offense.

title: Iowa State Routs Missouri With 3 Late Scores, 4517
description: AMES, Iowa, Nov. 13 (AP)Iowa State tallied three touchdowns in the fourth quarter today to defeat Missouri, 4517, in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: Legislator, 22, Eager to Start
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I.Thomas J. Downey is doing well for a 22yearold one year out of college.

title: Late Hofstra Rally Fails As Central Mich. Wins, 2413
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, Mich., Nov. 13  Hofstra's Flying Dutchmen got their offensive cylinders working a little too late today and suffered a 2413 loss to Central Michigan.

title: Music
description: OUR ship will go very fast. We have five sails. It used to be that we had only one sail and five Isoldes. Now we have five sails and one Isolde. This apparently cryptic comment was made by Birgit Nilsson about the Metropolitan Operas new production of Tristan und Isolde, which will be unveiled on Thursday night and in which she will be the Irish princess. The soprano made it with her characteristic good humor. It sounded in no way immodest. How could it? The Mets production will be the 20th of the Wagner opera to be mounted for her. It must be record of some kind.

title: C.C.N.Y. HARRIERS WIN TITLE MEET
description: A fourthplace finish by Dave King set the stage for C.C.N.Y. to continue its domination of the City University of New York crosscountry championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

title: Bridge
description: THE postmortem after a really swinging deal can be a test of character, courtesy and manners. Suppose that at rubber bridge you pick up a giant hand, on which a slam seems highly probable. But to your surprise you end up defending a slam contract instead of playing one, and the opponents make their slam by brilliant play. It then appears that your partner missed an equally brilliant countermove to defeat the slam. Do you scream at your partner? Congratulate the declarer? Or enter the score in gloomy silence and calculate the opponents' enormous cash profit?

title: Eleanor And Franklin
description: To the Editor:

title: 27 More in House Join Fight to Reissue $2 Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens, has announced that 27 more House members have joined his effort to reissue the $2 billthis time with a portrait of Susan B. Anthony, the suffragette.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: HAROLD SCHONBERG in his recent article, J. C. SuperstarNo Rock of Ages, draws a rather sharp line between popular or commercial music and good or classical music. Furthermore, he appears to equate the former with junk and the latter with art. While I am certain that Schonberg would be able to find some popular or commercial music worthy of the name of art, just as he would be able to find some classical music sufficiently unworthy to merit being called junk, I am not so certain that his choice of artistic popular music would ever be entitled to the term good in his mind.

title: An Operation Bootstrap Seeks to Aid the Frightened L.I. Poor
description: GREAT NECK, L. I.,Not far from the most opulent area of Nassau's North Shore, from the. Miracle Mile of glittering shops in Manhasset to the waterfront mansions of Kings Point in Great Neck, there exists a tarnished section of poverty.

title: CITY UNIT TO FIGHT EVICTION IN SOHO
description: In the first action of its type, the City Planning Commission has Bone to court to oppose the eviction of a small hatmanufacturing concern from a loft building in the SoHo district of lower Manhattan.

title: Preps
description: A touchdown on a disputed call gave McBurney a 120 firstquarter lead and it went on to rout Fieldston, 480, yesterday at Fieldston. McBurney finished with a 62 record. Fieldston dropped to 52.

title: Pop
description: THAT silent minority of stubborn sentimentalists, the big band buffs, are virtually ignored by today's record companies, whose balance sheets prove, beyond a doubt, that the Jefferson Airplane outsells the Chattanooga Choo Choo. Yet, occasionally, RCA, Columbia, and even Decca will throw the old hepcats a bone in the form of reissued vault treasures.

title: WALL STREET
description: There are rumors that duPont Glore Forgan, Inc. is having more troubles. Morton Meyerson has heard the rumors and doesn't believe them.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: MICH. STATE TOPS MINNESOTA, 4025
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 13 (UPI)Eric (the Flea) Allen smashed a Big Ten season rushing record and became the first player to score more than 100 points in a Big Ten season today as he led Michigan State to a 4025 victory over Minnesota.

title: Back Home, Mrs. Gandhi Warns of Rising Danger
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, returning from a threeweek Western tour, said today that the military confrontation with Pakistan was becoming less and less tolerable.

title: Iraq Reopens Airspace
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 (Agence FrancePresse)  Iraq has decided to reopen her airspace to Jordanian planes, the Jordanian civil aviation department said today. The move, the agency said, arose from Iraq's recently expressed wish to unify Arab efforts in the current Middle East crisis.

title: Eastern Military Wins
description: SOUTH HUNTINGTON, L.I. Nov. 13  Eastern Military Academy stunned previously undefeated Fordham Prep today by downing the Little Rams, 1312. Eastern used a combination of a strong running attack, led by Stan Heath, and a number of Fordham Prep mistakes and penalties to register the upset.

title: The First Boy on the Block to Own a Railroad Car
description: When George Pins told his mother he intended to buy his own railroad car, her reaction was swift and decisive: Jewish boys from Forest Hills don't own their own railroad cars.

title: The Nation
description: On Nov. 6 the Atomic Energy Commission's largest underground nuclear explosion went off as A.E.C. experts had plannedand not as test opponents had feared. There was no environmental catastrophe. Alaska suffered no damaging earthquake, Hawaii experienced no massive sea wave or tsunami and no cloud of radioactivity escaped through earth cracks from the miledeep explosive.

title: President's Proclamation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's Thanksgiving Day proclamation, which was issued by the White House:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: MRS. JOSEPH HAVILAND
description: REIN BANK, N. J., Nov. 13Mrs. Irene C. Haviland, who at one time was director of the Xray program of the New York Tuberculosis Association and also was administrative secretary of the Xray department at Riverview Hospital here, died at that hospital today. She was the widow of Joseph J. Haviland and is survived by a brother and sister.

title: SCABIES OUTBREAK REPORTED IN MAINE
description: MEXICO, Me., Nov. 13Public schools in this community of 5,000 persons were closed the last two days of this week because of an outbreak of scabies, a highly contagious skin infection.

title: Leonard Boudin:
description: THE frayed and faded jeans, the flimsy shirts and heddbands of the Catholic left are behind him in the street as Leonard Boudin makes his way through the lobby of the Federal courthouse in Harrisburg, Pa. Through a bulge of glass in his dark rims which makes his weakened right eye serviceable, he can see the starched shirts of the Government guards and the large men in suits that allow more than mortal flesh to fill out waist and chest. Peace buttons fade into badges. His pass issued, his briefcase thoroughly nosed and picked over, he is herded to the elevator set aside exclusively for the run to the ninth floor. Upstairs, before walking a zigzag path to pass him between two metal poles that detect concealed weapons, he leans against a corner of the elevator, smiles wearily and says in response to a fellow passenger's comment about the elaborate security measures: No, no, my friend, don't call them Gestapo tactics. Instead you must not only permit it, you must grin, and if your sanity is of concern, you must even learn to enjoy it.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: LAUREL, Md., Nov. 13Golden Eagle II, a 6yearold from the M. H. Van Berg Stable of Columbus, Neb., pulled away in the last eighth of a mile today and easily won the $30,350 Congressional Handicap at Laurel Race Course be fore a crowd of 14,712.

title: PARIS WOULD REPAY ISRAEL FOR MIRAGES
description: PARIS, Nov. 13The French Government unofficially confirmed today that it was prepared to reimburse Israel for 50 Mirage V fighter planes she had bought but which had been held in France under an arms embargo since the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Music
description: IN 1889, Mrs. John Crosby Brown donated her collection of musical instruments to the Metropolitan Museum. At that time it consisted of 276 objects, chiefly of oriental nations, and savage tribes. Mrs. Brown kept adding to the collection as the years went on, and shortly after 1900 there were almost 4.000 instruments. Many of these were exhibited at the Museum.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Architecture
description: AS with practically everything else, building in America today is in a deep crisis.

title: The Last Word: The Novel, Redux
description: In his long essay on John Updike (Page 1), Richard Locke refers early on to a certain kind of novel as a secular news report. Now, this is precisely the sort of novel that was supposed to disappear from serious literature at least a decade ago under a pile of myth and ritual, aggression and silence, absurdity and cruelty, stylized anxiety, radical juxtaposition, purely verbal artifact, Freudian hieroglyph and the autonomous imaginings of new forms.

title: U.S. SHIFT ON CUBA IN 1960 DETAILED
description: Philip W. Bonsai, the last United States Ambassador to Cuba, says in a new book that the Eisenhower Administration's economic sanctions against the Cuban Government of Premier Fidel Castro in the summer of 1960 were imposed without the prior knowledge of the State Department or the United States Embassy in Havana.

title: UCONN 106 WINNER, SHARES YANKEE TITLE
description: KINGSTON, R.I., Nov. .13 (AP)A 22yard field goal in the third period by Bob Innis, a sophomore, led Connecticut to a 106 victory over Rhode Island today and gave the Huskies a share of the Yankee Conference championship.

title: Behind the Masks, Violent Sensuality
description: WHEN Harold Pinter's The Homecoming opened on Broadway In 4987, New York audiences had a chance to play an intriguing game. Critics, celebrities and scholars, actors, writers and psychiatrists vied with each other on the cultural pages of newspapers and magazines, all anxious to give their own interpretations of the play. So mystifying were Pinter's meanings, so dense his technique and nuances that dozens of explanations appeared in the press, numerous symposia took place in churches and schools and a collection of essays on The Homecoming was brought out later by Pinter's publisher.

title: Reader's Report
description: Letty InnesGore is a middleaged English widow, stranded in Vichy France during World War II. Poor as a churchmouse and ostracized by her French neighbors as the Enemy, you would think that Letty's chances for survival would be slim. Well, how wrong you are! Through circumstances as unique as an eclipse, Miss Lord's starveling becomes a spiv entrepreneur, dabbling in currency exchange and illegal commerce, plus the semilegitimate manufacture of merchandise hard (stoves) and soft (high fashion).

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: As a stockholder who attends over 70 annual meetings a year, I have always wondered how corporations are able to hide excessive expenditures from their stockholders. The Executive Retreats article on socalled workshops for company executives out of town (Travel section, Oct. 31) does stockholders a great favor by bringing this abuse of the corporate expense account into the open. And it has given me plenty of ammunition for a whole list of new questions to ask at the various meetings I attend.

title: Computers Aid In Decisions
description: Management, not machines, must make corporate decisions, but increasingly computers are providing the men in charge with the information needed to reach their decisions.

title: The Kopits Have Son
description: A son was born on Oct. 10 to Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kopit of New York at the New York LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named Alexander Garis. The child's father is a playwright and author of Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mama's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feeling So Sad, and Indians. Mrs. Kopit, the former Miss Leslie Ann Garis, is a daughter of Mrs. Mabel R. Garis of Amherst, Mass., and the late playwright Roger Garis. The child is a greatgrandson of the late Howard R. Garis, author of the Uncle Wiggily stories and the Tom Swift series and of the late Mrs. Lillian Garis, author of the Bobbsey Twins books.

title: Author's Query
description: I am writing a study of Dorothea Dix (18021887), the lady responsible for the founding of many state mental institutions in the United States and abroad. Any information relating to her history and to the whereabouts of her correspondence would be very much appreciated.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Akron was surprised when the B. F. Goodrich Company went out of its own company and the rather ingrown tire and, rubber industry for a new chief executive officer several weeks ago.

title: Et Al.
description: Another visionaryapocalyptic work. First, the catastrophe: ecocide, technologization, unending war, spiritual nihilism. Then a world city, that is, a world order, which the inevitable crisis forces into anguished birth. Mr. Wagar sketches his brave new world in some detail. Those with a taste for a blend of scifi and socsci may find this provocative.

title: Business and Cultural Interests Collide in Fight to Save Flatbush Town Hall
description: Petitions bearing the signatures of 3,000 Flatbush residents were sent last week to Brooklyn Borough President Sebastian Leone urging that the 67th Precinct station house be preserved as a historic landmark.

title: A FluLike Illness at Ohio School Is Linked to Earth Day Project
description: When a group of students in Delaware, Ohio, got the antipollution spirit of Earth Day in April, 1970, they vigorously raked leaves and swept up dirt and debris that had accumulated for 20 years in an old bird roost that had since become their junior high school courtyard.

title: What's New At the Movies
description: FIDDLER ON THE ROOF, directed by Norman Jewison, seeks to enlarge the physical frame of the show by setting it in a real village with real houses, in real fields and real landscapes, writes Vincent Canby. They want to show us everything, to give us our money's worth. In so doing, they've not just opened up the play, they've let most of the life out of it. Not quite all of the life is gone. The Sheldon HarnickJerry Bock score is practically all there, and it's one mixed marriagebetween Tin Pan Alley and Jewish folk music  that really works. However, the gap between the reverential intention of the filmmakers and the film itself is constantly being emphasized by a kind of visual and aural grandeur that is at odds with the poverty and simplicity and faith of the Aleichem characters. Aside from Molly Picon, who is generously and outrageously authentic as the matchmaker, and Leonard Frey, who is the best thing in the film as the timid tailor, and aside from Topol, who, though I feel he's miscast as Tevye, displays such willingness to please it's almost rude not to respond to him, the performances are surprisingly mechanical and bland. Fiddler on the Roof has traveled a long way from its source, from the pages of Sholem Aleichem, and it has become so rich and affluent it seems to have forgotten its humble beginnings in recognizable human experience. At the Rivoli.

title: Lawyers' FreedomofSpeech Rights May Be Determined by the Outcome of Litigation Pending Here
description: One year ago Martin Erdmann told a reporter that the judges of the state's Appellate Division were no better than any other judges, and were, in fact, simply the whores who became madams. Now Mr. Erdmann is in trouble with the judges, facing possible disbarment as a lawyer for what he said.

title: 17,241 at Buffalo See Bucks Defeat Braves, 127 to 106, for Seventh in Row
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 13 (AP)The Milwaukee Bucks romped to their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory tonight by whipping the Buffalo Braves, 127106, before a record crowd of 17,241.

title: RODNEY TROT WON BY MARLU PRIDE
description: YONKERS, Nov. 13Marlu Pride, beaten 2 lengths by Cathy Lee a week ago, turned the tables on that mare, reversing the defeat with a threequarterlength triumph in the $20,000 Duke Rodney Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: I.R.S. Says Rent Rises Are Not Legal
description: A number of New York City apartment dwellers have received illegal requests from landlords who want higher rents for the last two weeks of November, after the wageprice freeze technically ends.

title: Cancer Van in Debut
description: A mobile cancer detection van for women made its debut in New York City at a threeday health fair in Brooklyn last week. Equipped to test for breast and uterine cancer, the van can accommodate 50 or 60 patients a day.

title: Tape Played in Fong Aide's Bribe Case
description: A jury heard a taperecording yesterday that an undercover agent said he made when a $2,500 bribery payment was given to Robert T. Carson, administrative assistant to Senator Hiram L. Fong, Republican of Hawaii.

title: Preps
description: Riverdale completed its 13th undefeated season under coach Frank Bertino yesterday by edging Hoarce Mann, 86, at Riverdale. Riverdale finished with eight victories, while Horace Mann dropped to a 52 record.

title: Maritain: Was It Possible to Update Aquinas?
description: This Thursday, Jacques Maritain, distinguished Roman Catholic philosopher begins his 90th year. Author of 50odd books and the subject of many others, Maritain is perhaps best known to American readers for his True Humanism (1938) and The Peasant of the Garonne (1968). The former volume (titled Integral Humanism in its newest translation) scandalized many political conservatives; the latter has had the same effect on many postVaticanII liberals. Both books have been bought, read and discussed to a degree far exceeding that of most philosophical  religious works. Pope Paul VI has said, I am a disciple of Maritain.

title: The Last Whole Earth Catalog
description: The Last Whole Earth Catalog, one million copies with national distribution by a New York publishing house, is going to distress true believers by winding up on a lot of Connecticut coffee tables. Actually, true believers are as extraneous to its spirit as are suburban voyeurs. The spirit isn't divisive. A sign back at headquarters (The Whole Earth Truck Store, Menlo Park, Calif.) proclaims it: DIG WHOLES. And the back cover displays a NASA photograph of the whole earth, captioned We can't put it together. It is together. Inside the 448page book oneliners abound: Trust is the reality of the road being cleaned, the trash being emptied. The consumer has more power for good or ill than the voter. Money makes the transfer so easy that the transfer itself becomes an obsession. If you want to try a new way, you've got to build something.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Nancy Erlich's review of The Moody Blues' Every Good Boy Deserves Favour states that the Moody Blues verbalize cosmic truths in the form of clichs. This is not true.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE Editor: John Canaday's article, A Mighty Big Hair of the Dog, attacking the vast, glaring, utterly unnecessary and unwanted paintings on the sides of buildings hit the nail on the head. They assault the eye and spirit. They add to the visual noise of the city. If the artists need work, let them find work that is wanted. Whether we, the citizens, are paying the bill for this labor or some benefactor is paying for it, it should be stopped at once.

title: Earl Monroe: A Spectacular Shooter and a Master Showman
description: Who is Earl (the Pearl) Monroe and why are New York Knickerbocker fans saying all those wonderful things about him?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Silence is consent; it is not golden in the case of a man who both speaks and acts on behalf of a convicted mass murderer and then neither speaks nor acts on behalf of this country's most decorated veteran of the Korean conflict.

title: A RECORD BUDGET ASKED FOR CITY U.
description: The City University of New York has prepared a record 197273 operating budget request of $496.4 million  a $114.3million increase over the current budget base.

title: Jack Greene Fiance of Karen Thompson
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 13Dr. and Mrs. Erroll A. Thompson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Julie Thompson, to Jack Martin Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Greene of New York.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: VIENNAThe contemporary dream most mentioned nowadays in Europe is that the nonCommunist and Communist blocs respectively symbolized by NATO and the Warsaw Pact will melt away and that the lands thus freed from entangling ties will somehow draw closer in a convergence of political and economic theories.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Rent Commissioner Benjamin Altman's refusal to allow the owners of 101 West 55th Street to clear the site for a major office building project is the ultimate in excessive use of political power in this city. Even if this building project were to be an economic failure for the ownership, it is not within the authority of any city agency to deny the builder the right to take a risk.

title: CITY URGED TO BUY TAXI MEDALLIONS
description: The city should buy and sel taxicab medallions to stabilize a rapidly deteriorating busi ness, bring in more minoritygroup members and help curb illegal gypsy cabs, the City Council President, Sanford D. Garelik, said yesterday.

title: France's Fickle Phones  What a Hangup!
description: PARISIt sometimes takes me less time to travel across Paris by subway to visit a friend than to try to reach him by telephone, and it's easier to fly to Amsterdam than to dial it from here. But despite this, my advice to anyone visiting in Paris is go by phoneat least once; you can ride the subway or the airlines any time.

title: New York
description: A bespectacled whore, dressed like a cornbelt matron on her night out, paused in her solicitation of passersby last Wednesday night at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 44th Street. No, she said, she hadn't heard of any recent shootings in the area. And I know what goes on in the streets, honey, she added.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article about Melvyn Kaufman [A Maverick, Builder Tries to Be Different, Oct. 17] was read with both excitement and alarm. My initial reaction was excitement, in that hero is one of our citys builders applying both imagination and inventiveness to his structures.

title: Recordings
description: THERE is something heartbreaking about Weber's Oberon. It was a work of great beauty and originality that was not fully realized when it was created and remains a maimed masterpiece that cannot be fully enjoyed today. Some aspects of the libretto, by an English writer named James Robinson Planch, provided the right kind of inspiration for the composer. But as a whole, the book could not endure beyond its time. It is practically unworkable on the stage today, although it does get produced fitfully.

title: Nebraska Downs Kansas State On Tagge's Passing, 44 to 17
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Nov. 13 (AP)Topranked Nebraska regained its composure after mild early scare and routed Kansas State, 4417, today behind the superb passing of Jerry Tagge in the Cornhuskers' final tuneup for their Thanksgiving Day showdown game with secondranked Oklahoma.

title: Graham Rally Had Deficit
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP)An auditor's report made public today showed that the Rev. Billy Graham's 10day crusade in Chicano last June ran a deficit of slightly more than $6,000.

title: Chaps Beat Rockets, 9792
description: DENVER, Nov. 13 (AP) A 22point explosion by Simmie Hill, a reserve who, going into the game, had scored only 21 points so far this season, sparked the Dallas Chaps to a 9792 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight.

title: ARIZONA STATE DRUBS WYOMING
description: TEMPLE, Ariz., Nov. 13 (AP) Arizona State University used a 21point surge in the third quarter today to rally for a 5219 homecoming victory over Wyoming. The victory gave the Sun Devils their third straight Western Athletic Conference football championship, an 81, wonlost record and a berth in the first Fiesta Bowl game. That postseason game will be played at Sun Devil Stadium Dec. 27.

title: Vienna's Opera: A Libretto for Tourists
description: VIENNA  At the end of World War II, with ninetenths of this city lying in rubble, the Austrians started rebuilding the bombedout shell of their beloved opera house before any other major structure in the capitaleven before schools. It took 10 years, and then on Nov. 5, 1955, the elegant house was reopened triumphantly with Beethoven's Fidelio, and Vienna's centurylong love affair with its Staatsoper (State Opera) was on again with renewed ardor. Today, 16 years later, the passion is as intense as ever. Indeed, there Is a local saying that of the 1.8 million residents of this city, 900,000 think they should be the director of the opera and the other 900,000 feel they should run the city's Burgtheaterone of the world's leading legitimate houses and itself an architectural and artistic jewel.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONNot long before President Nixon showed up to substitute for the White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, at the 4 o'clock briefing on Friday, United States Park Police hauled away another batch of the antiwar demonstrators who kept flopping on the White House sidewalk all week to play deadVietnamese dead.

title: Strider and Magnabid Take Mile Events at Louisville
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13 (AP)Strider and Magnabid won the two divisions of the Falls City aHndicap at Churchill Downs today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I think it is interesting, although it in no way detracts from what was said, that Peter DeAnda, Whose article,

title: Meany Decision Awaited
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 13 (AP) George Meany, who arrived here yesterday in preparation for the labor federation's convention next week, is apparently keeping his own counsel about labor's continued participation in the Federal Pay Board decisions for Phase Two of the Nixon Administration's economic program.

title: Quiet Man From L.I. Prefers Capitol Cubbyhole
description: WASHINGTON  Most members of the House of Representatives after gaining a few years of seniority jump at the chance to move their offices into the Rayburn House Office Building.

title: Andrea Stavin, Alan I. Hyman Plan Marriage
description: Miss Andrea Kasman Stavin, a thirdyear law student at New York University, and Alan Ivor Hyman, a lawyer, will be married here Dec, 14.

title: Hamilton Tips Union, 1210, For First Victory of Year
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 13A freshman, Bob Winter, replaced injured quarterback, Mark Rice, after the first play of the game and led Hamilton to two firsthalf touchdowns as the previosuly victoryless Continentals upset Union, 1210, in the 76th renewal of New York State's oldest football rivalry.

title: Bulk Defeat Rockets
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP)The Chicago Bulls, leading by 22 points at the beginning of the final quarter, scored only two baskets in the next seven minutes tonight but managed to outlast the Houston Rockets, 111102.

title: DONNA LEREW GIVES A RECITAL ON VIOLIN
description: There were many admirable qualities to Donna Lerew's concert Friday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Aside from her overall technical expertise and rich, singing tone, the violinist is an uncommonly flexible stylist with the knack of projecting the precise musical essence of a piece.

title: Youth Vows to Upset Nassau Driver Ban
description: SYOSSET, L.I.A 17yearold high school student said last week that he would persist in his efforts to regain the right of young people with licenses to drive on Nassau County roads.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: FAVORS FIDDLER

title: City Jails Held short of Repair Funds
description: Nearly 200 cells in the over crowded Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island are presently unoccupied because, the Correction Department says, it cannot afford to repair toilets and washbasins damaged by inmates in the past year.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WITH pessimism pervasive and no significant buying support on the scene, the stock market fell hard last week in a resumption of its autumnal slide. It skidded to a new low for the year on Thursday and again on Friday, but a sharp technical rally reduced losses late in the final session of the dispirited week.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: I am writing in response to Jack Scott's article on the use of drugs in American sports. My event being the decathlon, I have had numerous opportunities to compete against William Toomey, finishing fifth behind him in the National A.A.U. Championships in 1967. I am currently training in Santa Barbara with a number of America's top hopes for the decathlon in the 1972 Olympic Games at Munich, Germany.

title: Bugner to Start Comeback With 3 Bouts in 3 Weeks
description: LONDON, Nov. 13, (AP) Joe Bugner, recently deposed British and European heavyweight champion, plans to start a comeback by fighting three Americans in three weeks.

title: WELFARE COSTS CUT $39MILLION
description: The city's welfare program is saving more than $39million a year under a reorganization plan that is providing more efficiency and better services to relief clients, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday.

title: Suffolk
description: Andy Burke and Guy Italiano sparked an offense that produced 501 yards and a 346 victory over Islip yesterday. The triumph was the eighth against no losses for Bayport, Suffolk County's lone undefeated and untied eleven.

title: Boy Held on L. I. in Death Of Woman Hit by Boulder
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 13Nassau County police arrested a 15yearold Roosevelt boy yesterday in connection with the death of a woman who was killed: Oct. 29 when the car in Which she was riding was struck by an 80pound boulder.

title: Photography
description: TWO new companion products introduced recently by the Eastman Kodak Company make it possible to take movies indoors in existing light without need for using floodlights. One is a new high speed (ASA 160) movie film, Ektachrome 160 (Type A for indoor use). The other is a new Super 8 movie camera which actually comes in two models, the XL33 and XL55.

title: National Forests: Physical Abuse and Policy Conflicts
description: The national forests, the country's biggest single reservoir of material and recreational resources, are in trouble.

title: Away Boarders
description: The idea of dtente with the Soviets has not yet filtered down to Boatswain's Mate First Class Fatso Ciononni, who has skippered his scowlike landing craft through two other novels by Admiral Gallery. This one finds Captain Fatso and his boys on duty in the Med, where they play chicken with Russian cruisers, and do other mean nautical things.

title: Vietnam Bonus Bill Vetoed
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has pocketvetoed a hill providing $10million more for the states Vietnam bonus program.

title: Democratic Reform Panels To Conduct a Joint Study
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI)The chairmen of two Democratic party reform commissions announced today that their groups would meet jointly to begin a study of the party's national committee system and proposals that might strengthen the national party structure.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I urge youto help prevent hijackingsto encour age stricter surveillance of every passenger on every flight. Having just returned from a business trip to the Far East, during which was carefully investigated, I searched and frisked at every airport, I was upset during a weekend visit to Puerto Rico by the lackadaisical attitude at Kennedy Airport and San Juan. Not only was our hand baggage not inspected at Kennedy but there was not even an electronic gate through which metal would be detected. Having sky marshals aboard is not half as good as careful inspection of each passenger.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: The progress of technology and growth of commerce, for all their benefit to mankind, have contributed to a tragic split in modern times between art and life, a split exemplified by the preference of at least one of our most prominent critics to confine his experience of art to the sacred shelter of the museum, rather than risk encounter with it in the streets.

title: Cougars Rout Squires
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 13 (AP)Larry Miller scored 31 points to lead the Carolina Cougars to their biggest scoring spree of the American Baskeball Association season tonight as they routed the Virginia Squires, 129109.

title: The Nation
description: The Democratic party's angels, the major donors and fundraisers for what doubtless will be the most expensive Presidential production ever put on the road, gathered last week from across the country. They crowded into a small secondfloor room at the Madison Hotel in the nation's capital to hear presentations by most of the major contenders for their party's nomination.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE PAY BOARD limited wage increases in Phase Two to 5.5 per cent and the Price Commission put a 2.5 per cent ceiling on price Increases, although there was some hint of flexibility in administering the controls.

title: White House Bars a Radical Reporter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13The efforts of the underground press to cover the Federal Government with its radical style of journalism have been set back by the White House's denial of a press pass to Tom Forcade, the Washington correspondent for the Underground Press Syndicate.

title: Life is Difficult for Ethnic Vietnamese Minority in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 7Pharr The Dien was arrested five months ago because she did not pay the full tax assessed against ethnic Vietnamese, as foreigners in Cambodia.

title: Football Rivals Friendly les Profitable, Too
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (AP)Loyola of Los Angeles and St. Mary's of Moraga in northern California have a rivalry in football dating to 1935, but apparently it lacks the ferocity of such annual confrontations as Notre DameSouthern Cal and TexasArkansas.

title: Father Blames LSD for Shooting Outburst by Son
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 13Larry J. Harmon was considered by his teachers as the most intelligent mathematics student ever produced in high schools here when he left in 1968 to study nuclear physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Miss Burden, David S. Wilson Married Here
description: In the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church at noon yesterday, Miss Elizabeth Burden, daughter of Mrs. Morton Burden Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., and the late Mr. Burden, was married to David Stafford Wilson, son of Mrs. Raymond J. Brady of New York and the late Capt. David M. Wilson, U.S.A.F.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE tremendous increase in home and apartment burglaries during recent years has caused more and more people to become interested in purchasing and installing security hardwaredoor locks, night latches, window locks, entry alarms, door chains, locking bolts, etc  and has led to a comparable increase in the introduction and general availability of products of this kind in local hardware and stores.

title: CARDEFECT SUIT UPHELD BY COURT
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13The Nebraska Supreme Court has upheld a $325,000 verdict against the Ford Motor Company over an allegedly defective steering gear in a 1960 Falcon.

title: Nassau South
description: West Hempstead defeated New Hyde Park, 217, and Berner routed Uniondale, 267, yesterday to earn the right to meet each other next Saturday for the South Shore championship. The winner takes on the North Shore champion Thanksgiving Day in a special ninth game to decide who is the county's best.

title: Caroline B. Lord Fiancee Of Lieut. G. A. Mackenzie
description: SEWICKLEY, Pa., Nov. 13 The engagement of Miss Caroline Bennett Lord to Lieut. (jg) Gordon Alexander Mackenzie, U.S.N.R., son of Rear Adm. DeWitt Clinton Mackenzie, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Mackenzie, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bennett Lord. Both families reside here.

title: Arthur KatzmanGrandfatherly Center of Furor
description: Arthur J. Katzman, the grandfatherly incongruous center of a series of irritable political confrontations, remembers the politics of a kindlier era.

title: Music
description: LONDON.

title: PayasYouView Movies for Hotels
description: The traveling salesmen and businessmen of America are likely to be offered a new diversion next year when they check into certain hotels and motels.

title: LETTERS
description: To The Financial Editor:

title: Religion
description: Members of the House of Representatives who voted against the proposed school prayer amendment to the Constitution last week know they now will have to face the fury of proamendment forces back home.

title: ILLINOIS DOWNS WISCONSIN, 3527
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13 (AP)Mike Wells passed for two touchdowns and George. Uremovich ran for two today in leading Illinois to a 3527 triumph over Wisconsin, its fourth straight Big Ten victory.

title: Rochester's 2dHalf Rally Turns Back Tufts, 2814
description: ROCHESTER, Nov. 13 (AP) Touchdown runs by Tony Serratore and Rich Parrnello helped the University of Rochester to a 2814 victory over Tufts today.

title: TIDE UNFORGETTABLE COLE PORTER
description: To THE EDITOR: I guess what moved me most about Richard Severo's article, Cole Porter Wasn't Perfect, Only Incomparable (Oct. 10), was his concluding conviction that today's kids would buy Cole Porter. Thank you for believing that some of us have a feeling for more than the latest electric vibrations.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Miss Wersba's book (like all great books, from Alice in Wonderland on), will have different levels of meaning for those of varying age, experience and imagination. But anyone would he hard put to accept the shallow conclusions of your reviewer.

title: FRANCIS P. CHAPMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 Francis P. Chapman, a circulation representative here for The New York Times, died today of a blood infection in Nazareth Hospital. He was 52 years old.

title: YUSUF KHAN VICTOR IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 13Topseeded Yusuf Khan, a pprofessional from Seattle, advanced to the semifinal of the annual Boston open squash racquets tournament at the Harvard Club today.

title: Riad Invited to Peking
description: CAIRO, Nov. 13 (AP)Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad has been invited to China and is expected to made an official visit to Peking in January, Egypt's Middle East News Agency reported today.

title: The World
description: SANTIAGOThis is a meeting of revolutionaries, said Cuba's Premier Fidel Castro during his visit to Chile last week. Our tactics are different, but we have the same revolutionary goals of economic independence and political sovereignty, said his Marxist host, President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: ELY MARGOLIS
description: Ely Margolis, vice president of Edward A. Viner & Co., investments, 50 Broad Street, who was formerly a member of the New York and American Stock Exchanges, died Friday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx. His age was 66.

title: An up and down house
description: Stairways zigzag through Lawrence Horowitz's remodeled West Side townhouse, joining the seven levels made from the former cellar, basement and parlor floors. The economical plan exploits the full 12foot height of the living room, kitchen and bedroom. The lowerceilinged dining room and bath float between floors. The eighteeneighties brownstone was a rooming house when the architect bought it for $72,000 four years ago. The remodeling, which included the transformation of the three upper floors into six apartments, cost $105,000. Turning the first three floors into a sevenlevel home and office raised costs about 5 per cent. The Horowitzes feel that the unconventional approach, which provided an extra room and dramatic spatial dividends, was worth the added expense.

title: R.O.T.C. Raise Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP)  The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill to double subsistence allowances for senior Reserve Officers Training Corps Students from $50 to $100 a month. It passed a similar measure for those in Marine Corps officer candidate programs.

title: What's wrong at State, and why
description: Initially, this book arouses considerable expectations. Dealing with the State Department and its organizational foibles, it comes extravagantly recommended by such foreignpolicy luminaries as George Kennan, George Ball and John Kenneth Galbraith. And it begins auspiciously with some graphic examples of bureaucratic foolishness of the kind that impelled columnist Joseph Kraft to christen the Department a fudge factory; examples of the kind that could only have come from a State Department insideras John. Franklin Campbell was for nine years (he is now on leave, and is managing editor of Foreign Policy). One's hopes rise. Tune in 272 pages later, and you are tempted to conclude that this is an earnest study of matters of the most massive irrelevanceirrelevant, at least, to the foreignpolicy questions of any real consequence.

title: Miss Richardson's Troth
description: SOUTH BERWICK, Me., Nov. 13Mr. and Mrs. John C. Richardson have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Curtis Richardson, to Walter Barney Cotter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Cotter of Barrington, R. I. Miss Richardson is the registrar of the Bath Marine Museum. Her fiance is a senior at Colby College.

title: Preps
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Nov., 13  TrinityPawling held off a fourthquarter rally by Canterbury today to earn a 1412 victory. Canterbury, which finished at 151, missed on a conversion attempt that would have tied the game late in the fourth quarter. TrinityPawling finished at 34.

title: Felt Like the Ouid Sod
description: COOKEVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13 (UPI)  East Tennessee State's Eddie Leddy was first across the finish line today with a time of 30:19 as his undefeated team, which has five runners from Ireland, won the Ohio Valley Conference crosscountry championship.

title: LETTERS
description: ... What I dispute and where Mr. Janeway seems to have a short memory is that he predicted in 1970 not as he says a plunge to 620 but to 500. Mr. Janeway appeared many times on Channel 9 in 1970 and on other channels occasionally predicting a downfall to 500 Dow Jones. ...

title: Preps
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 13 Tom Tsagarakis, a senior from this city, led undefeated Moses Brown to its seventh victory today, 4013, over Thayer. Tsagarakis gained 182 yards on the ground, including two touchdowns, one on a 67yard lateral; added a conversion run and passed 12 yards for a touchdown.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Referring to John Canaday's piece on Knox Martin's contribution to the New York landscape, I agree that such use of art is an affront to all who must view it. But it is also an additional hazardous distraction for West Side highway drivers, as the accident record for the next few months will no doubt testify.

title: Education
description: Just as the financially strapped colleges thought their prayers for Federal aid had been answered, they ran into new obstacles last week. Developments in Congress made uncertain substantial subsidies that had been dangling before the colleges.

title: Three new ventures in the continual rephrasing of faith
description: One might have thought that the death of God, so celebrated a concept a few years back, would have buried religious fervor, religious studies in colleges, religiousbook publishing as well. Now it seems, to no one's real surprise, Jesus freaks abound in the land, students register in droves for electives in religious studies, traditional as well as Eastern, and books theological and meditative still pour from the presses. No wonder. The death of God, a centurieslong philosophical demise, leaves a void unlikely to be filled by failed technology or absurdist cynicism. Man has not ceased to ask who he is or why; here are three books offering philo sophical, theological and personal glimpses of the search for the nature of religion, the existence of God, and the meaning of Jesus today.

title: Jews Are Urged by Fund Head To Back Religious Day Schools
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13The head of the coordinating body of Jewish communal fundraising groups called on the organized American Jewish community today to intensify its financial support for Jewish education to assure Jewish cultural, spiritual and communal survival.

title: Miss Stonberg Becomes Bride
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Nov. l3Miss Margery Ellin Stonberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Stonberg, was married here today to Alberto Luciano Enrico Berti, son of Mrs. Ernani Luciano Enrico Berti of Rome, and the late Mr. Berti.

title: When a Family Spent the Summer To ether, Navajos Benefited
description: ELKINS PARK, Pa.Little did the Navajo nation reckon, in the summer of 1970, what would happen when they were invaded by the family of Ralph J. Roberts.

title: Horst Gerjets, Wendy Welling Marry in Jersey
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Nov. 13The marriage of Miss Wendy Corcoran Welling to Horst. Gerjets of Dillenburg, West Germany, took place here this afternoon. Judge William Klatsky of the Municipal Court of Red Bank performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Leo Stoll. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Anton Francis Gerjets of Emden, West Germany, and the late Mr. Gerjets.

title: Child to the David Siegals
description: A daughter was born on Nov. 2 to Mr. and Mrs. David M. Siegal of Flushing, Queens. Mrs. Siegal is the former Miss Susan Katz. The child, the couple's second, is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Katz of White Plains and Mr. and Mrs. Irving Siegal of Flushing. Her father is a buyer for the J. C. Penney Company. The child has been named Sandy Gail.

title: Connally Doubts Accord On Monetary System Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said today that world monetary uncertainty could continue for an almost indefinite period.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONWith scarcely protest from the White House or the State Department, Congress decided last week that the United States should defy the United Nations.

title: For L.I. TV Viewers, A Series on Ecology
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.Long Island's communityoriented television station takes a giant step Tuesday when it begins showing its first locally produced documentary, a 10part series on the problems of pollution control and the environment, on Channel 21.

title: Greece, Diplomatic Rift Healed, Drops Claim to Part of Albania
description: ATHENS, Nov. 13  The Greek Government shelved an old territorial claim against Albania today and hailed the restoration of full diplomatic relations with her Balkan neighbor.

title: TolliescA Homecoming For Ethel Shutta
description: WHEN Ethel Shutta moves to stage center at the Winter Garden to belt out the lyrics of her Follies you might reasonably wonder if, some nights, the lady's feet aren't a little tired. After all, she is beginning her 50th year on Broadwayand in the same theater where she made her first Broadway appearance in The Passing Show of 1922 for the Shuberts; she is the happy grandmother of fourthe children of her two sons from her marriage to the late bandleader, George Olsen; and, come December 1, she will celebrate her 75th birthday. Tired feet? It's only my knees that trouble me a bit, she says candidly. You know, I was a dancer, too. For Miss Shutta (it rhymes with but say), whose last Broadway show was the 1963 musical Jennie with Mary Martin, her return in Follies is more than just a homecoming. It's so wonderful, she says after climbing to her dressing room (it was fffour ffflights up and she was humming all the way), I mean the young people. They come to see me backstage and say I've seen you two or three times, and love the way you work It's revitalized me.

title: CURB ON TRAFFIC URGED IN MIDTOWN
description: To meet Federal airquality standards by 1975, the city should restrict midtown vehicular traffic and conduct emission inspections for cars, trucks, taxis and buses, according to the Environmental Protection Administration.

title: China and Taiwan Keep Up Their Radio War, With U.N. Loser Gaining in Volume
