description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov 18 (AP)Simon Nolet, the leading scorer in the Western Division of the National Hockey League, scored his 12th goal of the season at 3:39 of the second period tonight to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to a 20 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MADRID, Nov. 18 (Reuters) Between 10 and 15 per cent of Madrid's three million resi dents are suffering from in fluenza, medical authorities re ported today.

title: Blood Bank Controls Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) Charging that alcholics, dru addicts and other paid donor are infecting thousands to Americans with henatitis Rep resentative Victor V. Veyse Republican of California, introduced legislation to reg ulate blood banks.

title: The Uses of Adversity
description: Almost everybody seems to be moaning low these days about wages fired prices, but one of the good things about the bad economic news is that it brings men in power back to reality. This is one of the uses of adversity: It compels longdelayed thought and action; it strips away slack practices, and enables institutions to face the awkward problems they usually evade in more prosperous days.

title: Books of The Times
description: EDWARD HOPPER. Text by Lloyd Goodrich. Illustrated. 306 pages. Abrams. $50.

title: The Screen:Documentary on Cuba Is at New Yorker
description: Felix Greene, the British cameraman-journalist-author, who gave us feature-length color close-ups of "China!" in 1965 and "North Vietnam" two years later, continues his role as a movie Marco Polo for the embattled Left in "Cuba Va!", his latest color documentary on a nation largely concealed by a "curtain." As in the previous cases, he illustrates a contented people, who admittedly haven't yet achieved their revolutionary goals but are, as the title translates, moving forward.Using some old black-and-white footage to stress the enrichment of the few wealthy, both local and foreign, and the deprivation of the masses of the poor and ignorant Latin Americans, Greene, who shot his color film over the last year or so, makes visual comparisons in generally calm and effective style.With Premier Fidel Castro appearing on a few occasions to explain that Cuban freedom could be achieved only by revolution after 400 years of foreign domination, the film's natural bias is apparent but not overpowering. It opened yesterday at the Bleecker Street Cinema.The "85 per cent" illiteracy that existed 12 years ago when Castro ousted the former dictator, Fulgencio Batista, is given cheerful counterpoint by happy youngsters and adults receiving free education and instruction in trades in various immaculate up-to-date urban and rural schools. The admitted fact that did not meet its 10-million-ton sugar cane goal last year is offset by various scenes showing the harvesting of eight and a half million tons, a record crop.A viewer is fascinated by workers from other areas chipping to voluntarily to help with the cane, tobacco and other harvests; by a fine teachers college, medical school with many distaff students, and an especially modern psychiatric hospital near Havana; by an orchestra devoted to Western classics that is viewed, somewhat less favorably, than an excellent modern dance team working with native rhythms as another sign of Cuba's socialistic approach to the arts.One is impressed by younger composer-guitarists such as Silvio Rodriguez, Noel Nicola and Pablo Milanes, whose fine voices extol their brave new world. And one assumes that Mr. Greene knows what he is talking about in noting that "the cinemas are filled and a nightclub has to be booked weeks in advance."One also get glimpses of modern highways being built and slums being razed and a climactic scene showing Cubans reacting forcefully in Havana demonstrations when their captive fishermen were freed by Americans last year. The over-all impression sought by Mr. Greene is a bright present and a brighter future. But despite his largely happy vistas, his "Cuba Va!" leaves a nagging feeling that it is only a partial view of current history that still desperately needs fuller explanations.Also on the bill is "Reggae," a 60-minute documentary on Jamaican music filmed at a concert in London last year and intercut with observations on its origins and purposes. As an outgrowth of traditional African, calypso, rock, soul and blues, its beat is infectious.And, even though Mike Raven, a British disk jockey, explains that "Reggae" was the name of the first record label to feature that genre and that it is also a form of protest, it is basically an item for the buffs, who should appreciate it most.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER CANUCKS,50
description: BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) The Boston Bruins exploded for four thirdperiod goals, includ ing a pair by Bobby Orr, in 50 National Hockey League victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: ROZELLE OPPOSES LEGALIZED BETS
description: Portraying professional foot ball as a sport that would be corrupted by legalized gambling, Pete Razell, National Football League Commissioner, opposed yesterday legislation to permit this, at the second and last day of hearings by the State Com mission on Gambling at 270 Broadway.

title: Allende Orders Prosecution of University Rector
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 19 President Salvador Allende Gossens today ordered criminal prosecution of the rector of the University of Chile and of group of opposition legislators who oppose Marxist control of the university.

title: ChrisCraft Shareholders Lose Bid to Delay Meeting
description: Dissident shareholders of ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., lost a bid yesterday to delay the annual meeting scheduled for Dec. 8. William Marvel, vice chancellor of the Dela ware Court of Chancery in Wilmington, ruled against is suing an injunction seeking to delay the meeting.

title: Prisoner Is Found Hanged
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Nov. 19 (AP) An Attica prison inmate was found hanged in his cell about an hour after he had asked to go on sick call, Superintendent Vincent R. Mancusi said. The inmate, George Jones, 50 years old, was serving a sevenyear sentence for attempted first degree assault.

title: McGrath Goes
description: City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath, considered a penal reformer when he took office early in the Lindsay administration, leaves the city's penal system in a terribly overcrowded and largely unreformed state. Perhaps he did not fight fiercely enough for the funds necessary to carry out badly needed improvements, but in any event he was never given adequate resources in a city budget already strained to meet what doubtless seemed more urgent priorities.

title: Colonels Top Floridians
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19 (AP)The Kentucky Colonels, getting 31 points from Dan Issel, held off a mild Floridians rally for a 114102 victory to might.

title: Bill Stern, Sports Announcer Known for His Anecdotes, Dies
description: Bill Stern, whose loquacious style and flamboyant anecdotes made him one of the nation's most colorful and controversial sportscasters, died yesterday afternoon after suffering heart attack at his home in Rye, N. Y. He was 64 years old and lived on Highland Ridge Lane in the Westchester community.

title: RustTainted Tap Water In Queens Found Safe
description: The city's Department of Water Resources indicated yesterday that there had been no health hazard in rusttinted tap water that generated hundreds of com plaints by residents of the Flushing and College Point sections of Queens Thursday night.

title: DONALD F. M'MANUS, SURROGATE REFEREE
description: Donald Fox McManus, a lawyer who was a special ref eree and law assistant in Man hattan Surrogate Court, died of cancer early yesterday morning at Doctors Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: Attica Remains
description: There is something wrong with a system that permits the walls of its prisons to lock the lawful out as well as the lawless in. The closed society of a prison cannot become, so closed that it disallows public inspection.

title: NEW HAVEN JUDGE ENDS PANTHER CASE
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 Judge Otto H. LaMarchia, in Superior Court here, brought the twoyearold Panther mur der case to an end today when he imposed suspended sen tences on the last two defend ants, Rory B. Hithe and Lan don R. Williams. They pleaded guilty to murder conspiracy charges last Oct. 26.

title: Hughes Contract Enlarged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (Reu ters)The Hughes Aircraft Company has been awarded a $25.5million firstyear increase in a $99.6million army con tract for a classified quantity of antitank missiles.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 As Senator James L. Buckley was announcing last Tuesday that Secretary George W. Romney had promised to re view plans for a controversial lowincome housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, he appeared to be startled when asked if he had carried that area in last year's elec tion. The Con servativeRe publican said with a smile that he really did not know how well he had run in the Forest Hills area and maybe that illustrated his political innocence.

title: The Talk of Nongorna
description: NONGOMA, South Africa, Nov. 6This town of cattle breeders in the hills of north ern Natal Province has a kingsized logistical problem because more than 50,000 tribesmen are expected to converge on it next month for the coronation of the new Zulu King. Crown Prince Goodwill Percival Zwelithini Zulu, a 23yearold alum nus of the Afri can college here, will be solemnly installed as the nominal and powerless  ruler of South Africa's largest tribal group early in December. It will be the biggest Zulu celebration anyone can re member, said David Infume, who operates an African res taurant here. We shall keep open around the clock and try to feed every corner.

title: RANGERS STRIVING FOR NO. 15 TONIGHT
description: With an unbeaten string of 14 games, including victories in their last six, the Rangers will resume National Hockey League competition tonight at Bloomington, Minn., against the surprising Minnesota North Stars.

title: Frankenthaler Paintings Displayed at 2 Galleries
description: The new paintings that Helen Frankenthaler is show ing at Andre Emmerich's two very spacious exhibition gal leriesuptown at 41 East 57th Street, downtown at 420 West Broadwayare some thing of a problem for the artist's admirers, of whom the writer is one. Or perhaps it would be more accurate to say that these paintings are not enough of a problem. Something, in any case, is amiss or missed or missing.

title: Cuba Postpones Airlift
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 19 (AP) The State Department said today that the Cuban Govern ment has postponed the refugee airlift to the United States next week because not enough peo ple have been approved by the two nation to permit operation.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS VOLUME EASES
description: The American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter mar ket turned in their third con secutive loss yesterday as both lists declined in lighter trad ing.

title: Colonial Cup Customs Retain HoHum Pace
description: CAMDEN, S. C., Nov. 19 In a town where only the laundromat stays open past 10 P.M., relaxation continued to mount here today as rac ing's beleaguered steeplechase set prepared for tomorrow's second running of the $100,000 Colonial Cup.

title: Namath Unlikely to Play; Bills Hill to Make Debut
description: While the status of Joe Na math remained questionable yesterday, there was no doubt in the mind of J. D. Hill, Buffalo's wide receiver, about his plans for tomorrow.

title: E.E.C. Trade Balance Gains
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 19  The European Common Market's trade balance improved ap preciably in the last few months, the sixnation unit's executive commission report ed today.

title: Market Place: Mistake Grows, With Internet
description: Ask Rudy Anderson of Streator, Ill., what he thinks about Ross Perot's backof fice brokerage management and he'll give you a wry Midwestern smile.

title: News Analysis
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19 The President of the United States did not really walk into a lion's den when he entered the Americana Hotel here this morning to address a conven tion of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of In dustrial Organizations.

title: Violations of Fair Value. Cited in Treasury Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) The Treasury Department ruled today that diamond tips for phonograph needles import ed from Britain are being sold at less than fair value in the United States.

title: Nyquist Bars Dismissal of Teachers in District
description: State Education Commission er Ewald B. Nyquist issued a temporary stay yesterday en joining central school authori ties here from taking action against Community School Board 3 in Manhattan for de fying citywide regulations on the dismissal of personnel. Mr. Nyquist said he had acted to give himself time to study the issues and promised he would act with dispatch. The matter is believed to be the first major conflict between central authorities and a local district to come before the Commissioner for a ruling since the school decentraliza tion law took effect in July, 1970.

title: FUTURES PRICES IN PLATINUM RISE
description: Trading in platinum futures accelerated here yesterday as prices rose by $2 to $4.50 an ounce. The biggest gains were trimmed by as much as $1 in later profit taking. Sales totaled 528 lots, including 400 switch es to other contracts in the same commodity.

title: Lakers Streak Hits 10
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers dis sipated nearly all of an 18 point lead but hung on in the final minutes to defeat the Houston Rockets, 10699, to night and stretch their win ning streak to 10.

title: Four Brave Men And Human Rights in Russia
description: MOSCOW My wife and I are, I believe, the first Americans to make a personal visit to the Committee on Human Rights of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

title: JACOB GLATSTEIN, YIDDISHWRITER,75
description: Jacob Glatstein, a leading Yiddish poet and writer, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at the age of 75. Mr. Glatstein, who lived at 82.15 Britton Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens, was stricken at home and died en route to the hos pital.

title: GREEKS FREE JURIST DEPICTED IN Z FILM
description: ATHENS, Nov. 19The for mer investigating magistrate whose 1963 inquiry into the murder of Gregory Lambrakis, a leftist Deputy, was portrayed in the film Z, was freed to night after spending 11 months in jail on charges of plotting to overthrow the military backed Government.

title: Transit P.B.A. Elects
description: John T. Maye was reelected to his fourth consecutive one year term as president of the 3,200member New York City Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday. Elected first vice president was Victor Augi and reelected as second vice president was Floyd Hol loway. Mr. Maye was unop posed.

title: Eagles Activate Dempsey
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP)The Philadelphia Eagles put Tom Dempsey, a place kicker, on their active roster today and dropped Happy Fel ler, a rookie placekicker, to their taxi squad.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In Lewis F. Powell's article reprinted on your OpEd page of Nov. 3, he concludes his discussion of the rights of defendants in criminal cases by stating: Rather than repressive crimi nal justice, our system subordinates the safety of society to the rights of persons accused of crime. The need is for greater protectionnot of crimi nals but of lawabiding citizens.

title: A New License Plate for Taxis To Be Issued by State for 1972
description: A new license plate exclu sively for taxicabs will be is sued by the state for 1972. Created at the behest of the New York City Taxi and Li mousine Commission, the new T designation plate will re place the present O license plate, which will go out of existence.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Given the justifiable and under standable concern of the American people for a greater allocation of our national resources to domestic and welfare needsand given the public repugnance to the Vietnam involve ment and the unfair spinoff of back lash against the militarythere is a desperate need for a wider public un derstanding not only that the balance of military power is shifting against the United States, not only that it is the first duty of the national Govern ment, to provide for the common de fense of our country, but as well that our domestic and welfare priorities mean nothing if we grow so militarily inferior that the enemy takes over.

title: $250MILLION REFUND IN TAXES IS APPEALED
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to review a lower court deci sion that United States Steel is owed $250million in tax re funds.

title: NETS WIN, 129127, AS BARRY GETS 51
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Nov. 19 Rick Barry scored 51 points, his high for the season, to lead the Nets to a 129127 victory over the Carolina Cou gars before 6,089 in an Amer ican Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Bucks Rally, Win by Point
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 19 (AP) Kareem Jabbar's two free throws with 6 seconds remain ing tonight gave the Milwaukee Bucks a hardearned 108107 victory over the Seattle Super Sonics. It was the Bucks 10th straight.

title: Minimal Art Shown at the Guggenheim
description: Much critical claptray has been written on minimal art. The catalogue introduction to the current exhibition of Rob ert Mangold, the minimalist artist, at the Guggenheim Museum is yet another bom bastic example of this. It seems that the simpler the art the more complex the criticism, as if esthetic econ omy attractedand had to be justified bya profusion of words and often absurd formal analysis. One bgins to wonder whether the critics who resort to such fustian are as franchised with the art as they are with their own ideas.

title: DR. ADELE BILDERSEE EXBROOKLYN DEAN
description: Dr. Adele Bildersee, who helped establish Brooklyn Col lege and was part of its ad ministration from its founding in 1930 until her retirement in 1954, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Hilaire Farm Nursing Home in Huntingtbn, Her age was 88.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Chides Black Caucus
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17  The Congressional Black Cau cus's conference for black elected officials, aimed at unit ing Negro Americans around the issues that affect our peo ple, opened on a note of dis cord this morning when Repre sentative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn complained that she was not being allowed to lead political workshops.

title: The AliniActors
description: Every Saturday afternoon at 2:30  despite measles, family vacations, birthday parties or scout meetings the show goes on.

title: Italy Is Less Hostile to Busy Mormon Mission
description: ROME, Nov. 10The 19 yearold from Salt Lake City pushed the buzzer on the gate of a small villa in the Monte Sacro section of Rome. When the owner appeared on the secondfloor balcony the youth anounced in halting Italian: We are missionaries from the Church of Jesus Christ of LatterDay Saints and we'd like to talk to you.

title: Monroe to Get His First Shot at Bullets
description: For the first time since they exchanged Dave Stallworth, Mike Riordan and an undis closed amount of cash for Earl Monroe, nine days ago, the Knicks will meet the Baltimore Bullets, Monroe's former team mates, tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: KENNECOTT DIVIDEND IS REDUCED BY HALF
description: Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share, thus halv ing the payout of the three previous quarters. The reduced payment will be made on Dec. 20 to holders of record Nov. 29. This means that Kenne cott's payout this year will be cut to $1.75 a share from $2.60 a year ago.

title: ROSENTHAL IRKED BY HOUSING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  If ever there was a commu nity that had the potential for understanding the needs of minority groups and deprived persons, the folks in Forest Hills have that potential, Rep resentative Benjamin S. Rosen thal said today.

title: HARRY G. SPERLING, AN ART DEALER, 65
description: Barry G. Sperling, president of F. Kleinberger & Co., art dealers of New York and Lon don, specialists in art of the 13th to 18th centuries, died Monday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 65 years old.

title: SHORT INTEREST CLIMBS IN MONTH
description: Shortselling activity on the New York Stock Exchange in creased in the month ended Nov. 15, the exchange reported yesterday.

title: U. S. Catholic Bishops Call For End to Indochina War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church ap proved today a resolution callI, ing for an end to the Indochina war with no further delay.

title: Yale Freshmen Win, 1310. Finish Season Undefeated
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19 Yale's freshman football team completed its first unbeaten season in six years today by rallying for a 1310 victory over Harvard.

title: Liberia Hangs Nigerian
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Nov. 19 (Reuters)Justin Obi, a Ni gerian chemistry professor con victed of the murder two years ago of the Most Rev. Dillard Brown, the Episcopal Bishop of Liberia, was hanged early to day. The professor had been convicted of shooting to death the Americanborn Bishop and his district treasurer, Claude Nadar, a Syrian.

title: PHILIP CHO SINGS WITH SENSITIVITY
description: Philip Cho, the young Korean tenor who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night, showed a sensitive regard for the infinite subtleties of sad ness, especially in Fame's sweetly mournful Po me d'un jour. Mr. Oho found a per suasive tone for this romantic little triptych, avoiding the darkly tragic accent that could have destroyed the music's gen tle charm.

title: MARKET WOBBLES 10 ANOTHER LOSS
description: Stock prices wobbled down ward yesterday to finish only an eyelash above their poorest closing level of 1971.

title: SAN LUCAS VICTOR AT TORONTO SHOW
description: TORONTO, Nov. 19  Joe Fargis of the United States Equestrian Team rode San Lu cas to victory in the interna tional jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight, but the Canadian Equestrian Team held onto a slim lead for the championship.

title: Trade Gap Estimate
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (Reuters) The Administration's current estimate of the 1971 balance oftrade deficit is that it will reach and possibly exceed $2 billion, Peter G. Peterson, as sitant to the President for in ternational economic affairs, told a news conference today.

title: MARINER 9 FINDS HUGE MARS BULGE
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 19 Scientists reported today that Mariner 9 had returned data showing Mars has a huge bulge at its equator and wide irregu larities in its gravitational field.

title: SAIGON ANNOUNCES STRICT PRICE CURBS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Govern ment announced today that it was imposing price controls to curb rises that followed deval uation of the piaster.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times recent field coverage from South Vietnam has persistently omitted reference to the highly suc cessful land reform program, even though you editorially referred to it upon passage in 1970 as probably the most imaginative and progressive non Communist land reform of the twenti eth century (April 9, 1970). Recent stories have cryptically referred to rural prosperity (e.g., Sept. 5) with out further elaboration.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (Reu ters) The State Department spokesman, Charles W. Bray 3d, asked about the Jerusalem report, said: There have been discussions on the possibility she might make official calls in Washington, but nothing is settled.

title: M'RAE DISPLAYS OLD PRO'S TOUCH
description: Willie Williams balled up a piece of used tape and tossed it toward the trash box in the New York Giants locker room yesterday. Bennie McRae, sitting with his head down less than three feet away, reached up and instinctively intercepted the object.

title: CHINA DENOUNCES INDIA AT THE U.N.
description: UNTIED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18China accused India today of interfering in Paki stan's affairs and of, obstruct ing efforts to restore peace on the subcontinent.

title: NationalStandard Shows Lag In Profits for Year to Sept. 30
description: The NationalStandard Com pany reported yesterday that its profits in the year ended Sept. 30 dropped to $4,458,000, or $1.74 a share, from $7,456, or $1.03 a share, from $7,486, preceding year.

title: M.T.A. IS BLOCKED IN RAIL TAKEOVER
description: A Federal judge in Philadel phia yesterday blocked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's takeover of the Penn Central's Harlem and Hudson commuter divisions.

title: Hong Kong Driver Killed
description: MACAO, Nov. 19 (AP) David Ma, a Hong Kong racing driver, died today after his Lotus 47 crashed near the Statue Corner during an official practice for Sunday's Macao Grand Prix. Ma was rushed to a Government hospital where both his legs were amputated above the knee. But he died 10 minutes after the operation was completed, hospital offi cials said.

title: Moorer Sees No Threat
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, chair man of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that North Vietnamese forces posed no immediate threat to Cambodia despite reports from Saigon that enemy forces have cut the major supply route between Pnonmenh and a 20,000man task force on the northeastern front.

title: Riots by Tokyo Youths Bring a Death, 1,785 Arrests
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19Six days of protests by radical youths reached a peak today with riot ing that led to one death, ex tensive destruction and 1,785 arrests.

title: Soviet Sees Grave Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19The So viet Union, apparently con cerned over the latest develop ments in China, said today that there was evidence of a grave crisis in the Peking leadership.

title: Campbell's Net Off; Botulin Cause Found
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 19 The Campbell Soup Company has been able to duplicate in over 300 recent tests the spoil age in a product that resulted in a botulin toxin and has con cluded that the problem oc curred when several unusual conditions occurred simultane ously, William B. Murphy, pres ident, said at the annual meet ing here today.

title: Garden Crowd Is Small For Midget Auto Racing
description: Madison Square Garden's first fling at auto racing pro duced smog, noise, little excite ment and many angry drivers last night. Luckily for auto racing, only 4,500 fans turned out.

title: L. I. Jewish Medical Center To Maintain Brooklyn Link
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 19The Long Island Jewish Medical Center said to day that it expected to con tinue its affiliation with the Department of Pediatrics at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn when it took over the staffing of the New Children's Medical Center of New York on its grounds here.

title: ROSEWALL AND OKKER REACH SEMIFINALS
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) Ken Rosewall defeated fellow Australian John Newcombe, 75, 62, 57, 63, tonight in the quarter finals of the $100,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Baltimore Teacher Accord
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (UPI)  Negotiators worked out tentative wage contract agree ment today averting a threat ened strike by the city's 8,600 public school teachers. Terms of the contract were not im mediately available, but in formed sources said it provided an average $400 a year pay increase and reduced class sizes.

title: Three at 135 Lead Azalea Golf by Shot
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Nov. 19 (AP)Jim Colbert chipped in twice, shot a sixunderpar 65 and moved into a threeway tie today for the top spot in the second round of the $35,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

title: Urge to Dial Answered. By Recorded Messages
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 Americans increasingly, initi ate telephone calls to listen rather than talk.

title: Bulls Crushed 76ers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (UPI)Chet Walker and Bob Love scored 25 points each and Howard Porter, a rookie, added 21 tonight as the Chicago Bulls routed the Philadelphia 76ers, 148104.

title: Avant Garde Festival Held at Armory
description: An electronic county fair camped for 12 hours yesterday in the 69th Regiment Armory, and television upstaged the other arts in the Eighth Annual New York Avant Garde Fes tival.

title: Slight October Price Rise Noted Locally
description: The Bureau of Labor Statis tics reported yesterday that consumer prices in the metro politan area rose moderately in October, the second full month of the wageprice freeze. But most of the rise was attributed to technical increases.

title: Back to Jarring?
description: Although he has donned a uniform and moved into military offices, President Anwar Sadat prudently refrained from belligerent rhetoric in his address some days ago at the opening session of his country's new People's Assembly. The Egyptian leader clearly is not eager to commit himself to the suicidal military action which he has repeatedly threatened for his selfpro claimed 1971 Year of Decision if no progress is achieved on the diplomatic front.

title: 4 OF 16 STOCKS GAIN IN NEWISSUE SALES
description: A large number of companies took advantage of a relatively strong newissue market this week to make first public of ferings of their stock. Investors, however, proved very selective and by week's end only four of the 16 issues were display ing premiums above the initial price.

title: Saigon Says Cambodians Seek Artillery
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP)  Government officials said today that high Cambodian officers had flown to Saigon to ask for South Vietnamese engineers and artillery to help relieve enemy pressure on a Cambodian task force cut off northeast of Pnompenh.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19De pending on one's perspective in the foreignpolicy debate, Con gress is impotently marching up the hill and clown again or is gradually encircling a once powerful Presidency.

title: Revue to Satirize Fun City
description: Fun City Freak, a revue by Leo Shull, is scheduled for Off Broadway presentation in December at a theater to be announced. The revue, consist ing of 30 sketches, satirizes a big citymayor, according to the author.

title: French Aide Backs U.S. in Drug Case
description: PARIS, Nov. 19The direc tor of a Government foreign aid agency thought to be front for intelligence work said today that he believed that narcotics traffic had been organized by French secret service agents.

title: Maddalena':New Italian Film Is At the Juliet I
description: The story of how a tormented, sensuous woman attracts but does not seduce a tormented, unsensuous priest, Jerry Kawalerowicz's "Maddalena" opened yesterday at the Juliet I Theater. Of course, there is more in it than thatself-doubts, mutual recriminations, a fatal accident, a suicidebut in fact "Maddalena" is 15 minutes of dull movie puffed out to more than an hour and a half by flashbacks, fantasy flashes, shifts of focus, pans, track, zooms, and whatever other tricks can be used to inflate cinema vocabulary and diminish the medium."Maddalena" is Italian (poorly dubbed), and you can trace the Antonioni attitudes flitting across the Fellini faces of all the minor characters; but the kind of bad filmmaking it represents seems above mere nationality. In my darker moments I suspect an international cabal of dreadful directors and cinematographers who have decreed that all their movies will share the same appearance of department-store mod decadence with the same lush surfaces surrounding no substance, and the same endless substitution of manufactured atmosphere for real feeling at any level.As the magical Maddalena, Lisa Gastoni seems overage, overweight and underendowed. To express passion, she twitches her eyebrows. To express everything else she walksunsteadily, fully clothed but barefootby the sea. This is a movie in which emotional abandon is taken to mean that anything may be worn to the beach except a bathing suit; and the excitement of the place, the dress, and the person is really less than one can bear.

title: Hearings on Butz Ended by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The Senate Agriculture Com mittee concluded three days of hearings on President Nixon's nominee for Secretary of Agri culture today and scheduled an executive session on Mon day to consider further action.

title: Art: The Figure as Defined by Mandel
description: John Mandel, who is hay ing his first oneman show at the Max Hutchinson Gal lery, 127 Greene Street, is a very good painter right now and might become an impor tant one as well if the re turn to figure painting is really on the way to becom ing the effective counterrevo lution that it promises to he. At the age of 30 Mr. Mandel is master of a technical dis cipline so demandinga very tight, smooth, unrelentingly scrupulous definition of form that would magnify his slightest error or false note that surely he can develop in any technical direction best suited to the growth of his ideas.

title: Amtrack Reduces Fare 22% On New YorkBoston Run
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Amtrak announced a 22 per cent reduction on New York Boston faresfrom $12.75 to $9.90 for oneway adult tickets.

title: C.B.S. IS ACCUSED ON MINORITY JOBS
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System was accused yesterday of consistently misrepresenting the number of minoritygroup performers it employs on day time serials and of misleadingly by listing minority movie ex tras and beauty contestants as its own performers.

title: SCHULTZ, HEIL SET MARKS IN TITLE RUNS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 Rich Schultz, a Swarthmore junior, and John Heil, a Lehigh senior prevailed by slim mar gins today in winning the col lege and university titles with record clockings in the 16th annual Middle Atlantic States Collegiate Athletic Conference crosscountry championships.

title: City Employes Strike in June Is Ruled Taylor Law Violation
description: The twoday work stoppage last June that caused massive, Chaotic traffic jams when city employes opened drawbridges and abandoned trucks on major highways was ruled yesterday a strike in violation of the state's Taylor Law.

title: China's Power Structure Appears Badly Disrupted
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 19  What appears to be the fall of Defense Minister Lin Piao, for years the closest collabor ator and chosen successor of Chairman Mao Tsetung, has al ready seriously upset the pow er structure in China and seems likely to cause still wid er disruptions.

title: Bridge: Aces and Arizona Team Play A PreTournament Exhibition
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 19  The small contingent of New York players attending the Fall National Champion ships, which began here this afternoon with the mixed pairs, were able to watch a pre  tournament exhibition match between the world champion Aces and an Ari zona team.

title: 2 Fire Marshals at Inquiry
description: HONESDALE, Pa., Nov. 19 (UPI)Two New York City fire marshals have been detailed to assist in a coroner's investiga tion into a nursing home fire that claimed 15 lives near Honesdale on Oct. 19. Robert F. Jennings, Wayne County coroner, said that Supervising Fire Marshal Joseph Kelly and Fire Marshal Edward Kelly had been assigned to the case, at no expense to New York, since Nov. 3.

title: Stage: A Feydeau Farce
description: MILWAUKEEThe more watch the plays of Georges Feydeau the more I admire them. He is dramatic comic technique raised to the level of the transcendental. His plays are machines for act ing inand such perfect, beautiful, happy machines that we can only wonder and admire. His farces are bliss fully predictable, but this turnofthecentury French man knew so precisely what he and his plays were doing that even their basic auto matism becomes a manic compulsion, so that the faults of their obviousness become entwined with the inevitabil ity of a foreseeable universe. Feydeau lives on many levels, and Feydeau is fun. Even before Freud he understood that sex made the world go round, and his insights have proved more durable.

title: A Woodland Fantasy
description: OLD FORGE, N. Y.At the confer ence on the Adirondacks at St. Law rence University, it was agreed that under the present policy of forever wild, lack of management of the northern hardwood on state lands in the Adirondack Park was resulting in practically pure stands of beech and hemlock. The northern hardwood type, of course, covers by far the majority of the lands in the park.

title: Antiques: Rogers Groups
description: Rogers Groups, that popular form of massproduced late 19thcentury American sculp ture, are looking their best in the current survey of the sculpture in the collection of the NewYork Historical Society.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In reading your recent editorial Middle East Roulette I was struck by the discrepancy between the edi torial and your news story of Oct. 16. That story accurately reported that 78 Senators44 Democrats and 34 Re publicans  joined in sponsoring a Senate resolution calling upon the United States to resume deliveries of Phantom F4 aircraft to Israel.

title: Belts in Red Hook Tightened by Dock Strike
description: The docks: on Buttermilk Channel that mark the west ern boundary of South Brook lyn's Red Hook section have been silent now for 50 days.

title: Senate Sets Vote on Campaign Fund
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Democratic and Republican Senators, at political swords points for three days over the financing of political cam paigns, agreed tonight to take a final vote Monday on a pro posal for public funding of the 1972 Presidential race.

title: Notes on People
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the President's national security adviser, may not think of everything his employer needs, but he seems to try hard. Mrs. Richard M. Nixon disclosed that Mr. Kissinger, returning from a trip to China, where he made prep arations for the President's visit, brought her a recipe for chicken and walnuts. Mrs. Nixon, who said the dish would be prepared for the President next week, said she didn't know whether she would go to China, but if she didn't, I certainly will be disappointed.

title: PATROLMAN CITED BY TRIAL WITNESS
description: A suspended patrolman testi fied yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx that a fellow policeman had taken possession of a brown paper bag contain ing about $45,000 in large bills that subsequently disappeared.

title: Defense Aide on Rights Chosen; Goal Is to End Military Racism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  Donald L. Miller, a Brooklyn shipbuilding executive and for mer Army major, was named today as Assistant Secretary of Defense for Equal Opportunity and charged with the respon sibility of trying to end racial strife in the armed forces.

title: Hanoi Premier Due in China
description: PEKING, Nov. 19 (Agence PrancePresse)Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam will arrive here tomorrow on an official visit at the invita tion of the Chinese Govern ment and the Central Commit tee of the Comthunist party.

title: Rockets Down Squires
description: HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 19 (AP)Ralph Simpson sank 29 points and Byron Beck scored 20, including a field goal with 40 seconds left tonight, to send the Denver Rockets to a 115 113 victory over the Virginia Squires.

title: Plane Picks Up Daughter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)President Nixon's plane from Florida landed at An drews Air Force Base in near by Maryland at 5:21 P.M. The plane stopped on the way from Miami at the naval air station in Jacksonville, Fla., and picked up Mr. Nixon's daughter Julie and her husband, Ens. David Eisenhower.

title: That Group of Chia Watchers With Headquarters on 7th Ave.
description: Henry A. Kissinger a fashion trendsetter?

title: Possible Blackmail of Nixon Officials Checked Here
description: At least two highranking of ficials in the Nixon Administra tion and other politicians in Washington, Albany and New York are among the people the Manhattan District Attorney's office intends to question about the possibility that they were blackmailed because of their associations with an East Side brothel.

title: MISS BERETTA SINGS UPSTAIRS AT DUPLEX
description: Despite the seemingly end less number of singers who turn up in New York's night clubs, those who have a really distinctive talent are so rare that a listener who comes across such a singer can scarce ly believe his ears. Joanne Beretta, who is singing at the Upstairs at the Duplex, 55 Grove Street, is one of these rarities.

title: Ruskin Studies Official's Role in Lindsay Benefit Ticket Salt
description: Commissioner of Investiga tion Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday that he had begun an investigation to determine whether a crime had been committed when Sani tation Department policemen were asked by a deputy corn missioner to sell tickets to a fundraising dinner for Mayor Lindsay.

title: Soviet Union's Plans Depend On the Strip Mining of Coal
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 19While strip mining of coal in the Unit ed States continues to be em broiled in conservationist con troversy, Soviet planners have laid out an ambitious plan to ex pand the coal industry on the basis of surface operations to meet mushrooming energy re quirements.

title: Union's Tactic Seen Periling Fire Safety
description: Vincent M. Canty, the Act ing Fire Commissioner, warned yesterday of possible difficul ties in maintaining full fire pro tection if the number of fire men on medical leave continued to grow.

title: TELEVISION BAN ON HARNESS RACES FACES COURT TEST
description: A showcause order was ob tained yesterday by Monticello Raceway calling on the State Harness Racing Commission to tell why it has jurisdiction over any planned televising of races from that track to the metro politan area.

title: 2 California Banks Confirm They Are Weighing Merger
description: The Crocker National Bank, San Francisco and Southern California First National Bank, San Diego, confirmed yester day reports that they were holding preliminary merger negotiations. No formal offers have been made in the talks as yet, the banks stated.

title: Harvard Defeats Yale, 21, To Finish 10 and 1 in Soccer
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19 Harvard scored two goals in the second half to overtake Yale and register a 21 soccer victory today.

title: McGrath Quits Jail Post; Says He Was Not Ousted
description: Commissioner of Correction George F. McGrath, whose de partment has been under in creasing criticism, resigned yes terday but said that suggestions he had been dismissed were totally false.

title: Conflicting Testimony on Loans Is Sent to Hogan by City Council
description: Conflicting testimony was presented yesterday about alleged business ties between a former head of the Municipal Loan Program and two devel opers for whom he approved loans while he was in office. The testimony was later re ferred to District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan by Edward I. Sadowsky, chairman of the Council committee that is in vestigating the program.

title: WOR to Show Kennedy Film
description: John F. Kennedy: Years of Lightning, Day of Drums, the highly praised film tribute to the late President by the United States Information Agency, will be televised for the first time Monday at 8:30 P.M. on Channel 9. The film will be seen without commer cial interruption.

title: House Unit Reopening Hearings On a Water Pollution Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. Representative John A. Blatnik, chairman of the House Public Works Committee, announced today that he would reopen hearings on a water pollution control bill.

title: Martin Papers Are Among Spoofs at Follies
description: The annual turning of the tables on the captains of in dustry, business and govern ment was enacted here last night in the Financial Follies of 1971.

title: Acquitted on Fraud Charges
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (UPI)S. Harry Galfand, city representative of Philadelphia, was acquitted of fraud charges today in the sale of stock of a bankrupt investment firm. A federal jury acquitted Galfand of the final 13 counts of an 18count indictment issued Jan. 29, 1970. Federal District Judge John B. Hannum dismissed five other counts yesterday. Mr. Galfand had been indicted with two of his partners in the Com monwealth Financial Corpora tion, Morise Thal and Albert Gerber.

title: Books of The Times
description: JOINER. By James Wintehdad. 463 pages. Knopf. $7.95.

title: Variable Rate Plan Urged For SavingsLoan Group
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee called on the savings and loan industry yesterday to develop a plan for variable rates on home mortgages that would move up and down with interest the generally. Speaking to the opening session of the 79th annual convention of the United States Savings and Loan League  whose mem bers provide the largest single share of home financing John J. Sparkman warned that if disinflation succeeds, your industry is going to be deluged with requests to re finance the many highinterest rate mortgages placed in the last few years.

title: PAY BOARD, 103, VOTES TO APPROVE MINERS 15% RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Pay Board approved a wage increase of at least 15 per cent for the nation's coal miners today despite a stern warning from its public mem bers that such raises would endanger economic stabiliza tion efforts.

title: Ed King, 50, Radio Writer For Garry Moore Show, Dies
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 (AP) Ed King, who wrote for the original Garry Moore radio show, Club Martinee, and for such popular radio soap operas as Ma Perkins and Road to Life died last night of cancer at his home. He was 50 years old.

title: Maine Cutting Short Deer Hunting Season
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 19 The State Inland Fisheries and Game commissioner, Maynard F. Marsh, ordered an early closing today to the deer hunting season to protect the dwindling herd.

title: Rogers and Dobrynin Confer On Soviet Arms Aid to Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  State Department officials said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers had discussed the recent Soviet deliveries to Egypt of aircraft and airto surface missiles with Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambas sador here.

title: Curb on 23 Companies Is Lifted In Alabama as Pollution Abates
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 19 A changing weather pattern ended the weeklong pollution threat to this industrial center today, and a Federal court lifted its order cutting production at local steel and cement mills.

title: Jackson in Race; He Asserts Nixon Fails to Win Trust
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Senator Henry M. Jackson offi cially became a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President today, running on a platform of law and order and a rekindling of the New Deal.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (UPI) Archie Clark and Dave Stall worth sparked a 37point third period tonight as the Baltimore Bullets posted their fourth straight victory, downing the Buffalo Braves, 126105.

title: GEORGE OLIVA DEAD.; NABISCO AD DIRECTOR
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 19 George Oliva, former direr for of advertising for Nabisco, died today at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York after a short illiness. He was 80 years old and lived here at 317 Booth Avenue.

title: The Injudicious Judges
description: BUFFALOOnce again attention is focused on the propriety of potential Supreme Court justices. The entire question of courtroom behavior is under review by the bench and bar. Courtroom disruption began to slip from public memory as the Black Panther conspiracy trials settled into memory. Then Chief Justice Warren E. Burger resumed the attack on what he called adrenalinfueled lawyers who disrupt, shout and come close to insulting judges.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DALLAS, Nov. 19After a recent meeting of the quarterbacks to examine the game plan, Roger Staubach, in the tradition of naval officers, strolled down the hall of the Dallas Cowboy offices to the coffee room. Moments later, when Craig Morton arrived there, Staubach departed without a word or a glance. On the sideline during a game, the same situation prevails. They coexist as rivals more than they confer as teammates. It's not new, says a con fidant of the Cowboy players. Roger is just that way.

title: State U. Rolls Set Record
description: ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP)En rollments at the 72 campuses of the State University reached a high of 226,623 fulltime stu dents in the fall, an increase of 19,700 over the previous year. The parttime student en rollment hit 122,063 students, a record and an increase of 7,833, the university reported.

title: Brandt Party Moves Leftward Despite His Pleas
description: BONN, Nov. 19Chancellor Willy Brandt's Social Demo cratic party stepped to the left yesterday and today at a spe cial convention here aimed at deciding upon a platform for the coming decade.

title: Utility Reports Gains
description: The Southern Natural Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first 9 months. The report placed revenues at $263,401,000 against $237,600,000 a year earlier. Net income rose to $28,432,000, or $2.77 a share, from $26,269,000, or $2.56 a share on fewer shares, reported in the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1970.

title: Secret Service Going Coed?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP)For the first time in its 106year history, the Se cret Service is considering women for its chief investi gative job: special agent.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Enter Mr. Jackson
description: In announcing his candidacy for the Democratic Presi dential nomination Senator Henry Jackson of Washington has tried Lo position himself as the middleoftheroad candidate, the spokesman for solid common sense, and the underdog battling against the odds in the Harry Truman tradition. But it is not apparent that he has the colorful, gamecock qualities of a Truman or that his potent if unannounced rivals, Senators Edmund Muskie and Hubert Humphrey, intend to yield him the middle the road on such issues as crime and the environment.

title: ATEST SITE HELD RADIATIONFREE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  No radiation has been detected entering the environment of Amchitka Island as a result of the Cannikin nuclear test of Nov. 6, the Atomic Energy Com mission announced today.

title: Met Elects Felt and Kendall
description: Donald M. Kendall and Irving Mitchell Felt have been elected members of the Metropolitan Opera's board of directors. Mr. Kendall is president of Pepsico and chairman of both the Emer gency Committee for American Trade and the Grocery Manu facturers Association. Mr. Felt is chairman of the Madison Square Garden Corporations and Madison Square Boxing, Inc., and chairman of the ex ecutive commitee of the Hotel Corporation of America.

title: Thanom Gives His Reasons for Seizing Power by Coup in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 19 Field Marshal Thanom Kit tikachorn said today that his seizure of power in a coup had been made necessary by in creasing resistance to Govern ment economic policies by Par liament, by growing confusion over changing political situa tions in Southeast Asia, and by the fact that the country's two andahalfyearold democratic institutions had become ineffi cient and were incompetent to run the country.

title: Drive Is Urged to Curb Sickle Cell Anemia
description: Sickle cell anemia, a hered itary disease that strikes hun dreds of thousands of people black and white  throughout the world, requires much more basic laboratory and human research before doctors can discover a cure for the blood disorder, experts concluded aft er a twoday symposium that ended here yesterday.

title: TWO SESSIONS HELD IN RHODESIAN TALKS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 (Agence FrancePresse)  Foreign Secretary Sir Alec Dou glasHome of Britain and his full team of negotiators met in the morning and afternoon with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia and his negotiators in the attempt to settle the Rhodesian independence dis pute.

title: Civil Liberties Union Supports Fight for Open Persico Trial
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union, acting on behalf of a reporters association here, is joining the legal fight to force State Supreme Court Justice George Postel to reopen the trial of Carmine J. Persico to the public even though the union agrees with Justice Postel that press reports mentioning such items as Persico's prior record are unjustified.

title: YANKELEV AND WIFE HEARD IN PROGRAM
description: Yosef Yankelev, violinist, and his wife, Yvonne Figueroa, pianist, made their first joint New York appearance in a con cert at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night, presented by the Manhattan Chapter of the Brandeis University Women's Committee.

title: TENANT ALLOWED TO KEEP HER DOG
description: Daniel, a very large black great Dane, and his owner, Mrs. Muriel S. May hew, a slender widow in her late 50's, won the right in State Supreme Court yester day to remain in their Green wich Village basement apart ment.

title: October Rise Was Slight In DurableGoods Orders
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 New orders tor durable goods stayed essentially flat in Octo ber at a level well below last summer's peak, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NET UPSET POSTED BY MISS HELDMAN
description: LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) Julie Heldman of New York upset Evonne Goolagong of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, 60, 06, 61, today and gained the singles final of the Dewar Cup tennis tour nament.

title: Nixon Asks School Funds
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Nov. 19 (UPI)President Nixon formal ly asked Congress today for $350million in the fiscal year that ends June 30 to pay the cost of legislation he signed yesterday providing Federal aid to medical and nursing schools.

title: Dr. Deso A. Weiss, Psychiatrist And Speech Therapist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Deso A. Weiss, an au thority on speech and voice therapy who retired last month as a supervising psychiatrist at Creedmore State Hospital in Queens, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief ill ness. He was 70 years old and resided at 1680 York Avenue.

title: Walston Is Fined $75,000 by Amex
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it had censured Walston & Co., a major brokerage house, and had fined it $75,000 for violations of exchange rules in connection with dealing in the stock of one of the concern's investmentbanking clients.

title: PRICE INDEX ROSE SLIGHTLY IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 The Consumer Price Index rose slightly in October despite the wageprice freeze, but the chief cause was normal and allowable seasonal increases for new cars and clothing, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: Samuel H. Ordway Jr. Is Dead; A Lawyer and Conservationist
description: Samuel H. Ordway Jr., a law yer who was a leading conser vationist and who had been active in Civil Service reform, died Thursday at his home, 155 East 72d Street. He was 71 years old. In World War II, Mr. Ord way served in the Naval Re serve, heading the employment branch and retiring with the rank of captain in 1945 after he had completed a history of the Naval civilian employment programs during the war.

title: Escaped Felon Is Captured
description: Freeman Mitchell, who es caped tom the State Supreme Court Building in Brooklyn in February, 1970, while awaiting sentencing on two murder con victions, was captured by Fed eral agents yesterday.

title: Dryfoos, Black Securities Sign Agreement to Merge
description: Dryfoos & Co., and the Black Securities Corporation, two small brokerage firms based in New York, announced the sign ing yesterday of an agreement in principle to merge. The new concern is to be called Dryfoos, Black & Co., Inc., and is sched uled to begin operations early next year.

title: 1+1 = Terror
description: There are about 180 school days in the school year. On every one of these days, more than one million children ride or walk to about 1,000 New York City schools. Not so long ago, these schools were safe places to learn and grow and have fun in. They aren't safe any more.

title: COPPER PRICE CUT BY PHELPS DODGE
description: The Phelps Dodge Corpora tion took the lead late yes terday afternoon and an nounced that it was cutting the price of whole plate copper cathode by 2.50 cents to 49.75 cents a pound, effective today.

title: MARC WALLENBERG, SWEDISH BANKER, 47
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 19Marc Wallenberg Jr., a member of the ruling family in one of the world's largest private for tunes, was found dead today in a wood near here, an apparent suicide. He was 47 years old.

title: Atlantic Air Fares Will Drop, But Not to Advertised Levels
description: The airfare compromise reached in Honolulu yesterday means that travelers will al most certainly De paying less next year, but will not be getting the bargains that have been advertised.

title: Meany's Salary Raised By $20,000 to $90,000
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19The salary of George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., was raised to day to $90,000 a year from $70,000 by the labor federa tion.

title: House Votes Radio Free Europe Funds for 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19  The House of Representatives approved an Administration backed measure today that would provide funds to keep, Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe alive for at least two more years.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Manufacturers of automo bile, trucks and aircraft tires are inspecting them for im perfections with Xray equip ment on which patents were issued this week to the Westing house Electric Corporation, Pitts burgh. The appa ratus gives tele vision pictures of the inside of tire treads and sidewalls, showing any breaks in the cords, voids in the rubber embedded foreign matter or other defects. Present use is in productionline testing of new tires, but a spokesman said a unit could be devel oped to examine used tires before retreading.

title: Executive Changes
description: Burgess Industries, Inc., announced yesterday Dallas that Donald L. Rogers was elected president at a special shareholder meeting. He succeeds D. W. Maclay, who remains as chairman. The two men will share the responsibility of chief executive of ficer, formerly held by Mr. Maclay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: God may be dead but it's reassuring to find out that the power of evil is alive and well in The Times. There he is, disguised this time as Kenneth B. Clark, offering to solve all our problems (anxieties, tensions, hostilities) [OpEd Nov. 9] and it will only cost us our souls. Old Scratch himself couldn't have said it better.

title: Some Labor Chiefs Say Nixon Will Be Hard to Defeat in 1972
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19The leaders of organized labor are President Nixon's most outspoken critics but they beiieve that he will be extreme ly difficult to beat in next fall's election. In fact, if the economy picks up as the President pre dicts, many labor leaders here see little chance of defeating him.

title: RUDOLPH P. MAFFEI, AD FIRM OFFICER, 46
description: Rudolph Paul Maffei, a direc tor and executive vice presi dent of Gardner Advertising Company, died of a heart at tack yesterday in the Union League Club. He was 46 years old and lived at 104 Meadow Road, Riverside, Conn.

title: Met's New Tristan Is Full of Idea's
description: Everybody for some time now has been wondering when the Metropolitan Opera was going to make full use of its stage facilities, facilities that, we were assured when the house opened, were the most modern of any major opera, house in the world. The Met ropolitan certainly has been reluctant to make much use of them. Even the Wolf's Glen scene in this season's new production of Der Frei schiltz, which screamed for the most imaginative use of modern technology, could have been duplicated by any secondrank house anywhere.

title: Man Arrested in Village Is Linked to 29 Robberies
description: Two members of a Green wich Village anticrime unit arrested a man last night, who the police said was wanted in connection with 29 robberies committed in thte area since Nov. 1.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 19 In a country full of contradictions, one of the most surprising institutions is the University of Rhodesia. It is an outpost of multiracialisin in a world of white supremacy: This year there are 526 white students, 395 Africans and 66 of Asian or mixed ancestry.

title: JACOB J. PANTELL
description: Jacob J. Pantell, a real estate lawyer in the Bronx for 62 years, died of pneumonia yes terday at Kingsbridge House in the Bronx. He was 90 years old and had practiced law until five years ago.

title: 300 Arrested in Alabama; Marched Without a Permit
description: CAMDEN, Ala., Nov. 19 (AP)  Some 300 predominantly black demonstrators, seeking more school integration and better jobs were arrested to day for marching without a permit, Wilcox County Sheriff F. R. Albritton said.

title: A G.O.P. Governor Tells Party to Keep In Touch With Poor
description: FRENCH LICK, Ind., Nov. 19  Gov. William G. Milliken of Michigan, the new chair man of the Republican Gover nors Association, urged his party today not to isolate our selves from the poor, the young and the black.

title: YONKERS TO TRY DISTANCE RACES
description: YONKERS, Nov. 19Long distance harness racing on an experimental basis will be of fered to the public three nights each week for the balance of the Yonkers Raceway meeting.

title: Cards Send Folkersto Tulsa
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals today assigned the contract of Rich Folkers, a lefthanded pitcher, to their Tulsa farm club in the American Association.

title: Heard's 137 Leads by Shot
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Nov. 19 (AP)  Jerry Heard of the United States posted a threeunder par 70 to day and took the lead by one stroke with a 137 after two rounds in the $15,000 Christ church Garden City golf clas sic. Graham Marsh and David Good, both of Australia, were tied for second at 138.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In reports on the nation's 1976 Bi centennial, The Times has noted that the national American Revolution Bi centennial Commission, preferring a multicity celebration, has been reluc tant to hold and fund an international exposition in any city. The shambles of Philadelphia's planning for a major exposition, however, is chieflyand significantlydue to local community opposition to a succession of sites. And opposition is already mounting once More against the latest choice across the river in New Jersey.

title: CITY BANK REDUCES BASE LENDING RATE
description: The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York, said yesterday that its mini mum, or base, lending rate for business loans would be 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday, down from 5 per cent this week.

title: Wind Clears Air Here; Pollution Threat Ends
description: Strong winds moving close to the ground into the New York area yesterday morning drove out to sea the stagnant air mass that had hovered over the city since Wednes day, trapping under it pol lutants in concentrations near the danger level.

title: Smith Will Seek 3d Term As the Governor of Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 19Gov. Preston E. Smith, who had been expected to step aside after two terms, surprised Texas Demo cratic politicians today by an nouncing his candidacy for a third twoyear term.

title: ACCOHICK WINS AQUEDUCT RACE
description: Under a carefully planned ride by Braulio Baeza in the feature race at Aqueduct yes terday, Stanley Joselson's Ac cohick registered a popular triumph. In the stretch of the sixfurlong sprint, Accohick overtook Sigmund Sommer's Pete Rose just in time to score by a head. Pete Rose, with Laffit Pincay riding, held the runnerup spot, by half a length over Boundless in the eighthorse field.

title: U.S. Asks Study of GATT
description: GENEVA, Nov. 10The U.S. called today for an inter national study to determine to what extent the postWorld War II trading system had been eroded by departures from the rules on which it was founded.

title: JOSEPH H. ZAROVICH, A CONCERT MANAGER
description: Joseph H. Zarovich, a concert manager who booked Soviet talent for tours of the United States, died in Moscow yester day. In 1966, he admitted to being at least 72.

title: RALLY BY ROYALS QUELLS CELTICS
description: BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP)  The Cincinnati Royals, led by Nate Archibald, Jim Fox and Nate Williams, rallied from a 14 point secondhalf deficit tonight and defeated the Boston Celtics, 110106, in a National Basket ball Association game.

title: 100 at Capital Welcome
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI)  About 100 Administra tion officials, including three Cabinet members, welcomed President Nixon back to the White House tonight in con trast to his reception by labor leaders in Florida. When the President's helicopter ferrying him from nearby Andrews Air Force Base landed on the south lawn, he was applauded by the 100 persons who stood there.

title: The Bus Is Coming' Is Engrossing
description: If you yearn for just one drama of small-town racial tensions that is strong, probing and impressively balanced, then see "The Bus Is Coming." It has no cast "names" and those lurid ads are as misleading as the title, since a school integration issue is handled only marginally. But this first, inexpensive project of a new black film unit called K-Calb, based on the West Coast commands nothing but admiration.With taut economy, tingling crescendo and a superb rounding out of characterizations, the picture closes in on a young black veteran of Vietnam, caught between equally explosive whites and blacks as he investigates his brother's murder. See this engrossing film, which has a cast headed by Mike Simms and Burl Bullock, excellent color photography by Mike Rhodes and keen direction by Wendell James Franklin. The catch is one puzzling bit of action at the finale.As for Horace Jackson, the scenarist-producer, he is an important man. K-Calb is off to a beautiful start.

title: Bowl Bids Upstage Last Curtain
description: Four undefeated teams do not play to day, but the bowl bids expected to be ex tended to them at 6 P.M. will undoubtedly arouse more interest than the results of the many games on the schedule as the curtain comes down on the 102d college football season.

title: Excerpts From an Address by President Nixon to the Biennial Labor Federation Convention in Florida
description: Following are excerpts from the transcript of President Nixon's speech yesterday at the A.F.L.C.I.O. biennial con vention, Bat Harbour, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: QUEENS PROJECT TIED TO 66 PLAN
description: The controversial housing project proposed for 108th Street and 62d Drive in Queens had its philosophical origins late in the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner and its of ficial origins early in the ad ministration of Mayor Lindsay.

title: House Inquiry Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) A Congressional subcommit tee plans an onthspot inquiry tomorrow into the handling of the Birmingham crisis.

title: Canadians Bar Exporting Of Additional Gas to U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 19The Canadian National Energy board announced tonight its decision that Canada's growing energy needs required that no additional supplies of natural gas be made available for ex port at the present time.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS LABOR'S SUPPORT; RECEPTION IS COOL
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 19President Nixon appealed to organized labor here today to cooperate with his Phase Two economic controls, but declared that he would proceed with his program whether we get that participation or not.

title: Auto Output Dips
description: DETROIT, Nov. 19 (UPI) Despite record sales during the last several weeks, the auto industry is maintaining its con servative production schedules, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Japan Regrets China's Test
description: TOKYO, Nov. 19 (AP)The Foreign Ministry issued a state ment today expressing Japan's deep regret over a Chinese nuclear test detected by the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If for every 1,000 cases of robbery there were one case of smallpox, an emergency would be declared, and we would have action. I applaud Fred Jacobson's suggestion [letter Nov. 15] that National Guard men patrol our streets. They should search everybody and arrest anyone carrying a knife or a gun.

title: Bernstein Conducts a Liszt Program
description: Leonard Bernstein began a fiveweek session with the New York Philharmonic Thursday night at Philharmonic Hall, and his first program was a contri bution to the survey of Liszt's music, that is occupying much of the orchestra's time this sea son. The conductor was fortu nate, in his particular material, because it included Liszt's beautiful setting of Psalm XIII for tenor, chorus and or chestra, and the Faust Sym phony, the latter being the composer's finest orchestral work. The good fortune was deserved, since Mr. Bernstein has been one of its few ex ponents in this city.

title: Woman In the News
description: Birgit Nilsson, undisputed queen of Wagnerian singers in her generation, enjoys scaling vocal heights, but no other kind. So, the Swedish soprano was upset when she found recently that the Met ropolitan Opera's mechani cally spectacular new pro duction of Tristan and Isolde called for her to be hoisted high above the stage on a hidden elevator. Hoping to calm her fears, the director told Miss Nils son: It will make you feel like a queen. The diva was not impressed. For that, she replied haughtily, I don't need an elevator.

title: EXTRADITION BACKED BY PARAGUAY COURT
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 19The Paraguayan high court ruled here today that a French born former Gestapo agent could be extradited to face charges of being the kingpin in a large heroin smuggling opera tion in New York.

title: Trial Transfer Put Off
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP) Transfer of the Angela Davis trial from Marin County to Santa Clara County was postponed today until Dec. 1 In an order by Superior Court Judge Richard Amason. The transfer had been scheduled for (next Monday. Attorneys for the black philosophy teacher, who lis charged with murder, kidnap ing and conspiracy in the Marin Civic Center shootings of Aug. 7, 1970, said they would con tinue efforts to have the trial moved somewhere else.

title: Undermining Phase Two
description: Organized labor no longer seeks to disguise its basis for participation in President Nixon's antiinflation pro gram. The resolution adopted by the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention and the keynote speech by George Meany make it plain that the aim of the labor members on the tripartite Pay Board is to defeat the goal of wage stabilization.

title: Alvin Lee and Ten Years After Play at the Garden
description: The English rock group Ten Years After has always sounded more like a soloist with accom paniment than a wellintegrated musical unit. In their concert at Madison Square Garden Thursday night they moved a few more giant steps in that direction, with Alvin Lee, guitarist / singer, dominating the show.

title: O.E.C.D. Fears Recession;
description: PARIS, Nov. 19Financial officials of 23 developed na tions arrived at a consensus to day that if the monetary crisis is not resolved within a reason ably short time, the world busi ness climate would deteriorate into a generalized recession.

title: For Indian Artifacts, Price Trend Is Up
description: Charles Greeves, in his cowboy hat, boots and beaded buckskin jacket, was one of the more flamboyant bidders at the auction of the Green collection of American Indian art at ParkeBernet yester day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Oct. 29, you published a letter from Rabbi Herbert H. Rose in support of furnishing Israel with additional Phantoms. Rabbi Rose brings up a point which has been bothering me greatly. At various times, both in the press and in official U.S. statements of policy, it has been said outright or clearly implied thatin spite of con tinuing and even growing Soviet mili tary aid to Egyptthe military balance between Israel and Egypt has not been affected because of the knowhow, skill and courage of the Israeli armed forces, particularly of Israel's air force pilots.

title: Housing Protest in Forest Hills Termed Deplorable by Mayor
description: While embittered residents of Forest Hills, Queens, insisted yesterday they would block construction of a lowincome housing project in their middle class area, Mayor Lindsay de nounced the community's torchburning and rockthrow ing at the site on Thursday night.

title: MRS. MEIR REPORTED SET TO VISIT NIXON
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 19 (Reu ters)Premier Golda Meir of Israel intends to fly to Wash ington soon for talks with President Nixon on their dif ferences over Middle East pol icy, usually reliable sources said today.

title: For U.N.s Chinese Interpreters, a New Vocabulary
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 19It's very tiring. You feel the tension and the fatigue, Chiaching Fan mur mured as he lit another cig arette.

title: Statements by Pay Board on Coal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 Following are the texts of the Pay Board's decision approv ing the firstyear provisions of the coal contract, of a supporting statement by busi ness members of the hoard, and of a dissenting opinion by the public representatives.

title: Condors Top Pacers, 124123
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 (AP) A bank shot by George Thompson with one second re maining gave the Pittsburgh Condors a 124123 victory over the Indiana Pacers tonight.

title: Merger News
description: The RCA. Corporation reached agreement yesterday to dispose of at least part of its computer operations. Robert W. Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, and J. Frank Forster, chairman of the Sperry Rand Corporation, announced late yesterday afternoon that Sperry Rand's Univac division would assume responsi bility for RCA's existing general purpose computer customers in the United States, Canada and Mexico. They add ed: The agreement also in volves maintenance and service agreements.

title: Supreme Court Declines To Delay Kent State Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) The Supreme Court declined today to delay the trial of 25 persons on charges growing out of the Kent State University disorders of May 4, 1970.

title: Nixon Pollution Aide Sees Wider Government Role
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 19President Nixon's chief en vironmental adviser said today that the action in Birmingham yesterday in which 23 com panies were ordered to halt production to cut air pollution is only the beginning of greater Federal involvement in the bat tle to control contamination.

title: Sayers Out for Season After Knee Is Put in Cast
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) Gale Sayers, star Chicago Bear running back, is out for the rest of the season, the Bears an nounced today.

title: Polish Parliament May Get Veto on Economic Plan
description: WARSAW, Nov. 19Polish leaders indicated today that Parliament would be given legislative power to veto any changes made by the Govern ment in the nation's fiveyear economic plan.

title: Coins
description: SOUVENIR proof sets of England's pre  decimal coins will be offered for public sale in Brit ain, it was announced in the House of Commons by Ter ence Higgins, Minister of State at the Treasury. (Brit ain officially switched to the decimal coinage system on Feb. 15, 1971there are now 100 new pennies to the pound.)

title: COLUMBIA RALLY TOPS BROWN, 246
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 20  Columbia's football squad closed its finest season since 1961 today by rallying for 246 triumph over Brown in an Ivy League game.

title: Cecily Riddell Becomes Bride
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 20Miss Cecily Ann Riddell of Providence daughter of Mrs. Rhoda Fulton Riddell of La Jolla, Calif., and Col. Rob ert Samuel Ridell, U.S.M.C., retired, of Casanova, Va., Was married here this afier noon to Richmond Viall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Viall Jr. of Saunderstoiwn, R.I.

title: Miss Andrea StrykerRodda Wed to James Laurence, Actor
description: Miss Andrea Stryker Rodda, an editing supervisor with the College Division of McGrawHill Book Com pany, and James Laurence Kepner, the actorsinger dancer known as James How ard Laurence of Indianapolis and Brooklyn, were married yesterday afternoon in Brook lyn Heights.

title: 1968 Mine Disaster Spurs Some Reforms
description: FARMINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 19On the third anniversary of a coal mine disaster here whose shock still reverberates far beyond this Appalachian valley town, Marion County today mourned the 78 husbands, fathers, sons and brothers lost in the explosion of the Con solidation Coal Company's giant mine, Consol No. 9.

title: Oppose a Cretan, My sae And You're a Dead
description: ON a summer's day two years ago a German tourist walked into the little taverna of a village in the mountains of Crete and began talking to the proprietor about people and places nearby. Asked whether he had been to the village before, the German answered that he had been stationed in the area during the war The inn keeper drew a revolver from under the bar and shot him dead.

title: Delaware Victor, 460
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 20 Gardy Kahoe, a halfback, scored four touchdowns and set a season rushing record for his school today in leading Dela ware to a 460 victory over Bucknell.

title: The Luddites Were Not All Wrong
description: YOU could very comfortably have stopped growing after the First World War, said the bearded Engtishman the other day, in a clipped Manchester accent, over a cup of tea. There was enough technology to make life quite pleasant. Cities weren't overgrown. People weren't too avaricious. You hadn't really ruined the environment as you have now, and built up entrenched industries so you can't go back.

title: The Citadel Romps, 47 to 7, Over Davidson to Finish 83
description: DAVIDSON, N. C., Nov. 20 (AP)Jon Hall scored on runs of 2 and 80 yards; Bob Carson tallied on two short runs, and Harry Lynch ran for one touch down and passed for another as The Citadel routed Davidson, 477, today.

title: 12 County Chiefs Join Big 6 Mayors
description: The mayors of New York State's six biggest cities and the executives of the 12 big gest suburban and upstate counties have reached informal agreement on a fourpoint pro gram to put before the Legis lature.

title: Children's Books In Brief
description: Facts of life primer, Gallic style. A baby is born of the love between a man and a woman. Like all love stories human life begins with chance meeting, and so on. It's bit like one of those enigmatically muzzy French moviesmetaphoric blurs, glancing allusions, sudden spe cifics. In the nuptial flight of bees, the queen chooses as her mate the male which can fly the highest. But in the case of sperm, it is sheer chance that determines which one will penetrate the ovum.
