description: CAMDEN, Ala., Nov. 20 (AP) More than 200 Negro demon strators were arrested today in this rural southwestern Ala bama town for marching with out a permit, one day after 300 were arrested on the same charge.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: During a visit Ito the Yuca tan last month, my wife and I observedcontrary to Mr. Gerberg's experienceeffici ency, promptness, courtesy and hospitality by the Mexi cans at every encounter., The author was off the mark in referring to 2,000yearold Mayan ruins. It is my under standing that they date to some time between A.D. 400 and 700.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Factorybuilt or manufac tured housing, the product of a comparatively new and certainly growing industry, has given renewed emphasis of late, especially at the state level, to a push for uniform building codes.

title: A Poll Finds Young Provide McCloskey With Most Support
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 20  Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey, Republican of Cali fornia, while favored as successor to President Nixon by only 13 per cent of Republicans, has substantially greater sup port among independent and young voters, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: Stanton Appeals
description: Frank Stanton, chairman of the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has is year: For 30 years the U.S.O. has served America's service men far away from home. In peace as well as war, a con tribution to U.S.O is a con structive way of showing you car.

title: N.Y.U. to Match Regents Grants in 72
description: New York University has an nounced that it will match re gents scholarships held by all incoming students, starting next September, as an incentive to attract more students.

title: SARTRE AND THE INTELLECTUALS
description: To THE EDITOR: John Gerassi in his introduction to his interview with JeanPaul Sartre (Sartre Accuses the Intellectuals of Bad Faith, Oct. 17) writes: Sar tre's position on [the Cuban poet Heberto] Padilla actually reaffirmed what he had tried to denynamely, that intellectuals have a privileged status.

title: Nassau North
description: Farmingdale, the only unde feated football team in Nassau County, rolled up 325 yards on dffense in the second half yes terday to defeat Westbury, 46 12, and capture the North Shore championship.

title: 3 Guards Hurt in a Melee At Trenton State Prison
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21 (AP)A fight broke out between in mates and guards in a dining room at Trenton State Prison today, causing minor injuries to three guards and some equipment damage, the police said.

title: Medicine
description: Slowly but inexorably medicine is learning how to beat the clock In com bating the nation's number one cause of deathheart attack, which claims 650,000 lives in this country each year. Armed with the knowledge that twothirds of these deaths occur with in hours or even minutes of the at tack, doctors are finding new ways to treat the patient in time to save his life. Their progress was described to the American Heart Association, which ended a sixday annual meeting in Anaheim, Calif., last Sunday.

title: RESTRICTIONS PUT ON HOLIDAY TRAFFIC
description: Restrictions on traffic to help shoppers and motorists get around the midtown Manhattan area during the holidayseason go: into effect tomorrow.

title: ARMY LIGHTWEIGHTS TIE NAVY FOR TITLE
description: For the first time since 1940, two teams share the title in the Eastern Intercollegiate Light weight Football League. They are Army and Navy, each with five victories and one defeat Army losing to Cornell, 2813, on Oct. 29, while the middies bowed to the cadets, 200, on Oct. 20. The deadlock in 1940 was achieved by Pennsylvania and Yale, which has since dropped out of the loop.

title: AntiEban Moves in the Knesset Fail Despite Criticism of Views on Nazis
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20Abba Eban had rough going in an angry parliament this week, ac cused of a blunder thoroughly uncharacteristic of the eloquent Foreign Minister: blurting an illconceived public statement on the Nazi holocaust.

title: BAFFA Symphony Flowers in Suffolk's Culture Garden
description: BAYPORT, L. I.  While Long Island's economy ap pears to have slowed, its cultural activities continue to thrive.

title: Colonels Clip Cougars, 120107
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 20 (AP)  Artis Gilmore outdid Jim McDaniels in their battle of 7footers, and Dan Issel scored 38 points to lead the Kentucky Colonels to a 120107 victory over the carolina Cou gars tonight.

title: Pasadena, Adjusts to Busing, But Opposition Remains
description: PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 20 Mrs. Maurice Morse had trouble last fall in determining the ethnic breakdown of her firstgrade class. All right, said the exasperated teacher, who is black, everybody who looks like me stand up.

title: Vandals Delay Improved S.I. Transit
description: Vandalism of tracks, trains and stations is hampering efforts of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to improve service on the cen turyold Staten Island Rapid Transit system, according to agency officials.

title: L. I Sculptor Carves New Life into Trees
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I.No one on Long Island's woodsy East End is quite as good to trees as Albert Price. A tree surgeon, he cares for them during their lifetime, and when they die, he makes them into sculpture.

title: Blues & Roots Rue & Bluets
description: In 1905, after touring Amer ica and surveying the great lonely land, Henry James re luctantly concluded in The American Scene that the pri mal curse of America was that nobody cares or notices. The few pockets of culture where the love of perfection was pur sued were faint lines which only served to define the over all constituted blankness. Americans were derelicts of their own inheritance, the new Laodiceans, James diagnosed their malady as social malnu trition due to a withholding of love from the land. Americans were ignorant of their own headwaters, architecture, flow ers, poets and fellow citizens; a vast general unconscious ness and indifference reigned. The milk and honey of the Promised Land curdled and spoiled from a lack of re sponse.

title: FROM DRAB TO DRAMATIC
description: The long foyer joining the dining and living rooms has no windows. The designers decided to exagger ate the darkness with blueblack walls and carpet. The painting by Pat Lipsky and the Mike Fox sculpture are highlighted by spots installed on a rectangular ceiling track. The result: a dramatic con trast of light and dark instead of the former conventionally drab hall.

title: U.S. FUNDS ALLOTTED FOR DEPRIVED PUPILS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  Fifteen states will receive smaller Federal grants for edu cationally deprived children this school year, according to, the United States Office of Education.

title: How we won our first Superbowl
description: War, as we hardly need to be reminded, is an important subject. But the history of wars, or military history, has a curious and precarious posi tion in the study of human be havior and experience. For the most part rejected or ignored by serious academic historians, military history commands an apparently insatiable audience of general readers whose de mand is for more of what they like best: the human drama of battlefield heroism, command decisions, strokes of genius, in credible blunders, remarkable luck, and missed opportunities.

title: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title

title: Brooklyn Team Defeats Rutgers of Newark, 3810
description: Brooklyn College defeated Rutgers of Newark, 3810, yes terday and ended its season with five straight victories after three losses. Rutgers of Newark is 27.

title: Kidney Disease Victims Seeking Blue Cross Aid for Home Dialysis
description: An organization of kidney ditease victims who depend on regular treatments with arti ficial kidney machines is bat tling to get New York City Blue Cross to pay the costs of ther apy when given at home rather than in the hospital.

title: Harvard Sets Back Yale On Big First Half, 3516
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 20There was nothing to choose between Harvard and Yale before their 88th game today. Both had won four prior games and lost four, and for the first time since 1965 the outcome had no bearing on the winning or losing of the Ivy League championship.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I am pasting Mr. Gerberg's article in the diary of my trip in the same territory in 1937 in a Model T Ford. We (two women) did it in five days and were the first non archeologists to go in.

title: S.M.U. WINS EASILY FROM BAYLOR, 206
description: WACO, Tex., Nov. 20 (AP) Chipper Johnson kicked two field goals and Gary Hammond connected on two short touch down passes today to give Southern Methodist a 206 Southwest Conference victory over Baylor.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMThings seemed to be going Wrens everywhere.

title: Gardens
description: LARGE water jugs found at auctions and antiqtie shops convert into spacious bottle gardens. So do acid jugs, fivegallon pickle jars and kerosene bottles.

title: Tennessee Defeats Kentucky, 217, and Gains Berth in Liberty Bowl Dec.20
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 20 (UPI)  Carl Johnson ran 85 yards with an intercepted pitch out for a touchdown today to seal a 217 Tennessee victory over Kentucky and give the Vols a berth in the Dec. 20 Liberty. Bowl game at Mem phis.

title: OBSERVER
description: ROMEThe current vicious; hyster ical propaganda campaign against the use of agricultural chemicals, being promoted today by fear  provoking, irresponsible environmentalists, had its genesis in the bestselling, halfscience halffiction novel Silent Spring, pub lished in 1962. This poignant, powerful bookwritten by the talented scientist Rachel Carsonsowed the seeds for the propaganda whirlwind and the press, radio and television circuses that are being sponsored in the name of conservation today (which are to the detriment of world society) by the various organizations making up the environmentalist movement.

title: Announceements 5000
description: ADLMANWEINBERGMr. and Mrs. Julius Weinberg of Kew Gardens Hills, N. Y., announce the engagement of their, daughter, Bonnie, to Mr. Fred Irwin Adlman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Adlmano of New York City.

title: Royal Harmony Wins
description: CHICAGO; Nov. 20 (AP)  Royal Harmony, 7yearold geld ing owned by Tom F. Dereux of Lexington, Ky., charged to the lead in the stretch today to win the $25,000 Chicago Today: Handicap at Sportsman's Park. A  crowd of 21,671 saw the close of the 1971 Chicago thoroughbred racing season.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The joy of Disney World in Florida was extolled in letter from a reader (Travel section, Oct. 31) who said it had nothing to prove, no axes to grind. Really? Aside from the vacuity of such a world, to what does one attribute its openly avowed re fusal to admit long  haired hippies?

title: PAKISTANI GROUP HELPS BOTH SIDES
description: CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 16 The razakars are no more the hated group they used to be. They have found a new role that makes them acceptable, at least partly, to the separatist guerrillas of East Pakistan.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It is interesting that, per centagewise, the greatest growth in American pro ductivity was the fiveyear span of 1940 through 1944, when the gross national product climbed from $99.7 billion to $210.1billion. Would you agree that this was due to the fact that massive Government outlays assured markets (consumers with money) for practically everything that could be made?

title: JAPANESE UPSET U.S SWINIMERS
description: TOKYO, Nov. 20 (UPI)Better conditioned Japanese swimmers upset an eight  member United States team today in five of 11 events on the opening day of a twoday international swimming meet.

title: Television
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich is the pot of gold at the end of the American Rainbow. They have a lot to be thankful for in Bir mingham. But unless things have changed since I left that suburban community outside of Detroit, they won't count blessings on Thanksgiving Day. They'll worry about to morrow.

title: Drugs and Alcohol Called Riskier Than Heroin
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 20A Cornell professor of industrial and labor relations has called on industry to broaden its per spective and end the costly parochial concentration on such drugs as heroin, which he said did not pose nearly as great a threat as legal drugs and alcohol.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20Two strong opinions about America are now widely held and fiercely defended in the capital. The first is that the major threat to the security of the nation still lies in the rising military, and particularly the naval, power of the Soviet Union. And the second is that the major threat lies in the internal divisions of the nation and in the social, political and economic derange ment of an overpopulated world.

title: The Secret of Looking
description: WHEN I started to conduct an elective in creative photog raphy for science, technology and architecture majors at Massachusetts In stitute of Technology about seven years ago, I was asked to provide something that would turn photography into a touchstone for creativity. That was in accord with my thinking, but no one foresaw where that would lead.

title: Valparaiso's Early Offense Sets Back Wagner, 3418
description: VALPARAISO, Ind., Nov. 20 (AP)Dave Zurcher ran for one touchdown and passed for another today as Valparaiso University defeated Wagner College of New York, 3418.

title: A ninepound monument
description: Over a long stretch of years, Edward Hopper enjoyed almost every kind of success an Amer ican painter of his generation could reasonably hope for. Recognition came early. He made his first sale of a picture out of the Armory Show of 1913. From 1924, the year of his first oneman show at the Rehn Gallery, to 1967, the year of his death at the age of 84, he was able to live in complete comfort from the sale of his works. He was lavishly, if often foolishly, praised by critics of almost every persuasion, and

title: Lindenwood Is Fighting a LowIncome Project
description: Although the City Housing Authority says It expects to begin construction of a con troversial 559unit lowin come housing project in the southwestern corner of Queens before the end of the year, it first must overcome several obstacles, all of which are giving local resi dents hope that plans for the development might have to be scrapped.

title: Protecting Trade Secrets
description: The entire subject of trade secrets has come in for re view as a result of recent court decisions, The Confer ence Board pointed out last week. There is growing con cern among corporations, it said, whether tradesecret agreements between com panies and their employes will remain entitled to legal protection.

title: Supershopper
description: A brisk and sensible examina tion of some of the assumptions underlying the economy and of the pressures under which the young consumer functions. The Kleins feel that the family is not a business arrangement, but one in which an affec tionate give and take is far better than fixed payments for services rendered. That is, the child should help, but simply because he is their child, the parents owe support. In the wider marketplace, questions explored deal with psychic dividends and status, and what happens when people choose a personality and then go out and buy things to reinforce it.

title: Bicycle Races set Today
description: The Century Road Club As sociation, will honor the mem ory of John F. Kennedy for the ninth year today by running bicycle races in Central Park. All races will start and finish at 89th street, off Fifth Ave. within the park.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Beyond Freedom and Dig nity has evoked an angry re sponse from Richard Sennett on the front page of your Oct. 24 issue. My only hope is that my book will be better under stood by those who read it dispassionately.

title: CATHARINE MEYER
description: Catharine Meyer, a former editor of Harper's magazine, died Friday in St. Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. She was 64 years old and lived here.

title: GYM IS THE SCENE OF DANCE UPTOWN
description: The ninth series of Dance Uptown, usually held at Bar nard College's Minor Latham Playhouse, opened Friday night instead in the college gymna sium. The informality and use of space in the works of the program's two choreographers, Phyllis Lamhut and Elizabeth Keen, made their choice of a gym floor not only suitable but also necessary.

title: Princeton Bows, 33 to 7
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20On paper, Dartmouth's strategy for beating Princeton didn't look too easy to ac complishkeep the Ivy League's No. 1 team in offense and defense from getting the ball. In operation, though, carrying out the strategy looked relatively simple, as Dartmouth trounced the Tigers, 337, and earned a share of its third straight Ivy League championship and eighth over all.

title: TRICITY TRANSIT AWAITED IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIVAccording to Is rael's Minister of Transport, Shimon Peres, the Israeli Cab inet is expected to give the green light soon to the most ambitious transit project ever undertaken in the Middle East a combination urban sub way and interurban rail system linking Tel Aviv, Haifa and Jerusalem.regions of San Francisco at a cost of $1.3billion. The Israelis believe they can hold the costs down to at least half the San Francisco figure.

title: Rock n Roots
description: D ETROIT: Detroit With, Mitch Ryder (Para mount). After the in tellectuals turned Sgt. Pepper inside out, the fun vanished from much of contemporary pop and rock music. Talking about signif icance replaced dancing to the music. Straying from its basic gutsy strength, rock began a search for respect ability that culminated in such pretentious nonsense as rock operas that were neither rock nor opera.

title: U.S. Operating a Still In Historical Program
description: THURMONT, Md., Nov. 20 (AP) Tucked away in a quiet little mountain glen on the doorstep of Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains, a moon shine still is producing 150 proof white lightning every weekend with the blessing of the Federal Government.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: There is the famous story of Oscar Wilde riding the Venetian canals in a black gondola and claiming after ward he felt as if he had traveled through filthstrewn sewers in his own coffin. Last spring I visited Ezra Pound who lives in San Gre gorio, one of the oldest sec tions of Venice. He told me there is no other city in the world in which he would rather live or die. I agree with Herbert R. Lottman (Travel section, Oct. 31) For young and old alike, Venice can truly be the City of Dreams.

title: About Pro Football
description: The game in the Los An geles Coliseum today between the Rams and the 49ers (Channel 2, 4 P.M.) will be seen by 80,000 spectators who will have walked into a clean stadium. That in itself is a wonder. Southern Cali fornia and the University of California, Los Angeles, finished their game there late yester day afternoon and left the usual mess. Bill Nich olas, general manager of the Coliseum, was the man in charge of clean ing up. He hired a force of 110, twice as large as usual, to work through the night and hoped to have the job done by 9 this morning.

title: Mary Garvey to be Wed
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 20Mr. and Mrs. James F. Garvey have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Mary Clare Garvey, to Harry, Pelt Frank. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley A. Frank Both families re side in Garden City.

title: The Stephen Lashes Are Parents of a Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Lash of New York on Tuesday in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Lash is the former Miss Wendy Lehman, daughter of Mrs. Richard Kaye Korn of New York and the late Lieut. Peter G. Lehman, Army Air forces, who was killed in England in 1944.

title: The World
description: The World

title: Children's Books In Brief
description: The life cycle of the grizzly from infancy to maturity, maternity and captivity. The setting is Yellowstone, and both the heroes and the (un witting) villains are humanthe foc mer the conservationists, the latter the contemporary bearbaiters who corrupt wild animals with candy bars and cupcakes. The nice orni thological, horticultural and zoologi cal detail is eroded somewhat by the touches of cutesiepoo and of psy chology: baby bear sneezes a ridicu lously small Choo!'. Mamma bear  who is Sylvia  is a very emotional type bear, subject to the vapors, embarrassment, nerves on edge and queer distractions; but when she is happy she holds out her arms and her black lips curl in big smile. When baby bear gradu ates to her fitst cubs, she is proud. With her forepaws folded in front of her chest, the corners of her big mouth turned up in a smile and her eyes glowing, she is a perfect pic ture of complacent motherhood.

title: Mexico for Kids
description: Its back cover on which a lumpy stylized folk figure spits out curlicues and Spanish words is a fair introduction to this volume. The prose is as corkscrewed and striated as the pictures, and gracelessness of approach is matched by that of style. The rooms in the Street and the Dead make you feel as though you are walk ing through a bunch of old houses without ceilings, and the roof of the Museum of Nat ural History looks like a bunch of cereal bowls tipped over. The American child comes through as a dedicated and energetic big spender, the Mex ican kid as mercenary and lazy. Mexican kids have a lot of ideas for making money. They are always ready to sell you something, and/or if you were a Mexican kid, you wouldn't go out and pick one of these bunches of bananas. You couldn't even carry it! What you would probably do is sit under the big wide leaves of the tree, in the shade.

title: Janie Pepper Is Married Here
description: Miss Janie CoatesCart wright Pepper, daughter of Mrs. John Arthur Reed Pepper of New York, and John Arthur Reed Pepper of Nas sau, the Bahamas, and Am barley, Sussex, England, was married here this afternoon to John Pattison Williams Jr., son of Mrs. John Bradley, Greene and John Pattison Williams, both of Dayton, Ohio.

title: A Night of Nostalgia Combined an Anniversary With a Benefit
description: It was, according to Mrs. William J. Levitt, com pletely accidental that the Night of Nostalgia ball, of which she was chairman, fell on the same day as her sec ond wedding anniversary.

title: OPPOSITION PARTIES BANNED IN THAILAND
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 20 (UPI)  Thailand's Revolution ary party, which seized power in a coup Wednesday, dissolved all opposition political parties today and banned the estab lishment of any new ones.

title: The Joy of Jazz As Celebration
description: FREDDIE KEPPARD (Terwin Records, P.O. Box 306, Glen Cove, New York 11542). Cornetist Freddie Keppard refused an offer to record his music for Victor in 1917. It was the kind of offer no company would make again until the blues craze of the early twenties, and we will never know whether Keppard re fused out of loyalty to his art, or simply paranoia. We do know why Victor was interested in Keppard; his Original Creole Orchestra left New Orleans in 1912, performed Los Angeles as early as 1913, and arrived in New York few years later. The Creoles played the first jazz heard outside the Crescent City, but they were a black band, and the world went jazz crazy only after Victor began to push a white group, the Original Dixieland Jass Band, who watered down the music of Keppard and other jazz originals.

title: JOHN F. PATT
description: John F. Patt of Cleveland and Delray Beach, Fla., a re tired radio executive, who was formerly president and chair man of the Good Will Station, Inc., in Detroit, died Friday in Delray at the age of 66.

title: Archibald A. Smith 3d Is Fiance Of Gay Richardson, a Teacher
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Nov. 20Miss Gay Brown Richard son who is teaching retarded children in Boston, has made plans to be married next June to Archibald Alexander Smith 3d; a senior at Trinity College in Hartford.

title: Richardson Seeks Gradual End of Health Unit's Corps System
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20The Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare announced acceptance today of a plan that would mean the eventual end of the onceelite Commis sioned Corps of the Public Health Service.

title: Serratore's 4 Scores Lead Rochester to 4114 Victory
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Nov. 20 (AP) Tony Serratore caught two touchdown passes and ran for twig touchdowns today as the University of Rochester ended its football season by defeating Hobart, 4114. Rochester's won lost record is 63. Hobart ended at 54.

title: Mary R. Cooney Bride of John H. Wilson
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Nov. 20Miss Mary Rosel len Cooney, daughter of Mrs. Stattel Cooney of Locust Val ley and of Colin Brooke Cooney of Greenvale, was married here today to John Hanford Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Wilson Jr. of Brookville. The ceremony was performed in. St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church by the rector, the. Rev. Howard M. Lowell and the Rev. Alan Placa of St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Glen Cove.

title: Clemson Loses, 3123
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Nov. 20 (AP)North Carolina State, be hind the running and timely passing of an allsophomore backfield, scored 17 points in the second quarter today and then held on to upset Clemson, 3123, in an Atlantic Coast Conference football game.

title: ABEL BID TO AID 2 IN JAIL REPORTED
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 20An un usual glimpse into, the murky past of Soviet foreign intelli gence operations under Stalin was provided this week in con nection with the death of Col. Rudolf I. Abel, the Soviet mas ter spy who operated in the United States for eight years until he was seized in 1957.

title: Insubordination Wins Hurricane Handicap as Tropical Park Opens Meeting
description: MIAMI, Nov. 20  Tropical Park as usual opened the South Florida winter racing season to day, but little else about the 197172 season will be tradi tional. For the first time in the 47year history of Florida rac ing Hialeah will not have the coveted middle racing dates.

title: Godspell, Musical On Life of Jesus, Arrives in London
description: LONDON, Nov. 20Pure in heart though Godspell may be, the closest stylistic equiva lent that London has seen to this Off Broadway musical on St. MattheW's Gospel is The Dirtiest Show in Town, an other piece of freeform group theatei With a buoyant young cast who supply most of the props and 7 hythms with their own bodies and dispense with the usual trappings of commer cial production.

title: Announcements 5000
description: BENDERRobert and Ellen (nee Asness) take great pride In announcing the birth of Howard and Leonard's sister, Stacey Joy, on Nov. 10,1971.

title: NEW COLLEGE VOTED BY RUTGERS BOARD
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 20The Rutgers Univer sity board of governors gave its c,onsent yesterday to the creation of Cook College, a co educational liberal arts under graduate school to replace the current College of Agriculture and Environmental Science.

title: Leonard Bernstein's MassTwo Views
description: M ORE important than the icons we make are the saints they represent. More important than the fact of Leonard Bern stein's Mass, its success, failure, rel evance, chicness, musicality, theatricali ty, posterity or oblivionquotient, may, be the concern embodied in it. Hair and Jesus Christ Superstar are mani festations of antiwar feelings and the new quest for transcendental faith. Bernstein's Mass is a cry for peace and brotherhood among men and as such is a humanistic document.

title: PARIS BID REPORTED IN DELOUETTE CASE
description: PARIS, Nov. 20An exam ining magistrate may furnish testimony in connection with a Newark narcotics case, it was reported here tonight.

title: Nassau County's O.T.B. to Start in Mid1972
description: MINEOLA, L. LOfftrack betting is one step closer to the starting gate in Nassau County.

title: Early Boston U. Offensive Sinks N. Hampshire, 337
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) Boston University combined a solid ground and air attack and a sharp defensive move by an end, Rick Versocki, to build a fourtouchdown lead in the first half today and coast to a 337 victory over New Hamp shire at Nickerson Field.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Vietnam war and the turmoil in domestic, politics that followed have profoundly changed the Democratic party, producing in most of its leaders less rigid attitudes toward foreign policy, a stronger com mitment to the rights of racial and political minorities and greater interest in the views of women and the young.

title: AROUND THE
description: Finish up most of the outdoor chores: bulb planting, tree moving, shrub transplanting, tool putting away and cleaning. Don't winter mulch this early.

title: Foreign Notes
description: On March 13, 1959, Jean Olivier, a Frenchman convicted of murdering two, children after raping one of them, was executed by guillotine. He was the last Frenchman to suffer such a fate. ThenPresident de Gaulle had refused to commute his sentence, a selective practice that the general followed. He commuted most of the average dozen death penalties imposed in France an nually but during his tenure there was Usually at least one guillotining a year.

title: Male Death Rate Rises, Ending Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 After falling or leveling off for half a century, death rates for most American men rose in the late sixtiesdramatically so for younger whites and for non whites of almost all ages.

title: Pollution Chief Urges Cut in Commuter Traffic
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 20 (AP) The administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency has told a national legislators conven tion that tough antipollution standards scheduled for 1975 cannot be met without reduc ing commuter traffic in the nation's cities.

title: Rabbi Kahane says: 'I'd Love to See The J.D.L. Fold Up. But'
description: MY appointment with Rabbi Meir Kahane (KaHAnee), founder, leader and preemi nent personality of the Jewish Defense League, was for 2 P.M. at the Tel Aviv Restaurant on East Broadway, a few yards from The Jewish Daily Forward building. I got there an hour early, in time to attend a small rally in behalf of Silva Zalmanson, who is serving a 10year sentence in a Soviet prison for her part in a plot to hi jack a Soviet airliner. A lavender flyer being passed around announced that Jewish militants had sworn to kill Premier Kosygin if the 28year old Mrs. Zalmanson, who has tu berculosis, dies in prison.

title: PENN SOCCER VICTOR, CAPTURES IVY CROWN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 Pennsylvania won the Ivy League soccer title with a 20 victory over Cornell today at Franklin Field.

title: KANSAS TRIUMPHS OVER MISSOURI, 72
description: LAWRENCE, Kan, Nov. 20 (AP)David Jaynes hit Marvin Foster on a 35yard pass for the only touchdown today as Kansas buried Missouri in the Big Eight Conference cellar with a 72 victory. The rivalry is the oldest west of the Mississippi.

title: Royal Mast 2Length Victor In Feature at Narragansett
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 20 (AP)Carole Burnette's Royal Mast, ridden by Charles Simp son, survived two foul claims today to win the $5,000 Little Rhody Handicap at Narragan sett Park, finishing two lengths in front of Bull Morin. Heart of Kings was third.

title: The game as seen from the gridiron and the grandstand
description: A much weightier look at our national pastime is Neil Amdur's The Fifth Down. Amdur is The Times's college football heavy hitter, and he turns two years worth of re search loose on the game he covers. It's a very hard look at the petty bureaucrats and despots who freewheel around our campuses, dictating hair styles and life styles in an effort to motivate their players to ward one shining goalknock ing hell out of your enemy

title: Suffolk
description: Brentwood completed its sec ond straight undefeated season yesterday by rallying to top South Huntington, 4214. The Indians, tied earlier this sea son by Lindenhurst, own an unbeaten streak of 17 games.

title: Columbia Students Raise $5,103 to Aid An Injured Athlete
description: Two Columbia sophomores, David Ho and Michael Rubin, have presented a check for $5, 103.93 to Patrick Orzano, the president of the Kenny Kunken Medical Foundation. The money was raised by the Columbia Stu dents Fund for Kenny Kun ken through various functions held last spring.

title: Syracuse Topa West Virginia, 2824,on Praetorius s 3d Touchdown of Game
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 20 (AP)Roger Praetorius's third touchdown of the game, a 9 yard sweep around left, gave Syracuse a 2824 football vic tory today over West Virginia.

title: America At 1750
description: The death last year of Richard Hofstadter, DeWitt Clinton Profes sor of American History at Colum bia, has left a palpable void in the ranks of his fellow historians. His friends and senior colleagues have been quick to declare the special place he held among them: to C. Vann Woodward, he was a pivotal figure in the history of American history, and to Arthur Schlesinger Jr., simply the most distinguished American historian of his genera tion. Similar estimates are widely diffused throughout the profession. Many younger scholars can recall, as I do, the time in college or gradu ate school when we first discovered such landmark studies as The Amer ican Political Tradition (published in 1948) and The Age of Reform (1955). These discoveries were piv otal in an immediate and personal sense, for they helped us find our vocation.

title: Revamping Bankruptcy Laws
description: Ernest Medders, a $75a week mechanic's helper with a wife and 10 children, de cided about 10 years ago to pull up stakes in Tennessee and move to Texas.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The words would have sounded more natural if they had been spoken by Joe Namath. But they undoubtedly assumed an extra trenchancy and impact because they were uttered by that old square, Weeb Ewbank. For the better part of two sea sons, the coach of the injuryriddled Jets has been scrounging and scraping to find enough bodies, each week to, man the platoons. When he groped for words to describe his constant predicament, the abstemious Weeb offered an analogy that was not quite in character.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: I too was brought up as a West Sider. My parents, my sister and I lived a somewhat fluid life between 106th Street, Riverside Drive and West 81st Street) where we final ly settled down.

title: One Time, One Place
description: Few writers of fiction can match Eudora Welty's eye for the eloquent physical gesture or the compelling detail of posture or of dress. Much more than is common, her characters are revealed to us by a precision of physical rendering that evokes our perceptions like so many small starts of discovery. And this fictional distinction of Miss Welty's might have pre pared us to expect at least something of what we find in her new book, which is not a work of fiction.

title: Art Notets
description: THE women artists liber ation movement has opened another front. After last year's siege at the Whitney Museum (With the result that the Whitney actually exhibited a higher percentage Of works by wo men in its Annual show), it's tackling that good gray emi nence across the river, the Brooklyn Museum.

title: 2 AT U. OF MICHIGAN ACCUSED OF A FRAUD
description: ANN ARBOR Mich., Nov 20 Two University of Michigan students are fading possible expulsion because they both turned in identical papers  ap parently bought from the same commerical paperwriting serv ice  to the same English class.

title: Honduras and Nicaragua Battle Pineapple Mob
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nev. 20The Honduran na tional policeaided by Nicarag uan police  are concluding what they regard, as a success ful campaign to eliminate the socalled Pineapple Mob.

title: CATHOLIC PAPER DIES IN GERMANY
description: BONN, Nov. 20A weekly newspaper named Publik died this week, and with it died the hopes of West Germany's pro gressive Roman Catholics that their church's hierarchy would maintain an openminded dia ogue on important secular and doctrinal issues.

title: Two Killed in Maine Crash
description: UPPER FRENCHVILLE, Me., Nov. 20 (UPI)Roger Pelletier, 22 years old, of Madawska and Hughie Devoe, 23, of Limestone were killed yesterday when their sports car collided with a school bus.

title: BRUINS DEFEAT BLACK HAWKS, 21.
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) John Bucyk's conversion of a Bobby Orr pass in the third period snapped a 11 tie and gave, the Boston, Bruins ttheir fourth straight victory, 21, over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

title: Anthropologists Clash Over Their Colleagues Ethics in Thailand
description: Customarily concerned with the habits of others, anthro pologists at the American An thropological Association meet ing yesterday turned  with what sometimes appeared a vengeanceto the rites of their own colleagues.

title: TAIPEI, U.N. LOST, TO STRESS TRADE
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 18in theory, the Nationalist Chinese Government here may continue to claim that Taiwan is part of China under the, designation Republic of China, but the real ity has finally registered.

title: California Law Seeks to Curtail A Heavy Influx of Illegal Aliens
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 20Gov. Ronald Reagan has signed into law a bill to punish employers who knowingly hire migrant Mexicans and other illegal aliens.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe Democratic party, facing its first national election in eight years without the resources of the White House, has developed creative new strategy. Why, its leaders ask, should we risk the old Electoral College try when we can win in ad vance in Congress?

title: Rainier's formula:
description: IN the four decades since the motion picture found its voice, few film makers have used it as intelli gently as a Frenchman of uncertain identity and obscure habits. Although the pictures he writes and directs have brought him international at tention, he avoids festivals, parties and press conferences, affecting disguises on those few occasions when he makes an appearance at a public event. Fantastically jealous of his private life, he is seldom quoted, being selfeffacing to the point of anonymity; he has been photographed exactly twice. He never signs mani festoes or petitions, belongs to no clique or coterie, refuses to own car or install a telephone, and sends back letters that reach his home with addressee unknown marked on them. His life has been called a chain of mysteries.

title: Criminals At Large
description: THE ROPEDANCER by Vic tor Marchetti (Grosset & Dun lap, $6.95) is all about the C.I.A. (called N.I.A. in the book). Marchetti worked in the Central Intelligence Agency for 14 years, serving the high brass and himself achieving high rank there. Naturally, he is not going to give away any secrets. (Guys go to jail for that.) Instead he has written a book that explores the mind of a spy.

title: VILLANOVA RALLY TIES TEMPLE,1313
description: PHILADELPHIA, NOV, 20 (AP)A 32yard field, goal by Duane Holland earned Villa nova a 1313 tie with temple today, in the first deadlock since the series was initiated in 1918.

title: A General's Autumn Beachhead: Stadiums in East
description: For a parent who has three sons playing the game in dif ferent, parts, of the country, footballwatehing can be a fulltime occupation.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: I am afraid the United States may have undone a lot of hard work by its bald resort to protectionism in the form of the import surcharge and the tying of the proposed investment tax credit to equipment made at home.

title: Albert Vogt Marries Mrs. Grace Whitcomb
description: Mrs. Grace Murphy Whit comb of East Cleveland, Ohio, Widaw of Harold G. Whitcomb, was married yes terday at noon to Albert. C. Vogt, of Bayside Queens, widower and president of the Roberta Nash Construction Corporation of Bayside.

title: Too Perfect? That May Be the Only Criticism of T is aris Restaurant
description: PARISPeople talk about Lasserre the way they talk about no other restaurant. If you accept the premise that the finest cooking comes from France, then this may be the best restaurant not only in Paris but in the whole world. Recently the food columnist of France's leading news weekly said it was urgent and neces sary to give the divine Lasserre four Michelin stars (the Guide Michelin's top ratingawarded to an even dozen res taurants in France, including Lasserre is three stars). The columnist's proposal was a little like calling for the return of the Emperor.

title: Letter to the Editor 6  No Title
description: To the Editor: Was Zweig perhaps attempt ing a complicated puton, in the manner of a Swiftian True Critick?

title: Bridge Bad score? Maybe you were fixed
description: To a navigator, a racketeer, a pho tographer, a horse player or a junkie fix is a word with a special ized meaning. For a bridge player the word strikes a sour note: it is used by a player who has suffered a bad score because a farout action by an opponent has, against all the odds, turned out successfully.

title: Gas Stations Plan Holiday
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP)Most gasoline service stations across the state will be closed Thanksgiving Day, the Retail Gasoline Dealers Association says.

title: Space
description: PASADENA Calif.  That Mars seems to experience weather is one of the features of that planet that has encouraged a belief in its resemblance to earth and has helped inspire the stubborn hope that life may exist there. Among all planets of the solar system, only Mars displays seasonal changes and is periodically obscured by clouds or haze.

title: Seven Policemen Suspended
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20 (UPI)  Seven city policemen charged with parking in a cemetery At the expense of their patrol dutywere suspended without pay yesterday.

title: PicassoPortrait Stamp Is Put on Sale at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20Stamp enthusiasts formed long lines here yes terday, to buy a new United Nations stamp bearing a pas tel portrait of a young girl by Picasso.

title: Education
description: New York has become a battle ground for rival teacher organiza tions. Although there has been talk about unity and merger, each organi zation suspects that the other wants to take over leadership and control.

title: Budapest on a Shoestring And All the Gypsy Music You Can Possibly Stand
description: THE words fairly leaped out of the page of the guidebook I was reading: A weekend in Budapest, complete with gypsy music and wine tasting, and at economy prices.

title: Hey, Wake Up! It's Gene Klavan Time
description: S O go ahead, be funny against all odds. Make people laugh at 6 o'clock in the morning  even when it's raining, for God's sake and see what it gets you. Know what it gets you? Lots and lots of money.

title: POLICE KILL SUSPECT WHOSE GUN MISFIRES
description: A Manhattan patrolman shot and killed a man threatening him with a pistol the man had apparently Just used to kill a third man early yesterday in East Harlem, the police re ported.

title: Student, 17 Leaves Princeton To Serve Newark School Board
description: NEWARK, Nov. 19  taw rence.:Hainni, the 17yearold student', appointed to the City Board of Education in June by Mayer, Kenneth A. Gibsbn has withdrawn from versity because his studies In terfered with his board duties.

title: D.E. Littlefield Marries Miss Elizabeth P. Hyde
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Paige Hyde, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Nevins Hyde of New York and Newton, Conn., to Durwood Earl Little field, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elroy Lee Littlefield of Man chester, N. H.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PEKING, Nov. 20 (Agence FrancePresse)  Premier Pham Van Dong, evidently seeking to dispel suggestions that Hanoi and Peking are in disagreement over President Nixon's proposed visit to China, tonight lauded the devoted and powerful sup port of China for North Viet nam. He spoke at a dinner.

title: Queens Residents to Seek to Bar Construction of Project Despite Court Order
description: Despite a court order, com munity leaders and residents of Forst. Hills, Queens, worked feverishly yesterday to prevent the:start of construction of a Iciiikincome housing project in this middleincthne neighbor hood.

title: Hempstead Beams the Only Live Weekly Rock Show in the Metropolitan Area
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.,Every Tuesday evening about 60 bearded, beaded, jeanclad youths manage to squeeze themselves into all the avail able space in the main studio of the UltraSonic Recording Studios on North Franklin Street to hear a free, live, twohour rock concert.

title: The Nation
description: The prospect in Vietnam for the rest of this year and well into 1972 is American withdrawal through air power. Last week  as if to punctu ate President Nixon's warning 10 days ago that air strikes on the infiltra tion routes would continue in sup port of the South Vietnamese until there is a negotiated settlement American pilots clambered aboard heli copter gunships, fighterbombers and B52's and strafed and bombed Com munist targets in South and North Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: Convenient belief in an old calumny
description: Many works of contemporary sociology can be defined as the sub stitution of selfimportant words like methodology where mere methods might do. It's as if every effort to look hard at some event had to be an examination, and every ex planation was an act of syn thesis. Imprisoned in his Latinate technical jargon of compounds and vulgarisms, the social scientist some times seems to be like a character in a play of Samuel Beckett: His language permits him no feelings, and his feelings lack a language. The result in a sort of inadvertent textu al comedy of the absurd, declama tory, selfindulgent, obscure: This dialecticthe source of all modifi cations, whether evolutive or invo lutive (the latter, in their own way, evolutive too)is effectively shaped by events which present themselves to us  as significant revelations.

description: PUNTA ARENAS, Chile, Nov. 20 (UPI)A Chilean Navy de stroyer with Premier Castro and Dr. Allende aboard was making 20 knots in calm seas today toward this southernmost city in the world, the navy re ported.

title: Chance and Necessity
description: Two preliminary points. By and large, biology has now taken over that central place in the layman's awareness of the sciences, in his sense of the new frontiers, which physics held from roughly the 1920's to the early 1960's. This is a consequence of the Darwinian revolution, though per haps delayed or obscured by the prodigious public role of atomic phys ics. As did Newton before him, Dar win in fact initiated reorientations of feeling, new metaphors and ways of experiencing man's location in na ture, which have gradually reshaped areas far beyond those of the life sciences.

title: Life, works and locus
description: My uncle Zev from Prague, who wanted to be a poet, kept a journal of metaphysical speculations, fleeting apprehensions and the remarks of his friend Kafka, a dark, sickly, skin ny lawyer with a Byzantine birdface. Around the time that my uncle came to America, abandoned poetry and hid his journal, Kafka became Franz Kafka of The Trial, The Castle, stories, diaries, letters and, in short, the most portentous, maybe great est, writer of our century. My uncle retrieved his journal and the pain he felt asks for no description be yond the fact that he banged his head against a wall until the bricks returned him to himself, a failure, but friend of genius. In his journal he saw his youthful aspirations with the Kafkesqueria sprinkled throughout, like stars penetrating dismal confu sion, Kafka's spoken words, The Word, as the world must make it flesh. So he ripped his journal into a hundred pieces and fed them to the Hudson River, beside which he lives today, a bitterly beatified Jew who smokes a cigarette and gazes the flux.

title: The man they loved to hate
description: Like Orson Welles after him, Erich von Stroheim was the classic example of the artist who was too big for Holly wood. His methods were alto gether wrong for the Dream Factory. Quite apart from the fact that his films portrayed humanity in a distinctly unflat tering lighthe was a Month erlant in a Gene Stratton Porter world  he worked extremely slowly, without regard for budg ets or the requirements of a mass audience. He completely ignored the fact that he was in the service of businessmen, and he was naively horrified when his films were trimmed to make them exhibitable. Fool ish Wives and Greed were mere excerpts from master pieces rather than masterpieces themselves.

title: Music
description: T HANKSGIVING is upon us, and in the spirit of the season I have been browsing in some books that tell something about the Puritans and music. It was not long ago that we were told all about the dour, thrifty, fanatic, musichating, entertain menthating, prim Pilgrim Fathers. It was taken as an article of faith that musical development in this country certainly in the New England states was immeasurably retarded because of the attitude of the Pilgrims. The classic piece of supporting evidence was Thomas Morton's visit to Plymouth in 1626. Morton, who celebrated May with a maypole dance and such bacchanalian music as Drink and be merry, merry, merry, boys, was made to feel unwel come. Ergo, the Pilgrims hated music.

title: The Council on Foreign Relations Is It a Club? Seminar? Presidium? Invisible Government'?
description: ON March 26, 1969, eleven places were set for lunch at the oval table in the Council on Foreign Relations stately meeting room overlooking Park Avenue. The guest list was not quite so distin guished as some from the past, judg ing by the photographs hanging on the black walnut paneling: Harold Macmillan chatting with Henry Wriston; John Foster Dulles wedged stiffly between John J. McCloy and Averell Harriman; John W. Davis towering over the King of Siam. But for a weekday working lunch, it was an impressive assemblage.

title: Substituting Our Magic for Theirs
description: THE radical change in esthetic taste that has led us to elevate the artistic endeavors of socalled primitive peoples to something like critical par ity with the art objects of highly developed civilizations is of relatively recent date. Both science and politics have played major roles in this fateful alteration of our esthetic perspectivewill we ever have a comprehensive study of the relation of mod ern ethnology to the rise and fall of Western imperialism? but the essential role was that of modern art itself. When the Cubists and Ex pressionists began to exploit for their own purposes what the anthropologists and co lonial administrators had garnered in museums devoted to man rather than his art, the esthetic outlook of the Western mind was perma nently changed.

title: Some sources of Walt Whitman's art, selfreported in
description: The physical design of books can make a difference in our reading. Every so often an imaginative book maker conceives a striking new for mat for an old familiar work and we see things in it we never saw before. The case at hand is a reissue of Walt Whitman's Specimen Days, a text that has always seemed to me (and to most people, I expect) a delightful hodgepodge less like a book with a center than a heap of autobiographical frag ments. That is partly because we so rarely encounter Specimen Days in its entirety. For years editors and publishers have been raiding the heap whenever they wanted a sam ple of the poet's prose to tuck away at the back of various editions of Leaves of Grass. But now David R. Godine, a Boston printer and pub lisher of fine books, has produced an edition of Specimen Days that is so handsome, so visually arrest ing, that one is tempted to read this late work of our greatest American poet as if it might be a real book after all.

title: Penny Lindell Engaged
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I. Nov. 20 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Lindell of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Penny I. Lindell, to Andrew H. Novak. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman J. Novak of New York and East Atlantic Beach.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MOUNT TABOR, Vt., Nov. 20Vermont's deer season, which opened a week ago in beautiful weather, has been dismal for Sam McLellan from the start. He couldn't even hunt on opening day.

title: JOHN MAJESKI SR., PUBLISHER, DEAD
description: John F. Majeski Sr., former owner and publisher of the magazine Musical America, died Friday night in Gracie Square Hospital, where he had been a patient since suffering a stroke early in October. He was 79 years old and lived at 101 West 55th Street.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 20At his office desk overlooking the surf sliding up the sand, Don Quixote was wearing an orchid shirt with a black, pink and orchid striped tic.

title: Curb on Debt Collectors
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Nev. 20 (AP)Debt collectors could no longer curse, punch or threaten persons who do not pay off their loans, undpra bill filed in the Florida Houpe. Representa tive John Forbes,:the bill's spon sor, said testiniony before the House BUsinesP Regulation Committee hadshown the ex istence of intolerable practices used by collection agencies in their efforts to obtain payments of debts: Practices banned in clude threats of actual violence, profane or abusive language and communicating with the debtor's employer without his permission.

title: Rigatoni King, $26.40, Wins $15,000 Coast Race by Neck
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 20 (UPI)Rigatoni King got up in the last couple of strides to nip the pacesetting Vikingson by a neck in the $15,000 feature purse at Bay Meadows today.

title: WALL STREET
description: Playing followtheleader is a fairly common game in the stock market. But it can have disastrous results when the leader trips and sends everyone else sprawling.

title: Chinese Please Smaller Powers by Having Tea in U.N. Lounge
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 20Huang Hua, the graying diplomat who is Chi na's new permanent repre sentative at the United Na tions, strolled over to the delegates lounge with a col league for tea one afternoon this week.

title: PACT LIMITS STATUS OF 2 ASIAN STRAITS
description: SINGAPORE, Nov, 20 (AP) Indonesia and Malaysia have agreed that the Strait of Ma lacca and Singapore Strait are not international straits, a joint statement said, but they recognized free use of the wa terways for international ship ping on the principle of inno cent passage.

title: Movies
description: E LAINE MAY is making plans for her honey moon. The comedienne playwright, who made her movie directorial debut earlier this year with the hit comedy A New Leaf, is about to add another leaf to her movie book. This time she'll direct The Heartbreak Kid, and the farout fun will revolve around a man who ditches his bride on their honeymoon when he spies an irresistible cutie. And just to prove that he is no prisoner of Broadway or Second Av enue, Neil Simon has written the screenplay for The Heartbreak Kid, basing it on Bruce Jay Friedman's short story, A Change of Plan. Shooting  for Palomar Pic tures  should begin some time in January in Miami.

title: GREECE VULNERABLE, LUNS WARNS THERE
description: ATHENS, Nov. 20 The North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation's new Secretary General, Dr. Joseph M.A.H. Luns, warned today that the growth of Soviet naval power in the eastern Mediterranean had made this area highly vulner able.

title: SEPARATE LOCALS ARE RULED BIASED
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 20A Fed eral district judge in Texas has found that sister union lo calsthose segregated by race and pairedare discriminatory by nature but may not violate Federal civil rights laws.

title: Steelers Activate Rookie
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 (AP) The Pittsburgh Steelers acti vated a rookie defensive back, Ralph Anderson of West Texas State, today for tomorrow's game with the New York Giants. The Steelers placed defensive back, Glen Edwards, on the move list.

title: Movies
description: HE LOOKS like a hard charging linebacker for the Baltimore Colts. Or the biggest bully on the block. Or Got ham's toughest cop, which is exactly what Gene Hackman plays in the new copsand crooks thriller, The French Connection. The film has fi nally catapulted the beefy 40yearold actor to the star categoryit's taken him al most half his life to get thereand he is so good as the brutish Popeye Doyle, the porkpiehatted narc who totes his gun around his ankle, that he is being touted for another Oscar nomina tion, his third in four years.

title: A breezy sketch of the first Fascist dictator
description: The story of Mussolini is full of human drama and excite ment. The son of a humble blacksmith, he worked his way to fame as a socialist leader, and then inaugurated a new Fascist party which carried out a remarkable coup in 1922. Aft er becoming the youngest Prime Minister in Italian history, he made himself into the first of those Fascist dictators who tore Europe apart and deluged the world in blood. After 20 years in power, he was assas sinated.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONThe curious role of Rich ard Nixon in the development of Brit ish policy is that he managed to create here the most European climate possible shortly before Parlia ment voted approval of this country's plan to join the Common Market.

title: Letter to the Editor 2  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: In his interview with John Gerassi JeanPaul Sartre states:  the Ger man intellectual who fled Hitler  was as responsible for Hitler as the German who closed his eyes, just as the American intellectual who  insists on law and order  is re sponsible for the murders [in the U.S.A].

title: McDotigair's 9 Goals Set Association Cup Soccer Mark

The previous mark was seven goals set by Billy Minter for St. Albans in 1922.

description: NEWTON, Mass., Nov. 20 (AP)Boston College combined the running of Tom Bogus, the passreceiving of Mel Briggs and an alert defense today for a 350 triumph over Massa chusetts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his first speech to the U.N. Assem bly, Communist China's chief represent ative said his people were determined to liberate Taiwan. This reflects typi cal Chinese chauvinism. Peking's claim to Taiwan is just as groundless and impudent as Chiang Kaishek's claim to the mainland.

title: Camera World
description: A NEW Super 8 movie camera that is really compact, yet still in cludes many desirable features, has been recently introduced by GAF Corpora tion, 140 West 51st Street, New York, N.Y. 10020. Called the GAF Compact 400, the camera features an unusual pistolgrip handle that folds up against the bottom for easy carrying, or that can be detached entirely. It has an f/1.8 power zoom lens with a 4 to 1 ratio (7 to 28mm) and has a Cds electric eye exposure control. Pressing a separate button compensates for the special problem of backlighted subjects.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The chairman of the Pay Board, Judge George H. Boldt, said today that the coal indus try might seek an immediate price increase of 55 cents ton, or about 8.5 per cent, to cover a newly approved wage rise.

title: Letter to the Editor 1  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Here we go again with the same old gunlobby, gunfreak argument in Bruce L. Cohen's letter (Oct. 31). A [hand] gun is an inanimate object, as are kitchen knives, bookends, jars of lye and automobiles. None of these items are capable of murder; only the people who use them improperly are capable of this deed.

Apparently, we who own handguns are gun nuts, gaggle of gun lovers, and the most serious handicaps [to total handgun control], oddly enough, are thrown up by the police and the nice people of America.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (Reuters)The Customs Bu reau seized illicit drugs worth $617.Z300,000, based on black market values, in the first 10 months of this year, the bureau reports. This was three times the amount seized in 1970. The bureau reported that individual seizures increased to 8,806 from 7,961.

description: Miss Olivia Jayne Simmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver R. Simmons, was married yesterday afternoon to Carey Alexander White, son of Mrs. Mildred White of Jacksonville, Fla., and William White of Frederica, Del.

title: Children's Books In Brief
description: Children run up and down the pavement and steps of this old school, and in and out of classrooms, as though theirs were like any other school in the city and not one of the oldest Federal buildings in New York. They wave at strangers from windows and doors without showing any sign that they learn their lessons in rooms used by other children so long ago. Thus Diana Cavallo on Old St. Patrick's, passed by many, noticed by few. Linking the present always with its past, she shows Man hattan to be composed not just of downtown, midtown and uptown, but of countless subdivisions, each with hidden corners into its unique heri tage. About present slums, present problems she is realistic, but she also sees that the city itself is fluid thing, alive and inherently hopeful. Remarkable old prints con trast dramatically with current pho tographs.

title: Police Detail Reports Success in Clearing the Theater District of Panhandlers
description: A special police detail as signed two months ago to rid the midtown theater district of panhandlers, loiterers and other undesirables is succeeding in its task, according to spokesmen for the legitimate theaters.

title: THE FISHING WAR STARTS EARLIER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 (Reuters)The fishing war that flares up along the LatinAmer ican coasts each season seems to have started earlier than usual this year.

title: HOUSTON SCORES OYER MIAMI 276
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 20 (AP) Houston got two touchdowns each from Tommy Mozisek and Robert Newhouse tonight en route'o a 276 victory over Miami.

title: Holiday Football Feast: Nebraska vs. Oklahoma
description: In the days when Bud Wil kinson was the magic name in Oklahoma and the rest of the Big Eight Conference were The Seven Dwarfs, Sooner football fans would bet enormous sums on their Big Red to beat the Saturday point spread.

title: EN POINTE
description: To THE EDITOR: Vladimir Nabokov's sister is quoted as saying, in the course of a talk about ballet, It always strikes me as laughable when men go up on their toes (Understanding Vladimir Nabokov, by Alan Levy, Oct. 31). Later in the article Nabokov remarks that this is also what his mother used to say about male ballerinas.

title: BULLS TURN BACK CELTICS 123106
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) The Chicago Bulls outscored Boston by 4121 in the second quarter and with, Bob Love hit ting for 38 points went on to beat the Boston Celtics, 123 106 tonight in a National Bas ketball Association contest.

title: Istomin: Like to Be Alone
description: A MONG virtuoso pianists of the day, Eugene Is tomin emerges as that rarity: an artist of de cided reticence, and even mystery. Solitary, serious, and of a brooding Beethoven esque disposition, he presents the image of a man years older than his 45 years. He quite easily resembles a char acter out of some late 19th century novel  a Russian novel, perhaps, for Russia is the country of his heritage, the birthplace of his parents. Indeed, there is something tortured about Istomin, as if within the fabric of his life, certain emotional threads had not taken holdhad in explicably eluded him, leav ing him to face certain con founding voids that he him self seems strangely at a los to fathom.

title: BLACK CHURCHMEN TERMINATE TALKS
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 20The fifth annual convocation of the Na tional Committee of Black Churchmen ended prematurely here after a woman was forbid den to speak from the pulpit of the Liberty Baptist Church. Mrs. Mary Jane Patterson, from the Washington office of the National Presbyterian Church, was about to deliver a report Thursday night from the work shop on The Black Church and American International Policy when the host pastor, the Rev. A. P. Jackson, objected.

title: Miss Russell Bride of Keith Damon
description: Miss Dorothy Anne Rus sell of New York: and Dr., Keith Gillingham Damon of, Stamford, Conn., were mar ried here yesterday afternoon at Holy Family Roman Catho lic Church by the Rev. Michael O'Connor. He was as sisted by the Rev. Frederick Boehmer of the Greenwich (Conn.) Baptist Church.

title: EWBANK TO DECIDE ON NAMATH TODAY
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 20Although most people seem more inter ested in the availability of Joe Namath, the Jets have to be more concerned with their abil ity to avert disaster in their game with the Buffalo Bills to morrow.

title: Chattanooga, With Brokas, Belts Virginia Military, 31.8
description: LEXINGTON, Va. Nov. 20 (UPI)Mickey Brokas threw three touchdown passes; scored one himself, and kicked a field goal to give Chattanooga a 31 8 triumph over Virginia. Military Institute today.

title: Quad Sound: On The Way
description: THERE is no question that in one form or another fourchannel highfidelity has come to stay. The arrival of quad raphonic reproduction, how ever has a pellmell, better okelter quality that makes the advent of stereo over a de cade ago seem a model of decorum and logical progres tion.

title: Robert Hogan, 59, Dies; Headed Realty Concern
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 20Robert R. X. Hogan, presi dent of the TaylorWarner Realty. Company of Garden City, and a former marathon swimmer, died Thursday at Nassau Hospital, Mineola. Mr. Hogan, who lived at 101 Sev enth Street, was 59 years old.

title: Local
description: The irresistible offense met the immovable defense yester day in the first official Public Schools Athletic League foot ball championship game since 1961, and the offense prevailed in a 488 Thomas Jefferson victory over Bayside before 3,000 fans at Flushing Memo rial Field in Queens.

title: NAVY DEFEATS ARMY IN SOCCER, RUNNING
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 20 (AP)  Navy's soccer team, which opens National Collegiate tournament play with South Florida here Tuesday, parlayed second and thirdperiod goals and a tight defense into a 21 victory today over Army.

title: Adjusting to Peking
description: Given enough time, America has found it possible to adjust to successful revolutions. The pattern of our policy since at least 1917 has been to employ outright force, and when this fails, to use the full extent of our power and influence to iso late and damage emerging rev olutionary governments by non military means. Finally, though it may take decades, an Admin istration gathers the courage to accept the accomplished reality. We are then expected to cheer.

title: 74Story Urban Complex Will Be Built in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 20Details of a new $100million urban de velopment, to include a major shopping center, a hotel and luxury apartments, have been announced here.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Good Lord! What a great way to cover up a plain rob bery done at a time when Greece, because of the Tur kish occupation, could not protect its archeological treasures from common thieves who appreciated art. That is my reaction to Lord Elgin's letter (Travel section, Nov. 7) who says his great grandfather took the Elgin Marbles to Britain to protect them from constant destruc tion. Now they are deterior ating due to the smog and humidity of London [the Mar bles are in the British Mu seum]. We are willing to pay all the money the good Lord paidto bring the marbles back to where they belong.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE combination planter table and storage cabi net illustrated at right is unusually attractive and luxurious looking be cause the top, exposed cen ter shelf, doors and planter box or tray in the center are all made of a recently intro duced synthetic material that looks so much like real mar ble that even after touching and closely examining the material it is hard for any one to accept the fact that it really isn't marble.

title: Rutgers Takes Advantage of Colgate's Errors 28to16 Victory
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov 20 (AP) A sophomore tail back, Jim Jennings, scored three touchdowns today to spark Rutgers to a 2816 victory over Colgate at Rutgers Stadium.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Letters To the Editor

title: 7th Ave.: Rainwear Maker Finds Sales Are Sunny
description: Cold, warm, wet or dry, it makes little difference at Count Romi, Inc., a manufac turer of highstyled rainwear. Business always seems to be booming, according to Irving Milstein, president, and Ben Rosen, vice president, who have built this Seventh Ave nue house to a leading posi tion in its field.

title: NO. CAROLINA WINS FROM DUKE, 380
description: DURHAM, Nr. C., Nov. 20 (AP), Lewis Jolley scored three touchdowns today as North Carolina's Tar Heels crushed Mike, 380, to win the Atlantit Coast Conference championship and a Gator Bowl bid.

title: A Rock Discography The Best of the 70's
description: WELL, here we are, nearly two years into the seventies, a fifth of the decade rapidly dwindling away, and the dire predictions of the death of rock that tolled through the declining months of the sixties have yet to be fulfilled. Rock is very much alive and healthy, its taproots reaching increasingly deeper into the rich soil of American pop music, its seeds mix ing and mingling with the many strains and varieties of music that preceded it.

title: Virginia Tops Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 20 (AP)Bi'ly Maxwell's 22 yard field goal with 18 sec onds to play gave Virginia 2927 victory over Maryland today in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: Growing Up In Old New England
description: The fictional journal of an early 19thcentury boy who aims to enlighten future gen erations about what comprised his daily life. Because he an ticipates our questions, he seems to have had access to a peephole into 1971; but to remind us that this was long ago, if not far away, his language is quaint and stilted.

title: Trial Transfer Put Off
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Nov. 19 (AP)  Transfer of the Angela Davis trial from Marin County to Santa Clara County was postponed Friday until Dec. 1 in an order by Superior Court Judge Richard Arneson. The transfer had been scheduled for next Monday. Attorneys for the black philosophy teacher, who is charged with murder, kidnap ing and conspiracy in the Marin Civic Center shootings of Aug. 7, 1970, said they would con tinue efforts to have the trial moved somewhere else.

title: Bowl Bids Accepted By College Elevens
description: Bids for many of the 18 postseason football bowl games certified by the Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation went out yesterday and were accepted.

title: Hawks Down Suns, 115109
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 20 (AP) Walt Bellamy's 28 points and Jim Washington's 17 rebounds helped the Atlanta Hawks de feat the Phoenix Suns, 115109, in a National Basketball Asso ciation contest tonight.

title: Builders Ban Lifted
description: MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 20 (UPI)President Nixon's com mittee to hold down wage in creases in the construction in dustry today began lifting, on a casebycase basis, the ban it ordered continued on all pay increases frozen under Phase One.

title: Late Bateman Field Goal Wins for Utah Eleven, 17.15
description: PROVO, Utah, Nov. 20 (UPI) Mary Bateman kicked a 32 yard field goal with 65 sec onds remaining to give Utah a 1715 Western Athletic Con ference victory Over Brigham Young today despite a record fourth punt return for a touch down by B.Y.U.'s Golden Richards.

title: Bombs Found at Five of Food Company's Sites
description: Five pipe bombs were discov ered early yesterday morning at installations maintained by an airline food service firm in and around metropolitan area jetports.

title: Malmberg San Jose Pilot
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20 (AP)  Harry Malmberg, manager last season of the Eastern League champion, Elmira, N. X, has been named mana ger of the Kansas City Royals farm club at San Jose in the Class A California League for 1972.

title: Vikiim End Hits Paydirt On HeirLine Decision
description: LOVELOCK, Nev, Nov. 20 (UPI)John Beasley, the Min nesota Vikings injured end, found out yesterday that he was related to a 74yearold Nevada physician who report edly made millions with the discovery of a wonder drug.

title: Broken Patterns
description: I'm still waiting for Fran Tarkenton to tell me some thing I don't know; his Broken Patterns; The Educa tion of a Quarterback is a quickie book, written by an Atlanta auto  racing writer named Brock Yates. I wonder how many times he's seen Tarkenton play. The New York Giant quarterback is careful to criticize only people who are no longer on the scene and praise those who are still around. He will not improve your understanding of either the game or the Giants or of Tarkenton himself, It's a low budget brushoff, and it'll prob ably earn him a lot of money.

title: Letter From Arizona
description: What's it like to be a writer in Arizona in two thousand words? Lonely.

title: Architecture Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IFEEL it is unfortunate that Ada Louise Hux table, in her recent col umn on The Plaza, managed to convey ie mis leading impression that The Plaza had undergone drastic internal physical changes and utter violation of its historic charm and elegance.

title: KINGS POINT TOPS FORDHAM BY 280
description: Fordham ended its football season yesterday with a 280 defeat by theMerchant Marine Academy before 4,019 fans at Jack Coffey Field.

description: PLANDOME, L.T., Nov. 20 Charles Benisch of 32 Heights Road, a partner in the Brook lyn firm of Benisch Brothers, which builders monuments and is a cemetery supervisory com pany, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Westchester

title: Medicine
description: When the two Houses of Congress pass sharply conflicting versions of bill, in both cases by whopping major ities, the stage would seem to be set for an epic confrontation in the joint conference committee that must re solve the differences. But appearances can deceive.

title: German Banks: Into the Marketplace
description: DUSSELDORF, West Ger manyIn Germany, a land where rulers were the cli ents of big bankers in former times, the banks have today become the clients of the Government in several im portant respects.

title: The World
description: The World

title: For Conrad Aiken, a modern consciousness, and heroic doubts
description: Ushant, published original ly in 1952, is a strange, deep, mysterious book. It is written in prose, but the kind to which it belongs is epic poetry, poet ry according to that tersest of adequate definitions given by Valery: It is what it says: It illuminates, as in turn it is il luminated by, the succession of Conrad Aiken's poems, novels and stories. And it puts the world together in more ways than I will be able to de scribe, though I will have a try; first, though, a few gener al observations.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The Federal Trade Com mission members seem to be rather interested in puf fery. And, because the ad vertising community should be terribly interested in what interests the F.T.C., let's take a look at puffery in adver tising.

title: JOHN JAY OARSMEN WIN 4 OF 8 RACES
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y. Nov. 20John Jay College won four of the eight races contested to day in the New York Rowing Association's collegeclub re gatta on the Orchard Beach lagoon.

title: Blass to Get Gold Key
description: NORWICH, Conn., Nov. 20 (AP) A World Series hero, Steve Blass of the Pittsburgh Pirates, has been named win ner of a gold key from the Con necticut Sports Writers Alli ance. He will be honored at the gold key dinner Jan. 31 at the Shereton Norwich Inn.

title: Hriniak Gets Executive Post With Farm Club of Expos
description: MONTREAL, Nova 20 (AP) Walter Hriniak has been named general Manager of the James town, N. Y., Falcons, a Mon treal aim farm team.

title: MinorityGroup Enrollment Sets Record at U.S. Medical Schools
description: This year, the largest fresh man class ever enrolled in the country's medical schools in cludes a record number of stu dents from minority groups.

title: JAKARTA NOVELTY: 8HOUR WORK DAY
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov 13Last April the Indonesian Finance Ministry introduced a revolutionary work concept: the eighthour day.

title: JOHN THIRLWALL, 67, ENGLISH PROFESSOR
description: Dr. John C. Thirlwall, profes sor of English, at City College, died yesterday of a heart ail ment at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 4414 Tibbett Avenue, River dale, the Bronx.

title: ILLINOIS IS VICTOR OVER IOWA, 31 TO O
description: CHAMPAIGN, III., Nov. 20 (AP)A sophomore George Uremovich, scored on runs of 42 and 3 yards and Illinois amassing 268 yards in the first half, then inserting reserves smashed Iowa, 310, today.

title: Rhode Island Red Takes Feature at Suffolk Downs
description: BOSTON, Nov. 20 (AP)  Rhode Island Red, starting from outside post position, led all the way in winning the $4,500 Smart Purse today before a crowd of 9,569 at Suffolk Downs.

title: Idaho's Victory Streak Ends As Utah State Wins, 42.13
description: MOSCOW, Idaho, Nov. 20 (AP)Utah State put an end to Idaho's eightgame winning streak today with a 4213 tri umph.

title: She's Putting Women's Lib Into Ballads
description: She is used to bad puns about her name and puts up with them, albeit with clenched teeth. She has trouble with her image because if she wears her hair in a fall, she is accused of being a sex symbol and if she wears it short and close cropped, which is com fortable, she is called a lesbian.

title: Windjammer Triumphs
description: LOUISVILLE, Nov. 20 (AP) Windjammer outdistanced sev en rivals today to win the 45th Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs.

title: Reader's Report
description: As if things in the magazine game weren't tough enough, here comes Hollis Alpert to rake over old coals and heap a few new ones on the heads of bigtime slickpaper journal ists. I know that this is fiction, but the protagonist publications seem darn familiar. Metropoli tan, a distinguished weekly spe cializing in urbanity and car toons. The New York Scene, a peppy muckraking periodical that does a threepart vivisec tion of the Metropolitan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Tom Wicker in his Nov. 11 column The Rehnquist Dilemma Mr. Wicket, the Senate, can reject Mr. Rehnquist only on the basis of his political views. Just below Mr. Wicker's column, how ever, are several of Mr. Rehnquist's quotations on the law.

title: Another Hearing Due on Jericho Apartment Proposal
description: JERICHO, L. LA proposal to build the largest apart ment community in the Town of Oyster Bay will come up for hearings again on Tues day and no one is betting on the outcome.

title: Hearings on Amtrak Show Big Variance in Railroads
