description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 In makeorbreak areas of service quality, ontime per formance and costs, the new Amtrak passenger train sys tem is still largely at the mercy of the individual rail roads that continue to handle direct operations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Robert Reinhart's other wise entertaining article on the Ansonia repeats the boner that the architect of this famous hotel was Stan ford White. This is a double insult, first to the reputation of White, whose prestigious firm of McKim, Mead and White never designed any thing in the vulgar, florid, Second Empire, French Beaux Arts style like the Ansonia, and second to its actual de signer (as well as owner and builder), W.E.D. Stokes.

title: Helen Harris Bride Of Ernest Akam Jr.
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 20Miss Helen Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Holbrook Harris of Port Washington and Quogue, was married here this noon to Engineman First Class Ernest Akam Jr. of the Navy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Akam of Port Washington.

title: Children's Books In Brief
description: From such sources as the Capitol, West Point and the Royal Ontario Museum, Shirley Glubok, who has

title: Marie L. Winters Bride in Rumson
description: RUMSON, N.J., Nov. 20 Miss Marie Louise Winters and Christopher Hallenbeck were married here this after noon by the Rev. Ambrose Graham in Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Iowa High School Mother Wins Right to Sports Role
description: DES MOINES, Iowa Nov. 20 (UPI)  A 17yearold mother and, other Iowa girls like her has won the right to compete in high school sports.

title: Starr May Play Tomorrow
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 20 (UPI)Coach Dan Devine said today Bart Starr, Green Bay quarterback who this week got the gosignal from the Mayo Clinic, would probably be acti vated for Monday night's game with Atlanta.

title: Reader's Report
description: Into the account of a leisure ly canoe trip down the Yukon River, Alan Fry weaves bits and pieces of the region's history and folklore. The canoeists are the narratoran unnamed white man  and Dave, his Indian guide. As the two paddle down stream, hunting and fishing as they go, Dave fills his patron's ears with yarns and legends. He tells stories of the days before the people had guns and TV dinners. He describes the rites of manhood among his people, his early life and court ship, and the curious behavior of some cheechakos he has known. These anecdotes are drenched in the atmosphere of the outdoors, although tainted by a certain social unease be tween the white and the red man. How this impediment is

title: Forecast
description: Autumn writes its signature in countless ways, and those who would read prophecy in it can find meaning in a leaf, a feather, a nut or a caterpillar. Look at the flight of geese penciled against the sky, arrowing south ward. See the glistening intricacy of a spider web jeweled with frost at sunrise. Exainine the cast feather of crow. Watch a woollybear caterpillar looping its way toward shelter from the winter.

title: Forest Failure
description: Who regulates the regulators? It is a problem as old as govemment itself. Officials chosen to keep Watch on specific private activities in behalf of the larger but less attentive public get on friendly terms with the private interests. They become lax in defending their trust. The pressures to compromise and conform intensify.

title: Swim Marks Ratified
description: SINGAPORE, Nov. 20 (AP) The Federation Internationale de Natation Amateur ratified world swimming records yes terday and resolved that Com munist China should join the association.

title: Brooklyn Peddler Has a 3Horsepower Stable
description: Although 45 year  old Jimmy Cincotta admits that a horsedrawn cart is not the easiest vehicle for peddling today, he has kept up this oldtime way of doing busi ness because of his love of horses.

title: Mrs. Willard Crosby Dies; Researcher for The Times
description: Mrs. Eleanor T. Crosby, a news staff researcher for The New York Times and the widow of Willard B. Crosby, who had been a copy editor for this newspaper, cued yes terday at Harkness Pavilion ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, after a long illness. Her age was 64.

title: $14 MILLION GOES TO 83 SCHOLARS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 The National Endowment for the Humanities has doubled its funds for distinguished schol ars by awarding a record $1.4 million to 83 winners of senior fellowships.

title: ExWashington Post Editor Joins St. Petersburg Times
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. Nov. 20 (UPI)Eugene Patterson, 48 years old, formed editor of The Washington Post, will become editor; of The St. Petersburg Times nxet May, the Florida newspaper announced last night.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE signals now being emitted by the nation's economy are becoming slightly stronger, but they have not as yet activated any noticeable response from the investment world. There has been little, if any, change in the gloomy mood that has enveloped Wall Street over the last two months.

title: ROTA, BLUE STAR IN SOCCER TODAY
description: Seven United States Challenge Cup matches will be held in the area today and NeW York Hota, the holder of the most coveted prize in American soccer, faces a strong opponent and is threat ened with elimination.

title: Local
description: Poly Prep finished its season yesterday by overwhelming Wingate, 416, at Poly. It was the sixth victory for Poly, which has lost twice: Wingate ended its first varsity campaign at 35.

title: Flyers, Stars Tie, 11
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP)Joe Watson, a defense man, scored his first goal of the season at 2:46 of the third period to earn the Philadelphia Flyers a 11 tie with the Min nesota North Stars tonight.

title: Israeli Cabinet Confirms Shift of BarLev
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21The Israeli Cabinet today confirmed the planned retirement of Lieut. Gen. Bairn BarLev as Chief of Staff of the Israel defense forces, paving the way for a new political career.,

title: Bridge: Lew and Eugenie Mathe Win Mixed Pairs in Fall Nationals
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 21 Two pairs from Los An geles battled for victory in the national mixed pair championship here last night, and a verdict on points went to Lew and Eugenie Mathe. A strong finish enabled them to overhaul the previous leaders, Barry Crane and Kerri Davis.

title: Projects'
description: In the seething debate over lowincome housing in Forest Hills, Queens, both sides frequently cite Latimer Gardens, in Flushing, as a comparable city project that has not measurably disturbed an established neigh borhood.

title: Rockets on Top, 11596
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 21 (AP)Little Johnny Egan sparked a fourthquarter rally that sent the Houston Rockets to a 115 96 victory over the Golden State Warrriors tonight.

title: First of 3 Recitals By Lateiner Settles On Romantic Course
description: Jacob Lateiner, renowned on one side of the musical spec trum as a Beethoven specialist, and on the other as a prime in terpreter of such modern com posers as Carter and Sessions, took the middle road of ro manticism in his first New York recital in more than six years.

title: Biggest Hurdle for the Colonial Cup Fans: Can It Last?
description: CAMDEN, S. C., Nov. 21When the 15 magnificent horses burst over the final barrier yesterday and surged toward the finish, the crisp, clear Carolina air was sud denly heavy with the mass mutual frenzy of the thou sands who had come to watch the country's premier steeplechase, the $100,000 Colonial Cup.

title: Low Marks on Civil Rights
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has hit on the useful device of rating the performance a wide variety of Government agencies in the battle against discrimination and social injustice. Unfortu nately, the initial report card is far from encouraging. Few of the agencies have risen above a failing mark.

title: LAKERS TOP BUCKS Mg FAST BREAK
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP)The Los Angeles Lakers, with Gail Goodrich and Jerry West leading a searing fast break, defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 112105, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS FACE STRIKE TODAY BY LAY TEACHERS
description: Unionized lay teachers, who bargain for more than half of the instructional staff at the 329 schools of the Archdiocese of New York, voted yesterday to strike this morning.

title: Layer and Rosewall Win To Gain Final in Tennis
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21 (AP)Australia's Rod Laver, the lead ing moneywinner on the pro tennis tour, overcame a second set lapse today to defeat Ar thur. Ashe of the United States, 6.3, 16, 63, 63, and earn a spot opposite Ken Rosewall in the $50,000 final of the World Championship Tennis tour.

title: Vietnam Vets Bring New Characters to Cast of Addicts: Bemedaled Junkies
description: Those Vietnam veterans who return to the city's streets with a craving for drugs have nurtured it on opiates so pure they were to the usual junkie's fare what a magnum of champagne is to a pint of Thunderbird. Ba sically two kinds of stories are told about what happens to them in their new jungle set ting. In the first story, the veteran is cast as a green horn. They don't have the animalistic qualities required to survive out there, said an exaddict now working at a treatment cen ter. They haven't been to jail. They haven't lived in cellars. They're not what you'd call real thieves.

title: PLANTS'
description: Expenditures by 1,000 of the nation's largest manufacturers totaled $6.1billion in the third quarter, an increase of 12 per cent over the level of the pre vious quarter, the Conference Board reported over the week end.

title: New York Five Triumphs
description: The Chinese Student A.A. of New York defeated the Chinese Youth Club of Washington, 8477, yesterday to win the second annual Chinese Intercity Basketball Tournament at Queensborough Community Col lege in Bayside, Queens. Bill

title: Star Sailing Starts Today
description: MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP)James Schoonmaker of Miami won a practice race today in the North. American Star Class sail ing championships that start tomorrow on Biscayne Bay.

title: Unbeaten Michigan and Penn State Accept Bowl Bids
description: Pairings for most of the post season football bowl games were set yesterday, with the Liberty Bowl and the Cotton Bowl awaiting the outcome of a single game Thursday before completing the picture.

title: Senators'
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Nov. 21 (AP)  The new name of the former Washington Senators, who moved their franchise here, will be announced Tuesday at a luncheon to be attended by Joe Cronin, American League president; Bob Short, owner of the team and Ted Williams, manager of the club.

title: Schwab House Inquiry Is Asked
description: Threequarters of the 600 tenants of Schwab House, 11 Riverside Drive, have refused the owner's offer to sell them the 17story building as a cooperative for $19million or $9.5million above its as sessed valuation.

title: JAMES GORDON TAFT
description: James Gordon Taft, a part ner in the law firm of Bendes, Stark, Amron & Taft, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, who specialized in advertising and television cases, died yesterday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hos pital. He was 42 years old and lived at 345 East 57th Street.

title: FLORIDIANS SCORE OVER PROS, 10386
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 21 (AP)The Floridians, paced by rookie Willie Long's 22 points, routed the Memphis Pros, 103 86, tonight.

title: COLOMBIAN WOMAN BUILDING A PARTY
description: BOGOTA, Colombia  Al though most Colombians view the women's liberation move ment as yet another Yankee aberration, this traditional stronghold of machismo may well become the first country in the hemisphere to send women to the presidency.

title: A Draft Law Loophole Tested in Court
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The latest legal wrinkle in the draft resistance movement is deluge of lawsuits across the country aimed at forestalling the induction of men into mili tary service under an apparent loophole in the recently re vived draft law.

title: Rangers'
description: Sending the Golden Seals goalie to the bench in tears, the Rangers last night scored the most decisive victory in their 46 years, a 121 pasting in which they broke one Na tional Hockey League record and tied another.

title: Questions and Answers From I. R. S. on Rules of Economic Control Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21,Following are questions and answers issued officially by the Internal Revenue Service yesterday in an attempt to explain regulations of the Government's economic con trol agencies.

title: School Plan Backed
description: The New School for Social Research has won community board approval to build a com bination city affairs institute, public library and neighbor hood meeting rooms on the site of the abandoned Women's House of Detention in Green wich Village.

title: Rosebloom to Open Jan. 5
description: Rosebloom, a play by Har vey Perr, has been booked into the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street, where it is to open Jan. 5 with previews starting on Dec. 25. The drama will be directed by Jered Bar clay and produced by Harvey Kleiman and Peter Goldfarb. It will feature Gary Merrill, Sylvia Miles, Ron Rifkin and Regina Baff.

title: 3 LABOR GROUPS IN ITALY TO UNITE
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Nov. 21Communist and nonCommu nist labor leaders said today they had reached agreement in principle to merge their organ izations into a single Itrade union movement within the next 15 months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Already the Senate battle lines are being drawn about President Nixon's two Supreme Court nominees., Appar ently Lewis Powell will be approved without a fight, a liberal sop to the South. But William Rehnquist will have no such easy time. Young and articulate Mr. Rehnquist has had his victories over the controlling liberal group in the Senate, and these men do not forget defeat easily. So Mr. Rehnquist will be grilled, accusations will be loud, if unsubstantiated, and before the end Mr. Rehnquist will un doubtedly be reviled in most of the media.

title: GONZALEZ GETS NOD IN DISPUTED FIGHT
description: MARACAIBO, Venezuela, Nov. 2 (UPI)Venezuela's Be tulio Gonzalez was awarded the World Boxing Council fly weight championship last night when the champion, Erbito Salavarria, of the Philippines, was disqualified fo using a stimulant.

title: G. M. Appliance Workers Waive Raises for 2 Years
description: DETROIT, Nov. 21Workers at the General Motors Corpo ration's appliance plants in Dayton, Ohio, agreed today to give up future pay rises for two years.

title: Steel Demand Lags
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21De mand for steel was still dis appointing last week. With auto companies starting to place orders for January de livery, total bookings remained at depressed levels.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Sadly, in the recent issueless New Jersey general election neither party managed to propose an attack on the causes of political corruption. Instead, the candidates sputtered on about jail ing their corrupt colleagues.

title: CHINESE REPORTS CHURCH AUTONOMY
description: ROME, Nov. 21The Italian News Agency ANSA today quoted a churchman in Peking as having said that the Roman Catholic community in China considered itself autonomous but in communion with Pope Paul VI.

title: Chess: A Simultaneous Exhibition Isn't Always a WalkOver
description: It is an old chess aphorism that, when a master gives an exhibition of simultaneous play, the hardest thing about it for him is the walking from hoard to board. There is some truth in this. The master may walk five miles in the course of an eveningquite a dis tance for a man who prob ably leads a sedentary life.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Adding to your Nov. 6 editorial A Transit Tax, it might be of interest to the Mayor (and he was in London), and other city officials eager to retain the present transit fare to know that in London (the city and Westminster) every owner or a motor car has to pay for the privilege of parking his car on the streets, whether it be by meter or a threemonth permit affixed to the windscreen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The numerous schemes being ad vanced to save New York City's thirtycent transit fare deserve the same fate accorded the transportation bond issue. The suggestion by The Times in its Nov. 4 editorial Holding Down the Farethat City Council levies on overnight parking, automo bile ownership, glass containers, cigars, smoking tobacco, beer and liquor may assume new acceptability if the alternative is a 45cent or 50 cent transit fareis plainly un founded in the light of voter action on the bond issue.

title: ANDRE CHERBONNIER, ADMIRALTY LAWYER
description: ST. MARY'S CITY, Md., Nov. 21Andre Victor Cherbonnier, an international lawyer who specialized in admiralty and labor relations cases, died Fri day in Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived here.

title: Jews Fotnd Turning Inward Away From NonJewish Affairs
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Nov. 21 The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted today that the American Jewish com munity, increasingly concerned over what the league called a lack of public indignation toward antiSemitic manifesta tions, was turning inward away from nonJewish affairs.

title: The Liberty to Know
description: Give me the liberty to know... above all liber ties... This plea by John Milton was at the heart of Peter Zenger's defense in the first American battle for a free press, forty years before the founding of the Republic. It has been a continuing battle.

title: City Says Its Addict Program Will Give Priority to Methadone
description: Stating that methadone main tenance will receive first pri ority for expansion in its strategy to combat heroin ad diction, the Lindsay administra tion announced yesterday that it planned to increase the num ber of patients in cityrun methadone programs to 11,000 by next June. There are now 3,000 patients.

title: Juilliard Actors Will Make Repertory Debut on Dec. 7
description: The Juilliard Acting Com pany will present its first repertory season in its own 206seat theater at the Juil Hard School from Dec. 7 to 17, with four productions representing four different periods and styles.

title: DOLPHINS VICTORS OVER COLTS, 1714
description: MIAMI, Nov. 21In a pri meval struggle that was throwback to football's leather helmet era, the Miami Dolphins rewarded a record regularsea son crowd of 75,312 with 1714 victory over the Balti more Colts today on Garo Yepremian's 20yard field goal midway in the final quarter.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The quality of fire protection is being adversely affected by the continuing reporting of all injuries and indispositions by fire fighters.Fire Chief John O'Hagan, in discitssing job action. [1:3.]

title: Iceland Seen Reconsidering Vow to Oust U.S. Force
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 21 Premier Olafur Johannesson's postelection declaration last July that Iceland's defense agreement with the United States would be taken up for review or termination aroused grave concern in capitals of the North Atlantic Alliance.

title: JOCK M'AVOY, BOXER WHO HELD 2 TITLES
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP)Jock McAvoy, former British Empire middleweight and light heavyweight boxing champion, was found dead at his home to day on his 63d birthday.

title: For Grownup Women, It's the LittleGirl Look
description: Well, if you don't want to look like a Chinese empress or a sailor next spring, how about playing a truant from nursery school?

title: Advertising:
description: Just between you and me and the bulls and the bears; it looks like Lehman Broth ers, one of the nation's lead ing investment banking firms, might be moving its adver tising account uptown.

title: Chinese Group Tours Manhattan, Tip to Tip
description: A group from China's dele gation to the United Nations spent yesterday afternoon looking at the George Wash ington bridge, Grant's Tomb and the Financial District.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: One cannot help but be taken aback by Senator Henry Jackson's recent con tentions that a third (or rather fourth) party would not hurt the Democrats in 1972 and that those who would be in clined to join such a movement might just as well get out of the party now.

title: The State's Fiscal Dilemma
description: The anticipated deficit in the budget for the State New York for the current fiscal year, $440 million before defeat of the transportation bond issue, has risen to $770 million with its rejection by the voters. Some $300 million in prospective bond money had been included in the budget, extremely unwisely in our view, but included nonetheless.

title: OHIO UNION ENTERS INSURANCE FIELD
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 21The Ohio A.F.L.C.I.O., frustrat ed for 15 years in its attempts to reform the state's automo bile insurance practices, is es tablishing its own insurance company for union members.

title: Salesman, 20, Stabbed to Death In Times Square Camera Shop
description: A 20yearold salesman was stabbed to death late Saturday night in a Times Square camera shop by a woman customer who was unhappy with a pur chase she had made, the police reported yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Judge Birdie Amsterdam's recent decision regarding the Forest Hills lowincome housing development is just one in a long series of events es tablishing the propriety of this hous ing. Plans for It were initiated six years ago and have been approved by all appropriate governmental agencies, local and Federal.

title: Lie Detector's Use By Industry Rises; Rights Peril Feared
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The lie detector, a device known to millions of readers of Dick Tracy as an implacable breaker of hardened criminals, is quietly coming into far wider use as a truthtelling informant in the world of ordinary sinners.

title: 3% Ceiling on Additives For Poultry Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP)lt comes too late to affect this year's Thanksgiv ing Turkeys, but after more than a year of consideration, the Agriculture Department has announced a 3 per cent ceiling on solutions and fats added to selfbasting poultry.

title: Futile Rent Confrontation
description: The strike confrontation between landlords and union ized apartment house employes, which threatens hard ship for Bronx tenants this week, is as unnecessary as is unjustified.

title: The Warren Commission Was Right
description: DES MOINES, IowaThe suscepti bility of human nature to the mystique of conspiracy has afforded a fertile field for the assassination sensation alists. Through misrepresentation, omission and innuendo they have been successful in deceiving a large body of world public opinion into ques tioning the validity and veracity of the Warren Commission conclusion that Lee Harvey Oswald on Nov. 22, 1963, murdered President John F. Kennedy and Dallas police officer J. D. Tippit.

title: Police in Philadelphia Face A State Corruption Inquiry
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) Gov. Milton J. Shapp asked Attorney General J. Shane Craamer today to con vene the Crime Commission for an investigation into alleged police corruption in Philadel phia.

title: Heindl Recalled by Stars
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP)The Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League re called Billy Heindl today from the Cleveland Barons of the American Hockey League to help out because of injuries to Bob Nevin and J. P. Parise.

title: 5 Weeks of Hearings Strengthen F.T.C.'s Determination to Continue Aggressive Regulation of TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Federal Trade Com mission, in five weeks of informational hearings that ended Thursday, has reassured itself of a continuing need for the aggressive regulation of television advertising.

title: BRITISH ECONOMY DEFIES TAX SPURS
description: LONDON, Nov. 21  Last March, the British Government slashed taxes by more than 2 billion to prod a sluggish econ omy into faster growth. Last July acknowledging that busi ness was in a recession, the Government cut taxes by an extra $960million.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: COWBOYS DEFEAT REDSKINS, 13 TO 0
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Dallas Cowboys, on the move at last with Roger Staubach (a running quarterback by his own choice), beat the wilting Washington Redskins, 130, to day and jumped over the losers into first place in the Eastern Division of the National Con ference.

title: German Rightists Reassert Their Opposition to Brandt
description: HOLZMINDEN, West Ger many, Nov. 21 (AP)  The right wing National Demo cratic party, ending the stormi est congress of its sevenyear history. reasserted today its determination to fight Chan cellor Willy Brandt's policy of improving relations with the Soviet bloc.

title: Antismut Drive in Italy Angers News Dealers
description: ROME, Nov. 21  Italy's leatherlunged news venders arc angry and have proclaimed what their union calls a state of war because a dozen were arrested last week and several hundred are under criminal in vestigation on charges of dis tribution of pornographic ma terial.

title: The Faltering War on Narcotics
description: PARIS, Nov. 21  The fire works set off by a French se cret agent indicted for smug gling heroin into the United States have overshadowed an even more preoccupying devel opment: the international war against narcotics seems to be falling apart.

title: A Reluctant Militant in Queens Gerry Birbach
description: Now I understand how the prisoners at Attica felt, said Gerry Birbach. The frustration led to violence. Rockefeller had his Attica. Lindsay has his Forest Hills.

title: Dartmouth to Go Coed in '72 and Operate All Year
description: HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 21Dartmouth College, a 202year old school that has awarded undergraduate degrees only to men, decided today to institute coeducation and yearround op eration by next fall.

title: QUICK END URGED TO 10% SURCHARGE
description: The United States surcharge on imports should be removed without undue delay, the Committee for Economic De velopment urged over the wee end.

title: 2 CITY AIDES HELD ON BRIBE CHARGES
description: Two purchase inspectors in the city's Emergency Repair Program have been arrested on charges of receiving bribes and unlawful gratuities from a con tractor, Benjamin Altman, Com missioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, and Robert Rus kin, Commissioner of Investiga tion, said yesterday.

title: Young Democrats Elect
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark. Nov. 21 (AP)Joseph Thomas of New Orleans was elected a vice president of the National Young Democrats early today. He will be the organization's only black national officer. Mr. Thomas is a law student at Loyola Univer sity of New Orleans.

title: Gaullists Affirm Movement's Raison d'Etre
description: STRASBOURG, France, Nov. 21Some 5,000 Gaullists who gathered here for three days went home today to spread the message that their movement was just as necessary to France and to the world as when Gen eral de Gaulle was running the country.

title: Steelers Are Outplayed
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21The topsyturvy nature of the 1971 season displayed itself in an other dimension today for the New York Giants, as they out played an opponent by the wid est margin in 16 games, but still lost, 1713, to the Pitts burgh Steelers.

title: CITY IS CRITICIZED ON WATER BILLING
description: The city is failing to collect millions of dollars worth of water bills, State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday.

title: ASHKENAZY SHINES IN HUNTER RECITAL
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy ended his program at Hunter College on Saturday night with music by Debussy. It is believed to be the first time he has programed the composer's works here, and he chose some of the most dif ficult from an interpretive standpoint, the 12 pieces that make up Book II of the Pre ludes.

title: Geography Puts Iceland In World Power Politics
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Nov. 21We have good water, good people, pretty girls, said Rolf Johannessen, but bad geography.

title: JAMES L. TRUSLOW
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 21James L. Truslow, a retired vice president with West Point Pepperell, Inc., textile manu facturers of West Point, Ga., died here yesterday. His age was 70.

title: Leafs Defeat Sabres, 43
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 21 (UPI)Jim Dorey, out of the penalty box for just 12 seconds, scored a breakaway goal at 7:25 of the third period tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 43 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Prison Guards Are Injured
description: TRENTON, Nov. 21Trenton State Prison officials today were investigating a mess hall disturbance in which several guards suffered minor injuries. A prison spokesman said the guards were hurt when they attempted to break up a fight that started between two in mates after the last evening's meal and spread until about 25 were involved.

title: Hotel Lobby Is Hub of Labor Convention
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 21Some of the business of the A.F.L.C.I.O. convention here is done in the conven tion center of the Americana Hotel.

title: Soviet Central Committee Reported Endorsing Plan
description: MOSCOW. Nov. 21 (AP)Eastern European Communist sources reported that the rul ing Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party met today to endorse the 19711975 national economic plan.

title: Fleming Wins 9Mile Run As 136 Compete in Bronx
description: Tom Fleming, a junior from Paterson State College, posted the second fastest time of the annual NineMile CrossCountry Memorial Run yesterday, de feating 135 other runners at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: Bombing Raid Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Nov. 22 (AP)  The United States Command to day announced one of the deepest bombing raids this year inside North Vietnam, against an antiaircraftgun emplace ment near Vinh.

title: Gem Caper Joins Crime Film Pulp For Double Bill
description: The European backgrounds in "The Dirty Heroes" and "The Marco Men" are the main diversion, even substance, of a double bill program that has appeared at the Penthouse Theater. Both color imports blend spoken and dubbed English.A leaner scenario and tighter direction could have worked wonders with the first movie, which has a small band of Allied ex-gangsters filching a diamond cache from Nazi headquarters in Amsterdam. Before the story levels off into pat, noble clichs, it does very well as a thriller melodrama, suffused with those graphic Dutch backgrounds. But it eventually caves in.Since Tom Tryon, the actor, has successfully emerged as a fiction writer, he can be forgiven for starring in "The Marco Men," obviously made some time ago. The film is nothing but cheap, tired, sleazy gangster pulp, somewhat offset by Spanish locales. The picture's salvation is Laura Guerrieri, who is delightful as a sweet, spunky hippie enamored of the churlish hero. Just why remains her secret.

title: Killing of Black by Trooper Stirs Protests and Violence in North Carolina Town
description: AYDEN, N. C., Nov. 21The killing of a black farm laborer by a white state trooper on a lonely road one midnight three months ago has triggered out bursts of racial violence in this east Carolina town that threaten to develop into a national con troversy.

title: Paris: Bardot -- From Star to Actress
description: PARIS  "Boulevard du Rhum," a new film by Robert Enrico, is not likely to impress the spectator more lastingly than a swig of the alcohol that gives it its name. It is light entertainmentand not really brilliant at thatbut it moves along briskly enough so one does not have the time to notice its shortcomings. Since to mention anything even remotely smacking of entertainment nowadays is more shameful than to confess a murder, it will surprise no one to learn that "Boulevard du Rhum" is, in a way, important. It marks the death of a starthe last star, perhapsand the birth of an actress: Brigitte Bardot.Arts AbroadStardom is based on worship, on belief, and belief must be blind. Nothing could have been more harmful to Miss Bardot's status as a star than the reputation of being a good actress and of appearing in good films. Fortunately, ever since Roger Vadim's "And God Created Woman," she has shown downright genius in dispelling suspicion of either of these crimes. Nobody remembered whom or in what she playedand that was just the point: One recalled "B.B.". In recent years, however, people have begun to notice, and this could mean only one thing: Miss Bardot was losing her stellar glow and descending inexorably toward earth.Re-entering our atmosphere is notoriously a complex, risky operation. Thanks to "Boulevard Du Rhum"and there is genius in that tooshe has made it. The film matches Miss Bardot, the Gallic Marilyn Monroe, with Lino Ventura, a French version of John Wayne. It is a cross-breed of "Some Like It Hot" and "The Quiet Man." During Prohibition a Hollywood actress becomes involved with an adventurer who spirits rum into the United States from the Caribbean. The only really French touch occurs when, to Miss Bardot's disclosure that she is about to ditch him, Mr. Ventura, who is having lunch, replies: "You might have waited till I had eaten my steak before telling me." One readily understands his dismay: Miss Bardot as eyelash-batting, cheesecaking Linda Larue, fresh and alive despite her crushing harness of movieland clichs, is irresistible. How did the director achieve this miracle? Simply by remembering that, to turn a bad actress into a good one, the surest way is to make her play a bad actress.Since its overhauling, the Grand Palais specializes in mammoth retrospectives of modern French masters. After Picasso, Chagall and Matisse, the turn of Fernand Lger has come. Three hundred and fifty workspaintings, drawings, ceramicssubstantiate Lger's claim to being, for better but also for worse, "the primitive of a century yet to come.""Everything in art is based on contrasts, it is the only general law in all major art," Lger once said. It is certainly the law of his own. His paintings of 1910-1913 is the one truly original brand of cubism invented after Picasso and Braque. It combines the curves of clouds and foliage with the straight lines of houses, sets up a counter-point between flatness and perspective. At once synthetic, frontal and broken down into subtle gradations, these canvases associate what had never been asociated before: monumentality and delicacy.Despite their abstract denomination, "Form Contrasts," the pictures of the next few years, remain recognizably landscapes, still-lifes and studies and figures. They turn Picasso's rectangles into cylinders: cubism becomes "tubism," not out of some arbitrary straining for originality, but because of Lger's instinctive affinities with weight, mass and volume.The war made him discover people, he later said. Actually, what he discovered was technology. Lger is the first artist to bring applied science within the compass of art, not by painting industrial machines and objects, but by painting mechanically, objectively. Between 1918 and 1925, he has produced canvases as perfect and terrifying as an automated factory. They are impeccable, self-sufficient: not a trace of human hand soils their smoothness. Although often as non-figurative as a Mondrian or a Malevitoh, they don't feel abstract, for their abstractness is the cold, dehumanized reality of technology. Nobody has given us a truer, more epic statement of the second industrial revolution.Visible it did become, especially since 1945. But a source of joy? Depicting workers is not enough to create a popular art. Despite its bright, straightforward colors, Lger's technological fauvism is no more joyous than the pure color schemes applied to large-scale housing projects. His figures possess the heroic dimension, but they have that defeated air and they look at us with that sad, empty stare one sees in the subway at the rush hour.How could a talent as warm and a temperament as tonic as Lger's come to this sadness, this emptiness? The fault is not his, but that of his solution: enlargement. Beyond a certain size, the medium becomes the message: blown up a thousand times, a faceany faceno longer belongs to man, but to space. It is neutral, barren space that paints, not Lger. He was the first to come to grips with a phenomenon, which, in art as in other domains, is the great problem of our age: the new, incredibly augmented scale of life. But he has done so at the expense of its very nature. That is why the death of painting, so masterfully brought about by Fernand Lger, cannot be looked at without misgivings.

title: MRS. DAVID CAMERER
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 21Mrs. Muriel Barnard Cam erer, wife of David M. Camerer, author and sports editor of The Stamford Advocate, died yes terday of cancer in Norwalk Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 245 West Hills Road.

title: NoCar Day Achieves Mild Success in Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 (AP) Twentynine cities and towns around Tokyo proclaimed a NoCar Day and succeeded in reducing traffic by about 10 per cent on main streets today, officials said, but Sunday drivers from Tokyo didn't help.

title: Red Smith Hard Times Beside the Potomac
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21So Dallas, which replaced Washington in the American League late in the baseball season, now has taken this beleaguered city's spot at the head of the National Football Conference's Eastern Di vision. Except for five heavenly Sundays when the Red skins won em all, this has been an autumn to try the souls of the most sanguine of the capital's sports fans, even including that incurable buff who lives at 1600 Pennsyl vania Avenue. (Indeed, some authorities predict that things don't get better and Phase Two doesn't work, he'll leave Henry Kissinger to mind the store and go get a job on the LBJ Ranch.)

title: Parker Senior Victor
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 21Frank Parker of Evanston, Ill., the former United States men's champion, defeated Torsten Johansson of Sweden, 76, 64, in the final of the Queen City international indoor senior ten nis tournament today. Parker and Johansson beat Bobby Riggs of Plandone, L. I., also a former United. States men's champion, and Tony Vincent of New York, 62, 63, in the dou bles final.

title: Heard Golf Victor at 269
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zea land, Nov. 21 (AP)  Jerry Heard of Visalia, Calif., shot a 64 today and captured the Christchurch Garden City Golf, classic with a total of 269. New Zealand's Bob Charles, who shot a 68, was second at 274.

title: Public Hearings Set
description: Proposals to narrow the dif ferences in petroleum indus try accounting practices have stirred up sharp opposition, particularly among small and mediumsized companies who charge that the changes would reduce earnings, retard their ability to raise capital and cause a reduction in explora tion for oil and gas.

title: Yiddish Fare on Broadway
description: Yiddish stage and film shows will come to Broadway starting Thanksgiving Day when Ben Bonus opens his Yiddish Musi cal. Story Theater in the May fair Theater, 46th Street west of Broadway. Shows based on classical writers will be pre sented for about two weeks each, with live performances to be alternated with Yiddish I films on every program.

title: U. S. Pamphlet Rebuts Welfare Myths
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 21 (UPI) The Nixon Administration has described as a myth a be lief that welfare families would use additional cash assistance to buy more whisky and big cars.

title: Antipollution Planning Asked
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (UPI)  The California Democratic Council called today for wide spread and stringent Federal planning to combat pollution and overpopulation. The dele gates to the Statewide Issue Conference voted overwhem ingly for the resolution.

title: 5 Buffalo Passes Stolen
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 21When Bob Davis, running out of bounds to escape a Buffalo tackler, skidded in a mud pud dle and got his foot stuck under a wooden fence, it appeared that the bad things that always seem to happen to the Jets in Buffalo were happening again.

title: Trouble Slows Liner
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 21 (AP)The Cunard Line announced tonight that the Cunard Adventure had developed propeller trouble on her maiden voyage and was making her way to Lisbon. She had been due in Lisbon this afternoon, but is now not ex pected in before tomorrow. Cunard said there was no danger.

title: Democratic Convention May Lack Usual Suspense
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21The Democratic reform movement, in its anxiety to transfer party power from the bosses to the masses, could have stripped the national nominating convention of its traditional drama and suspense.

title: Ethics Seminar Held
description: ABSECON, N. J. Nov. 21Big Business got fairly high marks this weekend, from James J. Needham, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Eagles Yield Last Place to Cards
Arkansas Tech Eleven Leads In N.A.I.A. Coaches'
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 21 (UPI)Arkansas Tech leads the list of Division 1, smallcollege football teams in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, a coaches committee announced today.

title: HIGHER COVERAGE FOR HEALTH URGED
description: The New York State A.F.L. C.I.O. yesterday urged the State Insurance Department to mandate increased medical and hospital benefits in its pro posed new regulations for ac cident and health policies.

title: WILLIAM F. CALLAHAN
description: William F. Callahan, founder and retired president of the Callahan Machinery and Equip ment Company, now of Ho boken, N, J., died Saturday in University Hospital after cardiac surgery. He was 67.years television cases, died yesterday lived at 345 East 57th Street.

title: ABUSES BATTLED IN SAVINGS FIELD
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board pledged over the weekend that his agencywhich regulates the $200billion savings and loan industrywould use its powers to prevent excesses and abuses and extremes in a key area of conflict of interest among savings associations.

title: LINDSAY WILL DECIDE ON RUNNING BY JAN.15
description: Mayor Lindsay, saying that he would not expect the en dorsement of the socalled leadership, indicated yester day that he would decide by Jan. 15 whether to enter pri maries to seek the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Take Your Pick of All the Fixin's That Go With the Bird
description: It is a littlenoted irony that one of our chief inheritances from our stern Puritan forebears Is an orgy of food. Perhaps it was the Indian, Squanto, with his alien corn and pagan freedom in matters of diet who tempted Plymouth Pilgrims into unbridled and historic feasting.

title: No Comment From Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 (AP)The Israeli Government made no comment today on President Sadat's speech, but officials suggested that he had left Egypt little way out of a con frontation.

title: DISSIDENT SLATE SET FOR TELEPROMPTER
description: Former Governor Raymond P. Shafer of Pennsylvania heads the slate of directors completed by Jack Kent Cooke,. a major shareholder of the Teleprompter Corporation, in his proxy fight to unseat the present management.

title: NASCAR RACE WON BY LUND'S CAMARO
description: NORTH WILICESBORO, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP)  Tiny Lund whipped his Camaro around fading Richard Petty and Char lie Glotzbach today with four laps to go and work the Wilkes 400 stock car race in one of the season's surprise finishes. The National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing event allowed small cars to mix with the bigbore vehicles.

title: THEODORE M'CLINTOCK
description: CROTONONHUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 21Theodore McClintock, an author, editor and transla tor, died today of a heart at tack in Phelps Memorial Hos pital, North Tarrytown. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: No to Rehnquist
description: In 1964, Senator Barry Goldwater won the Republican Presidential nomi nation. Governor George Wallace abandoned his putative candidacy. The stage was thus cleared for united bid for power by the most re gressive factions in national politicstee Southern racists and the right wing of the Republican party.

title: DRAFT EVADER ENDS DEPORTATION FIGHT
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 21 (UPI)Thomas G. Jolley, a Uni versity of Georgia graduate who fled to Canada in 1967 but later returned to the United States, says he will drop his legal fight against plans of the United States Government to deport him.

title: Arab Guerrillas Said to Shift Strategy
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 21The Palestinian resistance move ment is shifting its strategy from regular army operations to urbanguerrilla action inside Israeliheld territory, according to a leading Palestinian theore tician here.

title: PATH UNCERTAIN IN BOND MARKET
description: The bond market seems to be hung up, unable to decide which way to move forcefully next.

title: Top Guerrilla Said to Die In Home of Gaza's Mayor
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 21Ziad elHusseini, said to have been the commander of the Arab guerrillas in the Gaza Strip, was reported to have been in the cellar of Mayor Rashad Shawa's home.

title: ELIE EDSON, 89, DIES; STAGE PRESS AGENT
description: Elie C. Edson, a retired the atrical press agent whose ca reer began with Sarah Bern hardt, died yesterday at his home, 419 West 115th Street. He was 89 years old.

title: Opera: Moses and Aaron in Concert
description: Several years ago there was a great todo in London When George Solti directed a production of Arnold Schoenberg's Moses und Aron. Not only was the music unconventional, but there also were certain ele ments of the production, in cluding a nude, scene, that had everybody talking.

title: Trials of 23 Begin Today In Disorders at Kent State
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 21 (AP) The longdelayed riot trials of 23 persons indicted by a special grand jury after the May, 1970, disorders at Kent State University will begin to morrow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Anthony Lewis Nov. 20 column from Salisbury, Rhodesia, tells of stories that... even the Chinese have secretly violated the embargo by buying Rhodesian ore and tobacco. This is entirely contrary to the facts.

title: VERSATILITY SHOWN BY YOUNG SYMPHONY
description: The program with which the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra opened its season, in Philharmonic Hall on Saturday afternoon, was un usually sophisticated. It was performed so well, it really de served to be heard by adults. Instead, it was played for the ensemble's customary teenage audience. Some of the young sters seemed engrossed; others wriggled, giggled and chattered, presumably bored by it all.

title: RULEBOOK ACTION REDUCING FORCES AND GEAR AT FIRES
description: Fire Chief John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that the strict adherence to regulations by the city's firemen in a pressure move for a new contract was forcing the department to send fewer men and fewer ladder and pumper trucks to fires.

title: North Vietnam Premier Hails China's Nuclear Gains
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 21China's nuclear arsenal was brought up for special mention by Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam in a speech in Peking yesterday.

title: 2 MINORITIES GAIN IN HOUSTON VOTING
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 21Negro and MexicanAmerican voters joined with liberal whites yes terday to elect two liberals to the Houston School Board, Negro to the City Council, and to throw the mayoral election into a runoff.

title: Jews in Moscow Brave Storm To Attend Chief Rabbi's Rites
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 21Moscow's religious Jews buried their chief rabbi today in a driving snowstorm as the succession to the leadership of the Soviet Union's largest Jewish congre gation remained in doubt.

title: Teaching the Hotel Help to Wear Shoes
description: Sometimes the people who are hired have never seen themselves in a mirror, don't know how to wear shoes, use a telephone or take a shower, But their employer, Inter Continental Hotels, soon has them running elevators and polishing floors, making beds, setting tables, mixing drinks and keeping their uniforms clean.

title: William Edgar John Dies; Owned a Shipyard in Rye
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Nov. 21 William Edgar John, boat builder and for many years owner and operator of the Mil ton Point Shipyard in Rye, N.Y., died here Thursday. He was 79 years old.

title: A Solution for Sinai
description: WASHINGTONThe Sinai peninsula occupies a critical position in the making of peaceand warin the Middle East. A solution for Sinai would provide the essence of a settle ment between Egypt and Israel.

title: RAMS TOP 49ERS, LEAD N.F.C. WEST
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21The Los Angeles Rams brutalized John Brodie and the San Fran cisco, 49ers today for a 176 victory and took over first place in the Western Division of the National Football Conference.

title: Lugano Blossoms as Swiss Banking Center
description: LUGANOThis lakeside re sort has been transformed into one of the principal fi nancial centers of Europe rivaling Zurich and Geneva, as a result of the almost irre sistible appeal of the depend able Swiss franc.

title: Coast Talks Resume
description: PALTO ALTO, Calif., Nov 21 (UPI)  Negotiations resumed today, under the auspices of the Federal Mediation Service, in the weeklong strike of lay teachers at seven Roman Catho lic high schools in the San Francisco Bay area.

title: Four Are Found Dead in Car
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., Nov. 21 (UPI)Three airmen and a teenaged boy were found dead in their car on a hunting trip apparently of carbon monoxide poisoning, the authorities re ported today. The victims were Lieut. Charles Guin, 24 years old, of Mooringsport, La.; M. Sgt. Dicke Grisham, 41, of Corinth, Miss.; M. Sgt. Earle Webster, 48, of Fayette, Mo., and Sergeant Webster's son, Larry, 14.

title: Gilligan is Expected to Endorse Muskie or Run as Favorite Son
description: COLUMBUS, OhioGov. John J. Gilligan of Ohio is nearing a decision on his role in the Presidential campaigna de cision that could prove to be one of the most fateful of the 1972 political year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: New York's voters were wise, it seems to me, in refusing to be hood winked Nov. 2 into approving the transportation bond issue.

title: Johnson, With Azalea Victory, Is 4th Black to Win on Golf Tour
description: WILMINGTON, N.C., Nov. 21 (AP)George Johnson, 32yearold Negro from At lanta rolled in a 20foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole today and won the Azalea open golf tournament. He is the fourth black to win on the Professional Golfers Associa tion tour.

title: Nixon Back at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after spending the weekend at near by Camp David with his wife, soninlaw and daughter, David and Julie Eisenhower, and a friend, C. G. Rebozo. They left the Maryland retreat by heli copter during a snowstorm. The President spent the afternoon watching two professional foot ball games at once, on twin television sets.

title: ANGERED MINERS MAY STAY OFF JOB
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 Concern mounted today among Government and coal industry officials that thousands of angry miners would continue to stay off their jobs this week in defiance of the United Mine Workers union.

title: Advertising:
description: William C. White and Sal vatore Auditore, until re cently president and execu tive art director of Papert, Koenig, Lois, have joined the growing horde of creative guns for hire.

title: Smith Stars for Sonics
description: SEATTLE, Nov. 21 (AP)Seattle's center, Don Smith, scored 10 points in the final two minutes tonight to lead the Supersonics to a 127117 vic tory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: N.A.I.A. Semifinals Set
description: KANSAS CITY, Nov. 21 (AP) Four teams with a combined record of 35 victories, two losses and one tie will meet in semifinal games of the Nation al Association of Intercollegiate Athletics Division I football championship next weekend. Arkansas Tech faces Northern State of Aberdeen, S.D., Satur day afternoon in Russellville, Ark., and Livingston of Ala bama goes against West Lib erty (Va.) State Friday night in Steubenville, Ohio.

title: DAVID BURNETT, 39, ANTHOLOGY EDITOR
description: David Benjamin Foley Burnett, coeditor with his mother, Martha Foley, since 1958 of the annual The. Best American Short Stories anthology, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital after undergoing a series of operations for stomach ulcers. He Was 39 years old and lived at 15 Charles Street.

title: GROUND IS BROKEN FOR CITY PROJECT
description: Groundbreaking ceremonies were held yesterday for Lionel Hampton Houses, a 355unit lowrent housirig project on Eighth Avenue between 130th and 132d Streets. Completion is expected by mid1973.

title: Chargers'
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP)Billy Parks of the San Diego Chargers, leading the Na tional Football League in pass receptions, suffered a broken arm in the 3433 loss to the Oakland Raiders and may be out the rest of the season.

title: Cause Pitchmen Set Up Shop in Bus Terminal
description: Victor A. Pixley wears lots of buttons, but he is proud est of three hanging from his tie that he had printed to order. They read, The Family that Works To gether Perks Together, The Family that Smokes Together Chokes Together, and The Family that Drinks Together Stinks Together.

title: Hawks Win, 73
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP)The Chicago Black. Hawks re ceived firstperiod goals from Stan Mikita, Bobby Hull, Pit Martin and Andre LaCroix, then cruised to a 73 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: Study Shows 40 Per Cent of Foods Here Increased in Price in September Despite Freeze
Corvette Wins at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP)Dave Heinz of Tampa, Fla., and Don Yenko of Canons burg, Pa., drove their Corvette to an overall victory today in the 20mile International Motor Sports Association GT cham pionship race at Daytona Inter national Speedway.

title: BandAids for the Subcontinent
description: The United Nations is drifting toward a disastrous failure on the Indian subcontinent because it is attempt ing to treat a potentially mortal wound with BandAids.

title: JAPAN BEATS U.S. IN TWODAY SWIM
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 (AP)Mark Spitz of Santa Clara, Calif., won his third event, the men's 200meter freestyle, today, but Japan ended up winning 12 of the 22 events in the twoday Tokyo international swimming meet.

title: Many Potholes Ahead for Poland's Auto Industry
description: WARSAW, Nov. 21  Last month, Poland signed a $400 million contract with Fiat, the Italian company, to produce popularpriced small car. The decision to sign the pact re solved a longstanding source of Polish consumer frustration.

title: Bigot and Liar Mark TV Clash on Forest Hills Project
description: Advocates and opponents of a planned lowincome housing project called each other bigot and liar in a rancor ous televised confrontation yes terday, raising the temperature of an already heated contro versy centering on the Forest Hills construction that is to be gin today.

title: Books of The Times
description: The title of Elizabeth Barlow's The For ests and Wetlands of New York City may strike one as amusinga gentle sick joke. And at first it makes one sad to be re minded by the author, who is a former Parks Council consultant, that wolves once roamed Manhattan, that Indians once hunt ed in the Bronx, and that Adrian Van der Donck, an early resident, once wrote that The air in the New Netherlands is so dry, sweet and healthy that we need not wish that it were otherwise... There are no heavy damps or stinking mists in the coun try, and if any did arise, a northerly breeze would blow them away, and purify the air. The summer heat is not oppressive in the warmest weather, for it is mitigated by the sea breezes, the northerly winds, and by showers.

title: Revenue Dip Seen If Brokers Abolish More Fixed Rates
description: The New York Stock Ex change has found in a statis tical study that abolishing the fixed sales commissions on a broader range of stock trans actions than at present might cost its member firms up wards of $200million a year under certain circumstances.

title: Fire Destroys Cape Cod Inn
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass., Nov. 21 (UPI) The Barstable Inn, an 18century stagecoach stop and noted eating place on Cape Cod, was destroyed by fire today. No injuries were re ported.

title: Article 1 No Title
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Nov. 21 (UPI)  Leon Rochefort's goal early in the third period today gave the Detroit Red Wings a 22 tie with the Vancouver Canucks in a National Hockey League game.

title: City Asks Delay in Apartment Strikes
description: Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, urged yesterday that apartment strikes threatened to start in the Bronx today be held off a few days to give time for Federal rent rulings.

title: Dance: Sunny Weekend
description: Yes, on the whole I would have preferred a weekend with the Bahamas, but tailing that, the New York City Ballet are very nice people to spend a weekend with. started with them at the New York State Theater on Friday night and I stayed there until last night. I played truant once in a whileI caught a couple of plays and a mid nightmatinee dance perform ancebut for the most part I was there watching ballet with considerable pleasure.

title: Richardson Critics Silenced by Singing Of National Anthem
description: A welfare rights demonstra tion against Elliot L. Richard son, Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare, here yester day lasted just seven minutes, ending with everybody involved joining in singing The Star Spangled Banner.

title: 51 ShortWeight Items Cited
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner Bess Myerson said yes terday that 51 violations for shortweighting customers had been turned up in a single visit by a team of inspectors to the meat department of the Key Food Supermarket at 235 East 106th Street. Each alleged viola tion could bring a $100 fine under city codes.

title: A 1969 Endorsement of Lindsay Helps to Open City Hall Doors
description: When Mayor Lindsay was running for reelection as LiberalIndependent, he wel comed the support of local Democrats, including Assem blyman Leonard M. Simon of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn. Mr. Simon said that he was plac ing principle above politics to endorse the Mayor because the survival of the city is at stake.

title: PLAYBOY FETE GAINS $100,000 FOR A.C.L.U.
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 21Playboy Mansion West, the opulent and grandiose West Coast center of an empire that symbolizes for many the de personalizing of women, was a gracious but somewhat un comfortable setting for a num ber of civil libertarians last night.

title: In Hard Times, U.N. Is a Boon to City
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21Manhattan real es tate concerns, eager for ten ants, are bombarding United Nations delegations with of ferings: a luxury town house for the men from Peking; a skyscraper suite for the dip lomats from the hot and sandy stretches of Bahrain.

title: RAPE SUSPECT SHOT ON A MIDTOWN ROOF
description: A 22yearold woman was raped after being forced into an empty office building on West 49th Street last night, the police said today. She eventually escaped and led the police hack to the building, where they shot and captured the alleged assailant.

title: The Mafia Is Dying Out, Talese Concludes
description: Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bo nanno delivered a bad review of Honor Thy Father di rectly to Gay Talese, the author said ruefully in a re cent interview.

title: BRUINS WIN, 62, FOR FIFTH IN ROW
description: BOSTON, Nov. 21 (UPI)Mike Walton scored a pair of goals, one in a threegoal third period burst, tonight to give the Boston Bruins a 62 victory over the St. Louis Blues in the National Hockey League. The triumph was Boston's fifth straight.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: INYANGA, Rhodesia It is early summer in Rhodesia; the rains have started. There are wildflowers in the long grass, and in the eastern high lands the woods are yellow with the flowers of acacia Mimosa. Down in the valleys, in the orchards, the peaches are ripening.

title: Brig. Babafemi agundipe, ExHead of Nigerian Army
description: LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP)Brig. Babafemi Olatunde Ogundipe, who served as Nigeria's armed forces chief of staff and envoy to Britain, died today after a heart attack. He was 47 years old.

title: Celtics Rout Cavaliers
description: CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP) The Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek and Dave Cow ens, outscored the Cleveland Cavaliers by 4022 in the third quarter tonight and rolled to a 128105 National Basketball Association victory.

title: In Pursuit of the Dollar
description: Governor Rockefeller's plan to let the genie out of the bottle by calling a spe cial session of the Legislature next month on, the state's fiscal crisis is contingent upon a pledge that, the genie will grant his wishes and not run amok. The genie in the case consists of the Repub lican majority members of both houses of the Legislature and the task facing the Governor and the majority leaders in the days ahead is getting them to agree on the essentials of a package to meet an antici pated deficit of $770million in the current state fiscal year.

title: RONAN IS WORRIED BY PAY PATTERNS
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority, said yes terday he was worried that pending transit union negotia tions could be hurt if the Fed eral Pay Board relaxed its wage guidelines.

title: US POSITION STIRS CRITICISM IN I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21A potentially serious clash is shaping up in the International Monetary Fund between the United States, on one hand, and the other members, together with the Fund's staff, on the other.

title: U.S. AIDES WARNED NOT TO AIR DISSENT
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 The State Department has cabled about 300 chiefs of mis sions and other principal diplo matic officers overseas warn ing them that reports of dissent by younger officers must not be allowed to leak to Congress or to the press.

title: Nayar Wins Squash Racquets
description: Anil Nayar of Boston defeat ed Vic Niederhoffer of New York, 1015, 1510, 1813, 158, yesterday in the final of the Joseph J, Lordi squashracquets tournament at the New York Athletic Club. In the semifinals Nayar beat Jim Nelson of the Harvard Club, 159, 515, 1513; 158.

title: State Department Aides, Told by the F.B.I. of Nixon's Travel Plans, Feel Bypassed on Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21There are times, in this age of Presidential summitry and White House diplomacy, when middlelevel officials at the State Department get the distinct feeling that they are being left out of the foreign policy process.

title: 15 Children Dead Among 19 in 3 Fires, One Termed Arson
description: Nineteen persons were killed in three early morning fires yesterday in Michigan, Califor nia and Alaska. The authorities said the Michigan blaze was the work of an arsonist. Fifteen of the victims were children.

title: Personal Finance
description: There's a sleeper in the tax law revisions now being con sidered by Congress that could cause quite a jolt to middleincome taxpayers with children in college. The pro posal, which seems likely to pass, would dilute substan tially the advantage of using a shortterm trust to finance a college education.

title: Aerosol Sniffing Kills Girl
description: MILAN, Ill., Nov. 21 (AP)Jim Shaw, the Rocky Island County coroner, said today that 16yearold Dona Leffler of Milan died after sniffing from an aerosol can that con tained a substance designed to keep food from sticking to pans. But he attributed the death to the manner in which the contents of the can were inhaled as much as to what was in the can. Mr. Shaw said that the girl, who was found dead today behind her home, had died of pulmonary edema caused by sniffing from the pressured can, which contained a substance called Pam, that is put out by the Gibraltar Indus tries in Chicago.

title: Giants Lose, Jets Win
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers de feated the New York Giants, 17.13, yesterday at Pitts burgh. The New York Jets, with 17 points in the second quarter, beat the Bills, 207, at Buffalo. Details on Page 55.

title: Theater: JFK Recalled
description: The real beauty of JFK is that this oneman show shares even more than it projects the image of John Fitzgerald Kennedy. Without an iota of theater razzle dazzle, last night's opening at the Circle in the Square made its point with quiet, un common persuasion. Reading the predominantly onthe record utterances of Presi dent Kennedy for the 90 minute program, a young actor named Jeremiah Col lins has also visually slipped into his skim

title: Sheila Kieran, Systems Analyst, Is Bride of Eric Joel Greenbush
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 21 Miss Sheila Christine Kieran, daughter of Mrs. James Michael Kieran of New York and the late Mr. Kieran, a political reporter and correspondent for The New York Times, and Eric Joel Greenbtish, a New York lawyer, were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Hershel Levin of Beth Sholom Temple in Flushing, Queens, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Meltzer, the bride groom's aunt and uncle.

title: Mrs. Herbert de Roth, 80, Leader in Civil Defense
description: Mrs. Lydia Morris Howard De Ford de Roth, a former lead er in civil defense, died Friday at her home, 40 East 66th Street. Her age was 80. She was the wife of Herbert Charles de Roth, a retired international banker.

title: Castro Greeted Warmly in Chile's Frigid South
description: PUNTA ARENAS, Chile Nov. 21 (AP)Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba came to this southern most city in the world today and was given one of the most enthusiastic receptions so far on his state visit to Chile.

title: Drive on High Blood Pressure Urged
description: Twentyfive million Ameri cans have high blood pressure, which is one of the greatest contributors to disease and death in this country. Yet num erous surveys have indicated that, only half of these millions know about their condition and only oneeighth of the total are being adequately treated to prevent the strokes and heart failure that are often its con sequences.

title: CITY TOLD TO PAY ANTIPOVERTY UNIT
description: The Federal Government has ordered the city to restore funds it had cut off for a Head Start program here while Federal investigators check charges that the stopping of funds involved discrimination against Puerto Ricans.

title: MRS. EUGENE M'CABE SR.
description: Mrs. Katherine Owens Mc Cabe, widow of Eugene J. McCabe Sr., an officer of the Guaranty Trust Company died Saturday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N. J. She was 78 years old and lived at 375 Riverside Drive.

title: Pay Board Weighs the Needs of Small Business, Too
description: Robert C. Bassett, a 60yearold Chicago business man, was chosen last month to represent small business on the Nixon Administra tion's Pay Board. He is Presi dent of Vertical Marketing, Inc., a magazine publishing company.

title: How to Roast a Thanksgiving Turkey
description: To thaw a frozen turkey, place the bird on a tray in the refrigerator in the original wrap, which has been punc tured, for two to four days or about 24 hours for each five pounds of turkey.

title: Cairo Seems Quiet; Troops on Standby After Sadat Alert
description: CAIRO, Nov. 21The lights were off tonight along Cairo's most fashionable shopping street, Kasr elNil, and pedes trians walked In darkness fol lowing president Anwar el Sadat's declaration to troops alone the Suez Canal that there is nothing left for us but the battle.

title: City College Celebrates Two Very Bygone Eras
description: The generation gap was more than four centuries wide at City College yesterday, but the Middle Age attitude clearly delighted the young in years.

title: Filipino Vessel Sinks; Toll Is Reported High
description: MANILA, Nov. 22 (UPI)A 30ton wooden cargo vessel carrying about 200 passengers, and suspected of having operated illegally, sank in choppy seas in the central Philippines yesterday with heavy loss of life, the Philippine Navy said today.

title: Women and the Fourteenth
description: In 1872, four years after the Fourteenth Amendment became part of the Constitution and commanded that no state deny the equal protection of the laws to any person within its jurisdiction, the Supreme Court upheld an Illinois law denying women the right to practice law. One Justice wrote in that decision: The paramount destiny and mission of women are to fulfill the noble and benign offices of wife and mother. This is the law of the Creator.

title: Knicks Waive on Price; Face Royals Here Tonight
description: Holding an abundance of backcourt talent the Knicks placed Mike Price their No. 1 choice in the 1970 college draft on 48hour waivers yesterday.

title: Thousands Visit Kennedy's Grave
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Nov. 22 (AP)Thousands of people climbed a grassy, windswept hillside today to pay tribute to John Fitzgerald Kennedy on the eighth anniversary of his assassination.

title: Frazier to Risk Title Against College Student Jan. 15
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 (UPI)  Joe Frazier world heavyweight champion signed today to come out smoking and defend his title against Terry Daniels a college student, on Jan. 15 the night before the Super Bowl football game here.

title: 2 Catholic Schools Here Shut by Strike
description: A strike by lay teachers in the Archdiocese of New York forced two parochial schools in the city to shut down yesterday, but had lesser or no impact on 327 other Roman Catholic schools in the 10county area.

title: Inscrutable Recipe Gap at the White House
description: If you've been waiting to try the chicken and walnut recipe that Dr. Henry A. Kissinger liked so much in Peking and was supposed to have brought back for the Nixons to try forget it.

title: Republic Corp. Reports Loss for 9Month Period
description: The Republic Corporation, in response to a request from the New York Stock Exchange, has issued a preliminary audited report indicating a net loss of about $43million for the nine months ended July 31. Sanford C. Sigoloff, chairman and president, noted that the company had changed its fiscal year to end July 31 instead of Oct. 31.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: These Models Seek Beauty in the Ghetto
description: ATLANTA (UPI)  Twice a week two Atlanta models step from the world of high fashion to that of runaways school delinquents and other youngsters in trouble with the law.

title: A Call for Candor
description: We are disturbed that one of the President's nominees  William H. Rehnquisthas resisted the Senate in the performance of its responsibility by means we regard as improper. No nominee may justify withholding from the committee, which must initially pass upon his qualifications and dispositions for handling this political power in legal form, a frank expression of his political and legal philosophy.

title: A Silent Minority Supports Forest Hills Housing Plan
description: Mrs. Jean. Rosenthal was sitting under a hair dryer in a Forest Hills beauty shop when a conversation exploded around her concerning the lowincome housing project planned for the middleincome community. The site is two blocks from her home.

title: POLICEMAN ACCUSED OF KILLING FRIEND
description: A 26yearold offduty policeman was charged with homicide last night after he allegedly killed a friend in a Brooklyn bar.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I think it is disgraceful that a conservative nominee to the Supreme Court, who certainly reflects the views of most of middle America, should have to put up with the character assassinations of the liberal left. The Negro groups, labor officials and other misguided liberals are not going to get another Warren Court with all its tragic decisions. Thus they are trying to pressure a spokesman for the majority into not accepting or being rejected for membership on the Court. It certainly doesn't say much for liberalism.

title: Architectural Study Says City Gets Poor Service at High Cost
description: A 20month study by the Urban Design Council of New York has concluded that the architectural services rendered, to the City of New York fall far short of the highest standard and recommended a radical revision of building processes.

title: Lebanon Parades Missiles
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 22 (AP)Lebanon celebrated her 28th anniversary of independence today with a 30minute military parade displaying for the first time 25 Crotale surfacetoair missiles from France, hauled past President Suleiman Franjieh?

title: Joseph C. Wilson of Xerox Dies at 61; Headed Presidential Panel on Health
description: Joseph C. Wilson, chairman of the Xerox Corporation and of the Presidential Committee on Health Education, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while lunching here with Governor Rockefeller, whose Steering Committee on Social Problems he also headed.

title: Chambliss of Indians Rookie of Year
description: Chris Chambliss of the Cleveland Indians was voted rookie of the year in the American League yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: About 15 Are Feared Dead as Europe Is Swept by Gales and Snow
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 Reuters About 15 persons were feared dead today across Europe as snow and gales swept the continent.

title: Reuss Comments
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 22 (Reuters)  Representative Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the Joint Economic subcommittee on exchange and payments, said today that he regretted Mr. Connally's statement that a change in the official gold price would not be negotiable at next Tuesday's Group of 10 meeting in Rome. This is sad news, the Wisconsin Democrat said.

title: Tight Curbs Placed on Kent State Trial
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 22The first of 25 persons indicted in the 1970 Kent State University riots went on trial here today with the judge imposing tight restrictions on press coverage and prohibiting any ,student demonsartions in, at, or near the courthouse.

title: Dividends Are Deferred By WheelingPittsburgh
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was deferring quarterly dividends on its two classes of preferred stock. The company said that directors had concluded that deferral was prudent at this time in view of continued uncertainties about demand for domestically produced steel. Steel users are working off excess supplies accumulated as a strike hedge.

title: Paint Brush Worker Kills Five Employes At Baltimore Plant
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (AP) An employe of a paint brush factory in southwest Baltimore opened fire inside the plant this afternoon, killing five coworkers and wounding a sixth and a policeman before being critically wounded by the police.

title: DOCTORS WARNED ON USE OF HORMONE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 The Food and Drug Administration plans to mail bulletins this week to more than 600,000 doctors and other health professionals warning against the use of the synthetic hormone diethylstilbestrol by pregnant women.

title: ChrisCraft Management Assails Insurgent Group
description: In a letter to stockholders released yesterday the management of ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., attacked two leaders of an insurgent group that is attempting to take control of the company.

title: Proposal on Acquisitions Of Thrift Units Opposed
description: Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, attacked yesterday proposals that bank holding companies be allowed to acquire savingsandloan associations.

title: Chilean Opposition Denounces Plan to Alter the Legislature
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 22The Opposition Christian Democratic party today denounced the Government's proposed constitutional reform that would creates onechamber legislature to replace the Senate and Chamber of Deputies.

title: New Flights Are Scheduled From San Juan to Barbados
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) Leeward Island Air Transport the newly reorganized regional airline in the eastern Caribbean said today that on Dec. 1 it would inaugurate daily jet service from San Juan, Puerto Rico, down the West Indies to Barbados.

title: DUST IN. SUBWAYS CALLED A HAZARD
description: Transit Authority data show that the air in the city's subway stations contains dangerously high levels of steel dust and iron particles, according to chemistry professor at York College, Queens.

title: New Election Ordered For Richmond Council
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 22 (AP) A Federal district judge today ordered a new election of Richmond's ninemember city council to provide a better racial balance in the vote of the city's 249,621 population.

title: Theismann Is AllStar Pick
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press)Joe Theismann, the rookie quarterback from Notre Dame who directed the Toronto Argonauts to their first Grey Cup berth in 19 years and 10 of his teammates were named to the Eastern Football Conference allstar list today.

title: Radcliffe Alumnae Get Vote
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP)The Harvard Board of Overseers agreed today to allow some 15,000 alumnae of Radcliffe College to vote in the annual election of overseers of Harvard University.

title: Pennsy Aide on Garden's Board
description: In an 11 thhour decision, the Penn Central Transportation Company has nominated a director for the Madison Square Garden Corporation, who was elected at the annual meeting yesterday.

title: League of Cities Gives Support To Senate Water Pollution Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22In the developing battle over a Federal water pollution control bill, the National League of Cities and the United States Conference of Mayors have lined up behind the Senate measure and against the substitute proposed by the Nixon Administration.

title: FirstYear Profit Seen
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation indicated yesterday that it might eventually pay as much as $130million for the part of the computer operations of the RCA Corporation that it has agreed to acquire.

title: Chemical Warfare Drugs Called Possible Aid to Heroin Addicts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 A representative of the pharmaceutical industry said today that the Defense Department might have developed potent chemical warfare drugs that might be used to fight heroin addiction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Nov. 9 editorial United States and World Law carried me back to my childhood when I listened to my parents and grandparents ventilating their outrage upon the Kaiser, who had described a treaty with a foreign nation as a scrap of paper.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22Many persons have been surprised recently by news stories indicating that the French are deeply involved in the international heroin traffic. Those who keep an eye on criminal circles, however, have been aware for some time that the dreaded French underworld organization known as the Ma Fia has been tightening its dirty grasp on the vice of five continents,
