description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 (AP) Cigarchomping Danny Murtaugh, architect of two World Series championships and a divisional title for the Pittsburgh Pirates, stepped down as the team's manager today.

title: Maisel Sees No Bar to Growth
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23A member of the Federal Reserve Board said today that achievement of a goal of which more rapid growth in the econ:. omy next year, as widely predicted, would not create any basic problem for monetary policy or the money supply.

title: Jury Bill Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a bill to lower the age for service on Federal court juries from 21 to 18.

title: Mrs. Lindsay Supports Holiday Gift Campaign
description: Mrs. John V. Lindsay announced yesterday a campaign by city agencies to amass holiday gifts from municipal employes for distribution in orphanages, municipal hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Michel Is to Become Partner in Kuhn, Loeb
description: Kuhn, Loeb & Co., one of the nation's leading investment banking firms, announced yesterday that Clifford W. Michel will become a general partner Jan. 1. Mr. Michel, 60 years old, had been the managing partner of Loeb, Rhoades & Co., another leading house, and is well known figure in Wall Street.

title: China Joins U.N. Council, Assails Superpowers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 23China took her seat as a permanent member of the Security Council today and charged that one or two superpowers continued to commit aggression and subversion against other countries.

title: Cardinal TubThumper's Beat Sounds Like a Dirge
description: When a team is going badly, its public relations department finds few positive facts to develop. More often, the remarks tend to sound wholly discouraging.

title: L.I.U. BOOTERS LOSE TO CORNELL, 2 TO 1
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Nov. 23 The Cornell soccer team defeated Long Island University, 21, today on a late goal by Bob Rechtscheffen and moved into the second round of the national collegiate soccer playoffs in the New York I State region.

title: U.S. AIDS NEWARK ON SCHOOL PLAN
description: NEWARK, Nov. 23  School officials here said today that the Federal Government's decision to finance a $17million Experimental Community School System in Newark marked the birth of a new day in public education in this city.

title: ExPolice Lieutenant Guilty in Bribery
description: One of the city's most decorated policemen  a retired commander of detectives in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn  has been convicted of conspiracy to extort{ and receive bribes to protect a policy gambling operation.

title: Peyton Ford, Truman Legal Aide Who Battled M'Carthy, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Peyton Ford, a Deputy Attorney General in the Truman Administration, died here last night. He was 70 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A consensus of American newspaper headlines during recent U.N. voting on the admission of China to that body, seems to indicate that headlinewriters throughout the land view the consequences of that voting to be in some way a great defeat for the United States. I count myself as one small, quiet American who does not see these results in this way.

title: U.N. ALL BUT HALTS ITS AID IN PAKISTAN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23  The United Nations has been compelled to restrict radically its relief operations in East Pakistan because of the upsurge in military activity in the last 48 hours.

title: O'Brien Sets Retirement At Associated Dry Goods
description: Arthur J. O'Brien, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a departmentstore chain, announced yesterday that he plans to take an early retirement to concentrate on personal interests. He will retire next Feb. 1.

title: EUROPE TROOP CUT BARRED BY SEN ATE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23The Senate deferred to Presi dent Nixon today by rejecting a proposal for a 60,000man reduction in the American forces in Western Europe.

title: An Italian Couple With Knack for Knits
description: It's what Chanel would be doing if she were alive, young and working in knits, a store executive remarked as she was viewing an informal showing of clothes by Rosita and Ottavio Missoni at the Plaza Hotel the other day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest your recent editorial Water on the Moon. While I fully agree with you on the paramount importance of the actual detection of water vapor on the moon, I must take issue with your statement: Until Drs. John W. Freeman Jr. and H. Kent Hills announced their finding, it had always been assumed that the moon was entirely without water.

title: KENT STATE JURY VISITS RIOT SITE
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Nov. 23The jury selected for the trial of the first of 25 persons indicted in the 1970 Kent State University disorders toured the campus at Kent today under heavy escort of sheriff's deputies.

title: Senate Panel Votes $1.5Billion To Widen Battle on Drug Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 A $1.5billion fund to combat drug abuse on the state and city level and for such special projects as fighting addiction in industry was added today to a bill to create a White House action office against drug abuse.

title: Curtis, Former House Member, Selected as Head of Rent Board
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23President Nixon announced today the appointment of 14 persons to be members of the Rent Advisory Board.

title: Bay State G.O.P. Elects
description: BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP)Robert C. Hahn, a Stoughton lawyer and a former State Representative who was reported to have the backing of Gov. Francis W. Sargent, has been elected chairman of the RepubliCan State Committee, succeeding Herbert Waite of Wellesley.

title: Red Smith
description: In the fullness of his 40 years, Willie Mays says he wants to play baseball two or three more seasons, maybe four. Not that he needs that job. If the legs gave out tomorrow, he could walk into a studio, hang a lavaliere microphone over his necktie and make it big as the new Dick Cavett or Mery Griffin or David Frost. That, in fact, is exactly what he did the other night.

title: Small Group of Owners Control A Majority of DayCare Centers
description: Almost twothirds of the city's 132 leased daycare centers are owned by a small group of landlords  with one owner listed for 29 of them  Controlier Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Ruth Alice Halsband Dies; Chemist Led the Norman Fund
description: Mrs. Ruth Alice Norman Well Halsband, chairman of the Norman Fund and founder of the Hickrill Chemical Research Laboratory in Katonah, N. Y., died yesterday at her home, 575 Park Avenue, following a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title: Insurer President Proposed
description: W. Clement Stone, 69yearold chairman of Combined Insurance Company of America, said yesterday that he would nominate his son, Clement, 43, president of European operations, as president of the company, effective Jan. 1. He would succeed Matthew E. Walsh, 49, who anounced his early retirement several months ago. The nomination is subject to approval by the board of directors on Dec. 16.

title: Notes on People
description: The word began to spread among his Washington supporters that Senator Edmund S. Muskie was tiring of snacks of milk and cookies While flying around the country on his undeclared campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. So a group of women in the suburbs of Washington started Mondays for Muskie, on which they prepare the goodies the Maine Senator prefers: Swedish cardamon cakes, apricot balls, smoked nuts, chocolate cakes and Chinese egg rolls. In the switch from stuffing envelopes to stuffing the candidate, the women also make quiche Lorraine and chopped chicken livers, and freeze it until needed. If any other candidate has such support, he hasn't announced it.

title: Playoff Countdown Begins With 14 Clubs Contending
description: We'll just have to win our next four games. That's what George Allen, coach of the Washington Redskins, said this week as did Dick Nolan of the San Francisco 49ers; Jim Dooley of the Chicago Bears; Joe Schmidt of the Detroit Lions; Don McCafferty of the Baltimore Colts and John Zook, defensive end of the Atlanta Falcons, in lieu of his coach, Norm Van Brocklin.

title: Nixon Pays Surprise Visit to Redskins, Gives Pep Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)President Nixon paid a surprise visit to the Washington Redskins practice session today and urged the team to keep its spirit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The idea of an Incomes policy is back in favor in Federal Government economic policy, in view of the Aug. 15 aboutface by the President and his announcement of the content of Phase Two.

title: C.I. Mortgage Sees Higher Net; Says Competition Never Hurt
description: The C.I. Mortgage Group expects further increases in earnings in its fiscal year ending next Oct. 31, Peter C. R. Huang, chairman of the real estate investment trust, said yesterday.

title: TRW Gets 70 Million Award To Build Two Spacecraft
description: TRW, Inc., has been awarded a $70million contract for spacecraft to measure highenergy radiation in space, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONThe oldest symbol of link between Britain and continental Europe is that of a tunnel under the English Channel. Strangely enough, although this was already discussed more than a century and a half ago, it may prove one of the last panEuropean projects realizeddespite the fact that the United Kingdom is well on its way to Common Market membership.

title: Chinese Flag Ripped Down At Rockefeller Center Plaza
description: Three teenagers ripped the flag of mainland China from its staff near Rockefeller Plaza yesterday and drove off with it.

title: CROSS URGES NIXON TO CHANGE BUTZ BID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)  Representative H. R. Gross, Republican of Iowa, urged President Nixon today to withdraw the nomination of Dr. Earl L. Butz for Agriculture Secretary and replace him with a dirt farmer.

title: U.M.W. Dissidents Pressing SoftCoal Walkout
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 23The number of striking softcoal miners dropped slightly from 16,000 yesterday to 15,000 today, but the flashfire pat, tern of the defiance indicated a continuing problem for the leadership of the United Mine Workers and the union president, W. A. Boyle.

title: North Vietnamese Are Received by Mao
description: PEKING, Nov. 23 (Reuters)Mao Tsetung made another public appearance last night, receiving Pham Van Dong, the Premier of North Vietnam, and other visiting North Vietnamese officials.

title: RALLY TOO LATE ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: It was the first sign of strength we have had in days but it came too late,

title: Peace Road on Pay Controls
description: It is not necessary to take sides in the bitter new exchange of unpleasantries between George Meany and the Administration to know that intensification of the feud can only result in grave damage to the wageprice stabilization effort. The success of this effort is much too important to permit it to be wrecked by political personal animosities.

title: Learning to Read in Peking
description: SAN FRANCISCOAs the reportage by Americans flows out of China, I am struck by the incredulity and delight in the discovery that the Chinese are, after all, more friendly and sophisticated than many Americans had believed possible. But the fact that Chinese at all levels relate with ease and assurance to ordinary Americans comes as no surprise to those U.S. citizens who have visited and worked in the People's Republic since 1949.

title: Stans Confers in Moscow On Soviet Trade Problems
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans met today for three hours with the Soviet Minister of Foreign Trade and then said that he was beginning to realize the problems involved in trade between two countries with different political systems.

title: Stan Kenton Optimistic on Big Bands'
description: For the 19member Stan Kenton band, the gross for night is sometimes only $1,500, the salaries begin at $200, the individual's motel hill is $56 a week, and sometimes for threemonth stretches there are no days off.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read with compassion Jane Everhart's account of her mugging in Harlem [OpEd Oct. 28]. My compassion for the pain of her experience, and its exposure of our vulnerability to violence in New York, is made more lively by the vigil my family recently concluded over our twelveyearold son, who was severely injured by a car at Ninetieth Street and Amsterdam Avenue as he ran from a group of Negro children. Fortunately, he is recovering.

title: YAREES TO OPEN AGAINST ORIOLES
description: The New York Yankees announced yesterday that they would open their 81game home schedule next April 6 against the Baltimore Orioles, threetime champions of the American League.

title: Rural Uruguayans Wary Of Communist Candidates
description: TACUAREMBO, Uruguay, Nov. 14In the Uruguayan range country around Tacuarembo distances across the prairie are still measured in leagues and until recently politics was seen in only two colors: the white of the Nationals and the red of the Colorados, the two parties that have governed the country for more than a century.

title: Fuller's Filly Dies
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP)Catmousan Road, owned by the Boston sportsman, Peter Fuller, worked out at Churchill Downs today, then died apparently of a heart attack. The 2yearold filly was being groomed for the Pocahontas Stakes on Thanksgiving Day. She raced at Aqueduct last Wednesday in the Demoiselle and finished fourth.

title: Preminger Retrospective At Modern Art Museum
description: A retrospective showing of 27 of the 35 films made by Otto Preminger, the independent producerdirector, will be presented at the Museum of Modern Art, starting Friday and continuing through Dec. 23. Mr. Preminger is to participate in a discussion of his work at 8 P.M. Dec. 9 prior to the screening of his 1970 feature Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon.

title: Britain and Rhodesia in Tentative Accord
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 23Britain reached a tentative settlement tonight with the white minority Government of Rhodesia.

title: Theater: The Sty of the Blind Pig
description: It was Chicago in the fifties, just before the start of the civil rights movement. A man named Martin Luther King Jr. was preaching down in Memphisand the nigger minstrel show had ended. Not everyone understood that small fact. Certainly not even everyone in Chicago.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose in Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Official to Leave L.I.U. Post
description: Dr. Edward C. Glanz, president of the Southampton Center of Lohg Island University since the Center's establishment in 1963, has announced that he will resign to return to teaching educational psychology,

title: Advertising:
description: Jay Wilson, executive vice president of International. Research Associates, has been named to succeed Oscar B. Lubow, who is resigning effective next Tuesday as president and chief executive of Daniel Starch & Staff.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23The world is now on the verge of another pointless human tragedy. India and Pakistan are slowly but surely sliding into a war which can only result in unutterable misery, and in this situation it will be interesting to watch the socalled Great Powers at the newly reorganized United Nations.

title: Chinese Hosts to 300 in Their First U.N. Social Event
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23Chiao Kuanhua and Huang Hua, leaders of China's delegation at the United Nations, displayed the warmth of Chinese hospitality tonight for the benefit of 300 guests from at least 50 countries at the first social function here by Peking.

title: Bulls Rout Blazers, 13094
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP)The Chicago Bulls put on a highpowered scoring display tonight by overwhelming the Portland Trail Blazers, 13094, for their sixth consecutive triumph.

title: The Story of a Chair
description: The wing chair, long a fixture by the livingroom hearth, may well end up in the bedroom if the public and decorators take heed of what the Metropolitan Museum of Art says was its use in the 18thcentury America.

title: $270,000 Picasso Is Stolen
description: PARIS, Nov. 23 (UPI)Two thieves smashed the window of a Paris art gallery today and fled with a Picasso painting valued at $270,000, the police reported. They said the painting was the Harlequin's Head, a painting on wood dating from the artist's Rose Period in 1905. Heinz Berggruen, an American industrialist who lives some of the time in Paris, had loaned the painting to the Knoedler Art Gallery as part of a current Picasso show, according to the police.

title: Frazier's Next Foe Is a la Ali
description: Displaying an ego and flippancy missing from boxing since Muhammad Ali was known as Cassius Clay, Terry Daniels yesterday predicted his balance of speed, power and style would help him upset Joe Frazier and take away the world heavyweight championship.

title: Blackout in Brooklyn
description: About 40 blocks in the East New York section of Brooklyn were without electricity yesterday from about 10 to 11:35 P.M. The blackout extended from Stanley Avenue to Shore Parkway and from Louisiana Avenue to Ashford Street. It affected 553 customers of Consolidated Edison.

title: Secretary Is Indicted in Theft Of $384,451 From Employer
description: A 26 year old secretary bought a bed for $3,600according to the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and jewelry for $41,000 and rode to work in a chauffered limousine.

title: Cougars Top Squires, 10298
description: NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 23 (AP) A free throw and a hook shot by Jim McDaniels in the closing minute led the Carolina Cougars to a 10298 American Basketball Association victory over the slumping Virginia Squires tonight.

title: Rarick Declines Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23A spokesman for Representative Rarick, who was holding an open house in his home district of Baton Rouge today, said that Mr. Rarick had told him he would have no comment on the report until he read it.

title: Eastern Air Lines
description: Eastern Air Lines, Inc., reduced its net loss in the month of October to $4.5million from the $8.5million deficit in October, last year.

title: Housing Agency Yields on Race Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 The Department of Housing and Urban Development agreed today to drop charges and award docked pay to 106 employes who were disciplined for participating in a series of protest demonstrations last year.

title: Market Place: A.T.&T. Stock Yielding 6026%
description: It may not be the most exciting news in the world but those of you out there in Telephone land who have bought American Telephone and Telegraph from time to time might like to know that the yield on the sharesat prices near yesterday's new low for the yearis 6.26 per cent.

title: DR. MOLLIE H. KOTHE
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Nov. 23Dr. Mollie Hubon Kothe, a physician long active with the New York Bureau of Child Guidance, and the wife of Howard K. Kothe, a New York lawyer, died last night in a fire that destroyed their summer home here. She was 43 years old and lived at 103 East 75th Street,

title: Hazzard Braves'
description: BUFFALO, Nov. 23 (UPI)Walt Hazzard scored 30 points, including the clinching basket tonight, in his first start against his former Atlanta teammates as he led the Buffalo Braves to a 10297 victory.

title: Westvaco Corp.
description: Sharply lower earnings in the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Oct. 31, was reported yesterday by the Westvaco Corporation.

title: FIREMEN AND CITY BARGAINING AGAIN
description: A new effort to resolve the firemen's contract dispute began last night as the number of firemen reporting sick after fires accelerated.

title: Hiroshima ABomb Log Nets $37,000
description: A handwritten log kept by the copilot of the Enola Gay during the B29's mission to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima was sold at auction at the ParkeBernet Galleries for $37,000 yesterday.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS 2 COURT NOMINEES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23The Senate Judiciary Committee voted overwhelmingly today to send the Supreme Court nominations of Lewis F. Powell Jr. and William H. Rehnquist to the Senate floor.

title: Request for Hearing by A.E.C. On Reactor for Queens Is Filed
description: A formal request for a public hearing by the Atomic Energy Commission on whether the longpending training and demonstration reactor should be permitted at the Hall of Science lin Flushing MeadowsCorona Park, Queens, has been filed by Assemblyman Joseph F. Lisa of Queens.

title: Thais Want Dollars Without the Diplomacy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 23The socalled revolution in Thailand is a week old now, and as its military leaders explain their disenchantment with democracy, they are also saying something about the inadequacy of American policies and inspirations.

title: Dentist Faces CourtMartial
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., Nov. 23 (UPI)An Army dentist will face a special courtmartial for refusing to obey an order to cut his hair to conform with regulations. The Army confirmed today that Capt. Frederick J. Blitzer, 27 years old, of Passaic, N. J., was offered nonjudicial punishment by his commanding officer, Col. R. B. Austin 3d, on Nov. 15. Captain Blitzer was given 72 hours to accept or decline the order. He refused and requested a trial by a military courtmartial.

title: Graebner Is 3Set Victor In South American Tennis
description: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York, Zjelko Franulovic of Yugoslavia and Ilie Nastase of Rumania advanced today to the third round of the South American tennis championships.

title: CONVOYS ARE SEEN
description: BAGDA, India, Nov. 23Large numbers of Indian troops pushed toward the nearby East Pakistani border today and, according to their officers, crossed into East Pakistan.

title: Toyota Raises Prices 2d Time in 2 Months
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Nov. 23 (AP)Toyota, the Japanese automobile manufacturer, announced today the second increase in two months in the suggested retail prices of its passenger cars sold in the United States.

title: APARTMENTS FAIL TO GRANT RAISES
description: Despite a ruling on Monday by the Price Commission exempting private, rentcontrolled apartments from Phase Two guidelines,. Bronx landlords and their workers failed yesterday to resolve a dispute over scheduled pay increases that would avert a strike against 2,000 apartment buildings housing 500,000 tenants.

title: Blues Triumph Over Kings, 31;
description: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23 (UPI)Jack Egers scored two goals tonight and Gary Sabourin tallied his fifth goal in the last six games to give the St. Louis Blues a 31 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in a National Hockey League contest.

title: 60 Vietnam Veterans Begin OTB Jobs Today
description: More than 100 Vietnam veterans have finished or are about to finish basic training with the Offtrack Betting Corporation for jobs as ticketsellers, cashiers and administrative assistants.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EDWARD REED LAUGHLIN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 23 Edward Reed Laughlin, who retired in 1958 as head of the Sand Springs Bottling Company in Williamstown, Mass., died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 10 White Plains Road.

title: OCCIDENTAL CUTS DIVIDEND TO 12C
description: Dividend news for shareholders was less than cheerful yesterday as various corporations announced reduced payments either because of corporate problems or Government restrictions.

title: Joe Adonis Is Near Death After Pulmonary Collapse
description: ANCONA, Italy, Nov. 23 (Reuters)Joe Adonis, said to have been a king of the Amer, ican underworld, suffered pulmonary collapse tonight and is close to death, according to hospital sources.

title: Inquiry Told That Lawyer for El Paso Gas Offered to Help Bank Get InterestFree Deposit
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)Two officials of a Utah bank told a Senate committee today that a lawyer for the El Paso Natural Gas Company offered to help the bank get a $100,000 interestfree deposit from the company.

title: Stars Win on Jones's Goal
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 (UPI) Jimmy Jones hit a 10foot jump shot with 5 seconds remaining tonight to give the Utah Stars a 114112 A. B. A. victory over the Pittsburgh Condors.

title: POLICEMAN DENIES HANDLING $45,000
description: Patrolman Louis Farina testified at his grand larceny trial yesterday that he never saw, handled, took or knew about the $45,000 to $50,000 the state alleges was handed over to him on May 23, 1970, by the man who found the money.

title: Planners Agree to Increase LowerCost Units in Yorkville
description: Acceding to community requests, the City Planning Commission yesterday approved an increase in the number of apartments for lowincome and moderateincome families scheduled for the Ruppert Brewery urban renewal project.

title: ExHead of Barber Union Gets Jail in Kickback Case
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPI) Joseph DePaola, former president of the Journeymen Barbers Union, has been sentenced to year in a Federal prison after pleading guilty last month to accepting about $65,000 in kickbacks for approving loans from the union's pension fund.

title: G.M. Seeks a rice Rise Of 3% on Its 72 Models
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23The General Motors Corpora tion, which accounts for more than half the nation's automobile production, asked the Government today to allow a 3 per cent price increase on its 1972 models.

title: Gulf &
description: Gulf & Western Industries Inc. announced yesterday that it was making the equilvalent of $1mlIllon tivaIrable immediately to the Indian Government for refugee relief.

title: WALSTON IN PACT WITH TRAVELERS
description: Wall Street is going into the life insurance business.

title: Henry Spiegel, Press Agent For Paramount Theater, 61
description: Henry Spiegel, the last publicity director for the Paramount Theater before the film showcase on Times Square closed in 1964, died of cancer on Monday in Long Island Jewish Hospital, New Hyde Park. He was 61 years old and lived at 13818 228th Street,, Laurelton, Queens.

title: 3 AGENCIES REVIVE PEP PILL ADVISORY
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP)  Ranking officials of three Federal agencies met in a hurriedly called session today to revive a recommendation, lost in the bureaucratic paper mills two months ago, to curb 1972 production of pep pills.

title: SOVIET PARTY ADDS AIDE TO POLITBORO
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23  The Communist party's policymak ing Central Committee ended a twoday session today by adding Mikhail S. Solomentsev, the new Premier of the Russian Republic, to the politburo.

title: Both Hold Meetings
description: R. H. Macy & Co. had a 21 per cent rise in earnings on an 8 per cent increase in sales in its first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 30, stockholders of the New Yorkbased departmentstore chain were told yesterday at the annual meeting.

title: Oil Spill Skipper Ousted
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 23 (AP)Capt. Jack L. Snyder, commander of the tanker Manatee, which dumped nearly 230,000 gallons of black oil off Southern California last August, has been relieved of his command, the Navy announced today. The oil came ashore from the MeXican border north to the beach of the Western White House at San Clemente, where President Nixon was vacationing at the time. Hundreds of sailors and marines worked 10 days to clean the beaches near Camp Pendleton.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Pressure Reported Relieved
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 23 (AP)Cambodian military sources reported today that the drive the South Vietnamese began into Cambodia yesterday had already relieved some of the enemy pressure on the front northeast of Pnompenh.

title: DOW INDEX FALLS BY 5.18 TO 797.97
description: Stock prices kept retreating yesterday along a wide front, although a rally led by glamour issues reduced some losses in the final hour of trading.

title: Official Says U.S. aloes FoodStamp Aid Here
description: New Federal food stamp regulations will slash Federal subsidies in New York City by $40million, down from a firstyear total of $80million in Federal bonuses, Arthur Schiff, director of the city's foodstamp program, said yesterday.

title: Screen: Ravi Shankar
description: See Raga. This quietly penetrating, beautifully made color documentary about the Indian musicianteachercomposer, Ravi Shankar, opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema. Everything about it is admirable.

title: Explosion Cuts Off Power
description: ATTLEBORO, Mass., Nov. 23 (AP)A feeder line, carrying 4,160 volts of electricity, exploded today, injuring one person, damaging a substation and blacking out much of the city for more than one hour. The line was in a substation of the Massachusetts Electric Company.

title: Buckley Drafting Letter
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 Senator Buckley said today that he was drafting a letter to Mr. Nixon outlining his views on the Forest Hills project and declared that he was extremely disappointed that Secretary Romney had said he could find no basis for reversing Federal commitments to build it,

title: Supermarket Proposal Faces Hyde Park Fight
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y., Nov. 23 A proposal to build a supermarket directly across the street from the home of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt is stirring considerable controversy here, where anything connected with the late President has been controversial for decades.

title: PETROFINA FAILS IN A SINCLAIR BID
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI)The Justice Department today rejected American Petrofina as a prospective buyer for the former Sinclair Oil Company properties in 14 Western states. The Atlantic Richfield Company was ordered Aug. 28, 1970, to sell the property. The or der was contained in a consent judgment settling the Government's antitrust suit challenging the merger of Sinclair into Atlantic Richfield. Atlantic Richfield was ordered to divest itself of extensive Sinclair holdings.

title: Penney Sets Records
description: The J. C. Penney Company, second only to the nation's leading merchandise chain, Sears, Roebuck & Co., achieved record sales and earnings. in the 13 and 39 weeks ended Oct. 30, it was reported yesterday.

title: Kerr's Guide to TheaterAvailable on Cassettes
Reading Co. Files Bankruptcy Petition
description: The Reading Company, corporate parent of the Reading Railroad, yesterday filed petition for reorganization under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act with the United States District Court in Philadelphia.

title: Bucks Turn Back Pistons;
description: DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP)Kareem Jabbar paced the hotshooting Milwaukee Bucks to a 112104 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: UNIT OF LOCKHEED CITES JOB GAINS
description: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 23Employment is stabilizing at the Lockheed California Company and will reach a peak of 27,000 by the end of this year, the company announced today.

title: Democratic Caucus Put Off
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 23 (UPI)The National Democratic Governors caucus, which was to have been held next month in Newport, has been postponed until April, Gov. Frank Licht said today. He said Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, chairman of the caucus, ordered the postponement after a survey of the 30 Democratic Governors showed they would be unable to make the conference next month.

title: Physician Weds Miss Friedman
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Nov. 23Miss Linda Sue Friedman of New York, speech pathologist at the MontefioreMorrisania Hospital affiliation in the Bronx was married here this evening to Dr. Steven Jonas of Brooklyn. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

title: Guatemalan State of Siege, Over Year Old, Is Lifted
description: GUATEMALA, Nov. 23 (UPI) The Guatemalan Government today lifted the state of siege modified martial lawit imposed more than a year ago to combat a wave of political murders and kidnappings.

title: DOCK TALKS RECESS; LONG STRIKE GOES ON
description: A Federal mediator said yesterday that negotiations between shippers and longshoremen to end the 54day North Atlantic dock strike had recessed indefinitely without agreement and that TaftHartley action by President Nixon was a real possibility.

title: EMERGENCY IS SET
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 23Pakistan declared a national emergency today and charged that Indian forces had seized two villages and some border outposts in East Pakistan.

title: ARMS REPORT CITES HEAVY BIG4 TRADE
description: STOCKHOLM, Nov. 23 (AP)  Four countriesthe United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France  have supplied more than 90 per cent of the major arms to the third world countries, where all wars have been fought in the past 25 years, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute reported today.

title: 44 Philippine Moslems Killed By Army in Election Incidents
description: MANILA,. Nov. 23 (UPI)A military spokesman said today that Government troops killed 44 Moslems Monday in two incidents during special elections in the southern Philippines.

title: PHONESTRIKE LOSS IS PUT IN MILLIONS
description: The 19week statewide strike against the New York Telephone Company has cost 38,500 employes more than $100million in wages, forced many of their wives to work and led to heavy dependence on umemployment checks.

title: PHILLIPS TESTIFIES AT OFFICER'S TRIAL
description: Patrolman William Phillips, key witness in the Knapp Commission's public hearings about police corruption, testified yesterday in the departmental trial of a lieutenant accused of taking graft from a gambler.

title: Bela Siki Offers 2 Kinds of Music At the Keyboard
PSYCHIATRIC UNIT ENDS TALKS HERE
description: The New York State Psychiatric Institute, the first psychologically oriented medical research center in the United States, ended its 75th anniversary celebration yesterday with reflections on the influential role it has played in the evolution of American psychiatry.

title: Mr. Connally vs. Europe
description: President Nixon's personal appeal to the Senate undoubtedly helped to turn the tide yesterday, for the second time in six months, against a unilateral reduction of American troops in Europe. But the Administration had itself largely to blame both for the need to fight this battle again and for the narrower margin of victory just as talks with Moscow on mutual force reductions in Europe are approaching.

title: COLLINS RADIO GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: The North American Rock well Corporation, which acquired a large interest in the financially troubled Collins Radio Company last August, yesterday named Robert C. Wilson as president and chief executive officer of Collins Radio. Mr. Wilson, who relinquished his post as executive vice president, electronics and industrial products group of NR, succeeds Arthur A. Collins who continues as a director and honorary chairman of Collins Radio.

title: MetalPlants Strike To Bring Lockouts In West Germany
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Nov. 23The metalworkers strike over wages in West Germany spread through the southwestern industrial belt of the country today, with 120,000 off the job in what loomed as a national trial of strength between the big manufacturers and the normally docile labor force.

title: VINCENT J. DELISO
description: MAHOPAC, N. Y., Nov. 23Vincent.1. DeLiso, designer of highfashion shoes who retired in 1957 as president of Palter DeLiso, Inc., of New York, died yesterday at his home on Wixon Pond Road. He was 74 years old.

title: A NEW CHIEF RABBI IN SOVIET EXPECTED
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 23A New York rabbi who flew here for the funeral of the Chief Rabbi of Moscow expressed confidence today that the vacant post would be filled soon despite a shortage of trained rabbis in the Soviet Union.

title: New Entry Policy at 4 Special Schools Is Urged
description: A special committee appointed by School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has recommended that the city's four specialized high schools abandon their traditional policy of basing regular admissions solely on competitive entrance examinations.

title: FREDERICK W. MEYER
description: NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 23Frederick William Meyer, retired director and secretary of the Pittsburgh Brewing Com pany, makers of Iron City beer, died today at the Eden Park Convalescent Home here. He was 89 years old.

title: Judge Finds Hamtramck Used Urban Renewal to Oust Blacks
description: DETROIT, Nov. 23A Federal judge ruled today that the city of Hamtramck, Mich., with the knowledge of the Federal Government, had used urban renewal and other government projects to force black residents out of the city.

title: Gov. Ogilvie to Run Again, Says He'll Be Underdog
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 23 (Reuters)  Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie announced today that he would run for a second fouryear term next November.

title: WALTER M. TAPLEY JR.
description: PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 23 Walter M. Tapley Jr., a high school dropout who later became a Maine Supreme Court justice, died today of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Osteopathic Hospital of Maine. He was 73 years old.

title: Philip Morris Lifts Dividend by a Cent
description: The board of Philip Morris, Inc., declared a quarterly dividend yesterday of 31 cents share on its common stock, payable Jan. 12 to holders of record Dec. 17. The increase of 1 cent, slightly under 4 per cent from the previous 30 cents a share, is within the Phase Two guideline, published Nov. 15, which allows a maximum rise of 4, per cent.

title: Dr. Dudley S. Stark Sr., 77, Former Bishop of Rochester
description: YORK HARBOR, Me., Nov. 24 Dr. Dudley Scott Stark Sr. retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Rochester, died yesterday of pneumonia in his home. He was 77 years old.

title: COMMISSION CUTS CHRYSLER FIGURE FOR PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 The Price Commission reduced for the first time today the amount of a price increase asked by a company. It allowed the Chrysler Corporation a 4.5 per cent increase on its 1972 model automobiles. Chrysler had asked for a rise of 5.3 per cent.

title: JOSEPH A. HOWELL, CHURCHMAN, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24The Rev. Joseph A. Howell, former secretary for personnel services of the division of Christian education of the United Church Board for Homeland Ministries, United Church of Christ, died Monday in the PresbyterianUniversity of Pennsylvania Medical Center. He was 56 years old.

title: Dance: Bejart's Company Returns
description: Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century, which is Belgium's leadingclassic ballet company, returned to New York last night to open a brief season at the New York City Center. It is a company with two magnificent dancers, quite a number of very good dancers, a great deal of tiresomely repetitious choreography, and recorded sound tracks.

title: NEW SAIGON UNITS IN CAMBODIA PUSH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 25  More South Vietnamese troops moved unopposed yesterday into the Communist base areas in eastern Cambodia that they had occupied before the beginning of the rainy season last May.

title: Drag Charges Dropped For Girl Tried by Peers
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Nov. 24 (AP)A judge dismissed drug possession charges against a teenage girl in the second day of a trial before a jury of fellow high school students.

title: Soccer Referee Accuses L.I.U. Player of Assault
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 24 (AP) A soccer referee swore out an arrest warrant today charging a Long Island University player with assaulting him during a National Collegiate championship regional game yesterday, at Cornell University.

title: NEW POPULIST GROUP CONVENES IN DALLAS
description: DALLAS, Nov. 24 (AP)Politic al activist and peace groups from throughout the nation met today to decide whether they should challenge Republicans and Democrats in next year's Presidential election.

title: Prayers, Parade and Feasting Add Up to Thanksgiving in City
description: The giving of thanks and the getting of heartburnor, for some, a not so traditional square mealwill unite New Yorkers for today, and they e.an expect it to rain at least a little on their parade.

title: Soviet Denounces Accord
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24The Soviet Union today denounced the settlement of the Rhodesian dispute as a betrayal of the interests of the African majority.

title: 16 Civic Groups and Defamation League Support Housing Project in Forest Hills
description: Strong endorsement for the controversial lowincome housing project just started in Forest Hills, Queens, came yesterday from 16 civic and community groups that work in Queens and Long Island.

title: Diplomat Defends Oil and Gas Policy Set by Venezuela
description: The Venezuelan Ambassador to the United States, Julio Sosa Rodriguez, said yesterday that there has been considerable misunderstanding in this country about the oil and natural gas laws recently passed in Venezuela.

title: The First Thanksgiving Proclamation
description: The New York Public Library's Manuscript Division has turned up this historical rediscovery: the first Thanksgiving proclamation. This document ordaining a day of thanks and prayer the Berkeley settlement in Virginia was issued in 1619before Governor Bradford established the famous celebration in 1623 for the Plymouth Colony in Massachusetts.

title: RICHARD JOHNSON, BOSTON PUBLISHER
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24Richard N. Johnson, who was president and publisher of The Boston Evening Transcript from 1939 until it closed in 1941, died on Sunday of cancer at his home. He was 71 years old.

title: Thanhgiving, the Dream...
description: Thanksgiving Day sprang from our own beginnings a time when those first settlers were grateful to be alive and have enough to eat. They asked little of life, but much of themselves. They were thankful for the strength to put down the roots of settlement, to build the beginnings of security. They had dreams, but they knew dreams are hopes for tomorrow and without today there would be no tomorrow. They faced reality and were thankful for today and the right to dream.

title: Lester G. Brookman, Philatelist Who Devised Price Guide, Dies
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 24Lester G. Brookman, one of the world's foremost stamp collectors died yesterday in his home at Edina, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: Devaney Unveils a Wishbone Defense
description: NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 24Bob Devaney disclosed Nebraska's plans for defensing the celebrated Wishbone offense of Oklahoma tomorrow afternoon in their showdown game for college football's No. 1 spot.

title: Thanksgiving: A Tradition That Changes With Our Way of Life
description: There they are, Grandpa, Grandma, and the children, immortalized by Norman Rockwell around the Thanksgiving table. They've surely come over the river and through the wood and any minute now somebody is going to yell Hurrah for the pumpkin pie!

title: Court Halts Draft In California Area Till Law Is Studied
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) Military induction of all draftees in seven California counties was halted today by two Federal judges pending judicial review of the new Selective Service Act.

title: Dispute Nears End As Rhodesia Signs Pact With Britain
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Nov. 24  The sixyear struggle between Britain and her rebellious territory of Rhodesia neared an end today as a con stitutional settlement was agreed upon.

title: Gaza Curfew Reimposed
description: GAZA, IsraelOccupied Egypt, Nov. 24 (Reuters)Israeli military authorities reimposed a curfew in the Gaza Strip today. It had been lifted for almost 40 days for the Moslem holy month of Ramadan.

title: DDT Peril to Pelicans Is Debated in California
description: ANACAPA ISLAND, Calif., Nov. 21On this starkly beautiful island, the traditional nesting grounds for pelicans, only eight chicks were hatched this year.

title: Mayor Wins Reelection
description: FRANKLIN, N. H., Nov. 24 (AP)Mayor Eugene S. Daniell Jr., a Democrat, was reelected to his fifth term last night, defeating Robert F. Goodearl, Republican, 1,363 to 490.

title: Increase in Radiation Noted After Chinese Nuclear Test
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) Higher radiation levels have been detected in the atmosphere over Japan and Hong Kong, and scientists believe they are the result of China's detonation of a nuclear device Thursday.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Millions of Americans today will eat turkey with all the trimmings and not even bother to wonder why. This is the trouble with today's Thanksgiving. Americans have forgotten the traditions and history that have made it what it is.

title: Film: The Pioneer Spirit:' Man in the Wilderness' Is at Loew's State 1
description: "Man in the Wilderness" must have been a backbreaking movie to make but it emerges as a flat, pretentious bore. The color vehicle starring Richard Harris opened yesterday at Loew's State 1 and other showcases.Apparently meant as a tribute to the American pioneer spirit, it opens with a truly horrendous scene with Harris, as a fur trapper, being mauled by a grizzly bear, the most impressive thing about the movie. Given token aid and then dumped by his buddies, the half-dead man inches back to civilization.If only the picture had held fast to a simple uncluttered Crusoe-style survival story.Instead, methodical flashbacks jump to the past, revealing only the hero's atheism and bitterness over his wife's death.Worse, the picture also shifts to the other trappers, commanded by John Huston, who speculate at length about the absent man, while wheeling over the mountains a weird-looking, amphibious boat that looks like a Rube Goldberg version of Noah's Ark. Richard C. Sarafian, the director, has staged some scenes involving Indian attacks and wild animals that although stomach-churning are not strong.The scenery is rugged and fine. But Harris, a fine actor, looks like Rasputin drawn through a meat grinder. All we got out of this ode to the pioneer spirit was one thing: never tango with a grizzly.

title: JOHN S. BAYLIS, 86, COMMODORE DIES
description: Commodore John S. Baylis, a 40year career man in the Coast Guard and Captain of the Port of New York during the war days of the early nineteenforties, died yesterday at the United States Public Health Service Hospital on Staten Island. He was 86 years old and had lived for many years at 416 Highlan Avenue, Clifton, N.J.

title: Seals Top Wings, 61
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP)Ernie Hicks scored his fifth and sixth goals of the season to lead the California Golden Seals to a 61 victory tonight over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: 31 Accused of Abusing Asylum Inmates
description: LIMA, Ohio, Nov. 24 (UPI)Thirtyone employes and former employes of the Lima State Hospital for the Criminally Insane have been arrested on charges of mistreating inmates physically or sexually.

title: Arthur Daley
description: There has never been any secret about the fact that Phil Wrigley, the owner of the Chicago Cubs, has long had a deep admiration and affection for Ernie Banks, the cheerful little earful of Wrigley Field. With the popular Ernie the end of his illustrious playing career and the unpopular Leo Durocher at a questionable point in his managerial career, there was much speculation over the last few months as to which way the ball would bounce.

title: World Bureau Votes Expo74 for Spokane
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Nov. 24 (UPI)Two years ago, the Spokane Historical Society reminded the Chamber of Commerce that the city's centennial was coming up in 1974, and that it would be a nice idea to commemorate it.

title: Schumann, in Spain, Says Madrid's Stand Prevents His Meeting Opposition
description: MADRID, Nov. 24Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann of France has told members of the Spanish opposition that the attitude of the Franco Government makes It impossible for him to see them.

title: Monetary Discussion Expected
description: PARIS, Nov. 24The world monetary crisis, in which France has been a major adversary of the United States, is expected here to be a major subject in the talks between President Nixon and President Pompidou.

title: Conservationists Buy a 500Acre Tract Near Puerto Rican Bay to Save Its Whirling Fire Creatures
description: The habitat of the whirling fire creatures of Phosphorescent Bay, P.R., is being saved, in part by conservationists.

title: Nixon to Meet With Pompidou In the Azores to Discuss Trips
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24President Nixon will confer with President Pompidou of France in the Azores next month regarding Mr. Nixon's forthcoming trips to China and the Soviet Union, the White House announced today.

title: Mary Baker Eddy Work Stirs Copyright Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Sixtyone years after the death of Mary Baker Eddy, the Christian Science Church she founded has nearly succeeded in getting Congress to pass a private bill that would give special copyright protection to her principal work, Science and Health With Key to the Scriptures.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I note your Nov. 12 editorial relating to child abuse, the concluding sentence of which very eloquently states that the life of a child transcends even the right of privacy of another. You have thus summarized the commitment of those of us who are prolife to the proposition that this right to life of the child exists before as well as after birth, and does indeed transcend the alleged rights of those who would take his life.

title: RUSKIN SAYS DUVAL IS BEING QUESTIONED
description: Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin said last night that Deputy Sanitation Commissioner Frank J. DuVal and a number of Sanitation Department police personnel were questioned yesterday in Mr. Ruskin's investigation of activities in the Sanitation Department,

title: Alcoa to Raise Output At Warrick, Ind., Plant
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 (UPI) The Aluminum Company of America announced today it would increase primaryaluminum production at Its Warrick, Ind., works. Alcoa said it would start one 45,000tonayear potline, bringing Warrick's rate back up to 140,000 tons a year Alcoa had shut 130,000 tons of annual capacity late in October and early in November because of the coal strike and general market factors. Warrick's total capacity is 275,000, tons a year, of which 50,000 tons are new, facilities that have never been operational.

title: LowIncome Housing Is Opposed By East New York Local Board
description: Voicing some of the same fears as their wealthier and largely white fellow New Yorkers in Forest Hills, black and white representatives of the slumpocked East New York section of Brooklyn have also expressed opposition to a scatteredsite, lowincome public housing project.

title: Nixon Focusing on Meant as Likely Campaign Target
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Richard Nixon has always been It his best as a campaigner when he has had a controversial target to attackwhether it was officials soft on Communism in 1946 or opponents ax on law and order in 1968.

title: Dollars Dumped in Europe As Speculation Intensifies
description: PARIS, Nov. 24Dollars were unloaded in the major European centers today and the price of gold rose to its highest level in almost four years as speculation on a dollar devaluation intensified before next week's crucial monetary meeting of 10 governments in Rome. A major aim of the current United States policy is the largest possible devaluation of the dollar. The decline of the dollar in foreign exchange markets such as today's is one way of Achieving that goal.

title: ChrisCraft Meeting Jan. 11
description: The Independent Stockholders Committee of ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., said yesterday that the Delaware State Supreme Court had reversed the Delaware Chancery Court's refusal to grant an injunction preventing management of ChrisCraft Industries, from advancing the date of the annual meeting to Dec. 8. The original date of the meeting was Jan. 11, 1972.

title: MRS. EARLE R. CUMMINGS
description: Pauline Bushnell Cummings, widow of Earle R. Cummings, former controller of the Community Service Society, died Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived at 235 East 22d Etreet.

title: 85 in Nevada Win a Battle On Dirty Air
description: YERINGTON, Nev., Nov. 24  Residents of the small town of Fernley, Nev., have won a major victory in their fight against a cement company that polluted the air with thousands of pounds of dust and dirt daily for 19 months.

title: Tribute to Porterfield
description: A memorial tribute to Robert Porterfield, founder of the Barter Theater of Virginia, who died last month at the age of 66, will be held in the Belasco Room in Sardi's on Tuesday at 4 P.M. Gregory Peck, Elizabeth Wilson, Fritz Weaver, Mildred Natwick, Larry Gates and Dorothy Stickney are some of the guest speakers.

title: Earnings of Teledyne Decline In Latest 3 Months and Year
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent letter of Henry G. Fischer, detailing the costs and inconvenience caused by the fact that the Suez Canal is closed, may be unexceptionableup to a point. That point is his conclusion that somehow this is tantamount to putting an exorbitant surtax on world trade in order to underwrite the Israeli occupation of the Sinai.

title: St. Cloud, Minn.: A Small City Faces Special Problems of Growth in the U. S.
description: ST. CLOUD. Minn.  When came here 20 years ago, was told there wasn't anything wrong with St. Cloud that a few funerals wouldn't cure, said Jerry Kigin, president of the Northwestern Bank and Trust Company.

title: Prosecutor Calls Henderson Inconsistent
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Nov. 24 The military prosecutor at the courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson hammered at the defendant today in an effort, to show that the former brigade commander must have known that many civilians had been killed at Mylai 4.

title: END TRADE CURBS, GATT CHIEF URGES
description: GENEVA, Nov. 24The director general of the international organization that oversees the world's trading relations called today for the quick removal of the more dangerous and irritating restrictive trade measures.

description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (Reuters)A soldier whose unit helps guard President Nixon at the Western White House was arrested today on charges of conspiracy and alleged trafficking in plastic bombs as he boarded a plane at the Los Angeles International Airport.

description: When Thomas Clementi, a slightly built 19yearold Brooklyn youth, saw three husky men tormenting an elderly man early last Thursday, he told them to stop.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI)  The business of scheduled United States airlines showed a sharp upturn in the third quarter, the Air Transport Association reported today.

description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 24Leaders of an African mediation mission returned to Israel today, fresh from their latest talks in Cairo. They conferred promptly with Premier Golda Meir and Foreign Minister Abba Eban.

title: MERIT RAISE ISSUE STIES CONFUSION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Officials of the Pay Board worked today to explain the agency's explanation of its ruling on whether the 5.5 per cent general guideline would apply to merit wage increases.

title: Silky Terriers'
description: Although Pan American World Airways probably isn't aware of it, that carrier played a role in the rise of the silky terrier in America. I started to work for Pan Am in 1943, said Mrs. Merle E. Smith of Los Angeles. My husband, who now is a captain on the Oriental run, joined us immediately after World War II, when we were using the old flying boats. The Smiths saw their first silky in 1950. We were having dinner in San Francisco, when a woman came in with a pup. I made such a fuss over it, my husband promised to get me one in Australia for a Christmas present.

title: Pakistan Is Slow to Appeal to U.N. Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24Pakistan, uncertain whether she would get the, necessary support from the big powers, was still reluctant today to call for a meeting of the Security Council to consider her charges of a largescale Indian invasion of East Pakistan.

title: Trims in Copper Prices Continue for 4th Day Brass Affected
description: Price cutting continued yesterday for the fourth consecutive day in the copper industry and extended into the brass industry.

title: Weakening Gun Control
description: The Gun Control Act, which became law after the murders of Martin Luther King and Robert Kennedy, was an inadequate measure but acceptable as the first step toward reducing this nation's homicidal slaughter. But the Administration, Congress and the sportsmen's lobby have contrived to regress rather than move forward from that initial step.

description: Nineteen of the season's debutantes, who are provisional members of the Junior League of Ne'w York, were honored at the league's 22d annual Debutante Ball at the Plaza last night.

title: EARL HINES SHOWS USUAL BRILLIANCE
description: Earl Hines, who long ago established himself as one of the greatest jazz pianists, is also proving to be one of the most durable of jazz musicians.

title: U.N. to Hear Details

title: Panel Backs Bill to Raise Duck Stamp Fee by $2

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Paul W. McCracken, who has been chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers since the start of this Administration, resigned today, effective Jan. 1.

description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 24 Plans for the $12million Sarah M. Scaife Gallery, to be erected as an addition to the Carnegie Institute and Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh, were announced today.

title: Banuelos Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee plans a hearing Monday on President Nixon's nomination of Mrs. Romana A. Bonnelos as Treasurer of the United States, Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, the committee chairman, announced today. Mrs. Banuelos has been under fire since it was disclosed that employes at her Los Angeles food company included aliens who had entered the United States illegally from Mexico.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh Sending Israel ShortRange Missiles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Senior Pentagon officials said today that the Administration was considering providing Israel with shortrange missiles rather than Phantom fighterbombers if Soviet shipments of modern weapons should threaten to tip the balance of power in the Middle East in favor of Egypt.

title: Court of Appeals Vacates an Order In Ellsberg Case
description: BOSTON, Nov. 24  A contempt order against Mrs. IdeIla Marx, motherinlaw of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was vacated today by the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: U.S. and Sudan Weigh Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Mansour Khaled, the Foreign Minister of the Sudan, today discussed the possibility of the United States and the Sudan resuming diplomatic relations. The Sudan broke relations during the 1967 ArabIsraeli war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I saw an old man eating scraps of leftovers from a garbage can the other day and I stopped at the corner and stared. Hundreds of people hurried through the busy intersection on that sunlit day but none of them saw or perhaps all of them chose not to see. I wonderedwhy the old man and not me?but I was secretly glad it was not me. He was chewing greedily on something he had taken out of a soiled, greasy bag, and at that moment he might just as well have been an alley cat or stray dog. I knew that come next Sabbath, would be discussing the biblical concept of the dignity of man, and yet was rooted to the spot; coolly observing with the eyes of a scientist as one might observe feeding time at

title: Market Place: Irate Investors Assail Brokers
description: Perhaps the reason there is such a strong response to articles about smallinvestor distress is because there are 31 million investors in the stock market.

title: Why, to China in March, Master Kissinger Says
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Nov. 24A 10yearold boy may have let President Nixon's announcement on his trip to China out of the bag tonight.

title: 2YEAROLD PACER IN YONKERS DRILL
description: YONKERS, Nov. 24Most of the horsemen and railbirds were surprised to see Strike Out, a promising pacing son of Bret Hanover and Golden Miss, working in the cold at Yonkers Raceway this morning. With John Hayes Sr. in the sulky the colt paced three separate onemile trips, the fastest in 2:07 4/5. Some wondered why the Canadian reinsman was working the juvenile at a time when virtually all 2yearold standardbreds already had been turned, out.

title: Most Tapewatchers Reflect BearishMood
description: The ranks of the boardroom faithful were noticeably thin at brokerage firms yesterday. One manager ex plained that it was probably because of the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: Screen: 'Black Beauty':Anna Sewell's Book Provides Source
description: Readers of Anna Sewell's famous autobiography of a horse will not find too much that is familiar in James Hill's new film version of "Black Beauty." But they will find an uncommonly interesting, handsome and sometimes quite marvelously inventive movie that might have been called "The Further Adventures of Black Beauty," including such episodes as Black Beauty among the Irish gypsies, Black Beauty on the Continent and Black Beauty preserving the Empire, at battle in India.Actually, the film's story pays frequent respects to the novel. It is much concerned with the humane treatment of horses. And at the end it even goes so far as to introduce Anna Sewell herselt (Margaret Lacey), as the noble benefactor of Black Beauty's serene old age.But its stronger interests lie elsewhere; in the Romantic intensity, sharp pathos, or dark humor of episodes that involve the horse but are not so much about the horse as about the various people who own it, use and cherish or betray it. Their lives have a very special, often fateful glamour that owes a good deal to 19th-century fiction (not the "Black Beauty" kind of fiction) but that survives today chiefly in the movies.I think the film appreciates the fragility of even its most vivid figuresits romantic lovers, its circus-world entrepreneurs, its thieves and squires, its officers of the cavalry, its miserable dealers in coal. It has therefore surrounded them with a dense and rather difficult atmospheric beauty, which both distances them and protects them in a supporting halflight of remembered fears and pleasures.At the simplest, "Black Beauty" is not only good to look at, it is also challenging to look at. Whether in the dangers of a fox hunt near the beginning (a conventional sequence that for once really words) or in the darkness of the coal mines where Black Beauty almost ends his days, the film creates an environment that is partly time and place, but is also the understanding of a privileged vision."Black Beauty" suffers mainly from the utterly pedestrian performances of its leading players: Mark Lester as young Joe Evans, the horse's first owner; and Walter Slezak as the European circus owner who later buys him. But these players lead in cast billing only. There are other roles as important that are wonderfully played, by Ursula Glas as the circus owner's spirited daughter, by Maria Rohm as the high-born English girl whose lover (Peter Lee Lawrence) may die for her but never marry her, especially by Patrick Mower as an evil young squire who hates horses and whom Black Beauty kills for his dreadful rage.I should not normally recommend a movie for children, because I don't like restrictions and I think that children often have tastes a little different and a little tougher than adults might prefer. There is some violence in "Black Beauty" and also a little sex (its lovers kiss as if they cared), and I can't imagine that kids would mind. Thus, "Black Beauty" is perhaps sexy and violent enough for kids, but pleasant and pastoral enough for their parents. It opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters and it is worth seeking out.

title: Wood, Field and Stream; Scoter (or Coot) Can Be Good Eating When It Is Prepared in Correct Way
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Invite a coastal New Englander over 40 years old to your home for a coot dinner and there is a good chance that he will instantly recall a previous engagement.

title: POLICEMAN KILLED AIDING A MOTORIST
description: One policeman was killed and another seriously injured in Brooklyn last night when an oil truck slamed into the rear of the police car.

title: P.B.A. LOSES ITS FIGHT ON STRIKE PENALTIES
description: A threejudge special panel siting in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a suit by New York City policemen challenging their Taylor Law penalties that resulted from a strike last Jan. 14 to 19.

title: BRITISH REACTION TO PACT IS MIXED
description: LONDON, May 24  The agreement between Britain and Rhodesia's white ruler, was greeted with relief in London today by those who saw an end at last to a decadelong diplomatic headache.

title: 2 Cincinnati Unions Ask Pending Raise Cut Nearly in Half
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 24 (AP)Two building trades unions in the Cincinnati area have asked that scheduled pay increases for their members be cut nearly in half to meet President Nixon's wage guideline of 5.5 per cent.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Excerpts From Chinese Statement in U.N. on Disarmament and Soviet Response
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Now 24Following, in unofficial translation, are excerpts from the address of Chiao Kuanhua, head of the Chinese delegation, before the General Assembly and the response by Yakov A. Malik, the chief Soviet delegate:

title: Japan Inc. and Nixon Shocks
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21In the big Black Book from which President Nikon was briefed on international economics this year, the main challenger to American wellbeing is listed as Japan Inc.

title: Berliners Enraged by Actor's Portrayal of Jesus
description: BONN, Nov. 24"Jesus ChristRedeemer, as played by Klaus Kinski in a oneman pop show, had a very had trip this week at the very beginning of a projected national tour.

title: Stokowski Gets a Medal And Gives Yale a Show
description: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 24Leopold Stokowski was awarded the Henry Elias Howland Memorial Prize during a special concert at Yale University's Woolsey Hall last night.

title: U.S. Commerce Officials Hear Kosygin Bid for Trade in Moscow Talk
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24  Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin presented the Government's new fiveyear plan to the Supreme Soviet (parliament) today and called on the United States to give up its attempts to discriminate against the Soviet Union in trade, financing and shipping.

title: Drive to Aid War Orphans Opened Here
description: Eli Cohen of Quakerstown, Pa., is just about 8 years old and almost always articulate. Occasionally, he lapses.

title: Chess: Gligoric, Yugoslav layer, Wins West Germany Laurels
Castro Pitches Into Work At a Chilean Copper Mine
description: CALETONES, Chile, Nov. 24 (AP)Premier Fidel Castro of CUba went to work today on the production line at the huge El Teniente copper mine, where the Chilean Government recently nationalized millions of dollars of private United States investment.

title: WILLIAMS, BRAVES, IS ROOKIE OF YEAR
description: Earl Williams of the Atlanta Braves was voted the National League's rookieoftheyear yesterday in a twoman race with Willie Montanez of the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: PAUL A. WILLIAMS
description: Paul Alexander Williams, former New York newspaperman, died Sunday in Washington at the age of 85. He had worked for The Daily News and the now defunct Mirror, and he had also contributed articles to The New York Times.

title: Credit Markets: Most Bond Prices Continue to Drop
Pincay Rides 5 Winners at Big A
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. made things warm for his followers among the 15,949 fans on the cold afternoon at Aqueduct yesterday. The methodical jockey from Panama rode five winners in seven attempts on the card, including a triumph on Harry Gordon's Projective in the feature race.

title: Life to Cut Its Circulation And Seek Rate Increases
description: Life magazine announced yesterday that it would cut 1.5 million from its 7 million circulation guarantee with the Jan. 14 issue. It will also seek to raise the cost to advertisers of reaching readers and increase subscription rates.

title: YORKVILLE LOSES PLEA ON HOUSING
description: The Board of Estimate gavel its approval yesterday to a Lindsay administration plan for a mixed housing development on Manhattan's East Side, rejecting an unusual appeal from the largely white neighborhood for an increase in the number of lowincome apartments in the project.

title: 2 Parties Charged With Manipulation Of Ethnic Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Representatives of Italian, Polish, Hungarian and other urban ethnic communities spoke out today against political manipulation of American ethnic groups.

title: More Notes From the Wilderness
description: HARBORSIDE, Me.Barrels of flour and sugar in the pantry were ordinary staples for New England country dwellers a hundred or more years ago. Molasses was kept by the pailful, dried beans and peas by the peck. Soda crackers, oyster crackers and ginger snaps were stocked in ordinary households by the barrel. Kegs of lard and butter were prime necessities. Down the cellar were boxes and barrels of apples, potatoes, beets, carrots, onions, rutabagas, turnips; crocks of sauerkraut, salted beans and waterglassed eggs. Cabbages hung head down from the ceiling. Hundreds of quarts of soups, sauces, juices, fruits and jams lined cellar walls. Up in the attic hung dried apples and herbs, with squash and pumpkins on the landing.

title: Markets idle Today
description: Stock exchanges, commodities markets, banks and most businesses throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Many businesses also will be closed tomorrow, although banks, securities and commodities markets and Federal offices will be open. Canadian and overseas markets will remain open both days.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Prices of soybean and grain futures on the Chicago Board of Trade improved yesterday with the news that the Nixon Administration may use a TaftHartley backtowork order for a 90day coolingoff period to break the deadlock in the AtlanticGulf Coast dock strike. Export shipments of soybeans and food grains have been held back because of the strike.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Confucius asked his disciple, What do you do when you see a little baby crawling near a well? The disciple answered, Master, no time for argument. I will rush to the baby and rescue it from the danger. Confucius was delighted, You are right. That is what is called human nature.

title: 100,000 Stage Protest
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 (Reuters)About 100,000 people demonstrated throughout Japan today to protest against the lower house's approval of an agreement to return Okinawa to Japanese rule.

title: MRS. DAVID SHUB
description: Mrs. Rebecca Shub, wife of David Shub, who until his retirement several years ago was an editor of The. Jewish Daily Forward, died yesterday in Jacoby Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 355 Eighth Ave. nue.

title: The Pilgrims as Outcasts
description: BOSTON  November is the pious month. In November, politicians, editorialists and sometimes historians spout platitudes as if Plymouth Rock were Old Faithful. It would be better this grim year to remember certain realities of the American experience that began with the Pilgrims.

title: Draft Plans No Action
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24A spokesman for Selective Service said tonight that his agency planned no additional action in the California case pending review of the case in the courts there. He stated that more than 200 inductees were involved.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you're in the stock market the chances are very strong that before long you'll be hearing from your broker about something new he has to offer: life insurance.

title: HARTKE PANEL BACKS AMTRAK EXTENSION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 Senator Vance Hartke, Demodiet of Indiana, moved today to extend for two years, until July 1, ,1975, the period in which the National Railroad Passenger Corporation is barred from dropping any of its Amtrak trains.

title: Navy's Van Loan Is Man Army Will Keep Eye On
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24If Fred Stuvek of Navy and J. Kingsley Fink of Army are the starting quarterbacks, as expected, in the 72d annual ArmyNavy game Saturday, it will be the first time since the 1940 game that both academies opened with sophomore quarterbacks.

title: Economic Pragmatist Herbert Stein
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24Herbert Stein, the man named by President Nixon today as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is an economist who has a reputation of being something of an ideologue but who turns out in practice to be a pragmatist. One of the ironies of recent economic history is that Mr. Stein, who has long been an articulate opponent of any effort  voluntary or compulsoryby the Government to intervene in private price and wage decisions, should play a major role in the first effort in United States peacetime history to enforce wage and price controls.

title: TWO ARE INDICTED IN POLICE KILLINGS
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday the indictment of a second and third man in the murder of two New York City policemen last May.

title: A $70MILLION PACT LET FOR SATELLITE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  TRW Systems Group has won a contract competition valued at more than $70million to develop a scientific satellite to study highenergy radiation in space.

title: Army to Punish 5 Officers In Attack on Vietnam Base
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27The Army has told five highranking officers, including a twostar general, that it plans to demote or reprimand them as a result of an enemy attack on a fire base in South Vietnam last March that resulted in 33 deaths and 76 injuries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In advocating a burial  albeit a decent oneof the U.N., Jeffrey St. John (OpEd Nov. 13) builds his case on the proposition that the U.N. Charter was clearly compromised when a founding member, Taiwan, was expelled. Apparently, Mr. St. John can no longer accept the fiction that the Government at Taipei represents the real China, which has now been expelled. Rather, he inventively suggests that it is Taiwan that has been member of the U.N. this past quarter century.

title: PAKISTAN REPORTS FIGHTING GOES ON, CALLS UP RESERVE
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 24Pakistan announced today that she was calling up her military reserves and said that heavy fighting with Indian forces was continuing in the eastern region.

title: 2 WELFARE PLANS BACKED BY H.E.W.
description: New York State's two controversial Welfare demonstration projects were formally approved yeSterday by Elliot L. Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to take effect Jan. 1.

title: CHINESE BIDS U.N. DROP SOVIET PLAN FOR ARMS PARLEY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24China urged today that the General Assembly shelve Soviet proposal for a world disarmament conference. This brought a charge by the Soviet Union that China and the United States were engaged in duet of negativism.

title: Archdiocese Revises Upward Number of Teachers on Strike
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York revised upward yesterday the number of lay and religious teachers it said were on strike.

title: Signalmen Approve Pact
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP)The Brotherhood of Railroad signalmen has overwhelmingly approved a tentatively agreed upon contract calling for a 46 per cent pay increase over 42 months.

title: Lower House in Japan Votes Okinawa Pact With U.S.
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24The lower house of the Japanese Diet (parliament) approved today the treaty with the United states under which Okinawa will be returned to Japanese political control next year.

title: Gen. Philip Strong, Expert on U2, Dies
description: Brig. General Philip G. Strong, who retired from the Marine Corps Reserve in 1964 and earlier had participated in the development of the U2 reconnaissance aircraft, died in Washington on Nov. 12. General Strong, who was buried in Arlington Cemetery with full military honors, was 71 years old.

title: Intercity Truck Tonnage Tops YearEarlier Week
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported today that intercity truck tonnage last week was 6.4 per cent above the yearearlier level. In a weekly survey of 35 metropolitan areas, tonnage increased at 28 localities.

title: Big 4's Total of 34,145 Autos a Day Is 5.4% Above 1965 Mark
Rattenni Is Guilty In Gambling Trial
description: A reputed Mafia leader, three state policemen and an alleged gambler were found guilty in Federal Court here last night of conspiring to protect organized gambling operations in Rockland and Westchester Counties.

title: Americana II First On Corrected Time In 128Mile Race
Rangers'
description: Another: thirdperiod scoring outbursts this time for six goalselevated the Rangers to an 83 victory over the St. Louie Blues last night.

title: U.N. RELIEF STAFF LEAVING PAKISTAN
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 24About half of the United Nations relief force in East Pakistan was evacuated today and others were being called in from the field as fighting between Indian and Pakistani forces continued to be reported in three areas.

title: U.S. Is Checking Report Of Swedish Steel Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP)  The Treasury Department said today it has begun investigating whether Sweden is dumping highspeed tool steel on American markets.

title: Sandy Ray Chorus Series
description: The Sandy Ray Chorus of the Cornerstone Baptist Church in Brooklyn will present a program of gospel songs at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater's Martinson Hall on Dec. 5 at 3 P.M.

title: B'nai B'rith Backs Project
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Nov. 24 The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith voiced its overwhelming support today of the controversial Forest Hills lowincome housing project and urged that more such projects be built to achieve racially and ethnically balanced communities.

title: Nicolas Balabanoff, Bulgarian Diplomat, Dies at 84
description: Nicolas Balabanoff, a Bulgarian jurist and diplomat, died last Sunday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived et the Chalfonte Hotel, 200 West 70th Street.

title: Dinner That Was More Than Feast
